context: The MOF material was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.5 mmol) in 20 mL of THF with the addition of pivalic acid (0.1 mmol) as a modulator. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and sealed, then heated at 233.6 °C for 287.543 minutes. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with THF, and dried under vacuum to obtain 12 mg of the crystalline MOF. Elemental analysis calculated for Zn(C8H4O4)·THF: C, 56.71, H, 4.86, Found: C, 56.68, H, 4.91. The IR spectrum displayed key absorption bands at 1685, 1500, and 1390 cm−1, attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylate groups, and a broad band at 3420 cm−1 confirming the presence of residual THF. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity and crystallinity of the synthesized MOF, with patterns closely matching those of the simulated structure, indicating successful synthesis as per designed parameters.

A novel metal-organic framework (MOF-66) was synthesized by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.156 g, 1 mmol) in dimethyl acetamide (50 mL). Sulfuric acid (0.1 mL) was added as a modulator to the reaction mixture. The sealed vial was subjected to heating at 331.350 K for 447.291 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting blue crystalline solid was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with dimethyl acetamide. The material was then dried under vacuum at ambient temperature, affording MOF-66 with a yield of 75%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed phase purity and crystallinity, while SEM analysis revealed the formation of closely packed hexagonal crystals with sizes ranging between 50−150 μm (Figure 3). IR spectra displayed characteristic peaks at 3421s, 2942m, 1718s, 1466w, and 1208m cm−1, confirming the successful incorporation of the organic linkers into the framework.

A synthetic procedure for the metal-organic framework was conducted by dissolving 0.15 g of terephthalic acid (1.80 mmol) and 0.25 g of CrCl3·6H2O (0.94 mmol) in 12 mL of C2H5OH. The resultant mixture was transferred to a 25 mL glass vial and tightly sealed with a screw cap. The vial was then placed in an oven and heated at 188 °C for 40.90 hours. After gradual cooling to ambient temperature, red polyhedral crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with ethanol, yielding 78% of the target compound. The crystalline product was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, indicating the formation of a three-dimensional network structure. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Cr: C 51.84%, H 3.81%, Cr 14.18%, found: C 51.90%, H 3.75%, Cr 14.12%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1689, 1605, 1562, 1480, 1444, 1388, 1317, 1205, 1144, 1035, 794, 742, 684, 618, 483.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, 100 mg of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.34 mmol) and 80 mg of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.48 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) under constant stirring to ensure complete dissolution. The mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was securely sealed and heated at 384.582 K for 418.7 minutes. After the programmed heating duration, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, at which point the formation of colorless octahedral crystals was observed. The resulting solid was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMSO three times to remove any unreacted starting materials, and subsequently air-dried. The yield of the obtained compound was calculated to be 30% based on the initial amount of zinc nitrate. Characterization by powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity and crystallinity of the synthesized MOF, with results comparing favorably to literature references for similar frameworks.

The synthesis of MOF-XYZ was undertaken using methanol (CH3OH) as the reaction solvent, with lithium hydroxide monohydrate serving as an additive. For a representative synthesis, H2L (100 mg, 0.45 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O (320 mg, 1.08 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (15 mL). To this solution, lithium hydroxide monohydrate (15 mg, 0.36 mmol) was added under continuous stirring to enhance crystallization. The mixture was then placed in a sealed glass vial and maintained at 298.7 K for 436.968 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the crystalline product was filtered under vacuum and washed with methanol to remove unbound constituents. The washed crystals of MOF-XYZ were then dried at ambient conditions, yielding 324 mg (71% based on H2L). Elemental analysis calculated for [Zn2L2(CH3OH)4(H2O)2]: C 49.2, H 5.13, N 8.7%, found: C 48.7, H 5.05, N 8.42%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3412br, 3086m, 2943w, 1675vs, 1608s, 1549m, 1503s, 1456

In a typical synthesis, H2BDC (0.15 g, 0.90 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.26 g, 0.90 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (CH3OH, 10 mL) along with HBO3 (0.02 g, 0.32 mmol) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was sealed and heated at 200.95 °C for 354.813 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, pink needle-like crystals formed, which were isolated by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried. Yield: 78.4 mg (65% based on H2BDC). Selected FTIR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3435 (br, w), 2972 (m), 1675 (s), 1609 (m), 1545 (w), 1492 (m), 1397 (vs), 1329 (w), 1258 (m), 1167 (w), 1114 (s), 1072 (m), 964 (w), 902 (w), 788 (m), 735 (s), 698 (w), 672 (s), 622 (w). Anal. Calcd for C8H6CoNO6: C, 34.91, H, 2.

Crystals were synthesized from a reaction mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (132 mg, 0.45 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (98 mg, 0.59 mmol) in MeCN (10.5 mL). The solution was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 478.992 K for 93.3 hours. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, purple crystals were obtained and isolated by filtration. Yield: 63% based on Co. Anal. Calcd. for C16H12CoN4O8: C, 42.16, H, 2.65, N, 12.29%. Found: C, 41.89, H, 2.79, N, 12.07%. IR (KBr): 3492 (w), 3064 (m), 1712 (s), 1580 (w), 1404 (s), 1336 (w), 1275 (m), 1148 (w), 1079 (m), 999 (s), 942 (m), 859 (w), 788 (s), 735 (m), 663 (s), 592 (m), 533 (w), 463 (s).

A precursor solution containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.250 g, 1.05 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.200 g, 1.20 mmol), and triethylamine (0.150 ml, 1.08 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 20 ml). The mixture was transferred into a 50 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction setup was heated to 430.388 K for 355.109 minutes under autogenous pressure and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Dark blue block-like crystals of the copper-based metal-organic framework (MOF) were isolated. The resulting crystals were washed with ethanol several times and air-dried at 60 °C for 30 minutes. The yield was calculated to be 52% based on copper content. Elemental analysis for C14H10CuO8 (calculated): C 41.52, H 2.49, found: C 41.60, H 2.45. IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1): 414 w, 550 m, 690 m, 768 s, 871 m, 1010 s, 1154 m, 1385 s, 1489 m, 1624 s, 1725 s. The framework was structurally characterized using single-crystal X-ray

In a glass reaction vessel, a mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (78 mg, 0.5 mmol), and terephthalic acid (83 mg, 0.5 mmol) was prepared. To this mixture, pyridine (10 mL) was added as the solvent, and HBF4 (30 µL) was introduced as an additive. The reaction mixture was stirred at 26 °C for 386.44 minutes. The resulting solution was left to stand, allowing slow evaporation at ambient temperature. Pale yellow needle-like crystals of the MOF were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was determined to be 30% based on zinc. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12N2O4Zn: C, 55.44, H, 3.49, N, 8.08%. Found: C, 55.52, H, 3.37, N, 8.15%. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1) showed characteristic peaks at 3142 (sb), 1678 (m), 1520 (s), 1415 (s), 1268 (w), and 1019 (w).

A solution of CoCl2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 23.8 mg) and H2BDC (0.05 mmol, 8.3 mg) was prepared in ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 10 mL) and transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed reaction vessel was then heated at 452.1 K for 45.59 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, pink crystalline clusters of Co-BDC were isolated, collected by filtration, rinsed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield was calculated to be 74% based on Co. Elemental analysis (%) for C8H4CoO4 found: C, 42.35, H, 1.78. Expected: C, 42.29, H, 1.77. The infrared spectrum (ATR, cm–1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3415 (br, w), 1608 (vs), 1557 (s), 1420 (s), 1350 (m), 1286 (w), 1140 (m), 1086 (w), 1015 (w), 860 (m), 812 (w), 775 (s), and 690 (m).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1.03 mmol) and trimesic acid (0.15 g, 0.71 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (15 mL) with NaOC2H5 (0.10 g, 1.11 mmol) as an additive. The solution was stirred for 1 hour and then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (50 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated to 341.64 K for 324 hours. After slow cooling to room temperature, green needle-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with DMF, and air-dried. The yield was 55% based on trimesic acid. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H18NiO12: C, 49.41, H, 3.11, O, 32.84. Found: C, 49.57, H, 3.25, O, 32.70%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 (br, m), 2922 (w), 1625 (s), 1453 (m), 1378 (s), 1256 (m), 1117 (w), 907 (w), 784 (m), 724 (s), 686 (w), 512 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.1 mmol), and HCl (0.2 mL, 1 M) was dissolved in 10 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) and filled into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated at 189.898 °C for 165.78 minutes. After the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with THF, and subsequently dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. Yield: 0.25 g (68%, based on BTC). IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3106, 1558, 1449, 1387, 1315, 1182, 1078, 877, 763. Anal. Calc. for C21H18O18Zn3: C, 32.03, H, 2.30. Found: C, 31.85, H, 2.34. The framework was stable under ambient conditions and maintained its crystalline nature as verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

The synthesis of the compound [Cu2(C9H5O6)2]·4H2O (3) was performed through a hydrothermal process. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.210 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (10 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then tightly sealed and heated at 74.9 °C for 484.10 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, crystalline blue block-like structures of compound 3 were formed. These crystals were isolated by filtration, followed by washing with water to remove any unreacted starting materials, and then air-dried. Characterization through X-ray powder diffraction confirmed the crystalline purity of the sample. Further elemental analysis of C18H14Cu2O14 (581.40) showed consistency with the intended stoichiometry: Calculated (%) C, 37.16, H, 2.42. Found (%): C, 37.20, H, 2.38. This result suggests that the hydrothermal method effectively facilitated the formation of a stable Cu-based MOF under the given conditions.

Synthesis of MOF-2: In a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol), 4-dicarboxy-1-benzeneamine (0.082 g, 0.6 mmol), and PYRIDINE (8 mL) was prepared. To this, formic acid (0.1 mL) was added as an additive. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 68.57 °C for 102.08 minutes in a programmable oven. Upon completion, the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting white crystalline solid was collected via filtration and washed thoroughly with PYRIDINE and ethanol. The pre-dried material had a yield of 72% based on the initial organic linker used. Elemental Analysis calculated for MOF-2, C28H22N2O8Zn2: C, 53.85, H, 3.55, N, 4.49. Found: C, 53.79, H, 3.60, N, 4.47. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) showed peaks at: 3332 (broad), 1610 (s), 1515 (m), 1420 (w), 1380 (s), 1220 (m

The metal-organic framework (MOF) [Compound X] was synthesized by combining copper(II) nitrate hemipentahydrate (Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O), terephthalic acid (H2bdc), 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in the presence of sodium acetate. Specifically, 250 mg (1.02 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF, to which 83 mg (0.50 mmol) of H2bdc and 78 mg (0.50 mmol) of bpy were added sequentially with continuous stirring. Following complete dissolution, 50 mg of sodium acetate was incorporated into the reaction mixture. The solution was vigorously stirred for 1 hour, then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 425 K for 216.80 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature gradually. The resulting crystalline product, composed of green block-like crystals, was filtered, washed sequentially with methanol, and dried in air, yielding compound X with a 70% conversion based on Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O. The phase purity of the synthesized MOF was validated by comparing the powder X-ray diffraction pattern to a

The metal-organic framework MOF-316 was synthesized under solvothermal conditions. A mixture containing 0.25 g (0.75 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.20 g (0.5 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), and 0.15 g (1.5 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL). Hydrofluoric acid (40 µL) was cautiously added as an additive to facilitate crystal growth. The resultant solution was stirred at room temperature until homogeneous and subsequently transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 316 K for 404.3 hours. Upon reaching ambient temperature, the crystalline product was carefully filtered, thoroughly washed with dimethyl acetamide, and dried under vacuum. The synthesis yielded 42 mg of pale yellow crystals, representing approximately 15% based on Zn. Elemental analysis of the compound revealed: C, 45.08, H, 3.16%, calculated for C16H20N4O8Zn: C, 44.96, H, 3.76%. Characterization by X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystallinity, while FTIR spectroscopy showed characteristic peaks at 1665, 1589, 1410, 1097,

A solution of H2BTP (20 mg, 0.050 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35 mg, 0.117 mmol) was prepared in 1,4-dioxane (12 mL) in a sealed glass vial. The reaction mixture was subjected to heating at 424 K for a duration of 250.99 hours. The vial was then allowed to cool to room temperature, and the resulting pale yellow crystals were collected via vacuum filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with 1,4-dioxane to afford the MOF compound as the final product with an isolated yield of 58%. Elemental analysis: calculated for C20H10N4O8Zn: C, 45.37, H, 1.90, N, 10.58, found: C, 45.01, H, 2.03, N, 10.63%. Selected FTIR data (neat, cm−1): 1665, 1588, 1420, 1367, 1112, 920, 812, 695, 625.

The synthesis of MOF-X was conducted by combining 0.05 g (0.25 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, 0.07 g (0.35 mmol) of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate, and 0.02 g (0.10 mmol) of 2,2'-bipyridine in 5 mL of 2-Amino-1-butanol. The resulting mixture was stirred for 20 min to achieve homogeneity and subsequently transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 196.8 °C for 308.293 hours under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1, blue-green crystalline solids were retrieved by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and left to dry in ambient air. The yield was obtained at 75% based on copper. Anal. Calc. for C24H18Cu2N2O9 (596.45): C, 48.34, H, 3.04, N, 4.69. Found: C, 48.40, H, 3.02, N, 4.68. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3431 (b), 1616 (s), 1575 (s), 1397

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.34 mmol), terephthalic acid (50 mg, 0.30 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (40 mg, 0.26 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of MeOH. To this solution, CH3ONa (30 mg, 0.56 mmol) was added as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 210 °C for 313.651 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, purple rod-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with cold MeOH, and dried in air, yielding 78 mg (67% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C18H14CoN2O6: C, 50.19, H, 3.28, N, 6.51, found: C, 50.08, H, 3.35, N, 6.59. Selected FT-IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 (br), 1610 (s), 1535 (s), 1440 (s), 1380 (s), 1220 (m), 1055 (m), 965 (w), 830 (m), 720 (w), 655

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in DMAc (5 mL) and transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to heating at 115.70 °C for 392.265 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The reaction yielded clear, colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Anal. Calcd for C16H14O8Zn (399.67): C, 48.08, H, 3.53, Zn, 16.32. Found: C, 48.25, H, 3.47, Zn, 16.27. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440(s), 1615(m), 1510(s), 1394(m), 1170(m), 997(w), 878(m), 742(s).

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 119 mg), H2BDC (0.2 mmol, 33 mg), and a 10 mL solution of PYRIDINE were combined in a borosilicate glass vial. The mixture was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 102 °C for 421.2 minutes. After cooling to ambient temperature over 12 hours, the resulting beige crystals were collected and washed with ethanol. The yield was determined to be 68% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis was performed: calculated for C16H14N2O8Zn2 (Mr = 481.12): C, 39.95%, H, 2.93%, N, 5.82%. Found: C, 39.65%, H, 3.01%, N, 5.76%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435 (br), 1624 (s), 1392 (vs), 1258 (m), 1087 (w), 800 (br), 754 (w), 702 (w), 623 (m), 517 (w).

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.125 g, 0.52 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.085 g, 0.51 mmol) were combined in 6 mL of N,N-DIETHYLFORMAMIDE. The resulting mixture was transferred into a sealed vessel and maintained at 332.3 K for 445.94 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature, yielding blue crystalline solids, which were subsequently isolated by filtration and washed with DMF. The product was obtained with an isolated yield of 68% based on terephthalic acid. The framework showed stability under ambient conditions and exhibited limited solubility in both water and common organic solvents like ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, and chloroform. Anal. Calcd for C8H6O4Cu: C, 45.68, H, 2.88. Found: C, 45.72, H, 2.85. FT-IR analysis (KBr, 4000−400 cm⁻¹) revealed characteristic bands at 3425 (br), 2961 (w), 1635 (s), 1540 (m), 1395 (m), 1238 (w), 1118 (w), 732 (m), and 570 (w). In a typical synthesis, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.246 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and the solution was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes until clear. Subsequently, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) and 0.5 mL of tetrafluoroboric acid (HBF4, 48% aqueous solution) were added to the mixture under continuous stirring, and the resulting homogenous solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 519.923 K for 50.92 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature over the course of 8 hours, colorless octahedral crystals were isolated via filtration, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and subsequently dried under vacuum for 12 hours (yield: 42% based on Zn). Elemental analysis revealed a composition in accordance with the calculated values: C, 47.90%, H, 3.96%, N, 0.00%. Infrared spectroscopy (IR, cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at 2940 (s), 2244 (m), 1601 (s), 1505 (m), 1382 (w), 1077 (vs), and

A combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.112 g, 0.384 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.064 g, 0.384 mmol) was suspended in 8 mL of acetonitrile in a 30 mL glass vial. The mixture was sealed and subjected to a temperature of 348.714 K for 372.8 hours under static conditions. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was gradually cooled to ambient temperature. Red cubic crystals of the resulting framework were harvested with a yield of approximately 27% based on H2BDC. The phase purity was verified through powder X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis for C18H14CoO8: calculated (%): C, 46.84, H, 3.06, Found: C, 46.59, H, 3.10. The infrared spectrum recorded in KBr (cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks: 3442 (w), 3068 (s), 1605 (s), 1517 (m), 1392 (s), 1245 (w), 1110 (m), 1018 (w), 878 (s), 831 (w), 775 (m), 662 (m), 532 (w).

To synthesize the desired MOF, a mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) was prepared. The mixture was dissolved in a solvent system of 10 mL DMF, supplemented with HCOOH (0.5 mL) as an additive to modulate the reaction conditions. This solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was subsequently heated to 407.17 K for a period of 197.88 hours. After the reaction duration, the system was allowed to naturally cool to room temperature. The resulting product was harvested by filtration, yielding pale yellow crystals with a purity of >95% as determined by elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for C18H14N2O7Zn (%): C, 49.29, H, 3.20, N, 6.39. Found (%): C, 49.24, H, 3.23, N, 6.41. The FTIR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 1690(s), 1600(s), 1415(m), 1245(m), 1100(m

A mixture of organic linker H3BTC (60 mg, 0.285 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.342 mmol), and bipyridine (20 mg, 0.128 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL) and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. To this solution, 200 μL of concentrated sulfuric acid (95-98%) was added dropwise with constant stirring. The sealed autoclave was then heated to 223.24 °C in an oven for 9.896 hours. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature gradually over 12 hours, yielding purple crystalline solids. The obtained crystals were isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with cold ethanol, and air-dried to yield the MOF material Co-BTC-bipy in a 63% yield (82.6 mg, based on cobalt). Elemental analysis calculated for C14H10CoN2O8 (%): C, 41.43, H, 2.48, N, 6.90, found: C, 41.36, H, 2.60, N, 6.78. IR data (cm−1): 3448 w, 1612 s, 1540 m, 1407 s, 1324 m, 1123 m, 764 s. A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0245 g, 0.1 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.0321 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-diethylformamide. The resultant solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to heating at 51 °C for 44.108 hours. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h⁻¹. Upon completion, blue crystals of the MOF were isolated with a 63% yield based on the copper source. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H14CuN2O6: C, 54.50%, H, 3.55%, N, 7.06%. Found: C, 54.72%, H, 3.43%, N, 7.21%. The phase purity of the obtained crystals was verified by PXRD. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3398 s, 1605 s, 1575 m, 1402 s, 1328 m, 1255 m, 1199 w, 1035 w, 983 w, 902 w, 780 m, 752 s, 655 m.

The metal-organic framework, designated MOF-X, was synthesized using solvothermal conditions. The reactants utilized in this procedure were copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 98%, commercial supplier), and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 98%, commercial supplier). Specifically, 0.482 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2 mmol) and 0.210 g of H3BTC (1 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (MeOH). This reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 149.609 °C for 457 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting dark blue crystalline product was isolated via filtration, rinsed thoroughly with methanol, and subsequently air-dried. The formation of MOF-X was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis, revealing a crystalline structure consistent with the desired framework.

In a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL), a mixture of 50 mg of ZrCl4 (0.215 mmol) and 40 mg of H2BDC (0.240 mmol) was combined with 3 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc). The vessel was securely sealed and subjected to heating at 130.8 °C for a duration of 58.728 hours. Following the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was carefully cooled to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of pale-white needle-shaped crystals. The solids were collected by filtration and thoroughly washed with fresh DMAc, yielding approximately 35 mg of product with a yield of 60% based on Zr. Elemental analysis showed (calculated): C, 48.32%, H, 3.22%, Cl, 11.51%. Found: C, 48.25%, H, 3.20%, Cl, 11.47%. The isolated MOF displayed stability in common organic solvents, with the exception of water, where it decomposes rapidly. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 3500(w), 1701(s), 1590(m), 1405(m), 1255(w), 1040(m), 800(s), 710(m).

All chemicals were procured from Sigma-Aldrich (USA) and utilized without further purification. In a standard preparation, the following substances were employed: copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.5 g, 2.05 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.33 g, 2.00 mmol). The reagents were dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH) with the addition of 0.2 mL of ammonia (NH3), and the resulting mixture was stirred at 47.9 °C for 20.715 minutes. The reaction mixture was subsequently cooled to room temperature, upon which blue crystalline solids were collected via filtration and washed with cold methanol. These crystals, identified as the metal-organic framework [Cu2(bdc)2(dabco)]n were obtained in a yield of 65% based on the starting amount of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate. Optical microscopy images of the crystals were captured and are provided in Fig. S2 of the supplementary material. For characterization, the crystals were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction, Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The FTIR analysis, performed on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer, revealed key absorption bands at 3420 (b), 2925 (s), 1605 (s), 143

A solution containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol), terephthalic acid (TPA) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and N,N-diethylformamide (10 mL) was prepared. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to heating at 80.2 °C for 248.3 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was gradually allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting product, comprising white crystalline solids, was isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide to remove any unreacted starting materials. The yield of the desired Zn-based MOF was approximately 72% based on the initial Zn content. After drying the crystals in air, the final material was characterized through various spectroscopic techniques. Elemental analysis computed for the MOF (%): C, 36.26, H, 2.44, N, 10.52, Found: C, 36.14, H, 2.57, N, 10.37.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.167 g, 1.0 mmol) was combined with ethanol (10 mL) in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 227.455 °C for 62.9 minutes, before being cooled to room temperature. Upon completion, white needle-like crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and washed with ethanol, yielding 68%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C8H6O4Zn: C, 42.18, H, 2.65. Found: C, 42.10, H, 2.60. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3210 (m), 1704 (s), 1586 (vs), 1415 (s), 1227 (m), 1103 (m), 876 (w), 650 (w).

A total of 0.50 mmol of MnCl2·4H2O (98 mg) and 0.30 mmol of H4BDC (66 mg) were dissolved in 10 mL of 1-butanol within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reactor was sealed and heated at 445.96 K for 485 hours, followed by a cooling period to room temperature at a rate of 0.05 K min–1. Pale yellow cubic crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated through filtration, rinsed with 1-butanol, and dried at room temperature. The reaction yield was 72% based on H4BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12O12Mn3 (%): C, 30.89, H, 1.94. Found: C, 30.75, H, 2.08. Infrared data (KBr cm–1): 3422 (br, m), 2971 (w), 1654 (s), 1458 (s), 1398 (m), 1156 (m), 1014 (w), 824 (m), 780 (w), 625 (m), 512 (w), 485 (w).

Synthesis of MOF-371: In a 25 mL Pyrex vial, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.158 g, 0.54 mmol) and H2BDC (0.06 g, 0.36 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of DMF under ambient conditions. The vial was securely capped and placed in a programmable oven set to 361 K for 372.2 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the solvent was decanted, and the resultant pale green crystalline product was isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with anhydrous acetone. The yield was 0.132 g, calculated based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C8H8NiO6: C, 34.30, H, 2.88. Found: C, 34.15, H, 3.07. IR (KBr disc, cm−1): 3420 (br), 2940 (w), 1660 (s), 1443 (m), 1384 (s), 1113 (m), 782 (m), 718 (w), 665 (m).

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.030 g, 0.10 mmol) and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (0.019 g, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 5 mL of DMAc. To the mixture, lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.004 g, 0.10 mmol) was added. The prepared solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The reaction system was heated at 58.1 °C for 414.0 minutes. Upon completion, the vessel was gradually cooled to room temperature over a period of 8 hours. Pale white crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with DMAc, and dried under vacuum. The isolated product was obtained with a yield of 54% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H16O8Zn: C, 52.86, H, 3.55%. Found: C, 52.72, H, 3.49%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3600 w, 3392 w, 1705 s, 1602 m, 1428 s, 1300 m, 1024 w, 782 m.

In a typical synthesis, ZnCl2 (0.068 g, 0.5 mmol), H2bpdc (0.046 g, 0.2 mmol), and L-LH (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in 5 mL of MeCN. The mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 15 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The resultant solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (10 mL), which was sealed and subjected to heating at 159.048 °C for precisely 79.40 minutes. After the specified heating duration, the autoclave was slowly brought back to ambient temperature. The product, consisting of pale yellow crystalline solids, was obtained through filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with MeCN to remove any impurities and then dried under vacuum. Yield: 52% based on Zn(II). Anal. Calcd for C28H24Cl2ZnN4O8: C, 50.12, H, 3.61, N, 8.36. Found: C, 50.19, H, 3.55, N, 8.30. IR (KBr, λ/cm–1): 3440 (m), 3062 (m), 1645 (s), 1502 (s), 1374 (s), 1230 (m), 1178 (w),

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g) was dissolved in 3 mL of DMAc, followed by the addition of H2bpdc (0.25 mmol, 0.056 g) and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) (0.25 mmol, 0.039 g) in another 3 mL of DMAc. To this mixture, HClO4 (50 μL) was introduced as an additive. The resulting suspension was sonicated for 15 minutes, yielding a homogeneous solution. This clear mixture was subsequently transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 163.556 °C for 69 minutes. Upon natural cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered to obtain a pale yellow solution. Pale yellow crystals of ZMOF-1 were obtained by slow evaporation of the solution at room temperature. The yield was 45%, calculated based on Zn(II). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd for C18H14N2O6Zn: C, 51.65, H, 3.37, N, 6.69. Found: C, 51.74, H, 3.41, N, 6.61. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3448 (m), 3076 (w), 162

Synthesis of [Cu2(bdc)2(dabco)]n (3): A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (bdc) (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) (0.112 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 10 mL) and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 246.63 °C for 476.30 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline blocks of 3 were formed and isolated by filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with DMAc and dried under vacuum (72.5% yield based on copper). C22H16Cu2O8N2: calcd. C 49.34, H 3.01, N 5.23, found C 49.10, H 2.94, N 5.30. IR (KBr pellets): 3432 (m), 2920 (w), 1680 (s), 1560 (m), 1400 (vs), 1105 (m),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89.5 mg, 0.3 mmol) and Hbtc (32.3 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (8.0 mL). The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and then heated at 89.912 °C for 219 hours under autogenous pressure. After the reaction was complete, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C/h. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were collected by filtration, washed with N,N-diethylformamide, and air-dried. Yield: 52% based on Hbtc. Anal. Calcd. for C9H10N2O6Zn: C 34.39, H 3.20, N 8.91%. Found: C 34.40, H 3.18, N 8.90%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3452 (s), 1685 (s), 1573 (m), 1410 (s), 1345 (m), 1195 (w), 1023 (w), 828 (m), 745 (w), 612 (m).

To synthesize the MOF, CoCl2·6H2O (0.50 g, 2.10 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol), and o-phenanthroline (0.10 g, 0.50 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated at 378.1 K for 303.09 hours under static conditions. Upon slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15 °C/h, pink crystalline material was obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions to yield the desired MOF (yield = 62%, based on terephthalic acid). Elemental analysis was performed, yielding the following results: Anal. Calcd. for CoC16H10O4N2, C, 53.41%, H, 2.80%, N, 7.78%. Found: C, 53.10%, H, 2.66%, N, 7.65%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3456 (w), 1634 (s), 1504 (m), 1386 (s), 1225 (m), 1100 (w), 766 (s), 674 (w).

A solution mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H4BDC (4.9 mg, 0.02 mmol) was prepared in 7 mL of H2O and sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was heated at 527 K for 372.1 hours and subsequently allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature. Blue crystalline needles of the resulting MOF were isolated by filtration, obtaining a 35% yield based on H4BDC. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C20H10Cu2O10: C, 46.24, H, 1.94, N, 0.00. Found: C, 46.51, H, 1.89, N, 0.00. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (broad), 1698 (strong), 1475 (medium), 1378 (strong), 1189 (medium), 1018 (medium), 837 (medium), 743 (medium).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0583 g, 0.2 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.0210 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CN (10 mL) and placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subsequently subjected to heating at 110 °C for 441.84 minutes. After gradual cooling to room temperature, green crystalline products were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried (yield: 42% based on Ni). Anal. Calcd for C12H12NiO6 (%): C, 44.44, H, 3.70. Found: C, 44.52, H, 3.69. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3400(m), 3050(w), 1700(vw), 1570(w), 1450(m), 1375(m), 1250(w), 1100(s), 1000(w).

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3BTC (21 mg, 0.1 mmol), and NH3 (0.5 mL) in DMF (8 mL) was prepared. The reagents were combined in a 25 mL glass vial and stirred at room temperature for 1 hour. The vial was then sealed and heated in an oven at 313.228 K for 76.19 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, bright blue cubic crystals were isolated via filtration, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 54% based on the ligand. Elemental analysis calc. for C18H12Cu2N2O9: C, 40.96, H, 2.29, N, 5.30, found: C, 40.84, H, 2.35, N, 5.27. FT-IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 (br), 1620 (s), 1445 (m), 1380 (m), 1315 (w), 1105 (w), 1032 (w), 878 (w), 725 (m), 545 (w).

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture comprising Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.045 g, 0.21 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was thoroughly homogenized at ambient temperature for 10 minutes. The resulting suspension was transferred to a 20 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a Teflon liner and subsequently heated at 172.683 °C for 54.8 hours. After the reaction period, a gradual cooling to room temperature allowed the formation of green crystalline material, which was isolated by filtration. The product was washed with deionized water and dried under vacuum. Yield: 60% based on Ni(II). Elemental analysis for C18H12Ni3O12 (691.46), calculated: C 31.26, H 1.73, Ni 25.50, found: C 31.41, H 1.68, Ni 25.65. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (b), 1596 (m), 1388 (s), 1102 (w), 758 (m), 669 (s).

A solution composed of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 10.2 mg, 0.060 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.100 mmol) in acetonitrile (2.5 mL) was loaded into a 15-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The device was sealed and heated to 118 °C for 109 hours, followed by a natural cooling process to ambient temperature. The resulting violet crystals were collected, washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried, yielding 25 mg (65% based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN4O8: C 43.34%, H 3.18%, N 12.64%, found: C 43.51%, H 3.05%, N 12.50%. FT-IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3425 (br), 1650 (s), 1587 (m), 1449 (s), 1396 (s), 758 (m), 668 (m).

To a 50 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar, ZrCl4 (350 mg, 1.5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (242 mg, 1.45 mmol) were added. Subsequently, 20 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMAc) was introduced as the solvent, and the mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 30 minutes until a homogenous suspension was formed. Hexafluoropropene (60 µL) was added dropwise to serve as an additive, enhancing crystallization. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to thermal treatment at 456.74 K for 470.3 hours. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resultant clear, needle-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh DMAc, and subsequently dried under vacuum for 24 hours to ensure removal of residual solvent. Yield: 150 mg (ca. 40% based on Zr). Elemental analysis calc. (%) for C36H24F6O12Zr2: C, 45.20, H, 2.53, F, 12.67, Zr, 23.63, found: C, 45.05, H, 2.72, F, 12.84, Zr, 23.47.

Synthesis of the Metal-Organic Framework [Zn2(TPA)2(DMF)]⋅nH2O. In a typical procedure, zinc nitrate hexahydrate (89.3 mg, 0.3 mmol) was combined with terephthalic acid (49.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) and dissolved in 12 mL of dimethyl formamide (DMF) under continuous stirring to form a homogeneous mixture. The resulting solution was then transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated to 484 K for 387.98 minutes. After completion of the heating period, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The post-reaction mixture yielded transparent hexagonal crystals, with an approximate yield of 65% based on zinc content. The crystals were isolated by vacuum filtration, followed by washing with fresh DMF and drying under ambient conditions. Analytical data revealed C, 45.31%, H, 4.85%, N, 9.71% (measured). Spectroscopic analysis confirmed the structure, with notable IR peaks at 1680(s), 1609(m), and 1384(s) cm⁻¹.

Synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3]·nH2O (3). Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (3.0 g, 12.4 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (ca. 50 mL), and an aqueous solution of trimesic acid (H3BTC) (1.2 g, 5.9 mmol) was added under constant stirring. Potassium hydroxide (KOH, 0.5 g, 8.9 mmol) was introduced to adjust the pH to approximately 8. The mixture was then transferred into a stainless steel autoclave lined with Teflon and heated at 113.6 °C for 454.7 hours. After allowing the system to cool to ambient temperature naturally, blue octahedral crystals of the product were isolated. The crystals were thoroughly washed with water and ethanol, followed by air drying. Yield was determined to be 55%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C18H24Cu3O18 (fw = 803.89 g/mol): C, 26.88, H, 3.01. Found: C, 26.74, H, 2.89. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3382b (ν OH), 1610s (νas COO), 1440m (νs COO), 1370w, 960w,

A mixture of 0.125 g (0.5 mmol) of zinc acetate dihydrate [Zn(OAc)2·2H2O] and 0.150 g (0.6 mmol) of terephthalic acid (H2BDC) was dissolved in 12 mL of NMP. To this solution, 0.5 mL of concentrated HCl was added as an additive. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently heated at 391.0 K for 403.80 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. Pale yellow needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh NMP, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the crystalline product was approximately 82% relative to Zn(OAc)2·2H2O. Suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the crystals displayed characteristic IR bands at 3450, 1620, 1525, 1380, 1210, 1100, 960, and 735 cm^-1.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework <MOF-Name>, a solution was prepared by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (145 mg, 0.5 mmol, Merck, CAS number 10026-22-9) and Terephthalic acid (H2TPA, 83 mg, 0.5 mmol, Alfa Aesar, CAS number 100-21-0) in 15 mL of H2O. The mixture was placed into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to solvothermal conditions at 235.1 °C for 417.12 minutes under static conditions. Following this process, pink hexagonal crystals formed with a yield of approximately 260 mg, which were isolated via filtration, rinsed with distilled water, and left to dry at ambient temperature. Elemental analysis yielded the following weight percentages for the dried product: C, 47.53, H, 2.98, N, 0. Found: C, 47.81, H, 2.96, N, 0. FT-IR spectra (KBr, cm–1) exhibited characteristic bands at 3412(m), 2923(w), 1683(s), 1609(m), 1535(m), 1405(s), 1103(m), 841(m), 776(s), 701(w), 661(w), 540

In a typical synthesis of the MOF, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (241 mg, 1.0 mmol), TPA (54 mg, 0.25 mmol), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (73 mg, 1.75 mmol) was dissolved in NMP (10 mL). The solution was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 491.3 K for 376.567 minutes before it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over 12 hours. Green block crystals of the MOF were obtained, washed with NMP, and dried at room temperature. Yields were approximately 64% based on the copper precursor. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H16Cu2N4O12: C, 42.46, H, 2.38, N, 8.26%. Found: C, 42.12, H, 2.47, N, 8.19%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited peaks at 3435 (m), 2920 (w), 1605 (s), 1473 (s), 1351 (m), 1157 (m), 1045 (w), 898 (m), 754 (s), and 613 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.060 g, 0.25 mmol) and H3btc (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) in a 30 mL teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated in an oven to 175.1 °C for 129.82 hours, after which it was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue cubic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated by filtration with a yield of 72% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The crystalline compound was characterized by elemental analysis, revealing a composition consistent with Cu3(btc)2·(CH3OH)6. Anal. Calcd for C18H24Cu3O12: C, 36.45, H, 4.08, Found: C, 36.51, H, 4.05. The phase purity was confirmed by powder XRD, matching the simulated pattern (see Figure S3, Supporting Information). IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3440(m), 1610(s), 1440(s), 1383(s), 1105(m), 963(w), 840(m), 720(w), 650(w).

FeCl3·6H2O (0.162 g, 0.600 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.100 g, 0.600 mmol) were combined with ethanol (10 mL) in a 30 mL screw-cap vial. The vial was securely sealed and heated in an oil bath at 148.905 °C for 172.0 minutes, followed by a gradual cooling to ambient temperature. Reddish-orange crystalline solids were harvested, providing a yield of 45% based on terephthalic acid, upon rinsing with ethanol and drying under vacuum. Anal. Calc. for C8H6FeO4: C, 44.20, H, 2.78% Found: C, 44.10, H, 2.85%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3392 (br), 1675 (s), 1605 (s), 1450 (m), 1395 (w), 1243 (m), 1090 (w), 873 (w), 750 (m), 678 (s).

Synthesis of Cu-MOF: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 g, 0.8 mmol), H2BDC (0.1 g, 0.6 mmol), and o-phenanthroline (0.05 g, 0.25 mmol) was combined in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The solvent system consisted of a solution of DMF (5 mL) and ethanol (2 mL). The autoclave was carefully sealed and subjected to a hydrothermal synthesis process at 249.9 °C for 440 hours. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting crystals, exhibiting a deep blue hue, were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 65% based on Cu. Anal. Calc. for C20H18CuN2O6: C 52.32, H 3.95, N 6.10, found: C 52.15, H 4.01, N 6.05. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (br), 1625 (s), 1384 (s), 1109 (m), 1012 (m), 846 (s), 603 cm−1 (w).

The synthesis of the metal-organic framework was initiated by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.025 g, 0.1 mmol) with 4,4'-bipyridine (0.015 g, 0.1 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.012 g, 0.072 mmol) in a solution comprising 1,4-dioxane (10 mL) and boric acid (HBO3, 0.005 g, 0.081 mmol) as an additive. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and maintained at a constant temperature of 79 °C for approximately 133.018 hours. Following the controlled cooling to ambient temperature, pink octahedral crystals of the MOF were harvested, achieving a yield of 52%, based on the limiting reagent. Elemental analysis for the compound corresponded to C26H20CoN4O9 (Mr = 587.39): C, 53.14, H, 3.43, N, 9.53. Found: C, 53.06, H, 3.51, N, 9.47. The infrared spectrum exhibited notable peaks at 3420(s), 1605(m), 1550(s), 1410(s), 1265(m), and 750(m) cm

A mixture of terephthalic acid (40 mg, 0.24 mmol), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (50 mg, 0.17 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 250.7 °C for 266.82 hours. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of colorless crystalline product. The crystals were recovered by filtration, thoroughly washed with water, and then dried in air. The final product yield was 68 mg (81%). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H18O9Zn2: C 42.13, H 3.98. Found: C 42.07, H 3.95.

In an attempt to synthesize a novel metal-organic framework, a solution consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.156 g, 1 mmol) was prepared in 10 mL of diethylformamide. CH3ONa (0.027 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to this solution to facilitate deprotonation. The reaction mixture was placed in a glass vial and heated to 59.556 °C for a duration of 5.95 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, resulting in the formation of light blue crystalline blocks. The crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with diethylformamide to remove any residual reactants, and subsequently dried under vacuum. The crystalline product was obtained in a yield of 64% (0.162 g based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(s), 2928(m), 1638(s), 1552(m), 1485(m), 1384(s), 1272(w), 1155(w), 1068(w), 755(m), 652(w). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H10CuN4O6 (%): C, 39.56, H, 2

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.250 g, 1 mmol), H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and N(Et)3 (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) was suspended in acetonitrile (50 mL) and heated in a 200 mL glass vial at 505.041 K for 359.9 minutes. The resultant blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and dried in air, yielding a formation of 45% based on H2BDC. Elemental Analysis Calculated for Cu(BDC)(N(Et)3)2: C, 55.40, H, 5.30, N, 7.20. Found: C, 54.95, H, 5.45, N, 7.15. The crystalline sample was further subjected to methanol exchange and activated under vacuum conditions at 100 °C for 12 h to obtain the desolvated MOF structure.

MOF-5 was synthesized by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (400 mg, 1.33 mmol) and terephthalic acid (250 mg, 1.51 mmol) in 20 mL of solvent 68-12-2, contained within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The prepared mixture was subjected to a thermal treatment at 451.32 K for 374 hours. Following the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline solids were filtered and subsequently purified by thorough washing with ethanol, followed by drying under vacuum at ambient conditions. The yield was determined to be 312 mg (60% based on Zn). Characterization through infrared spectroscopy revealed key absorbance peaks (cm−1) at 1602 (s), 1508 (w), 1417 (m), 1385 (s), and 1256 (w), aligning well with reference spectra for MOF-5.

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2bdc (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was combined with methanol (5 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 479 K for 6.000 hours. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, blue crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried. The yield of the crystals was 68% based on H2bdc. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6NiO6 (Ni(bdc)(H2O)2) (%): C, 34.78, H, 2.19, found: C, 34.53, H, 2.12. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3412(m), 1697(s), 1530(s), 1307(m), 752(m), 690(w).

In a typical synthesis procedure, cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) were combined in 15 mL of diethylformamide within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was subjected to a heating cycle at 101.53 °C for 265.02 hours. Following this, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting solid was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with diethylformamide to remove any excess organic linkers, and subsequently dried in vacuo. The yield was 82% and yielded purple crystalline blocks suitable for X-ray crystallography. Anal. Calcd. for C10H8CoO4: C, 43.12, H, 2.90. Found: C, 43.08, H, 2.85. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430(s), 1595(m), 1510(s), 1405(s), 1360(w), 1205(w).

The resulting solution was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 461.440 K for 8 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature, and the resulting clear crystals were collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum to yield approximately 65% (0.073 g, based on Zn) of the product. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4O4Zn (%): C 44.21, H 1.85, found: C 44.30, H 1.80. A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4BDC (33.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was suspended in dimethylformamide (10.0 mL) with an additive of H2O2 (0.1 mL). The resulting solution was sealed in a glass vial and heated to 475.1 K for 89.327 hours in an oven. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of dark green polyhedral crystals. The crystals were carefully collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with fresh dimethylformamide, and subsequently dried under high vacuum for 15 hours. The yield was determined to be 21.7 mg, corresponding to 41% based on H4BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for the final compound, Ni3(BDC)3(OH)2(DMF)4: C, 48.12, H, 4.16, N, 3.23. In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1 mmol) and a ligand H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol (CH3OH) in a glass vial. To this solution, formic acid (0.1 mL, 2 mmol) was added under continuous stirring until a clear blue solution was obtained. The reaction vessel was then sealed and transferred to a preheated oven, where it was maintained at 227.780 °C for 83.9 minutes. After cooling naturally to ambient temperature, the resulting product was filtered, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried, yielding blue needle-like crystals of the metal-organic framework (yield: 75%, based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for Cu(C8H4O4)·(H2O) (248.59): C, 38.65, H, 2.98%. Found: C, 38.58, H, 3.01%. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited absorption peaks at: 3431s, 1689s, 1419s, 1352s, 1245s, 1158s, 1083s, 783s, 721s.

In a typical synthesis, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.035 g, 0.17 mmol) were dissolved in CH3CH2OH (15 mL), and pivalic acid (0.25 mL) was added under stirring. This homogeneous mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 248.0 °C for 464.09 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature over 12 hours, transparent crystalline polyhedra were obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CH2OH, and dried in air, resulting in 0.022 g of the product (yield: 45% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Comparative powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements confirmed that the pattern of the as-synthesized material closely matched the simulated diffraction pattern, verifying its structural integrity. The product's purity was corroborated by elemental analysis: Calcd for [Zn3(BTC)2]: C, 29.0, H, 2.0, Zn, 38.0. Found: C, 28.7, H, 1.9, Zn, 37.5. Synthesis of MOF-789: In a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.1 mmol, 16 mg) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated at 461 K for 281.978 hours. After cooling slowly to room temperature, purple crystals suitable for further analysis were collected by filtration. The crystals were washed with DMF to remove any unreacted starting materials and dried under ambient conditions. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H12CoO8 (Mr = 389.21): C, 49.36, H, 3.11, Co, 15.12. Found: C, 49.51, H, 3.09, Co, 15.20. PXRD confirmed the crystalline phase and integrity of the synthesized framework.

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.4 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol) in DMAc (15 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed reaction vessel was heated at 411 K for 202.117 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, clear, colourless crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered and washed with fresh DMAc to remove any unreacted starting materials. Yield was 68% based on zinc. Anal. Calcd for C10H8O5Zn: C, 43.86%, H, 2.94%, Zn, 23.89%. Found: C, 43.50%, H, 2.92%, Zn, 23.81%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3417(s), 1678(m), 1524(s), 1380(vs), 1142(m), 1019(w), 829(m), 656(w), 475(w).

Subsequently, 0.5 mL of a solution containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (220 mg mL⁻¹) was added, followed by the addition of 0.32 g (2.5 mmol) of sodium methoxide (CH3ONa). The reaction mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 454.016 K for 109.746 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction was allowed to cool to room temperature, and the resulting violet crystalline product was collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with DEF, and air-dried, yielding 82.3 mg of the cobalt-based metal-organic framework (MOF). For activation, the as-synthesized MOF was subjected to solvent exchange using methanol for 24 h, followed by thermal activation under vacuum at 150 °C for 18 h. To synthesize the MOF, a mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 g, 1.68 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.15 g, 0.90 mmol), and 2,6-lutidine (0.20 mL) was dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (MeOH) with the addition of acetic acid (AcOH, 0.30 mL) to aid in coordination. The resulting solution was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 454.215 K for 67.80 hours. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature gradually. Pale yellow cubic crystals of the MOF were isolated by decanting the mother liquor and washing the product thoroughly with cold MeOH. The yield, calculated based on the initial amount of Zn, was approximately 55%. In a standard synthesis procedure, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (20 mg, 0.095 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (50 mg, 0.227 mmol) were combined in a solvent mixture of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 10 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) within a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. To this, tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.1 mL, 25% w/v aqueous solution) was added as an additive. The autoclave was tightly sealed and subjected to heating at 216.3 °C for 355.1 minutes. After naturally cooling to ambient temperature, prismatic white crystals were obtained by filtration and subsequently washed with ethanol and diethyl ether. The crystalline product was air-dried and yielded 65% based on the acid. Vibration frequencies observed by FTIR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1620 (s), 1550 (m), 1440 (w), 1380 (s), 1260 (m), 1090 (w), 980 (m), 880 (w), 785 (m), 750 (w). Synthesis of [Cu3(BDC)3(2-Amino-1-butanol)2]·H2O: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 mmol, 36 mg), H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg), and 2-amino-1-butanol (5 mL) was combined with HNO3 (0.3 mL, nitric acid, 65% in water) in a 20 mL glass vial. The sealed vial was heated to 62.48 °C for a duration of 401.1 minutes. Upon completion of the heating process, the vial was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The blue crystalline product was subsequently isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried under reduced pressure. Yield: approximately 42% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis for C24H28Cu3N2O7: Calcd (%): C 47.45, H 4.65, Found (%): C 47.08, H 4.58. Complex MOF-X was prepared using a solvothermal synthesis approach. Initially, 500 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.68 mmol) and 300 mg of terephthalic acid (1.8 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of NMP, serving as the reaction medium. To this mixture, 50 mg of CH3ONa (0.93 mmol) was added to facilitate the deprotonation of the acid. The resulting solution was continuously stirred for 15 min to ensure homogeneity. The prepared solution was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained under static conditions at a temperature of 49.390 °C for 453.5 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, resulting in the formation of light yellow crystalline solids. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh NMP to remove any residual reactants, and dried in a vacuum desiccator. The isolated crystals were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and infrared spectroscopy (IR), which confirmed the expected structural formation. The yield of the synthesis, based on Zn, was determined to be 82%.

2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.100 g, 0.50 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (0.110 g, 0.50 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of benzene in a 25 mL glass reaction vessel. The solution was stirred at room temperature until a clear uniform mixture was obtained. The reaction vessel was then sealed and heated in a thermostatic oil bath at 319.85 K for 492.72 hours. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals of the metal-organic framework formed during the reaction were collected by filtration, yielding 65% with respect to zinc. These were washed thoroughly with benzene to eliminate any residual unreacted ligands, followed by air drying. The formation of MOFs was confirmed by infrared spectroscopy, which showed characteristic absorption bands at 3442 (b, m), 1605 (s), 1412 (m), 1320 (w), 1157 (w), 1098 (m), 995 (s), 847 (m), 792 (m), and 722 (s) cm⁻¹.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 mmol, 0.121 g) and H2BDC (0.25 mmol, 0.042 g) was dissolved in THF (8 mL) to form a homogeneous solution. This solution was transferred into a 20 mL glass reaction vial, which was then sealed tightly with a screw cap. The mixture was allowed to react at 30.9 °C for 455.6 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the vial was cooled to room temperature, and blue rectangular crystals were separated by filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with fresh THF and air-dried for 24 hours. The yield was determined to be 47% based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12O8Cu: C, 48.85, H, 3.07, found: C, 48.92, H, 2.89%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (b), 2923 (m), 1675 (s), 1582 (s), 1433 (m), 1363 (s), 1238 (m), 1116 (w), 1001 (w), 783 (w), 655 (m), 557 (w).

A mixture of H2BDC (0.150 g, 0.904 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.217 g, 0.746 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (15 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 454.48 K for 436.792 hours, yielding pink crystalline products upon cooling to room temperature. The crystalline material was isolated by filtration and washed with fresh dimethylacetamide. The yield of the final cobalt-based MOF was 0.232 g, representing a 72% conversion based on H2BDC. Anal. Calcd. for C18H14CoN2O8: C, 46.55, H, 3.04, N, 6.04%. Found: C, 46.25, H, 3.01, N, 6.12%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3387 w, 2976 w, 1685 s, 1521 m, 1440 s, 1361 vs, 1215 m, 1082 m, 964 s, 825 s, 749 m.

A reaction mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, 1.5 mmol), and Na2CO3 (2 mmol) in 15 mL of CH3OH solvent was placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 108.1 °C for 29 hours under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to ambient temperature. After the reaction, transparent needle-like crystals of the MOF were obtained and isolated via filtration. These crystals were washed with methanol and dried in air, affording a yield of 58% based on zinc. The crystalline product was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing a two-dimensional coordination polymer with interpenetrated layers. The thermal stability of the MOF was examined and confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), indicating stability up to 300 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis corresponded closely with the simulated pattern, verifying the phase purity of the produced material. Further elemental analysis showed the expected elemental composition, with calculated values aligning closely with experimental data, attesting to the successful synthesis of the desired product.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.130 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.105 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of ethanol. The solution was then treated with sodium hydroxide (0.040 g, 1 mmol) to aid crystal formation. The mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a heating program at 447.881 K for 73.475 hours. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C h−1. The resulting clear hexagonal crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 72% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for Zn3(BTC)2(C7H5O2)4: C, 41.18, H, 2.51. Found: C, 41.02, H, 2.63. Selected IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450, 1650, 1395, 760.

A combination of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 mmol, 17.4 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 mmol, 8.3 mg) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (5 mL) and placed into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 482.346 K for 105.46 minutes. The reaction mixture was then permitted to cool to ambient temperature over a period of several hours. The resulting pale green block crystals were isolated, washed thoroughly with fresh DMF, and air-dried. The yield of the product was found to be 30 mg, corresponding to a 48% yield based on Ni. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H8O4Ni: C, 47.52, H, 3.18, O, 25.33, found: C, 47.68, H, 3.12, O, 25.50. FT-IR analysis (KBr pellet, cm−1) revealed characteristic absorption bands at 3064.25(s), 1723.52(m), 1385.71(s), 1148.59(m), 754.31(w), and 615.43(w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.15 g), and MeOH (10 mL) was prepared in a glass vial. The vial was sealed and the contents stirred until fully dissolved. The reaction mixture was then maintained at a constant temperature of 307.070 K for a duration of 128.94 hours. Afterward, the solution was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting crystalline product was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with methanol, and air-dried to yield red crystalline Co-MOF in 65% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C10H8CoO4: C, 45.48, H, 3.05, Co, 22.34. Found: C, 45.31, H, 3.14, Co, 22.50%. Characteristic IR peaks (KBr pellets, cm−1) appeared at 3460(s), 1620(m), 1550(vs), 1435(s), 1302(w), 765(m), 690(m), indicative of the coordination environment within the framework.

Synthesis of Zn(BDC)2(DMA)2 (1): Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148 mg) and terephthalic acid (H2BDC) (0.25 mmol, 41 mg) were dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL) and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 341 K for 78.20 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 62% based on Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O. Elemental analysis: calcd (%) C, 45.78, H, 4.54, N, 4.37. Found: C, 45.45, H, 4.76, N, 4.12. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) featured characteristic bands at 3062, 2927, 1681, 1598, 1455, 1384, consistent with the expected framework structure.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.289 g, 0.974 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.150 g, 0.734 mmol), and NaOC2H5 (0.050 g, 0.586 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (10 mL) and placed in a glass vial at 43.77 °C. The reaction was maintained at this temperature for 419.930 hours. After the completion of the reaction, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature slowly, forming colorless block crystals. These crystals were collected by vacuum filtration and washed sequentially with dimethylacetamide and acetone to yield the MOF product in a 62% yield. Elemental analysis calc. for C18H14N2O8Zn (%): C, 47.87, H, 3.13, N, 6.20, Zn, 14.52, found (%): C, 47.60, H, 2.95, N, 6.11, Zn, 14.68. IR (KBr): 3438 (O−H, H2O), 2930 (C−H, aliphatic), 1690 (C=O), 1595 (C=C, aromatic), 1405 (N−O)s, 812 cm−1

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol) and H2BDC (0.029 g, 0.17 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF, 5 mL) in a screw-capped glass vial (15 mL). The reaction mixture was sonicated for 10 minutes to achieve a homogenous solution. The vial was then tightly sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 140.155 °C for 48.833 minutes. After the designated heating period, the reaction vial was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The resulting pink crystal clusters were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMF (5 mL × 3), and dried under ambient conditions (yield: 68% based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C24H16Co2O12: C, 50.35, H, 2.82, Co, 20.38%. Found: C, 50.11, H, 2.72, Co, 20.52%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (b), 1662 (s), 1413 (m), 1225 (w), 775 (m), 664 (w).

In a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of diethanolamine while stirring. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 250.45 °C for 259 hours under autogenous pressure, then allowed to cool to room temperature. The resultant crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with methanol, followed by drying under ambient conditions. Deep blue block crystals of the Co-MOF were obtained with a yield of approximately 42% based on Co(NO3)2. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C14H14CoO8: C, 44.45, H, 3.73, O, 33.88. Found: C, 44.67, H, 3.69, O, 33.54. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3410(m), 2925(m), 1695(s), 1610(s), 1505(m), 1390(m), 1250(m), 1140(w), 1080(m), 980(m), 870(w), 780(m), 650(w), 520(m), 440(w).

Synthesis of MOF 2: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.154 mmol) and H2BDC (0.037 g, 0.222 mmol) dissolved in a solvent mixture of 68-12-2 (4 mL) and glycol (2 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and maintained at 84.030 °C for 451.346 minutes under autogenous pressure. The mixture was subsequently cooled to ambient temperature, yielding red needle-like crystals of MOF 2, collected in approximately 55% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Co(BDC)(glycol)]·(68-12-2)1.5(H2O)3: C, 42.30, H, 3.85, N, 3.60. Found: C, 42.10, H, 3.90, N, 3.45. The desolvated MOF 2a was achieved by heating the crystals under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 hours. Elemental analysis (%) for 2a: C, 40.85, H, 2.75, N, 3.20. Found: C, 40.70, H, 2

A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.085 g, 0.365 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.085 g, 0.511 mmol), and oxalic acid (0.012 g, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 10 mL). The solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 456.5 K for 15.07 minutes, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. The precipitated white crystalline solids were collected by filtration, washed with DMSO three times, and air-dried. Yield: 64% based on ZrCl4. Elemental analysis results were consistent with the calculated values: C, 30.23%, H, 2.54%, Zr, 28.17%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418 (b), 1610 (s), 1510 (m), 1390 (s), 1252 (w), 1113 (w), 1009 (w), 872 (m), 729 (m). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of a stable Zr-MOF structure as depicted in Supplementary Figure S1.

The synthesis of the MOF was conducted via a solvothermal method. A mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol) and the organic linker H4TPA (75 mg, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 18 mL of diethylformamide in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was subsequently sealed and subjected to heating at 367.463 K for 419.1 hours. Upon completion, the reaction system was cooled to room temperature, yielding pale yellow cubic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The isolated product was washed with fresh diethylformamide to remove any residual reactants and dried under vacuum. The yield was approximately 60% based on the organic linker. Anal. calcd for C36H40N2O12Zn: C, 53.28, H, 4.97, N, 3.45. Found: C, 53.14, H, 5.01, N, 3.37. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3435 (m), 1693 (s), 1578 (m), 1463 (m), 1032 (w), 854 (w), 712 (m), 639 (w).

To synthesize the target MOF material, a reaction mixture was prepared by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.120 g), BTC (0.5 mmol, 0.105 g), N(Et)3 (0.5 mL), and MeCN (10 mL). The mixture was thoroughly homogenized and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was maintained at a temperature of 526.3 K for a duration of 461.3 hours to promote crystal growth. Upon completion of the heating period, the system was allowed to cool slowly to ambient conditions. The resultant product was isolated by filtration, yielding vibrant green crystalline structures (yield: approximately 72% based on Cu). Elemental Anal. Found: C, 42.65, H, 3.98, N, 9.12%. Calculated for C48H24Cu3N6O12: C, 42.61, H, 3.93, N, 9.07%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3436(br), 2361(w), 1698(s), 1604(s), 1500(m), 1375(s), 1312(m), 1268(w), 1235(s), 1180(w), 1130(s), 1075(w), 1020

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 mmol, 0.074 g) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.15 mmol, 0.032 g) was dissolved in acetone (10 mL), characterized by CAS number 68-12-2. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 467.277 K for 503.88 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless cubic crystals formed and were harvested by filtration, yielding 48% based on the initial quantity of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Anal. Calc. for C18H12O18Zn3: C, 29.19, H, 1.63. Found: C, 29.24, H, 1.61. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3415(s), 1595(m), 1418(s), 1263(m), 1157(w), 865(m), 730(w), 495(w). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis determined the material crystallizes in the rhombohedral system with a R-3c space group. The framework features trinuclear {Zn3(COO)6} secondary building units interconnected by the organic linker, forming a robust three-dimensional network with a pore aperture

Synthesis of Zn3(IPA)2(AIBA)2: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (23.4 mg, 0.078 mmol) and isophthalic acid (H2IPA, 9.2 mg, 0.055 mmol) were combined with AIBA (2-Amino-1-butanol, 2 mL) in a 10 mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated in an oven at 143 °C for 261 minutes. After allowing the reaction system to cool to room temperature, pale yellow polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol. Yield: 72% (based on H2IPA). Anal. Calcd for C18H26N2O8Zn3: C, 33.24, H, 4.02, N, 4.31, Found: C, 33.15, H, 4.09, N, 4.45. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (m), 1605 (s), 1551 (s), 1448 (m), 1374 (s), 1236 (m), 1092 (m), 968 (m), 886 (w), 765 (m), 704 (w), 652 (m), 598 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.21 mmol), H4BDC (0.035 g, 0.17 mmol), and Na2CO3 (0.020 g, 0.19 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (4 mL) within a 30 mL glass vial. The solution was carefully sealed and subjected to heating at 176.932 °C for 104.516 hours. Upon return to ambient conditions, the reaction system was cooled, resulting in the formation of light blue crystals. These crystals were isolated and dried under ambient air, achieving a yield of 55% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis (wt%) calculated for the resultant compound, C24H16CuN2O10, was as follows: C 54.12, H 3.02, N 5.26%. The found values indicated: C 54.08, H 2.95, N 5.32%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430(m), 2923(w), 1691(s), 1549(m), 1384(s), 1235(m), 1111(m), 755(s).

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.25 g, 0.84 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDA, 0.1 g, 0.42 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of 1-butanol with the addition of three drops of hexafluoropropene. The resulting solution was thoroughly mixed and then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 454.7 K for 426.60 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 K h−1, colorless needle-like crystals of the metal-organic framework were harvested. Yield: 80% based on H2NDA. The crystal structure was confirmed via single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and its composition was verified through elemental analysis with the following results: calculated for C12H10O4Zn: C, 55.47, H, 3.88, Zn, 25.00, found: C, 55.60, H, 3.94, Zn, 24.78. IR data (cm−1, KBr pellet): 3440(m), 1700(s), 1602(m), 1416(s), 1168(w), 874(w),

Synthesis of [Co(L)2] (1): A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2L (15 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (C2H5OH, 3 mL) in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 151 °C for 206.726 minutes, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. Upon cooling, blue crystalline material was formed, which was collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield of the product was approximately 65%. Crystal data for 1: Formula C28H26CoN4O12, orthorhombic, space group P222, a=10.1234(9) Å, b=14.5678(13) Å, c=20.9876(17) Å, V=3098.4(5) Å3, Z=4, T=296(2) K, R=0.0673, wR2=0.1984, GOF=1.038. CCDC-789123 contains the supplementary crystallographic data, available free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Synthesis of MOF-101: To synthesize MOF-101, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.85 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.14 g, 0.85 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (15 mL) with the addition of Na2CO3 (0.09 g, 0.85 mmol) to the solution. The reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and was heated at 118 °C for 18.63 minutes. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Colorless crystalline solids were obtained, washed with MeOH, and dried under ambient conditions with an isolated yield of 60% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. calc.: C 37.20, H 2.52, N 0.00, Zn 15.56. Found: C 37.15, H 2.60, N 0.05, Zn 15.50. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3450 (br), 1620 (m), 1500 (s), 1380 (s), 1250 (m), 1105 (m), 989 (w), 905 (w), 860 (w),

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.50 mmol) and H3btc (0.105 g, 0.50 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (8 mL) was prepared and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 396.8 K for 306.470 hours. Following this period, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. Blue crystalline solids suitable for various structural characterizations were isolated by filtration and washed with 1,4-dioxane multiple times. Yield was determined to be 56% based on H3btc. Anal. Calcd. for C18H12CuN2O8: C 46.38, H 2.59, N 6.00%, Found: C 46.21, H 2.61, N 5.92%. IR (KBr): ν = 3434(w), 2921(w), 1732(s), 1607(m), 1468(s), 1385(s), 1267(m), 1110(w), 1031(w), 968(w), 823(s), 744(m) cm–1.

To a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave was added cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (0.15 mmol, 43.7 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg), isobutanol (10 mL), and sodium ethoxide (NaOC2H5, 0.05 mmol, 3.4 mg). The resulting mixture was thoroughly homogenized and sealed in the autoclave, which was subsequently heated at 181.28 °C for 186.9 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was gradually cooled to ambient temperature. The reaction yielded dark purple octahedral crystals suitable for further analysis. The initial pH of the mixture was adjusted to 5.0, and the final pH was recorded at 4.1. Isolated yield: 68 mg (60% based on cobalt). Elemental analysis (EA) for C10H10CoO6 (285.1): found (calcd) C 42.13 (42.11), H 3.60 (3.52). Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) confirmed characteristic peaks: ν̃ = 3410 (br), 2923 (m), 1599 (s), 1387 (s), 1173 (m), 729 (w) cm⁻¹. The crystalline product was thoroughly washed

A metal-organic framework was synthesized by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (20 mg, 0.083 mmol) and the ligand H2bpdc (10 mg, 0.042 mmol) in 4 mL of MeCN with the addition of 0.05 mL of 50% HBF4 in a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 87.55 °C for 475.723 minutes. Upon returning to ambient temperature, the resulting yellow crystalline product was obtained by filtration, providing a yield of 50% based on H2bpdc. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H12CuF4N2O8: C, 44.72, H, 2.25, N, 5.22, Found: C, 44.68, H, 2.28, N, 5.18. IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) showed bands at: 3057(m), 2243(w), 1705(s), 1589(m), 1457(m), 1398(s), 1257(s), 1150(m), 1022(s), 881(m), 778(s), 698(m), 548(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.060 g, 0.25 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.052 g, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) with 3 drops of HClO4 (8 mol L−1) in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was maintained at 215.74 °C for 242.4 hours and then allowed to cool gradually to room temperature.
