The resultant blue cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and air-dried, resulting in a yield of approximately 68% based on 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. The phase purity was ascertained by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9Cu3O12: C, 34.57, H, 1.45. Found: C, 34.12, H, 1.62. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421(s), 1618(s), 1545(s), 1448(m), 1387(s), 1265(m), 1140(w), 1083(w), 945(w), 834(m), 758(s

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.084 mmol) and H2BDC (15 mg, 0.09 mmol) were dissolved in a 15 mL glass vial containing 68-12-2 (1.5 mL) as the solvent. To this mixture, o-phenanthroline (0.05 g, 0.25 mmol) was introduced as an additive. The solution was subjected to constant stirring for 18 minutes at 302.3 K. The reaction vessel was then tightly sealed, maintaining the conditions for an additional duration at the specified temperature. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The resulting colorless crystalline solids were collected via filtration, rinsed thoroughly with fresh 68-12-2, and subsequently air-dried. Yield: 13.6 mg. Analytically calculated for C24H14N4O10Zn: C, 50.72, H, 3.09, N, 9.89%, found: C, 50.55, H, 3.21, N, 9.74%. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic bands at 3439 (broad), 1582 (s), 1420 (m), 1355 (s), 1224 (w), 1086 (m), 882 (w), 756 (m

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 59 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg), and triethylamine (0.05 mL) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide. The solution was carefully transferred into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to heating at 115 °C for 363 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, colorless block-shaped crystals of the metal-organic framework were obtained. Yield: 29 mg [50% based on ligand]. Anal. Calcd For C10H10N2O6Zn (315.59): C, 37.98, H, 3.18, N, 8.87. Found: C, 38.12, H, 3.25, N, 8.74. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3405(m), 2925(w), 1655(s), 1590(m), 1458(s), 1384(s), 1236(w), 1105(w), 997(vw), 804(s), 723(m).

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture was prepared by combining 0.225 g (0.87 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.150 g (0.75 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), and 3.0 g of the solvent designated as 68-12-2. To this, 0.1 g (0.74 mmol) of sodium acetate trihydrate was added as an additive. The mixture was stirred thoroughly for 30 minutes to ensure homogenization. The autoclave was then sealed tightly and subjected to hydrothermal conditions by heating at 430.7 K for 129 hours. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, violet rod-like crystals were collected (yield: 65%). The product was washed with acetone and deionized water to remove any residual starting materials, followed by drying under a vacuum at ambient temperature. The phase purity of the obtained crystals was verified by powder X-ray diffraction, and the patterns matched well with the simulated data from known crystal structures. Elemental analyses indicated good agreement with the calculated values: C, 40.78%, H, 3.33%, N, 6.18%. The infrared spectrum exhibited characteristic peaks confirming the coordination of the organic acid to the cobalt centers, with prominent signals at 1680 cm−1, 138

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.123 g, 0.5 mmol) and ligand H2bdc (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of methanol. To this solution, 1,3-Dimethylurea (0.046 g, 0.5 mmol) was added under constant stirring at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred for 45 minutes to ensure homogeneity and then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 165.860 °C for 486 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature over a 24-hour period, blue rectangular crystals were obtained. Yield: 68% based on Cu(II) salt. Anal. calcd. for C20H18N2O8Cu: C, 47.36, H, 3.58, N, 5.52. Found: C, 47.59, H, 3.67, N, 5.39. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν(NH), 3360 (m), ν(C=O, urea), 1675 (s), ν(C=C), 1585 (m), ν(C–O), 1379 (s), ν(Cu–O), 679 (w).

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.300 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of DMSO. The resulting solution was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to thermal treatment at 115.22 °C for 463.7 minutes. After the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool down to room temperature naturally. The resultant colorless cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMSO, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 0.145 g (78% yield based on terephthalic acid). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Zn: C 50.52, H 3.71, found: C 50.60, H 3.68. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3375(w), 2921(m), 1598(s), 1445(m), 1382(s), 1296(m), 1175(w), 1103(m), 1018(m), 808(m), 690(m).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.286 g, 0.963 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.00 mmol), NaOH (0.080 g, 2.00 mmol), and methanol (15 mL) was combined in a glass vessel and stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes. The pH of the mixture was adjusted to 9.0 using additional NaOH. The solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 432 K for 348 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals were isolated via filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried. This compound exhibited high thermal stability and sustained framework integrity in methanol for several weeks. The yield was calculated to be 58% based on Zn. Elemental analysis for C16H10O8Zn: Calculated: C, 46.18, H, 2.42%, Zn, 19.95. Found: C, 46.22, H, 2.38%, Zn, 19.88%. The structural identity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, with characteristic bands observed at 3420 m, 1680 s, 1604 m, 1510 s, 1395 s, 1225 m cm

A new metal-organic framework, MOF-X, was synthesized using a combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 g, 0.2 mmol) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) in a solvent system composed of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (5 mL) and an additive of oxalic acid (0.012 g, 0.3 mmol). The mixture was thoroughly stirred and transferred to a 20 mL glass vial, which was securely sealed. The reaction was conducted at a temperature of 342 K for 294.79 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, resulting in the formation of translucent prismatic crystals of MOF-X with a yield of 48% based on the H2BDC ligand. The crystalline product was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction to confirm its phase purity. The IR spectral data showed characteristic bands at 1702 (s), 1589 (m), 1384 (s), and 748 (m) cm−1, indicative of the successful coordination between Zn(II) centers and the dicarboxylate linkers. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MOF-X crystallizes in the triclinic system with a P-1 space group. Structur

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (28.5 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 16.6 mg, 0.10 mmol), and water (8 mL) was combined in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. To this, 0.5 mL of a 48% aqueous solution of HBF4 was added as an additive. The sealed vessel was then placed in an oven and heated at a temperature of 153.750 °C for 347.906 minutes. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting pink crystalline solid was collected by vacuum filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at room temperature. The crystallinity and phase purity of the product were confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction, which matched the theoretical pattern generated from single-crystal data for the anticipated metal-organic framework. The yield of the crystals was determined to be 45%, with elemental analysis showing close agreement with the calculated values. Anal. Calcd for C8H6O4Co: C, 40.74, H, 2.56%. Found: C, 40.65, H, 2.61%. IR (ATR, cm−1): 3400 (br), 1620 (s), 1504 (m),

A solution containing 0.050 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.170 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.028 g, 0.170 mmol), and 0.1 mL of formic acid was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (3 mL) and sonicated for 15 minutes. The mixture was transferred into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, filled to 70% capacity, and heated at 500.230 K for 106 hours under autogenous pressure. The resulting mixture was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h−1. Yellowish block-shaped crystals of the MOF were harvested by filtration, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and dried in air, resulting in a yield of 63% based on zinc. Elemental analysis (%): calculated for C16H10O8Zn: C, 46.58, H, 2.44, found: C, 46.61, H, 2.47. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm−1): νOH 3440, νas(CO2) 1540, νs(CO2) 1400, δ(CH) 730.

A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.63 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.10 g, 0.64 mmol) was combined with 5 mL of 68-12-2 and a touch of NH3. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 502.0 K for 111.108 minutes. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature, the formed crystalline solid was isolated by filtration, washed with 68-12-2, and dried in air, yielding light pink needle-shaped crystals (approx. 65% yield based on CoCl2·6H2O). Elemental analysis for C14H14Cl2CoN2, calculated: C, 48.21%, H, 4.05%, N, 8.04%. Found: C, 48.10%, H, 3.98%, N, 8.11%. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1): 3434 (s), 2915 (m), 1569 (vs), 1415 (s), 1342 (s), 1205 (m), 1138 (w), 1024 (w), 868 (m), 750 (s), 622 (m), 523 (w).

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, 0.512 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 ml of benzene and gently stirred to ensure complete dissolution. Subsequently, 0.254 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was added to the mixture, followed by a careful addition of 1 ml of hydrochloric acid as an additive. The homogeneous solution was transferred to a 50 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed securely. The reaction vessel was subjected to a consistent temperature of 435.1 K for 330.74 hours in an oven. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally over several hours, resulting in the formation of pink crystals. These crystals were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any residual solvent or unreacted materials. The crystalline product was dried in a vacuum desiccator to yield the metal-organic framework suitable for further analysis. Caution is advised during the synthesis due to the use of hydrochloric acid, necessitating appropriate safety measures, including the use of protective gloves and eyewear.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) was prepared in 15 mL of isobutanol. The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 214.734 °C for 500.01 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the blue crystalline product was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with isobutanol, and dried under vacuum for 24 h. The yield was 0.278 g, corresponding to 68% based on Cu-BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4CuO4 (%): C, 39.58, H, 1.66. Found: C, 39.22, H, 1.52. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3398(s), 1595(s), 1507(m), 1384(s), 1105(m), 833(m), 746(s), 674(m), 529(m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), H2BDC (0.042 g, 0.25 mmol), and N(Et)3 (0.101 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in diethanolamine (10 mL) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 10 minutes before being transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel. The vessel was heated at 53.4 °C for 483.7 minutes. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. Prismatic blue crystals were collected, rinsed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.108 g, 55% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calcd for C24H30Cu2N6O10 (%): C, 42.74, H, 4.48, N, 12.47. Found: C, 42.83, H, 4.50, N, 12.51. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3325m, 2948m, 1637s, 1570s, 1458m, 1395s, 1287m, 1172w, 1095m,

To synthesize the target metal-organic framework, a solution was prepared by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) in 10 mL of DMF. Ethylenediamine (0.01 mL, 0.15 mmol) was added as a modulating agent. The solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 383.957 K for 261.811 minutes. After the reaction was complete, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, yielding dark red octahedral crystals. The crystals were subsequently collected by filtration and rinsed with additional DMF (yield: ca. 85%, based on benzenetricarboxylic acid). Characterization by IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet) indicated the presence of the following bands: 3465 (s), 1608 (s), 1560 (m), 1423 (s), 1345 (m), 1203 (w), 1056 (w), 962 (w), 822 (m), 750 (s) cm–1. Elemental analysis for C21H16CoN2O9 (%): Calcd C, 51.21, H

In a typical synthesis, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.519 mmol) and trimesic acid (0.050 g, 0.237 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of H2O. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 424.52 K for 227 minutes. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the mixture was filtered to collect the formed crystals, which were washed thoroughly with water. The obtained purple crystals, suitable for further structural analysis, were isolated with a yield of 35% based on trimesic acid. The purity and composition were confirmed by elemental analysis and X-ray diffraction, revealing the formation of a robust coordination network consistent with expected MOF architecture.

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.3 mmol) in H2O (20 mL) was prepared by stirring for 45 minutes until homogeneity was achieved. Benzoic acid (0.15 g, 1.2 mmol) was added to the mixture, which was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 45 °C for 33.42 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. Pale pink needle-like crystals were obtained and collected by filtration, washed with distilled water, and air-dried (yield 44% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%) of the final compound gave the following: C 52.33 (calcd 52.50), H 3.06 (3.21), N 9.87 (10.01). The IR spectrum (KBr, cm⁻¹) featured characteristic bands at 3420 (b), 2928 (m), 1654 (s), 1575 (s), 1420 (m), 1310 (w), 1265 (w), 1150 (m), 1019 (w), 750 (m), 693 (s).

A synthesis was carried out by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.075 g, 0.25 mmol), H3BTC (0.036 g, 0.15 mmol), and lithium hydroxide (0.010 g, 0.25 mmol) in 8 mL diethylformamide. The solution was stirred at ambient temperature until complete dissolution was achieved. The resulting mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and incubated at 380.099 K for 162.5 minutes. Following the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. Upon filtration, a green crystalline material was isolated. The product was washed with diethylformamide and dried under vacuum to yield the zinc-based MOF with a 53% yield based on Zn(II). The synthesized material's structural integrity was confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction analysis, which matched closely with the simulated pattern (Figure S2).

The synthesis of the MOF was conducted by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.236 g, 0.8 mmol), H2BDC (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and bpy (0.156 g, 1.0 mmol) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 10 mL). The solution was thoroughly mixed, and KOH (0.056 g, 1.0 mmol) was added to adjust the pH to a basic level. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and placed in an oven at 508.7 K for 117.913 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, pale pink polyhedral crystals were obtained, yielding about 45% of the theoretical product based on cobalt. Elemental analysis (%) for C36H28CoN4O8 calculated: C 60.19, H 3.93, N 7.78, found: C 60.32, H 3.85, N 7.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3424 (w), 1678 (s), 1590 (s), 1514 (m), 1398 (s), 1267 (m), 1104

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.168 mmol) and H3BTC (21 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resulting solution was tightly sealed and subjected to thermal conditions at 492.32 K for 263.18 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale blue crystalline solids were collected by filtration and dried under vacuum for 12 hours. Yield: 68% based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H15O7Zn (459.68): C, 47.10, H, 3.29. Found: C, 46.83, H, 3.41. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1610(s), 1445(m), 1118(w), 780(s).

For the synthesis of the desired MOF, a mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.264 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and hexafluoropropene (0.5 mL) was combined with 10 mL of ethanol (CH3CH2OH) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 182.093 °C for 196.98 hours in a preheated oven, allowing for the gradual crystallization of the framework. Post-reaction, the system was cooled to room temperature at a controlled rate. The formed colorless cubic crystals were isolated by vacuum filtration, thoroughly rinsed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield of the product was determined to be 57%. Elemental analysis calculated for the resulting compound [Zn(C8H4F6O4)]: C 31.45%, H 1.33%, N 4.58%, found: C 30.92%, H 1.29%, N 4.82%. FT-IR (solid KBr pellet, cm−1) analysis confirmed the structure with bands at: 3348 br, 1605 s, 1510 m, 1418 s, 1245 m, 1138 m, 978 w,

To a 15 mL solution of N,N-dimethylacetamide was added Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (550 mg, 1.85 mmol) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (300 mg, 1.64 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred for 15 minutes until a homogenous solution was obtained. The pH was adjusted to approximately 4.5 by dropwise addition of 0.1 M HNO3. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 317.127 K for 161.62 minutes under static conditions. After gradual cooling to room temperature, the precipitated yellow cubic crystals were filtered off and washed with cold N,N-dimethylacetamide and ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The product was dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight, yielding 225 mg of the desired metal-organic framework. Yield: 55% based on zinc nitrate. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H8N2O4Zn (346.56): found C, 34.70, H, 2.43, N, 8.05, Zn, 18.83. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1658 (s), 1595 (m), 1517 (m), 1458 (w), 1290 (s), 1245 (m),

A compound comprising 0.050 g (0.124 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) and 0.120 g (0.81 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in a 30 mL glass container with 15 mL of N,N-DIMETHYLACETAMIDE (DMA). The container was sealed and heated at 136.69 °C for 458 minutes. Upon completion of heating, the system was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The resultant material consisted of dark red rod-like crystals, which were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with DMA to remove impurities. After drying under vacuum at room temperature, the product yield was determined to be 72% based on H3BTC. The elemental analysis showed consistency with the calculated values for [Co3(BTC)2(DMA)3(H2O)3]·(DMA)2: found: C, 38.47, H, 4.89, N, 7.21. Infrared spectroscopy confirmed the framework structure with characteristic peaks at ν (cm−1): 3432 (b), 1602 (s), 1397 (s), and 1110 (m).

A mixture of H2bpy (45 mg, 0.22 mmol), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (130 mg, 0.44 mmol), and CH3COOH (0.5 mL) was dissolved in a solvent mixture of DMF (15 mL) and H2O (5 mL) within a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated to 214.956 °C for 471.34 minutes. After the natural cooling to ambient temperature, dark green crystals of Ni-bpy MOF were harvested. Yield: 78 mg (56% based on H2bpy). Anal. Calcd for C14H12N4NiO8 (426.96): C, 39.39, H, 2.83, N, 13.11. Found: C, 39.62, H, 2.90, N, 13.02. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3422(vw), 2927(m), 1705(s), 1598(m), 1455(s), 1384(s), 1264(w), 1103(vw), 996(m), 777(s), 654(m), 502(w).

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 g, 0.6 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of 1-butanol in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated to 148 °C and maintained for 452.83 hours before being allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 0.5 °C per minute. The resulting blue needle-like crystals were harvested by filtration, rinsed with fresh 1-butanol, and allowed to dry in ambient air. Yield was approximately 52%. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4O4Cu: C, 42.53, H, 1.78%. Found: C, 42.60, H, 1.74%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3402 (broad), 2918 (m), 1594 (s), 1384 (s), 1157 (m), 1022 (w).

Synthesis. A total of 0.500 g of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), 0.600 g of terephthalic acid, and 0.150 g of sodium acetate were combined with 10.0 mL of methanol (MeOH) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was stirred vigorously for 30 minutes to ensure thorough mixing. The sealed autoclave was then placed in an oven and heated at 501.999 K for 209.80 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale blue octahedral crystals were collected by filtration, washed with additional MeOH, and air-dried to afford 0.550 g of product, corresponding to an 82% yield. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for CuC8H4O4: C 42.24, H 1.77, Cu 18.64, found: C 42.10, H 1.89, Cu 18.72. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystalline structure matched with known phase data, and optical microscopy revealed uniform crystal morphology with negligible amorphous content.

H4L (0.25 g, 0.32 mmol) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.22 g, 0.75 mmol) were combined and dissolved in DMAc (20 mL) in the presence of HCOOH (0.5 mL) within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resulting solution was heated statically at 472.85 K for approximately 288.3 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C/h, dense, emerald-green cubic crystals formed on the vessel's walls. The crystals were isolated by decanting the supernatant and subsequently washed with fresh DMAc. The crystalline product was obtained with a yield of 47% based on H4L. Elemental analysis calculated for C54H64Ni3N6O20: C, 47.92, H, 4.77, N, 6.21. Found: C, 47.75, H, 4.95, N, 6.03. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432, 2924, 2854, 1620, 1551, 1464, 1386, 1285, 1109, 1035, 873, 756, 692.

A synthesis was conducted by combining ZrOCl2·8H2O (0.256 g, 0.8 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in N,N-Dimethylformamide (15 mL) with pyrazine (0.080 g, 1 mmol) as an additive. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 201.2 °C under autogenous pressure for 445 hours. Following the programmed cooling to ambient temperature, colorless block crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with DMF, and air dried. The synthesis yielded 57% product based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H20N4O10Zr2: C, 29.32, H, 3.08, N, 8.54. Found: C, 29.45, H, 3.12, N, 8.46. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) exhibits peaks at 3410 (m), 1680 (w), 1575 (s), 1447 (m), 1300 (w), 1158 (s), 1070 (m), 938 (w), 825 (s), 750 (m), and 620 (w).

A complex of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) and terephthalic acid (33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was prepared with 4,4′-bipyridine (31.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of PYRIDINE with sodium acetate (16.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL) and subjected to autogenous pressure at 169.5 °C for 79.322 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, purple crystals were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried (yield: 62% based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C28H22CoN2O8: C, 56.95, H, 3.75, N, 4.74. Found: C, 56.87, H, 3.80, N, 4.68. Infrared (IR, KBr, cm–1): 3423 (m), 1609 (s), 1541 (m), 1489 (s), 1405 (s), 1315 (m), 1242 (w), 1178 (s), 1052 (m), 894 (w), 746 (m),

A combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.45 g, 1.55 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) was dissolved in EtOH (30 mL) and the solution was added to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to a thermal treatment at 148.01 °C for 424.09 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, achieved at a rate of 0.1 °C per minute, orange rod-shaped crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum to furnish the product. Yield: 0.35 g (78%). Anal. calcd: C 64.89, H 4.21, N 5.67, found: C 64.55, H 4.15, N 5.60. Selected IR (cm−1): 3420 (br, s), 1680 (m), 1590 (vs), 1455 (m), 1370 (m), 1250 (w), 980 (m), 769 (m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.059 g) and terephthalic acid (0.2 mmol, 0.033 g) was dissolved in 5 mL of 1-butanol. To this solution, lithium hydroxide (0.03 mmol, 0.0013 g) was added as an additive to promote the deprotonation of the ligand. The reaction mixture was transferred into a 15 mL glass vial and heated at 243.03 °C for 256 minutes in a conventional oven. Upon cooling to room temperature, the solution yielded colorless needle-like crystals, which were isolated by decantation and washed in 1-butanol. The overall yield was 58%, based on the zinc source. Analytical data for the compound C16H10O8Zn (molecular weight: X): calcd. C 49.02, H 2.57, Zn 16.67 %, found: C 48.97, H 2.61, Zn 16.31 %. The infrared spectrum (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3416 (m), 1602 (s), 1517 (s), 1402 (w), 1325 (m), 1258 (w), 1118 (w), 1025 (w), 856 (m), 752 (m),

A mixture of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (10 mg, 0.048 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 220 °C for 500 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale yellow needle-like crystals were obtained with a yield of approximately 40% based on the Mn. Anal. calcd for C18H10O12Mn2 (%): C 38.69, H 1.81. Found (%): C 38.59, H 1.90. Selected IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3550(m), 1667(s), 1435(s), 1371(m), 1264(w), 1084(m), 820(s), 758(m), 701(s), 615(w).

Synthesis of compound X: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.15 mmol), and 2-Amino-1-butanol (12 mL) was prepared in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Hexafluoropropene (0.25 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, which was then sealed and heated at 527.218 K for 398.660 minutes. After the reaction time, the autoclave was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 K per hour. Colorless cubic crystals of compound X were isolated with a yield of approximately 45% based on Zn. Anal. calc. for C16H18F6N2O4Zn: C: 41.68, H: 3.94, N: 6.08, found: C: 41.59, H: 3.99, N: 6.15. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3425m, 1716s, 1584s, 1403m, 1335w, 1190w, 1075w, 814s, 752m, 670w, 615w.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol), H2BDC (0.042 g, 0.25 mmol), 1 drop of ammonia, and acetonitrile (12.0 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 448.68 K for 393.264 minutes and then slowly allowed to cool to room temperature over 12 hours. Colorless needle-like crystals of the metal-organic framework were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 72% based on Zn. Elemental analysis (%) for C16H14O8Zn (Zn-MOF): calcd, C 44.12, H 3.24, found, C 44.01, H 3.30. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (s), 1682 (vs), 1610 (s), 1555 (s), 1464 (m), 1380 (s), 1302 (m), 1090 (m), 1005 (w), 870 (m), 812 (s), 725 (s).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0895 g, 0.30 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.0831 g, 0.50 mmol) was prepared in benzene (5 mL). The mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 80.7 °C for 493 hours. After cooling to room temperature, yellow cubic crystals were isolated via filtration, washed with benzene, and air-dried, resulting in a 45% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.051 g). Elemental analysis calculated for C20H16O8Zn (%): C, 53.10, H, 3.57. Found: C, 52.98, H, 3.49. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(s), 3085(m), 1608(s), 1492(m), 1387(s), 1212(m), 1106(w), 1025(m), 866(s), 721(m), 620(w), 543(m).

Synthesis of MOF-3: In a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (60.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) and H2BDC (33.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in a solvent blend of 1-butanol (5 mL) and glycol (0.5 mL). The reactor was sealed and subjected to heating at 175 °C for 464.6 minutes under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to room temperature, the resultant colorless prismatic crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with 1-butanol and diethyl ether, yielding MOF-3 with a 68% yield based on H2BDC. Anal. Calcd. for C16H12O8Zn: C, 48.74, H, 3.07, Found: C, 48.66, H, 3.12%. The FTIR spectrum (KBr, ν/cm−1) showcased peaks at 3440 m, 2927w, 1698 s, 1605 m, 1510w, 1412 s, 1289 m, 1110w, 1007 m, 877w, 742 s, 670 m, 515w, providing insights into the framework structure.

In a Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor (20 mL), a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.0291 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.2 mmol, 0.0332 g) was dissolved in 8 mL DMSO. The solution was subjected to a heating condition of 393 K for 172.029 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour. The resulting light-purple octahedral crystals were collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with DMSO, and air-dried, yielding approximately 30%. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN2O8: C, 44.64, H, 3.28, N, 6.51. Found: C, 44.50, H, 3.33, N, 6.47. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3438(m), 1605(s), 1558(s), 1482(m), 1384(s), 1341(m), 1211(w), 1136(m), 1012(w), 916(w), 842(m), 785(m), 701(m), 625(m), 535(m). The purity and crystallinity were

Synthesis of {(Cu2Br2)(bpy)2}n. A mixture of CuBr (0.2 mmol), bpy (0.4 mmol), and MeCN (10 mL) was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 247.1 °C for 80 minutes. After the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting product, pale blue crystals, was isolated by filtration, washed with MeCN, and left to dry at room temperature. Yield: 65% (based on Cu). Elemental analysis calculated for (C20H16Br2Cu2N4): C, 41.12, H, 2.76, N, 9.59%, found: C 41.05, H 2.68, N 9.53%. The crystal structure was corroborated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and phase purity was confirmed using powder X-ray diffraction, as shown in Figure S4.

A solution was prepared by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (15 mg, 0.07 mmol) in benzene (5 mL). The mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 69 °C for 326.6 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, yielding purple prismatic crystals. These were then filtered, washed with benzene, and air-dried to afford a yield of approximately 54% based on BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12CoN3O12: C, 40.53, H, 2.27, N, 7.88. Found: C, 40.45, H, 2.33, N, 7.92. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited absorption bands at 3448 (br), 1615 (s), 1458 (m), 1340 (s), 1227 (s), 1120 (w), 913 (w), 788 (m), 698 (m), 620 (w), 505 (w), 455 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.126 g, 0.42 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.084 g, 0.5 mmol), and isobutanol (15 mL) was prepared and subsequently treated with 0.5 mL of HBF4 as an additive. The resultant suspension was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 240 °C for 85.088 hours. Following the cooling process to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals of the desired metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration. The obtained yield was 65%, calculated based on Zn(II). IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442 (b), 1703 (s), 1590 (s), 1456 (m), 1388 (m), 1261 (w), 1115 (w), 1023 (m), 893 (w), 805 (m), 758 (w), 650 (w).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (0.25 mmol), and methanol (10 mL) was combined in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 249 °C for 274 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Green needle-like crystals of the Ni-MOF were obtained by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried. Yield: 65%. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H8NiO8: C 32.72, H 2.20, Ni 31.96, found: C 32.68, H 2.24, Ni 31.92. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3371 m, 2925 w, 1658 s, 1587 vs, 1460 m, 1389 s, 1295 w, 1229 s, 1150 w, 945 w, 834 m, 740 w, 685 w.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (75 mg, 0.25 mmol), H2BTB (30 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,2,4-triazole (15 mg, 0.18 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (8 mL), and HBO3 (20 mg) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reactor was placed in an oven and heated to 74.8 °C for 71 minutes. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Upon filtration and careful washing with diethyl ether, pale yellow needle-shaped crystals suitable for single-crystal XRD analysis were obtained. The yield was calculated to be 60% based on H2BTB. Anal. Calcd for C30H24B2N14O12Zn3: C, 35.12, H, 2.36, N, 19.05. Found: C, 34.98, H, 2.45, N, 18.90. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3410w, 3126m, 2924w, 1655s, 1500s, 1412m, 1358s, 1187m, 1048m, 882w, 749m, 615w.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, 150 mg (0.225 mmol) of H6L and 0.28 g (1.12 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 8 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMAc) in a 20 mL pressure-resistant glass vial. The resulting mixture was thoroughly stirred until homogeneous and then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a heating program set at 142.331 °C for 30 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The white crystalline product was separated by filtration, washed extensively with DMAc to remove any unreacted starting materials, and subsequently dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 85.2 mg (45% based on H6L). Selected FTIR (cm–1): 3548 (br, w), 2963 (w), 1680 (vs), 1609 (s), 1525 (m), 1470 (m), 1420 (s), 1385 (vs), 1320 (w), 1265 (m), 1201 (w), 1152 (w), 1103 (s), 1070 (m), 950 (w), 890 (w), 810 (m), 750 (s), 730 (w),

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (29.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, followed by the addition of bipyridine (15 mg, 0.1 mmol) and terephthalic acid (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) under continuous stirring. Tetrafluoroboric acid (5 μL) was then introduced as an additive to the reaction mixture. The solution was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 330 K for 199.7 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, colorless crystals of the zinc-based MOF were obtained in a 45% yield based on zinc nitrate. The crystals were filtered, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Anal. Calc. for C24H18N2O6Zn: C, 54.23, H, 3.42, N, 5.27%. Found: C, 54.10, H, 3.50, N, 5.10%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1654(s), 1507(m), 1371(s), 1236(m), 732(s), 686(m).

A synthesis was conducted by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.240 g, 1.0 mmol) and H3BTC (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) with the addition of hexafluoropropene (0.5 mL) as an auxiliary agent. This mixture was placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to heating at 425.296 K for a duration of 479.4 minutes. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. Blue octahedral crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated, with a yield of 0.275 g based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The role of hexafluoropropene in this reaction was found to be crucial, as attempts to synthesize the framework without it resulted in significantly reduced crystallinity and yield. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3442 (br), 3098 (w), 1645 (s), 1579 (s), 1421 (m), 1020 (m), 804 (s), elemental analysis calculated (%) for the MOF (C18H12Cu3F12O18): C: 25.82, H: 1.44, found: C 25.65, H 1.

The metal-organic framework [Ni3(BDC)3(DABCO)]∙guest (2⋅g) was synthesized using a solvothermal method. A mixture comprising Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O (0.500 g, 1.72 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.300 g, 1.80 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO, 0.200 g, 1.78 mmol) was dissolved in 25 mL of diethanolamine with sodium acetate trihydrate (0.100 g, 0.74 mmol) as an additive. The solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) and heated at 210 °C for 362.419 hours. Subsequently, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 0.05 °C min−1. The resulting dark-orange cubic crystals were obtained by vacuum filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum, yielding 215 mg (yield 61%). Elemental analysis for the guest-free framework [Ni3(BDC)3(DABCO)] indicated: Calculated: C 43.75%, H 3.67%, N 2.81%. Found: C 43.72%, H 3.70%, N

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.032 g, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (0.021 g, 0.1 mmol), potassium iodide (0.015 g, 0.09 mmol), and THF (10.0 mL) was stirred and then heated at 38 °C for 55 hours in a sealed Teflon-lined vessel. After cooling to room temperature over 12 hours, the resultant pale yellow hexagonal crystals of compound 2 were obtained by decanting the solvent and washing with cold THF. Yield: 72%. Anal. calcd for C8H6O4ZnI (2): C, 29.88, H, 1.88%. Found: C, 30.12, H, 2.01%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3437 (b), 1710 (s), 1595 (m), 1450 (s), 1371 (s), 1248 (m), 1105 (w), 1025 (m), 871 (w), 741 (s), 612 (m).

A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (5.2 mg, 0.025 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (14.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) was combined in a reaction vessel. Following this, tetramethylammonium hydroxide (4 mL, 0.1 M) was added carefully to the mixture. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 1 h to ensure complete dissolution, producing a homogeneous solution. The reaction vessel was then sealed and transferred to a convection oven, where it was maintained at 104 °C for 346.860 hours. Upon cooling to ambient conditions, the solution yielded transparent crystalline products. These transparent crystals were thoroughly rinsed with methanol to remove any unreacted material and then air-dried. The yield was determined to be 68% based on zinc nitrate consumption. Elemental analysis revealed values: calcd for C20H30O10Zn2N4 (ZnMOF): C, 39.27, H, 4.94, N, 9.16%. Found: C, 39.34, H, 4.80, N, 9.09%. All starting materials were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received without further purification.

For detailed experimental procedures including syntheses and characterization data, see the Supporting Information. Briefly, commercial Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (150 mg, 0.62 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 42 mg, 0.20 mmol), and ethanol (10 mL) were added to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was sonicated to ensure a homogeneous dispersion. The sealed autoclave was placed in a preheated oven at 173 °C for 77 minutes. After the reaction time, the autoclave was removed from the oven and allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting suspension was filtered to isolate blue crystalline solids, which were washed thoroughly with fresh ethanol (3 × 20 mL) to remove any unreacted compounds. The crystals were then transferred to a vacuum oven and dried under reduced pressure at 60 °C for 5 hours. The dried material was obtained as blue square-shaped crystals of [Cu3(BTC)2] with a yield of 72%.

For the synthesis of MOF-100, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and 25 µL of HCl was prepared in 10 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) and transferred to a 20 mL screw-cap glass vial. The vial was securely sealed and subjected to a controlled heating cycle in an oven at a temperature of 499.821 K for 309.576 hours. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature. The resulting product consisted of dark blue microcrystals that were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with MeCN, and subsequently dried under vacuum. The yield was 0.295 g, corresponding to 79% based on Cu. Anal. Calcd. for C16H12CuO8: C, 47.21, H, 2.97%. Found: C, 47.05, H, 3.04%. IR (cm−1): 3437 w br, 1678 s, 1621 m, 1505 s, 1381 s, 1122 m, 1068 m, 895 m, 750 s.

All starting materials and solvents for the synthesis were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. The synthesis of the metal-organic framework involved combining a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in 10 mL of isobutanol as the solvent. To this mixture, CH3ONa (0.054 g, 1 mmol) was added as an additive. The solution was loaded into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reactor was sealed and subjected to heating at 460 K for 5 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant white crystalline precipitate was collected by suction filtration, followed by washing with isobutanol several times to remove impurities. The washed crystalline product was then dried overnight under vacuum at room temperature to yield 0.212 g of product (77% yield based on Co). The single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the formation of the intended metal-organic framework. Further attempts to modify the structure by varying the molar ratio of the reactants did not lead to significant improvements in crystallinity or yield.

Zinc acetate dihydrate (0.0540 g, 0.25 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.0330 g, 0.20 mmol), and KOH (0.0112 g, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in DMAc (6 mL). The solution was transferred into a 20 mL scintillation vial and heated to 101.104 °C for 18.032 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the reaction yielded colorless needle-like crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMAc and ethanol, and left to dry in air (42 mg, 57% yield based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). A purity analysis yielded: C, 49.05, H, 3.20, N, 0.00%. IR (cm−1): 3445 (w), 1669 (m), 1584 (s), 1504 (s), 1396 (s), 1298 (m), 1210 (m), 1115 (w), 947 (w), 865 (m), 813 (m), 750 (s), 683 (m), 641 (s). These crystals were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction, confirming their structural integrity and phase purity. Detailed crystallographic information and data refinement statistics are provided in the supporting information

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.34 mmol) and H2BDC (0.05 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in pyridine (7 mL) along with glycol (50 μL) as an additive. The resulting solution was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 521.837 K for 116.4 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. Purple cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with pyridine, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 75% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C14H10NiO6 (321.94 g/mol): C, 52.21, H, 3.12, N, 0.00%. Found: C, 51.98, H, 3.25, N, 0.00%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445 (s), 3005 (w), 2927 (w), 1685 (s), 1600 (s), 1384 (s), 1210 (m), 1155 (w), 1100 (m), 998 (w).

Synthesis of [Zn4(BDC)3(DMA)2] (MOF-1): Terephthalic acid (40 mg, 0.24 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.34 mmol) were dissolved in dimethylacetamide (15 mL) to form a clear solution. This mixture was then loaded into a 20 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 57.511 °C for 87.341 hours. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature, resulting in the formation of colorless octahedral crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh dimethylacetamide, and left to dry in air. The structural integrity and phase purity of the product were confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction, indicating good agreement with the simulated pattern. Elemental analysis for C24H20N2O14Zn4 calculated (%): C, 33.56, H, 2.35, N, 3.26. Found: C, 33.68, H, 2.28, N, 3.35. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1623 (s), 1540 (m), 1448 (m), 1393 (s), 1200 (m), 1050 (w), 898 (m),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol), the organic linker H3BTC (benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, 0.05 mmol), and sodium acetate trihydrate (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. The solution was stirred for 15 minutes before being transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed and heated to 106.375 °C for 309.1 minutes in a programmable oven. After completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting off-white crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with water. The product yield was 68% based on Zn. The composition was further confirmed by elemental analysis: calc. for C, 33.49%, H, 2.81%, found: C, 33.32%, H, 2.97%. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm⁻¹) data show prominent peaks at 3440, 1608, 1550, 1392, 1270, 1120, 1010, 820, 775.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.20 g, 0.67 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, 0.10 g, 0.61 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. The solution was stirred for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The resultant mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 172.88 °C for 46.176 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature over 24 hours, colorless block crystals of the MOF were obtained. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with ethanol to remove any residual solvent. Yield: 75% based on BDC. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C16H24N2O8Zn: C 46.38, H 5.84, N 6.77, found: C 46.50, H 5.70, N 6.80. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3430 (w), 1608 (s), 1556 (m), 1467 (m), 1384 (s), 1247 (m), 1017 (w), 878 (w), 732 (m), 686 (w), 513 (m).

A synthesis mixture comprising 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.100 mmol, 21.0 mg) and copper(II) nitrate hemipentahydrate (Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, 0.200 mmol, 56.0 mg) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL glass vessel. The sealed vessel was then subjected to heating at 421 K for a duration of 388.920 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature, blue platelet crystals were obtained and collected by filtration, followed by air drying to yield 62% based on Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O. Elemental analysis (%) of the compound, formulated as [Cu2(BTC)2(DMF)2]·(DMF)3(H2O)4, showed a calculation of C, 42.34, H, 3.89, N, 5.92. The experimental values found were C, 42.21, H, 3.81, N, 5.88. The characterization by IR spectroscopy exhibited notable peaks (cm−1) at 3436 m, 1623 s, 1398 m, 1256 s, and 758 m, indicative of the structural integrity of the synthesized framework.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol) and H2bdc (0.040 g, 0.24 mmol) was dissolved in EtOH (5 mL) and placed in a 20 mL reaction vial. The mixture was then heated at 167.65 °C for 401 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resultant precipitate was collected via filtration, yielding pink crystalline blocks of the product. Yield: 58% based on Co(NO3)2. Anal. calc. for C14H12CoO8 (365.18): C, 46.02, H, 3.31, Co, 16.12%. Found: C, 45.98, H, 3.30, Co, 16.15%. IR (KBr pellet): 3420 (m), 1618 (s), 1572 (m), 1405 (s), 1328 (w), 1223 (m), 1120 (w), 744 (s), 683 (m) cm⁻¹.

0.150 g (0.55 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of isobutanol in a 20 mL glass vial. To this solution, 0.120 g (0.60 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) was added. The vial was sealed, and the mixture was stirred thoroughly to ensure homogeneity. The sealed vial was then placed inside an oven preheated to 369 K and maintained at this temperature for 88.8 minutes. Upon completion of the heating, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature before opening. The resulting white crystalline product was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with isobutanol (∼10 mL), and subsequently air-dried. The yield was determined to be 58% based on BDC. Characterization was performed using powder X-ray diffraction and IR spectroscopy. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3065 (w) ν(OH), 1713 (m) ν(CO), 1605 (vs) νas(COO), 1512 (s) ν(C═C), 1382 (s) νs(COO), 759 (s) δ(OCO).

Synthesis of the MOF-5 Complex: A stoichiometric mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.298 g, 1.0 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) was prepared in 10 mL of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE. To this, TETRAMETHYLAMMONIUM HYDROXIDE (0.080 g, 0.5 mmol) was added as an additive to facilitate deprotonation. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and sealed. The system was heated at 220.191 °C for 230.170 minutes. After completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature over the next 20 hours. The precipitated colorless cubic crystals were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with water and ethanol, yielding 68% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. calcd for Zn4O(BDC)3 (C24H12O13Zn4): C, 42.24, H, 1.77, found: C, 42.12, H, 1.69. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448(s, br), 1620(m), 1592(m), 1518(m), 1417

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 g, 1.68 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.3 g, 1.81 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 25 mL) and transferred to a 100-mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was set to maintain a temperature of 299 K for 135.2 hours without any stirring. Upon completion of the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to naturally cool to ambient temperature. The resulting colorless crystals were separated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and air-dried to afford a yield of 67%. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14N2O8Zn2 (477.65): C, 40.25, H, 2.95, N, 5.88. Found: C, 40.12, H, 3.10, N, 5.78. Characteristic IR bands: νC=O = 1705 (s), 1598 (m), 1412 (vs), 1385 (m) cm–1.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.165 g, 0.55 mmol) and H2BDC (0.092 g, 0.45 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. The resulting solution was stirred for approximately 30 minutes at ambient temperature. The mixture was then transferred into a glass vial, sealed, and heated at 49.184 °C for 49.17 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, yielding transparent needle-like crystals. These crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, and air-dried. The obtained crystals were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, confirming the formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.200 g, 0.67 mmol) and H2BDC (0.120 g, 0.72 mmol) was prepared in 15 mL of MeCN. To this solution, 0.25 mL of tetrafluoroboric acid (48% in water) was added dropwise with continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 434 K for 470 hours under autogenous pressure. After the heating period, the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature over 24 hours. Pale yellow crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration, washed with MeCN, and air-dried, yielding approximately 53% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis for the MOF (%): C, 39.74, H, 3.21, N, 5.62, Zn, 19.17. Found: C, 39.70, H, 3.18, N, 5.65, Zn, 19.13. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3410 (br), 3135 (w), 2910 (m), 2365 (w), 1710 (s), 1590 (m), 1505 (m), 1435

Synthesis of [CoL2(H2O)2]n: In a 20 mL glass vial, a mixture of Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (0.074 g, 0.25 mmol), ligand L (0.050 g, 0.20 mmol), and NMP (4.5 g) was combined with Hexafluoropropene (0.5 mL). The mixture was stirred for 20 minutes at room temperature. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon vial, which was then sealed in a stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 70.150 °C for 255.189 minutes and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature. Upon cooling, crystalline blue rods of the product [CoL2(H2O)2]n formed and were isolated via filtration. The crystals were washed with ethanol and dried in a vacuum desiccator, yielding 0.045 g (64% based on ligand L). Elemental analysis for C20H24CoN4O8, calcd (%): C 46.95, H 4.73, N 10.94. Found (%): C 46.81, H 4.71, N 11.00. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3410(s), 2924(s), 1598(s), 1382(s), 1220(m

To a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) in DMF (15 mL) was added H2BDC (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and the resulting mixture was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor. The sealed reactor was then heated at 150 °C for 475.3 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the solution was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 K·h–1. Pale yellow block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated with a yield of 68% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C16H18N2O10Zn: C 40.53, H 3.83, N 5.91, found: C 40.46, H 3.87, N 5.88. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(w), 1648(s), 1590(m), 1410(s), 1315(m), 1075(m), 1012(w), 845(w), 755(s), 689(m), 622(w).

To synthesize [Zn2(bdc)2(dmf)2], zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 200 mg, 0.67 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 15 mL) and combined with terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 56 mg, 0.34 mmol) in a separate DMF solution (15 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred into a Duran glass tube with a diameter of 18 mm and a height of 180 mm, which was then tightly sealed and placed in an oven at 448.83 K for 20.7 hours. Upon completion, the reaction yielded colorless crystalline solid, recovered by filtration and repeatedly washed with DMF (∼10 mL). The crystals were subsequently dried under vacuum for 30 minutes. The final product, with a yield of 153 mg (79%), was characterized using infrared spectroscopy: selected IR (KBr) ν values included 3448 (w) for ν(OH), 2926 (w) for ν(CH), 1654 (m) for ν(CO), 1591 (s) for νas(COO), 1387 (s) for νs(COO), 1256 (m), and 755 (s) for δ(OCO) cm−1. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14N2O

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol), H3TATB (0.054 g, 0.15 mmol) and MeCN (8 mL) was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL). The sealed vessel was heated at 252.7 °C for 237 hours and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting dark purple block-like crystals were isolated and washed with MeCN, yielding 61% (0.080 g, based on H3TATB) of the product. Anal. Calcd for C30H36CoN6O12: C, 48.01, H, 4.83, N, 11.20%. Found: C, 47.89, H, 4.90, N, 11.13%. IR (KBr disks): 3433 (w), 2925 (m), 1657 (s), 1454 (s), 1384 (m), 1269 (m), 1108 (m), 936 (w), 787 (m), 671 (w), 543 (m).

All commercially available chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. Synthesis of MOF compound 3: A mixture containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (42 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of diethylformamide within a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 509.826 K and maintained at this temperature for 252.56 hours. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale blue octahedral crystals were harvested by filtration, washed thoroughly with diethylformamide, and allowed to dry under ambient conditions, affording a yield of 75% based on Cu(II). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12Cu2O12: C, 36.47%, H, 2.04%, Found: C, 36.63%, H, 1.96%. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3345 (m), 3014 (w), 1685 (s), 1512 (m), 1432 (s), 1389 (s), 1268 (m), 1172 (w), 1105 (w), 1025 (w), 929 (m

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), H2BDC (0.018 g, 0.10 mmol), and 1,4-bimb (0.015 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of dimethylacetamide. The solution was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel and heated at 251.6 °C for 92.9 minutes. Upon slowly cooling to room temperature, transparent needle-like crystals were obtained by filtration and subsequently washed with dimethylacetamide. The yield was 48% based on H2BDC. Anal. Calcd for C25H22N4O8Zn3 (Mw = 695.15): C, 43.18, H, 3.21, N, 8.06%. Found: C, 43.31, H, 3.15, N, 7.98%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3438 (m), 2925 (w), 1628 (s), 1530 (m), 1445 (s), 1347 (m), 1290 (m), 1190 (w), 966 (w), 890 (w), 815 (m), 783 (w), 710 (w), 678 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.122 g, 0.50 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (15 mL) and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 127.9 °C for 135.52 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline solids of the Cu-based MOF were collected, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was calculated to be 55% based on copper. Elemental analysis found: C 45.12, H 3.59, O 30.92, Calcd. for C8H8CuO4: C 45.25, H 3.79, O 30.15. IR (KBr): 3440 (br), 1625 (m), 1577 (s), 1405 (m), 1098 (w), 898 (w), 752 (m), 491 (w) cm−1.

A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89.3 mg, 0.3 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (24.9 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of THF, alongside hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.1 mL, 0.5 mmol) as an additive to modulate crystal growth. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a hydrothermal reaction at 481.755 K for 185.991 minutes. Post reaction, the vessel was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Subsequently, colorless octahedral crystals were obtained, rinsed with THF, and isolated. The yield of the crystalline product was approximately 58% with respect to Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10O9Zn: C, 45.95%, H, 2.41%. Found: C, 45.82%, H, 2.38%. The FTIR spectrum (KBr disc, cm−1) showed characteristic bands at: 1685(s), 1595(s), 1518(m), 1449(m), 1295(s), 1208(s), 1155(m), 1101(s), 986(m), and 820(m

Synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3]n. A reaction mixture was prepared by adding Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.62 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.105 g, 0.50 mmol), and concentrated HCl (0.1 mL, as an additive) into 10 mL of methanol. The mixture was stirred for 30 minutes to ensure homogenization. The reaction solution was then transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, occupying approximately 20% of its volume. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 194.6 °C for 119 hours under static conditions. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting blue crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh methanol, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 65% based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd (%) for Cu3C18H12O24: C 36.83, H 2.06, Cu 32.52. Found: C 36.78, H 1.98, Cu 32.40. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) exhibited peaks at 3456(m), 1620(s), 1475(vs), 1386(m),

A new metal-organic framework was synthesized using zinc nitrate hexahydrate Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.25 g, 4.2 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.50 g, 3.0 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. The resulting homogeneous solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, tightly sealed, and heated at 174.4 °C for 402 minutes under autogenous pressure. After completing the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, resulting in the formation of colorless crystalline solids. These crystals were carefully collected via filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol (4 × 15 mL) to remove any unreacted organic ligands and byproducts, and subsequently dried under a gentle stream of nitrogen gas at room temperature. The phase purity of the synthesized MOF was confirmed by comparing the experimental X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) pattern with a simulated pattern generated from the single-crystal structure. Yield was determined to be 0.085 g, corresponding to a 12% yield with respect to the metal precursor.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol), H3btc (0.042 g, 0.1 mmol), and 1,4-dioxane (2.5 mL) was prepared in a 15 mL round-bottom flask. To this solution, HCl (0.1 mL, 6 M) was added dropwise under stirring. The flask was then sealed and maintained at a controlled temperature of 302.448 K for 243.0 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in the formation of pale blue octahedral crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with 1,4-dioxane, and air-dried, yielding a material with 76% yield based on H3btc. Analytical data calculated for C18H12O15Zn3 (Mr = 679.49): C, 31.89, H, 1.79, N, 0.00. Found: C, 31.76, H, 1.88, N, 0.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3436(m), 2929(w), 1692(s), 1597(m), 1495(m), 1394(vs), 1268(w), 1105(m), 835(m), 779(s), 680

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol, turquoise powder) and ligand H2BDC (0.1 mmol, white crystalline solid) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1-butanol. To this solution, pivalic acid (0.5 mmol) was added as a modulating agent. The reaction mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and subjected to heating at 82.0 °C for 405 minutes under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature naturally, turquoise-blue needle-like crystals of the Cu-MOF were obtained in 85% yield (51.3 mg, based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). The crystals were washed sequentially with hot 1-butanol and ethanol, followed by acetone, and allowed to air-dry. Anal. Calc. for C16H18CuN2O10: C, 40.24, H, 3.80, N, 5.87%. Found: C, 40.13, H, 3.75, N, 5.71%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3410(m), 2924(m), 2854(w), 1620(s), 1578(s), 1440(m), 1386(s), 1260(w), 112

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.126 g, 0.6 mmol), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.042 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in H2O (10 mL) and placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated statically at 146.384 °C for 120 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the reaction yielded pink octahedral crystals. The isolated compound was thoroughly rinsed with deionized water and dried under ambient conditions. The phase purity was validated by powder X-ray diffraction analysis (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Elemental analysis for C18H12CoLiNO12 (524.17) gave the following values: calculated (%): C, 41.25, H, 2.31, N, 2.67, found (%): C, 41.00, H, 2.25, N, 2.60. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited peaks at: 3432 broad, 1602 strong, 1425 medium, 1384 medium, 1268 weak, 1197 weak, 1112 medium, 973 weak, 888 medium, 781 medium, 625 medium, and

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture composed of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.34 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.05 g, 0.24 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (CH3CN, 5 mL) within a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes to ensure complete dissolution and homogeneity. Subsequently, the clear solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to hydrothermal conditions by heating at 192 °C for 155.121 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The crystalline product, obtained as colorless needle-like crystals, was carefully isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with cold acetonitrile, and dried under reduced pressure to yield the MOF. The resultant material was characterized and confirmed through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, showing high purity and a 68% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. The material was subsequently stored in a desiccator awaiting further analysis.

A novel Zn-based metal-organic framework was synthesized by combining 0.5 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (1.68 mmol) with 0.4 g of 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2.08 mmol) in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) under solvothermal conditions. To this mixture, 0.1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid was carefully added as a modulator. The reaction was carried out in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed and heated at 381.769 K for 116.722 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting yellowish crystals were filtered, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed the framework's crystallinity and ensured phase purity. The as-synthesized framework displayed remarkable thermal stability up to 300 °C, as confirmed by TGA analysis (Fig. 2), and exhibited a unique microporous structure with potential for gas adsorption applications.

To synthesize the MOF, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 2-amino-1-butanol (15.0 mL) under continuous stirring, followed by the addition of benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol). The solution was carefully adjusted by adding sulfuric acid (0.05 mL), and a homogeneous mixture was obtained. This reaction mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL capacity), sealed, and heated at 398.130 K for 163 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting product comprised blue crystalline solids, which were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum for 10 hours. The yield was 0.320 g, corresponding to 65% based on Cu2(bdc)2(2-amino-1-butanol)2. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for the framework: C 45.67, H 4.89, N 3.21. Found: C 45.51, H 5.02, N 3.14%.

The synthesis of Compound 2 was achieved using solvothermal methods. A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of pyridine. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL). The sealed vessel was heated at 467.7 K for 178.2 minutes. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. The procedure resulted in the formation of deep-blue crystalline materials, which were isolated by filtration and washed with fresh pyridine (yield: 72% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9Cu2N3O9 (528.36): C 40.89, H 1.72, N 7.96, Cu 24.05. Found: C 40.92, H 1.75, N 7.94, Cu 24.00. IR (solid KBr pellet, cm−1): 3430 (br), 1610 (s), 1575 (m), 1448 (w), 1384 (s), 1287 (s), 1210 (w),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.17 mmol), 2,5-Dihydroxy-1,4-benzoquinone (18.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (15.6 mg, 0.10 mmol) was thoroughly dissolved in diethylformamide (10 mL). Subsequently, 0.2 mL of hexafluoropropene was added to the solution under constant stirring to ensure homogeneity. The resulting mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then tightly sealed and heated at 314 K for 369 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow block-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with diethylformamide, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 69% based on 2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzoquinone. Analytical data: Calculated for C24H18F6N4O8Zn2: C, 40.92, H, 2.57, N, 7.95. Found: C, 40.80, H, 2.63, N, 8.02. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3444(m), 1710

Synthesis of [MOF-XYZ]: A total of 0.100 g of H2L ligand (0.300 mmol) and 0.150 g of ZrCl4 (0.643 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was stirred for 30 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The autoclave was then sealed and heated at 517.801 K for 496.9 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting product, composed of colorless crystals, was isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with methanol. The yield of the synthesized MOF was 0.180 g, corresponding to an 85% yield based on the initial amount of H2L ligand. Elemental analysis for C24H20ZrN2O8 (MW: 560.66 g/mol): calculated C 51.43%, H 3.60%, N 5.00%, found: C 51.55%, H 3.48%, N 5.12%. The integrity and phase purity of the MOF were confirmed by PXRD analysis, which matched the simulated pattern derived from the single-crystal data. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (b, O−H), 2950 (m, C−

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol) and TPA (0.120 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in NMP (20 mL) and stirred at ambient temperature until a clear solution was formed. The resultant solution was then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was subsequently heated to 393.79 K for 89.79 hours. After the heating period, the reaction system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting white crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with NMP, and air-dried (yield: 48% based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for C30H24N4O8Zn: C, 55.31, H, 3.71, N, 8.60. Found: C, 55.09, H, 3.84, N, 8.43. The IR spectrum exhibited characteristic peaks at (cm−1): 3300 (w), 2925 (w), 1620 (s), 1545 (m), 1420 (s), 1250 (m), 1120 (w), 930 (s), 825 (w), 770 (m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.200 g, 0.67 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.174 g, 1.05 mmol) was dissolved in THF (15 ml) in a 20 ml glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 85 °C for 362.9 minutes in an oil bath to yield a dense suspension. After cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature, the suspension was filtered and washed thoroughly with fresh THF (2 × 5 ml) to remove unreacted ligands. Residual solvent was removed under vacuum, and the final product was dried at 40 °C for 1 hour. The crystalline material obtained showed high purity and the infrared spectrum (KBr, cm–1) indicated key vibrations: 3431 (br, w), 1650 (vs), 1580 (m), 1430 (w), 1395 (vs), 1290 (m), 1190 (w), 992 (s), 750 (m), 724 (s). Elemental analysis for C8H6ZnO4 calculated (%): C, 38.50, H, 2.42, Zn, 26.12. Found (%): C, 38.36, H, 2.45, Zn, 25.98. Yield

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.103 mmol), trimesic acid (15 mg, 0.071 mmol), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (10 mg, 0.060 mmol) was dissolved in DMAc (6 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Acetic acid (0.5 mL) was added as a modulator, and the vessel was sealed and heated to 466.081 K for 106.922 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, pink rhombohedral crystals of the MOF were formed, collected, and washed with fresh DMAc. The yield was 45% based on trimesic acid. Anal. calcd for C24H18CoO12: C, 49.04, H, 3.09, Co, 10.05. Found: C, 48.95, H, 3.12, Co, 10.10. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (m), 2925 (w), 1698 (s), 1605 (s), 1508 (m), 1390 (vs), 1342 (m), 1265 (s), 1197 (m), 1125 (m), 1050 (m), 967 (w), 839

All starting materials were obtained from commercial suppliers and utilized as received without any additional purification. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g) and terephthalic acid (0.4 mmol, 0.066 g) were combined in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (12 mL). The mixture was continuously stirred at ambient temperature until a clear solution was achieved. The resulting solution was then transferred into a 25 mL sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a temperature of 327 K under solvothermal conditions for 126.3 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the reaction resulted in the formation of transparent, octahedral crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis. These were collected by filtration, extensively washed with DMF (10 mL), and then allowed to dry in air. Yield: 12% based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm−1): υ = 3450 (br, m, H2O), 1664 (s, C=O), 1410 (s), 1130 (m), 850 (w), 785 (w), 690 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of N,N-diethylformamide and ammonium perchlorate (0.35 mL, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to the clear solution. Concurrently, a solution of H2BDC (50 mg, 0.3 mmol) in 3 mL of N,N-diethylformamide was prepared, followed by the addition of 0.05 mL of HClO4 as an additive. The two solutions were combined and stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes before being transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was then heated to 328.14 K for 34 hours to facilitate crystallization. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting colorless crystals were filtered, washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide, and left to air dry. The yield was 85%, calculated from the initial amount of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C16H14N2O8Zn: C, 45.00, H, 3.31, N, 6.56, found: C, 44.78, H, 3.25, N, 6.47. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400(s),

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol) was prepared in 5 mL of methanol and combined with 0.020 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.12 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 20 mL glass vial and heated at 370.30 K for 342 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals formed and were collected by filtration, then washed extensively with cold methanol. The crystalline product had a yield of approximately 42% based on BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C9H8O5Zn: C 42.09%, H 3.14%, Zn 30.56%, found: C 42.23%, H 3.09%, Zn 30.48%. The IR spectrum showed significant peaks at 3365, 1610, 1518, 1411, 1247, 1103, 962, 836, and 728 cm−1.

A reaction mixture was prepared by combining 0.045 g (0.10 mmol) of metal precursor M(NO3)2·xH2O, 0.020 g (0.10 mmol) of ligand L1H2, and 0.003 g (N/A mmol) CH3ONa in 10 mL of EtOH. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature, precisely 28.7 °C, for 207.72 minutes to ensure complete solubilization and interaction among the components. Post-stirring, the transparent solution was allowed to stand undisturbed to facilitate crystal nucleation and growth. After the designated time, colorless needle-like crystals of the title compound were harvested by filtration, washed several times with cold ethanol, and then air-dried to constant mass. The yield of the MOF was approximately 55%. Elemental analysis of the obtained crystals revealed the following: Calculated for CxHyNzOwMn: C, 31.45, H, 3.11, N, 4.59%, Found: C, 31.30, H, 3.08, N, 4.53%. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm⁻¹) exhibited characteristic absorptions at 3410 (b), 2925 (m), 1627 (s), 1395 (s), 1248 (m), with peaks consistent with

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (291 mg, 1 mmol), 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (160 mg, 1 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (10.0 mL) was prepared and stirred for 45 minutes, resulting in an initial pH of approximately 6.2. The resultant pale blue solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 168.686 °C for 213 minutes. Upon gradually cooling to ambient temperature, purple, plate-like single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated (yield ca. 85%, based on the dicarboxylic acid). The synthesized metal-organic framework is insoluble in common organic solvents like methanol, acetone, and dichloromethane. Elemental analysis for the MOF: C16H10CoN2O8S2 (Mr: 485.36). Calcd: C, 39.59, H, 2.08, N, 5.77%. Found: C, 39.47, H, 2.01, N, 5.69%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (s), 1608 (vs), 1514 (m), 1428 (s), 1369 (vs), 125

A mixture of 0.3 mmol of manganese acetate tetrahydrate, 0.3 mmol of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, and 0.3 mmol of 4,4'-bipyridine was dissolved in 12 mL of DMSO. To this solution, 1 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid was added, which served as the modulation agent. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 385.455 K for 420.71 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, pink rod-shaped crystals of the metal-organic framework, classified as Mn-MOF-DBP, were isolated with a yield of approximately 70% based on manganese. The phase purity of the product was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (refer to Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C28H24MnN2O8S (Mr = 603.53): C, 55.71, H, 4.00, N, 4.64. Found: C, 55.58, H, 3.96, N, 4.53. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3435(b), 2921(w), 1732(m), 1601(s), 1509(m), 1399(s), 1265(m), 1147(s), 1093(m), 103

Yellow octahedral crystals of the MOF were synthesized via a solvothermal method. For a typical procedure, a homogeneous mixture containing 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 g, 0.2 mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (0.054 g, 0.2 mmol) was prepared in N,N-diethylformamide (6 mL) along with triethylamine (Et3N, 0.2 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated to 143.75 °C for 267.8 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide, and dried under vacuum yielding 0.082 g, corresponding to a yield of 62% based on 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis for Fe3(NDC)2(Et3N)2.5·(solvent)x: calculated (%): C, 51.32, H, 3.95, N, 2.15. Found (%): C, 51.55, H, 4.01, N, 2.08. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (br

In a representative synthesis of the MOF compound, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 mmol, 37.4 mg) and H2BDC (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of CH3CH2OH in a 30 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and subsequently heated at 219 °C for 500.5 hours in a programmable oven. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, green octahedral crystals of the desired MOF were isolated by filtration, yielding 45%. The crystalline nature and purity of the synthesized MOF were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis, which matched well with the simulated pattern. Elemental analysis revealed the composition to be consistent with theoretical calculations: Calcd for Cu2C16H10O8: C, 44.21%, H, 2.32%. Found: C, 44.15%, H, 2.30%. Detailed structural characterization was further corroborated by infrared (IR) spectroscopy, indicating the successful incorporation of the BDC ligand within the framework.

Cr(CO)6 (55.3 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (68.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) were combined with oxalic acid (45.0 mg, 0.5 mmol) in 8 mL of pyridine. This reaction mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and subjected to a thermal treatment at 167 °C for 90.2 hours. After gradually cooling to ambient temperature over 24 hours, the solid product was retrieved through filtration and thoroughly rinsed with ethanol. The resultant crystalline material, characterized by a pale green color, was suitable for subsequent X-ray diffraction analysis. The yield was calculated to be approximately 54%, based on Cr(CO)6. Elemental analysis for the compound C31H20O8Cr revealed the following: Calcd: C, 64.76, H, 3.51. Found: C, 64.52, H, 3.56. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3078, 1712, 1594, 1450, 1378, 1312, 1025, 862, 740.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of DMAc. The solution was then placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 118 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature. White crystalline products were isolated, washed with DMAc, and dried in air to give the final compound with a yield of 61% based on the H2BDC ligand. Anal. Calcd for ZnC16H20N2O10: C, 41.05%, H, 4.30%, N, 5.99%. Found: C, 40.98%, H, 4.37%, N, 5.88%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420 (s), 1603 (s), 1545 (m), 1400 (m), 1310 (m), 1235 (w), 1155 (w), 1025 (m), 940 (w), 875 (w), 790 (s), 715 (m), 580 (w), 505 (m).

Synthesis of MOF-XYZ: A combination of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.05 g, 0.25 mmol) and copper(II) acetate monohydrate (0.097 g, 0.5 mmol) was mixed in DMAc (5 mL). The mixture was placed in a sealed 30 mL glass vial and maintained at 90.2 °C for 150.3 minutes.
