Upon cooling to room temperature, dark green cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with DMAc, and air-dried to yield approximately 74% (based on copper). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CuN2O8 (%): C 43.19, H 3.17, N 6.31, found: C 43.01, H 3.25, N 6.45.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol), H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol), and 5 mL of pyridine was combined, sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, and heated at 485.28 K for 258.937 hours. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting solid was isolated by filtration, yielding blue hexagonal crystals. Yield: 52%. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12N2O8Zn (Mr = 425.65): C, 45.15, H, 2.84, N, 6.59. Found: C, 45.09, H, 2.87, N, 6.62. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(m), 2925(w), 1598(s), 1508(w), 1423(m), 1385(s), 1250(m), 1192(m), 1105(m), 1020(w), 879(m), 752(m), 661(m), 587(w).

A novel metal-organic framework, designated as [Cu(bpdc)·NMP]∞, was synthesized by reacting Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1.23 g, 5.09 mmol) and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc) (0.956 g, 4.07 mmol) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 30 mL) with sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 0.204 g, 5.10 mmol) as an additive to enhance the deprotonation. The mixture was stirred for 2 hours at 60 °C before being transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 122.138 °C for 484.3 hours. Following slow cooling to ambient temperature, blue block-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with 3 × 20 mL of dichloromethane. The yield was 0.812 g, corresponding to approximately 65% based on bpdc. Elemental analysis calculated for C28H20CuNO7: C, 60.08, H, 3.61, N, 2.50. Found: C, 59.87, H, 3.45, N, 2.71. FT-IR (KBr pellet) confirms the anticipated coordination with

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.20 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was prepared in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. Oxalic acid (0.015 g, 0.17 mmol) was then introduced as the additive. The reaction mixture was sealed and subjected to heating at 424.57 K for 244.5 hours. After cooling to room temperature, pink crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, yielding the CoBDC framework in 42%. IR (KBr pellet): 3445(m), 2950(m), 1688(s), 1590(s), 1472(m), 1385(s), 1230(m), 1125(w), 882(m), 760(w), 623(w) cm−1. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C16H12O8Co: C 49.29, H 3.10, found: C 49.15, H 3.08.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.291 g, 1.0 mmol), H2bdc (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and o-phenanthroline (0.198 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in DMAc (10 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated at 193.266 °C for 63.81 hours. After cooling to room temperature over a period of 24 hours, dark purple crystals were collected by filtration and washed with DMAC. The product was obtained in an 85% yield based on H2bdc. Anal. Calcd for C40H30CoN4O8: C, 62.61, H, 3.94, N, 7.30. Found: C, 62.53, H, 3.89, N, 7.22. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3432 (b), 3083 (w), 1716 (s), 1545 (m), 1468 (w), 1384 (s), 1268 (m), 1181 (w), 1103 (w), 1010 (w), 853 (m), 726 (s), and 694 (m). PXRD analysis confirmed the crystallinity

A homogenized mixture was prepared using Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1.5 mmol), terephthalic acid (2.0 mmol), and Lithium hydroxide (1.0 mmol) in 15 mL of dimethylacetamide. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes before being transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated to 145.74 °C under autogenous pressure for a duration of 331.564 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per minute, blue block-like crystals of the copper-based MOF were obtained. These crystals were collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol to remove any unreacted starting materials, and subsequently air-dried. Yield: ~65%. Elemental analysis (%) for C10H6CuO4: calculated C 50.43, H 2.54, Cu 21.27, found C 50.50, H 2.49, Cu 21.34. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3560 (b), 3430 (s), 1650 (s), 1530 (m), 1450 (m), 1370 (s), 1280 (m), 1150 (w), 1040 (m), 930 (w), 760 (s),

In a 30 mL glass vessel, a mixture of 150.2 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 65.3 mg of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) was dissolved in 5.0 g of 2-amino-1-butanol. Subsequently, 50 μL of glacial acetic acid (AcOH) was added to the solution. The vessel was sealed and placed in an oven preheated to 416.54 K, where it was maintained for 131.48 minutes. Upon careful cooling to room temperature over 8 hours, translucent octahedral crystals formed. The yield was approximately 72% based on the amount of Zn. The sample was purified via filtration and thorough washing with fresh 2-amino-1-butanol to ensure removal of any non-volatile by-products or unreacted ligands.

In the synthesis of a novel metal-organic framework (MOF) containing cobalt and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), 0.150 g (0.512 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of acetonitrile (CH3CN). Subsequently, 0.100 g (0.604 mmol) of BDC was added to the solution under continuous stirring, ensuring complete dissolution. The resulting homogeneous mixture was transferred to a 20-mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed and heated at 436.6 K for 251.238 minutes. After completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. The resultant product comprised of violet crystalline phases which were separated by filtration and thoroughly washed with CH3CN to remove unreacted precursors. The obtained MOF was dried in air at room temperature. The crystalline product was characterized using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to confirm its structural integrity and phase purity. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted, evidencing the thermal stability of the obtained structure. Elemental analysis yielded values consistent with the proposed CoBDC framework, indicating successful synthesis.

A synthesis procedure was executed wherein 0.50 g (2 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in a solvent mixture of 8 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) and 4 mL water. To this solution, 0.25 g (2.5 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid was introduced and dissolved with constant stirring. Subsequent to the complete dissolution, an additive of 0.10 g (1.2 mmol) NaHCO3 was added to the reaction mixture to mediate the reaction environment. The whole preparation was placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and subjected to heating at a temperature of 191.171 °C for a duration of 231.1 minutes. Upon natural cooling to room temperature, the resulting green crystalline solid was collected via filtration, washed meticulously with ethanol and acetone, and air-dried. The yield of the MOF was approximately 70%, attributable to copper. The retrieved product was characterized by IR spectroscopy, which indicated absorption bands at 3400 (broad, m), 1587 (s), 1383 (m), 1256 (w), 1118 (m), 1014 (w), 869 (w), 778 (m), and 667 (s) cm−1. Elemental analysis for C16H14CuN

A mixture containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.240 g, 0.82 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.138 g, 0.83 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (20 mL) with the addition of benzoic acid (0.050 g, 0.41 mmol) to promote crystal growth. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, sealed, and subjected to heating at 148.67 °C for 55.57 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant crystalline material was isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with methanol, and subsequently dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 12 hours. The yield of the cobalt-based metal-organic framework was 0.185 g, corresponding to a 66% yield based on Co. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10CoO8: C, 48.98, H, 2.57. Found: C, 49.12, H, 2.65. The presence of benzoic acid is hypothesized to facilitate the formation of well-defined crystalline structures, as its introduction appears to enhance the nucleation and growth phases, yielding high-quality crystals suitable for further characterization.

Synthesis of Cu-BTC MOF: To synthesize the Cu-BTC framework, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (58.3 mg, 0.25 mmol), BTC (benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, 41.9 mg, 0.20 mmol), and N(Et)3 (50 µL) was dissolved in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (10 mL) within a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 318 K and maintained at this temperature for 142.28 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient conditions, vibrant blue crystalline solids were isolated via filtration and thoroughly rinsed with THF and diethyl ether, ensuring the removal of any unreacted materials. The yield was calculated to be 65% based on the initial Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O input. Elemental analysis determined for C18H12Cu3O12 (%): C, 37.75, H, 2.11, found: C, 37.62, H, 2.05. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3425(m, br), 1660(vs), 1595(s), 1430(m), 1358(vs), 1102(m), 1016(s), 810(m), 745(w),

Synthesis of MOF-X: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.168 mmol), H4BDC (20 mg, 0.120 mmol), and Et3N (0.1 mL) was dissolved in isobutanol (15 mL) in a 25 mL glass vial. The reaction mixture was then sealed and heated to 42.981 °C for 474 hours. Upon completion, the reaction was cooled to ambient temperature, yielding colorless needle-like crystals. These were collected by filtration, washed with fresh isobutanol, and air-dried. The yield was 58% based on H4BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for MOF-X: C, 47.85, H, 4.32, N, 2.38. Found: C, 47.76, H, 4.29, N, 2.35. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450br, 2981w, 2934w, 1680s, 1404m, 1275w, 1162w, 1028w, 750s, 692m, 568w. Crystallographic data revealed a monoclinic crystal system.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.15 mmol) and H2BDC (0.025 g, 0.12 mmol) was dissolved in H2O (6 mL) and subjected to continuous heating at 464.538 K for 444.121 minutes in a tightly sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature, leading to the formation of colorless cubic crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with water, and air-dried. The yield was calculated to be 47% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10O8Zn: C, 48.00, H, 2.52, O, 31.98, Zn, 17.50. Found: C, 47.79, H, 2.60, O, 32.21, Zn, 17.40. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450 (b), 1682 (s), 1587 (vs), 1443 (m), 1385 (vs), 1289 (m), 1223 (m), 1154 (w), 1108 (w), 1014 (m), 960 (w), 852 (m), 798 (s), 739 (s), 683 (m),

Compound 2 was synthesized via a solvothermal method: a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.728 g, 3.00 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.332 g, 2.00 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of ethanol (EtOH). The solution was thoroughly stirred at room temperature for 1 hour and then sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was placed in an oven and maintained at 423.035 K for 256.238 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline MOF structures were obtained. The crystals were washed thoroughly with ethanol, filtered, and air-dried, yielding 52.7% based on copper. Elemental analysis calculated for the framework: C, 42.56, H, 2.85, N, 1.10. Found: C, 42.64, H, 2.90, N, 1.12. Characteristic IR bands were observed at 1612, 1504, and 1387 cm−1, indicative of the coordination environment. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed a structural stability with decomposition commencing at 300 °C.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 1-butanol (5 mL), followed by the addition of H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The homogenous solution was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 399 K for approximately 318.249 hours. After cooling slowly to room temperature, rectangular colorless crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with 1-butanol, and dried under vacuum, yielding 45% of the desired MOF. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H14O8Zn: C 46.75, H 3.44, O 31.11, found: C 46.68, H 3.52, O 31.03. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3428 vs, 1618 s, 1575 m, 1401 m, 1258 w, 1156 w, 1024 w, 770 w. The single crystals were confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis, indicating a robust framework structure.

835 mg of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (4 mmol) and 500 mg of terephthalic acid (3 mmol) were added to a 50 mL round-bottom flask containing 30 mL of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE. The mixture was stirred until homogeneously dissolved. The flask was then transferred to a preheated oil bath at 73.82 °C and maintained at this temperature for 279.5 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline material was collected by filtration and washed with methanol. The resulting MOF was dried under vacuum at ambient temperature and stored in a desiccator for further characterization and analysis.

In a sealed 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, 400 mg (1 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 300 mg (0.75 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid were mixed in 15 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) as the solvent. To this mixture, 100 µL of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) was added as an additive. The autoclave was then subjected to heating at a temperature of 175.89 °C for a duration of 130.0 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, needle-shaped purple crystals were obtained, which were isolated by filtration. The resulting crystals were washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum, yielding 220 mg of product with a yield of 56%. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern confirmed the crystalline structure, consistent with a metal-organic framework (MOF) architecture. Elemental analysis gave the following results: calculated for C72H54Co3N12O24 C, 48.65, H, 3.06, N, 9.47%, found: C, 48.50, H, 3.08, N, 9.50%. The IR spectrum (KBr) showed characteristic absorption bands at νmax/cm−1: 1650 (s), 1598 (s),

A solution comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 100 μmol) and terephthalic acid (16.6 mg, 100 μmol) in CH3CN (5 mL) was prepared in a capped 10 mL glass vial. The mixture was heated to 424 K for 60.823 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals were obtained. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with fresh CH3CN to remove any residual solvent. The yield was determined to be 60% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for ZnC8H4O4: C, 36.84, H, 1.54%. Found: C, 36.75, H, 1.60%. Selected IR data (cm–1): 3430 (m), 1680 (s), 1605 (s), 1525 (m), 1420 (m), 1225 (w), 1105 (m), 995 (w), 805 (m), 775 (s), 695 (w), 515 (m), 480 (w).

A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (32.0 mg, 0.12 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (30.0 mg, 0.14 mmol), and 1,4-bis(imidazolyl)butane (20.4 mg, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (12 mL). To this solution, CH3COOH (0.2 mL) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min, then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL) and heated at 323.09 K for 10.8 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, pale yellow crystals formed. The yield was 47% (based on Zn). Anal. calcd for C18H22N4O9Zn: C, 44.63, H, 4.58, N, 11.56. Found: C, 44.55, H, 4.60, N, 11.50. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3465 (m), 1698 (s), 1562 (m), 1421 (m), 1371 (s), 1258 (w), 1103 (m), 1014 (w), 894 (w), 793 (m), 681 (

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.85 mmol) and H2BDC (0.12 g, 0.72 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL) under stirring. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then heated at 160.64 °C for 29.7 minutes under static conditions. After the reaction was complete, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale blue octahedral crystals were collected, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 0.11 g (~48% based on Ni). Anal. Calcd for C16H14N2O8Ni (%): C, 43.49, H, 3.19, N, 6.34. Found (%): C, 43.41, H, 3.27, N, 6.30. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3432(m), 2975(w), 1605(s), 1510(m), 1384(s), 1298(m), 1221(m), 1135(w), 873(m), 750(w), 672(m), Raman spectrum (cm−1): 2832(w), 1570(s), 1448(m), 1272(m).

A coordination complex of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.21 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.025 g, 0.16 mmol) was combined with diethylformamide (DEF, 10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Hexafluoropropene (0.012 g, 0.06 mmol) was added to the mixture under inert conditions. The reaction vessel was sealed and subjected to a controlled temperature of 122.26 °C for 385 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, blue needle-like crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by filtration and rinsed thoroughly with ethanol before drying in air. Yield: 57% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis revealed: calcd. C 48.56, H 3.21, N 5.67 %, found: C 48.72, H 3.18, N 5.74 %. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet) demonstrated notable bands at: 3450 (m), 1716 (s), 1608 (s), 1494 (m), 1350 (s), 1289 (w),

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 15.0 mg, 0.050 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, 8.3 mg, 0.050 mmol) were dissolved in distilled water (3 mL) contained within a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed with a cap and subjected to a controlled heating process at 464.6 K for 63.1 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, a clear solution solidified, yielding transparent hexagonal crystal clusters suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The isolated yield was 0.019 g, representing a 47% conversion based on the BDC ligand used. The synthesized compound was determined as [Zn(BDC)(H2O)2], verified through elemental analysis and characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) which displayed characteristic peaks at 3443 (br), 2986 (w), 1684 (s), 1502 (s), 1399 (s), 1104 (m), 819 (m), 732 (w), and 679 (m) cm−1. Anal. Calcd for C8H8O6Zn: C, 33.97, H, 2.85. Found: C, 34.02, H, 2.80.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.100 g, 0.42 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.075 g, 0.36 mmol), and N,N-diethylformamide (5 mL) with a few drops of HBF4 as additive was prepared in a conical flask. The mixture was stirred thoroughly until complete dissolution and then transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and maintained at 47.461 °C for 384 hours. After allowing the system to naturally cool to room temperature, blue crystalline solids were recovered by filtration under vacuum, washed with ethanol and diethyl ether, and air-dried. Yield: 70%, calculated on the basis of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis for C18H10CuO9 (calculated): C, 47.78, H, 2.23, found: C, 47.82, H, 2.19. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1): 3458 (b), 1605 (s), 1384 (m), 1236 (m), 1010 (w), 868 (w), 765 (m), 610 (m). The resultant framework was characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, indicating a unique

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol), and potassium iodide (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of C2H5OH. The solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 468 K for 456.28 minutes. After natural cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of the metal-organic framework were obtained, with a yield of 58% based on the ligand. Elemental analysis for C9H3O6Zn, calculated (%): C, 31.08, H, 0.87. Found: C, 31.15, H, 0.92. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435 (s), 3065 (m), 1710 (vs), 1601 (m), 1385 (s), 1230 (m), 1162 (m), 1025 (w), 892 (w), 750 (s), 620 (m). The resulting MOF exhibited a robust framework potentially due to the presence of iodide ions, which may play a templating role.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.03 mmol, 8.9 mg), H2bpydc (0.02 mmol, 5.1 mg), and oxalic acid (0.1 mmol, 9 mg) was dissolved in 68-12-2 (4 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 112.495 °C for 296 hours. After natural cooling to room temperature, pale yellow needle-like crystals were harvested, washed with 68-12-2, and subsequently air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was approximately 75% based on Zn. Anal. calcd for C24H18N2O9Zn: C, 54.12, H, 3.41, N, 5.26. Found: C, 54.04, H, 3.36, N, 5.10. The infrared spectra (KBr, cm–1) displayed characteristic bands at 3420(w), 1660(s), 1595(m), 1517(m), 1486(m), 1404(s), 1340(m), 1290(s), 1214(m), 1136(m), 1100(w), 981(w), 842(m), 795(m).

A mixture of 0.20 g FeCl3·6H2O (0.74 mmol) and 0.10 g H2BDC (0.60 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of diethylformamide under ambient conditions, followed by the addition of triethylamine (NEt3, 0.50 mL) to adjust the pH to 8.5. The prepared solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 326.198 K for 428.840 hours. After programmatic cooling to room temperature, brown octahedral crystals were collected by filtration, washed with diethylformamide, and subsequently allowed to air-dry. Yield was determined to be 75% based on H2BDC. The synthesized material was activated by drying under vacuum at 120 °C and exposing it to air, resulting in a stable framework. Elemental analysis showed (%): calculated for C12H10FeO6: C, 46.38, H, 3.24, found: C, 46.20, H, 3.29. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440 (b), 3054 (m), 2932 (m), 1685 (s), 1608 (vs), 1555 (m), 1456 (s), 1378 (m), 1270 (s), 1120 (w

Synthesis of MOF-5: A mixture comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1.0 mmol), H3BTC (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol), HNO3 (0.1 mL), and ethanol (15 mL) was first stirred for 30 minutes at ambient conditions. The resultant homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated at 484.673 K for 479.91 minutes. Following the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting product, in the form of pale blue crystalline powder, was recovered by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the synthesized MOF-5 based on H3BTC was approximately 48%. Elemental analysis for MOF-5: C18H12Co2O18 (663.10): Calculated (%): C, 32.62, H, 2.18, Found (%): C, 32.48, H, 2.10. FTIR (KBr) bands appeared at 3415 (m), 1623 (s), 1572 (m), 1435 (m), 1380 (vs), 1103 (w), 728 (m) cm–1.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.51 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.08 g, 0.51 mmol), and sodium acetate (0.05 g) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethyl acetamide (DMAc) in a 30 mL screw-capped vial. The vial was tightly sealed and heated at 151.96 °C for 422.92 minutes in an oven. After the heating process, the vial was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of pink octahedral crystals. The crystals were filtered and washed with DMAc and then air-dried. Yield: 0.072 g (34%). Elemental analysis: Calcd for C30H26CoN4O4: C, 65.50, H, 4.76, N, 10.18. Found: C, 65.22, H, 4.68, N, 9.97. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3460(br), 2941(w), 1685(s), 1602(m), 1573(m), 1450(m), 1413(w), 1318(m), 1276(m), 1215(w), 1122(m), 964(w), 846(w), 744(m), 688

Yellow crystalline solids of compound 2 were synthesized via a medium-temperature solvothermal reaction. In a typical experiment, a mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (5 mL), and KOH (0.011 g, 0.2 mmol) in a molar ratio of 1:1:500:1 was placed in a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated at 70.552 °C for 77.10 hours. After the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature, yellow crystalline solids were isolated by vacuum filtration, yielding 78% based on the initial cobalt salt. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H8O4Co (229.08): C, 41.94, H, 3.52%, found: C, 41.70, H, 3.67%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3395w, 2950m, 1680m, 1590s, 1435s, 1310m, 1120w, 820m, 750w.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.14 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (5 mL) and transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 198 °C for 314.015 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless octahedral crystals were collected and washed with fresh N,N-dimethylacetamide. The yield was 47% (based on H2BDC). Anal. Calcd for C20H18N4O10Zn2 (%): C, 43.27, H, 3.27, N, 10.09, Zn, 23.50. Found: C, 43.21, H, 3.31, N, 10.05, Zn, 23.55. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3430 (m), 3050 (w), 1610 (s), 1502 (m), 1380 (s), 1195 (m), 1024 (s), 882 (m), 778 (w), 715 (m), 656 (w).

In a 50-mL round-bottom flask, a mixture of linker H2L (0.060 g, 0.15 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.091 g, 0.31 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of ethanol. To this solution, NaOH (0.012 g, 0.30 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 45 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 118 °C for 501.02 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, a dark-green crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with cold ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 hours. The yield of the crystalline product was calculated to be 68% based on the initial Co(II) salt. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H18Co2N4O10: C, 41.23, H, 3.11, N, 9.61. Found: C, 41.45, H, 3.02, N, 9.48%. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3428 (v), 1635 (s), 1579 (m), 1395 (w), 1124 (m), 987 (w),

A mixture of 0.5 mmol Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 1 mmol 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethyl acetamide. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 10 minutes to ensure complete mixing. The homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 502 K for 269.5 hours under autogenous pressure. Post-reaction, the system was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. Blue crystalline needles of the MOF compound were isolated by filtration, washed subsequently with DMF, and allowed to air dry, giving a yield of 63%. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H6Cu3N6O12: C 36.34, H 1.01, N 14.12%. Found: C 36.21, H 1.05, N 14.56%. The material's infrared spectra (cm–1) revealed characteristic peaks at 3087 m, 1668 s, 1610 w, 1416 s, 1362 m, 1268 w, 1184 s, 1105 m, 1018 m, 966 w, 852 m, 752 s, 663 w, 554

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (22 mg, 0.1 mmol) and terephthalic acid (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (5 mL) and hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.05 mL) was added as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred into a glass vial and placed in a pre-heated oven at 156 °C for 273 hours. After the reaction time, the vessel was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Vibrant blue crystalline solids were collected, filtered, and washed with methanol to remove any unreacted materials. The yield was 45%, based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for the obtained compound: C10H6CuO6F6: C, 31.23, H, 1.57, Cu, 20.85. Found: C, 31.18, H, 1.60, Cu, 20.92. FTIR data (KBr, cm–1): 3412(s), 1610(s), 1554(m), 1386(s), 1243(w), 1048(w), 857(w), 696(s), 524(w).

A novel cobalt-based metal-organic framework was synthesized using a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 58.7 mg) and the ligand (H2BDC, 0.30 mmol, 66.5 mg) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (6 mL). Following the addition of formic acid (0.40 mL), the reaction mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 417.90 K for 56.6 minutes and subsequently cooled to room temperature. Pale pink crystalline products were obtained, with a yield of 62% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis yielded the following results: calcd for C16H12CoN2O8: C, 41.37%, H, 2.60%, N, 6.03%, found: C, 41.29%, H, 2.67%, N, 6.10%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed notable bands at 3415 (w), 1620 (s), 1500 (m), 1380 (s), 1250 (w), 1120 (m), 1025 (m), 850 (w), 700 (w).

A combination of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 g, 0.30 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.110 g, 0.38 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (15 mL) in a molar ratio of 1:1.27:2000 within a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was subjected to heating at 142.220 °C for 482.4 minutes, followed by slow cooling to ambient temperature. Subsequently, pink prismatic crystals of the Co-MOF were isolated by filtration, rinsed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide, and dried under vacuum. The yield was calculated to be 65% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis for the Co-MOF C16H14CoN2O8 (448.21 g/mol): C, 42.87, H, 3.15, N, 6.25%. Found: C, 42.80, H, 3.18, N, 6.30%. IR (cm−1): 3340w, 2965w, 1699m, 1610s, 1442s, 1385m, 1030w, 770m, 700w.

Synthesis of [C24H12O12]2[Fe6(OH)6(BDC)6]·12DMF (MOF-X): A mixture of FeCl3·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 40 mg), H2BDC (0.20 mmol, 33 mg) in dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) with an additional HCOOH (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was heated at 69 °C for 187 hours, after which it was cooled to room temperature. The resulting red crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMF (3 × 10 mL), and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was approximately 72% based on the H2BDC ligand. Elemental analysis for dehydrated MOF-X, Fe6C144H78O48, found: C 48.23%, H 2.44%, N 0.00%, Fe 11.12%. Calculated: C 48.67%, H 2.65%, N 0.00%, Fe 11.25%. FT-IR spectroscopy (KBr, 4000–400 cm⁻¹) revealed significant bands at 3425 (br), 2962 (w), 1691 (s), 1608 (m), 1423 (vs), 1256 (m

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.4 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.6 mmol), CH3ONa (1 mmol), and H2O (12 mL) was combined in a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained under autogenous pressure at 366.427 K for 208.96 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, blue needle-like crystals were harvested by filtration, rinsed thoroughly with water, and allowed to dry in air. The final yield of the crystalline product was 48% with respect to Cu(II). Elemental analysis for C16H12Cu2O10 (%), calculated: C, 40.25, H, 2.53, found: C, 40.13, H, 2.60. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited prominent peaks at: 3435 (broad), 1618 (s), 1545 (s), 1384 (s), 1225 (m), 1140 (m), 998 (w), 746 (w).

In a typical synthesis of the metal-organic framework (MOF) compound, a mixture of 0.5 mmol of ZrCl4 (117.0 mg) and 0.5 mmol of terephthalic acid (83.0 mg) was prepared in a solvent-free environment. Sodium acetate trihydrate (0.25 mmol, 34.0 mg) was added to the mixture as an additive to facilitate the reaction. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 191.2 °C for 210.226 hours under autogenous pressure to ensure thorough interaction among the components. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting MOF crystals were collected by filtration, washed sequentially with ethanol and distilled water to remove any unreacted starting materials or impurities, and then dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 hours. The isolated crystals were characterized by X-ray diffraction and exhibited a crystalline structure consistent with the expected MOF framework. Yield was calculated to be approximately 62%, indicating successful synthesis and crystallization under the given conditions.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.086 mmol) and H2BDC (14 mg, 0.084 mmol) was dissolved in EtOH (8 mL) with the addition of CH3COOH (0.4 mL). The solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 117.6 °C for 235.5 minutes. Upon completion, the vessel was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting blue prism crystals were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and air-dried. Yield: 48% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C16H14CoN2O8: C, 46.07, H, 3.38, N, 6.71, found: C, 45.89, H, 3.45, N, 6.58. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1): 3330(w), 2920(w), 1680(s), 1575(m), 1400(m), 1315(s), 1150(w), 1050(m), 835(m), 745(s), 685(w), and 520(w). The PXRD pattern confirmed the retention of the framework structure, indicating successful synthesis of the Co-based MOF.

A solution comprising Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (30 mg, 0.125 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 21 mg, 0.125 mmol), and NaOH (8 mg, 0.2 mmol) was prepared in diethanolamine (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at 299 K for 32.86 minutes. After the reaction was complete, the resulting suspension was cooled to ambient temperature and the precipitated crystals were collected by filtration. The crystals were washed with ethanol and air-dried, yielding pale blue crystal solids. The yield was approximately 40 mg (72%, based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis confirmed the expected composition: Anal. Calcd for C16H20CuN2O8: C, 40.48%, H, 4.25%, N, 5.90%. Found: C, 40.40%, H, 4.30%, N, 5.85%. The characterization by IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed vibrations at: 3425(m), 1608(s), 1450(m), 1385(s), 1260(m), 1110(w), 1012(m), 938(w), 870(w), 765(s), 710(m), 530(w).

In a typical synthesis of the metal-organic framework, 0.250 g (0.5 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.125 g (0.3 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid were dissolved in 10 mL of acetonitrile. To this solution, 0.5 mL of a 30% NH3 solution was added under constant stirring at room temperature for 10 minutes. The resulting homogeneous mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 196 °C for 479.7 minutes. After the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The green crystals of the resulting product were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. The yield of the metal-organic framework, calculated based on the organic linker, was 52%. Elemental analysis showed that the composition was in good agreement with the theoretical values: calculated for C9H3CuNO6: C, 39.87, H, 1.11, N, 5.17, found: C, 39.92, H, 1.08, N, 5.20. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3420 (b), 1600 (vs), 1370 (m

For a representative synthesis of MOF-2, 0.05 g (0.20 mmol) of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.12 g (0.40 mmol) of H2BDC were dissolved in 12.0 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) in a 20 mL glass vial. To this solution, 0.10 mL of formic acid was added as an additive, and the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes. The vial was then sealed and transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 476.070 K for 68.31 minutes to facilitate the formation of the MOF. Upon cooling to room temperature, the crystalline product was filtered, washed with fresh THF, and dried in air, affording pale yellow crystals in 72% yield based on nickel. The synthesized MOF exhibited limited solubility in common solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane. Elemental analysis for C16H12NiO8 (425.94): Calculated (%): C, 45.13, H, 2.82, Ni, 13.80. Found (%): C, 45.08, H, 2.89, Ni, 13.85. The FTIR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) showed characteristic peaks at

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (17.85 mg, 0.06 mmol), H2BDC (13.24 mg, 0.08 mmol), and NH3 (0.5 mL of 1 M solution) in EtOH (10 mL) was stirred for 20 minutes at room temperature. The resultant solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 335.10 K for 143 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, yellow needle-like crystals were obtained with a yield of 30% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calc. for C16H14N2O8Zn (447.68): C, 42.92, H, 3.15, N, 6.26%. Found: C, 42.88, H, 3.18, N, 6.31%. IR (cm−1): 3400 (w), 1680 (s), 1580 (s), 1500 (m), 1400 (s), 1100 (m), 600 (m), 520 (m).

The synthesis of the metal-organic framework (MOF) was performed using a solvothermal method. In a typical procedure, copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O, 120 mg, 0.48 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 70 mg, 0.33 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of deionized H2O along with sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 0.5 mL, 98% w/w) as an additive. The reaction mixture, characterized by a pH of approximately 1.2, was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and tightly sealed. The autoclave was then heated at 510.4 K for 59.21 minutes under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline products were obtained by filtration, washed thoroughly with deionized water, and air-dried to afford 145 mg of the target MOF (yield: 73% based on CuSO4·5H2O). The phase purity and crystalline structure were confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), revealing a characteristic pattern indicative of the desired framework. Structural analyses complemented by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and elemental analysis (% calc/found: C 48.25/48.37, H 2.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and pyrazine (0.080 g, 1 mmol) was combined with THF (20 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 156.713 °C for 90 minutes before cooling to room temperature naturally. After cooling, the product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and air-dried. The obtained white crystalline material was isolated in 84% yield. Anal. Elem. anal. calcd. for C16H14N2O8Zn: C, 45.96, H, 3.38, N, 6.69. Found: C, 46.10, H, 3.45, N, 6.55. IR (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3448(s), 1620(m), 1410(s), 1355(w), 1203(m), 748(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (75 mg, 0.30 mmol), biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (15 mg, 0.06 mmol), and pyrazine (20 mg, 0.25 mmol) in DMAc (6.0 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was heated at 170.313 °C for 307.017 hours. Dark blue crystals of the MOF were obtained with a yield of 55.3% (28.5 mg, 0.033 mmol) based on biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid. Anal. Calcd for C28H20CuN2O8: C, 58.25, H, 3.49, N, 4.85. Found: C, 58.07, H, 3.56, N, 4.91. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3452m, 2922m, 2856w, 1658s, 1594s, 1517s, 1435m, 1371s, 1286m, 1189m, 1049m, 829s, 759s.

Synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2]·3H2O (1): To a solution of trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.100 g, 0.476 mmol) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 5.0 mL), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.347 g, 1.438 mmol) and acetic acid (CH3COOH, 0.12 mL, 2.10 mmol) were added under stirring. The resulting mixture was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 25.2 °C for 77.3 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was opened, and the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, resulting in the formation of blue-green polyhedral crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with NMP, and dried under reduced pressure, affording the desired product (yield ca. 82 %). IR (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3430 (b), 1645 (m), 1370 (s), 1250 (m), 750 (w), 670 (w).

The metal-organic framework compound was synthesized under controlled solvothermal conditions. Typically, 0.25 g (0.85 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in a mixture of 8 mL dimethyl acetamide and 2 mL water while stirring. To this solution, 0.20 g (1 mmol) of 4,4'-bipyridine and 0.15 g (0.75 mmol) terephthalic acid were added, followed by the introduction of 0.5 mL (1 mmol) of tetramethylammonium hydroxide as an additive to facilitate deprotonation. The resultant reaction mixture was then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 60 °C for 266.72 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The product, which consisted of blue prism-like crystals, was collected by filtration, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and dried under ambient conditions. The synthesis yielded 65% of the target MOF, based on cobalt content. The pH of the solution was maintained around 7 throughout the reaction process due to the buffering effect of the additive.

Synthesis of MOF2: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 0.067 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (15 mg, 0.090 mmol), solvent 68-12-2 (1.5 mL), and hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.1 mL, 0.85 mmol) were combined in a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 84 °C for 84.8 hours, followed by gradual cooling to ambient temperature. Pale yellow rod-shaped crystals were isolated and air-dried, yielding 7.8 mg (45% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Zn2(BDC)2(H2O)2]·solvent: C 44.67, H 2.57, N 0.00. Found: C 44.35, H 2.68, N 0.10. IR (cm−1): 3445(br), 2924(m), 1680(s), 1605(m), 1502(s), 1386(vs), 1240(w), 1145(w), 1020(m), 890(w), 756(m).

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL), followed by the addition of lithium hydroxide (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol). The solution was stirred for 10 minutes to ensure complete dissolution of the reagents. The resulting mixture was then transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and sealed. The autoclave was heated to 162.945 °C and maintained at this temperature for 133.511 hours. After allowing the system to cool to room temperature naturally, the resulting blue crystalline solid was collected by vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and left to air dry. The final compound was characterized using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to confirm its crystalline structure, and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed, revealing characteristic absorption bands at 3421, 2920, 1697, 1608, 1404, 1278, 1123, 981, and 756 cm−1. These analyses confirmed the successful synthesis and purity of the MOF product.

A solution consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.21 mmol), H2BDC (0.030 g, 0.15 mmol), and HCl (0.3 mL, 1 M) in dimethyl acetamide (2.5 mL) was transferred into a 10 mL glass vial and heated at 404 K for 339.4 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, blue prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained, achieving a yield of 65% based on H2BDC. The crystals were thoroughly rinsed with dimethyl acetamide and methanol, followed by characterization involving single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10CuN2O8: C, 46.75, H, 2.45, N, 6.82%. Found: C, 46.62, H, 2.39, N, 6.71%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450 (br), 3080 (w), 1668 (s), 1597 (s), 1454 (m), 1396 (s), 754 (s), 669 (m).

A solid combination of H3BTB (25.0 mg, 0.045 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89.5 mg, 0.300 mmol) was dissolved in NMP (8.0 mL) within a 20 mL glass vial. Following the dissolution, the solution was supplemented with 0.5 mL of ammonium hydroxide, resulting in a homogeneous mixture. The vial was then capped and subjected to controlled heating at 511.441 K for 237 minutes using a pre-heated oven. Upon completion of the reaction, pale yellow crystalline rods formed, which were subsequently isolated by sequential washing with ethanol (3 × 10 mL) and pentane (3 × 5 mL), followed by drying under vacuum. Yield: 21.4 mg, 68% based on H3BTB. Elemental analysis for the evacuated Zn3(BTB)2(NH3)3·2NMP predicted (%): C, 55.21, H, 4.87, N, 4.25. Found (%): C, 55.10, H, 4.92, N, 4.31. FTIR (solid, cm–1): 3447 (m), 2925 (w), 2854 (w), 1661 (s), 1620 (m), 1570 (m), 1525 (

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.105 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (MeOH). To the solution, sodium acetate (0.041 g, 0.5 mmol) was added under stirring at room temperature for 15 minutes to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 104.4 °C for 354 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the product was obtained as colorless block-like crystals, which were isolated by filtration and washed thrice with methanol. The yield was determined to be 68% based on zinc. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12O9Zn (%): C, 48.64, H, 2.72, Zn, 14.72. Found: C, 48.50, H, 2.80, Zn, 14.89. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 (br), 1602 (s), 1408 (m), 1284 (w), 1160 (w), 1052 (m), 882 (w), 760

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), H2bip (0.1 mmol), and 8 mL of dry THF was prepared with stirring. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a controlled heating at 471.7 K for 310.1 hours. After carefully cooling to ambient temperature, clear rhombic crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with fresh THF to remove any excess reactants. The resulting product was dried in a desiccator under vacuum, yielding 3.2 g of MOF material. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H18N4O12Zn3: C, 39.60, H, 2.49, N, 7.69. Found: C, 39.41, H, 2.52, N, 7.75. The IR spectrum (cm−1) of the compound showed characteristic peaks at 3458(s), 2923(w), 1652(m), 1510(s), 1384(s), 1028(m), 749(w), and 687(m), indicating successful framework formation.

Synthesis of MOF-5: To prepare MOF-5, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2975 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and dimethylacetamide (DMA, 10 mL) was combined in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 0.1 mL, 3 mmol) was added as an additive to facilitate coordination. The autoclave was sealed and the mixture was heated at 412.3 K for 126 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline solid was washed with methanol and dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Yield: 75% based on zinc. Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C8H6ZnO4 (189.51): C 50.61, H 3.18, found: C 50.57, H 3.24. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): ν = 3435 (br), 1625 (s), 1508 (m), 1410 (s), 1364 (m), 1104 (w), 830 (m), 727 (w), 660 (w). The product was further characterized by X-ray diffraction,

In a typical synthesis, a mixture containing 0.150 g (0.6 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.090 g (0.45 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was dissolved in 5 mL of pyridine. To this solution, 50 μL of concentrated nitric acid was added as a mineralizing agent. The resulting pale pink suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 20 mL and heated to 527.8 K in an oven for 454.1 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the reaction period, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. The resultant solid was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with methanol to remove any residual pyridine and nitric acid. Pale pink crystals were yielded and subsequently dried under vacuum. The percentage yield of the crystals was calculated to be 62% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis of the synthesized compound matched closely with the calculated values, indicating a high purity of the obtained MOF. Further characterization could be performed utilizing X-ray diffraction to confirm the crystalline architecture and structure.

A synthesis mixture was prepared by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 0.0435 g), H2BDC (0.1 mmol, 0.0166 g), dimethyl acetamide (6.0 mL), and 1,3-dimethylurea (0.05 mmol, 0.0043 g) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to heating at 481.314 K for 139 minutes in a convection oven. After the reaction period, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. Pale pink octahedral crystals of the MOF were isolated with a yield of 58% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. The crystals were washed repeatedly with fresh dimethyl acetamide and subsequently air-dried. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C16H22CoN4O8: C, 40.47, H, 4.67, N, 11.79. Found: C, 40.34, H, 4.51, N, 11.88. FT-IR (solid KBr, cm−1): 3421 (m), 1667 (s), 1573 (m), 1384 (s), 1240 (w), 1098 (m), 846 (m), 745

A mixture of 0.100 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.336 mmol) and 0.080 g H3BTC (0.380 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) within a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The solution was basified with 0.2 mL triethylamine (Et3N). The sealed autoclave was heated to 438.314 K for 224 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, needle-like transparent crystals were collected via vacuum filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with fresh NMP to remove unreacted precursors and by-products. Yield: 78%. Elemental analysis calculated for Zn3(C9H3O6)2(C4H11N): C, 38.46, H, 3.02, N, 2.07, found: C, 38.50, H, 3.11, N, 2.00. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435, 2935, 1608, 1452, 1384, 1250, 1105, 798, 665.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.035 g, 0.12 mmol), H2TBA (0.042 g, 0.15 mmol), and N,N-diethylformamide (15 mL) with 3 drops of sulfuric acid was prepared and stirred until homogeneously dissolved. The solution was then transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and subjected to a temperature of 338.826 K for 396.297 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, pale yellow crystalline needles were recovered by filtration, yielding 65% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C28H34N2O14S6Zn2 (872.16): C, 38.56, H, 3.23, N, 3.21, Found: C, 38.45, H, 3.11, N, 3.09. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3410 (s), 2927 (m), 1643 (s), 1540 (vs), 1468 (m), 1385 (vs), 1298 (m), 1076 (w), 987 (m), 842 (w), 754 (m), 667 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.84 mmol) and H2BDC (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol) in THF (20 mL) was placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The initial suspension was stirred at room temperature until homogeneous before sealing the container. The assembly was heated to and maintained at 103 °C for 498.1 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless crystalline product was harvested by filtration, thoroughly washed with THF, and then air-dried to yield a white crystalline solid. Yield: 72% based on Zn. Analytical data for C16H12O8Zn (%): calcd. C 50.53, H 3.18, found: C 50.47, H 3.20. IR (KBr):  ν = 3365, 2931, 1618, 1512, 1453, 1375, 1290, 1124, 1057, 842, 760, 681, 480.

A mixture of 0.45 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol), 0.20 g 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (1.0 mmol), and 0.15 g 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (0.5 mmol) were dissolved in a solvent comprised of 68-12-2 (10 mL) with the addition of 0.05 g pivalic acid. The reaction mixture was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 194 °C for 178 hours under autogenous pressure. After the reaction period, the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature at a uniform rate of 5 °C/h. The result was the formation of colorless block crystals, which were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at ambient temperature. The yield was 57% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C48H54N6O22Zn3: C, 43.26, H, 4.08, N, 6.31%. Found: C, 43.12, H, 3.95, N, 6.45%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435m, 3052m, 2923

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol, 0.087 g) and H2BDC (0.15 mmol, 0.027 g) was prepared in diethylformamide (12 mL). Subsequently, KOH (0.4 mL, 2 mol·L–1) was added as a base to adjust the pH to approximately 8.5. The reaction mixture was subjected to a well-sealed environment and heated to 523.36 K for 243.93 hours, after which the system was allowed to naturally cool to ambient temperature. Black crystalline solids were filtered and washed thoroughly with diethylformamide (3 × 5 mL) and dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 50 mg [46% based on H2BDC]. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4CoNO6 (251.07): C, 38.30, H, 1.61, N, 5.58. Found: C, 38.25, H, 1.60, N, 5.60. PXRD analysis confirmed that the obtained product is crystalline and aligns well with the calculated pattern of the intended structure, indicating phase purity. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed a weight loss consistent with the removal of diethylformamide before decomposing at higher temperatures. Furthermore, IR spectra

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol), 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol), and pyridine (0.016 g, 0.2 mmol) in MeCN (8 mL) with the addition of HCOOH (0.2 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL). This mixture was heated at 526.733 K for 413.72 hours. After allowing the mixture to cool slowly to ambient temperature over 24 hours, pink hexagonal crystals were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN, and air-dried, obtaining a 79% yield based on the thiophenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for C12H10N2O8CoS: C, 33.89, H, 2.37, N, 6.58. Found: C, 33.95, H, 2.49, N, 6.63. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic bands at 3399 m, 3067 w, 1605 s, 1447 s, 1391 s, 1223 m, 1084 w, 761 m, 679 w, 535 m.

Synthesis of 2: A mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35.0 mg, 0.12 mmol) and terephthalic acid (20.1 mg, 0.12 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of DMAc (N,N-dimethylacetamide) and stirred gently to achieve a homogeneous solution. The solution was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 517.50 K for 344.915 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 2 °C·h−1. The reaction yielded colorless block crystals, which were isolated by filtration and briefly washed with DMAc. The yield was quantified as 58% based on the zinc nitrate salt. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6O4Zn: C, 40.38, H, 2.54, Found: C, 40.21, H, 2.69. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430(br), 1713(s), 1600(s), 1510(s), 1396(vs), 1260(m), 1140(w), 1012(w), 850(m), 730(s), 680(s), 622(m).

The synthesis of the metal-organic framework was carried out using a hydrothermal method. A mixture of 0.150 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.6 mmol), 0.120 g of trimesic acid (0.57 mmol), and 5 mL of H2O was combined with 0.2 mL of ethylenediamine as an additive. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15 minutes at ambient temperature before being transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 387.750 K for 242.809 minutes. After gradually cooling to room temperature, the reaction yielded blue needle-like crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried (yield = 52% based on Cu). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H14CuN2O8: C, 48.32, H, 3.16, N, 6.26. Found: C, 48.05, H, 3.28, N, 6.34. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1): 3412(s), 1615(m), 1385(s), 1252(w), 1158(m), 1083(w), 960(s), 865(m), 783(m).

Synthesis of Zn[(BDC)(EDTA)]·2H2O (MOF-23): A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol), H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and Na2EDTA (0.146 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (20 mL) under stirring. Ethylenediamine (0.5 mL) was added dropwise to the solution to adjust the pH to approximately 7. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 506.6 K for 29.5 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature, the formed micro-crystalline powder was collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The yield was 75% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H22N2O10Zn: C, 40.62, H, 4.69, N, 5.92%. Found: C, 40.44, H, 4.57, N, 5.81%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3447, 2924, 1692, 1595, 1518, 1428, 1379, 1245, 1106, 101

The metal-organic framework, designated as MOF-2, was synthesized under solvothermal conditions. In a typical synthesis, 0.300 g (0.984 mmol) of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA). To this solution, 0.150 g (0.492 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was added. Additionally, 0.200 mL of triethylamine (N(Et)3) was introduced to facilitate the deprotonation of the ligand. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 307.7 K for 500.6 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, yielding pale blue crystalline solids. These were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and dried under ambient conditions. The MOF-2 was obtained with an 82% yield based on copper. Elemental analysis results showed C, 49.82%, H, 5.17%, N, 2.31%. Experimental values found were C, 49.63%, H, 5.09%, N, 2.25%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (m), 1622 (s), 1578 (m), 1440 (s),

To synthesize ZIF-90, ZrCl4 (0.14 g, 0.60 mmol) was combined with a solution of BTC (0.10 g, 0.47 mmol) in CH3CN (6 mL) with continuous stirring. NaHCO3 (0.03 g, 0.36 mmol) was added to the mixture, which was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The assembly was heated to 156.4 °C for 171.90 hours, followed by cooling to ambient temperature. The resulting pale yellow crystals were isolated via filtration, washed with CH3CN, and air-dried (yield 69%, based on ZrCl4). Elemental analysis calculated: C 33.31, H 2.53, N 8.21, Zr 18.72. Found: C 33.48, H 2.45, N 8.16, Zr 18.69%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3375 (m), 2950 (w), 1682 (s), 1578 (s), 1423 (m), 1289 (m), 1104 (w), 952 (m), 812 (m), 714 (m), 628 (w).

In a typical synthesis of a metal-organic framework (MOF), 0.180 g of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.75 mmol) and 0.145 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of 1-butanol. To this mixture, 0.2 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added to adjust the acidity. The resultant solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was tightly sealed and subsequently heated at 376.116 K for 159.03 hours. After completion of the heating process, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The synthesized product, appearing as blue crystalline blocks, was isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any unreacted precursors or occluded solvents, followed by air drying. The yield of the crystalline material was found to be 67%, based on copper(II) nitrate trihydrate. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12Cu2O12: C 46.35, H 2.59. Found: C 46.12, H 2.68. IR spectroscopy (cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at: 3435 (s, br), 1608 (s), 1384 (vs), 1220 (

A mixture of FeCl3·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.37 mmol), H3BTC (0.084 g, 0.4 mmol), and methanol (10 mL) was combined in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. TETRAMETHYLAMMONIUM HYDROXIDE (0.05 g, 0.3 mmol) was added slowly under stirring until completely dissolved. The resulting solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and subjected to a hydrothermal reaction at 496 K for 474 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, dark brown microcrystalline powder was obtained and collected by filtration. The product was washed with methanol and dried under vacuum for 12 hours, yielding a 45% crystalline product. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3423 (br), 2924 (m), 1649 (s), 1482 (m), 1379 (s), 1258 (m), 1080 (w), 822 (w), 775 (w). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C10H8FeO6: C 34.07, H 2.29, found: C 34.13, H 2.35.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (200 mg, 0.67 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (75 mg, 0.35 mmol), and a measured quantity of 1,4-DIOXANE (20 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 15 min until a homogeneous suspension was obtained. To this mixture, hydrofluoric acid (HF) (0.5 mL) was carefully added under constant stirring. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL) and heated at 465 K for 69.461 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resultant white crystalline solids were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with fresh 1,4-DIOXANE, and dried under ambient conditions, yielding 72% of the desired product based on Zn. Phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis, exhibiting no secondary phases. Elemental analysis for C24H18Zn3O12, calculated: Zn, 22.30, C, 36.89, H, 2.32%, found: Zn, 22.45, C, 36.74, H, 2.25%.

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148 mg), trimesic acid (0.5 mmol, 105 mg), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.2 mmol, 8.4 mg) were dissolved in 15 mL of 68-12-2 solvent. The autoclave was securely sealed and heated to 525.8 K for 458.2 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/hour, clear phosphorescent crystals were recovered by filtration. The product was washed with ethanol (3 × 10 mL) and dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 24 hours, yielding a crystalline powder (yield: 215 mg, 67%). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12O12Zn: C, 40.39, H, 2.26. Found: C, 40.28, H, 2.31. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420 (m), 1635 (s), 1512 (m), 1365 (s), 1248 (w), 896 (m), 756 (m). Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were prepared under identical conditions by reducing the reaction time to 350 hours. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Cr

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), trimesic acid (0.210 g, 1 mmol), and dimethyl acetamide (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and maintained at 421.64 K for 455.692 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was slowly cooled to ambient temperature, yielding purple crystalline materials. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with dimethyl acetamide, and air-dried. The purity and phase identity of the product were confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Morphological characterization using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) revealed well-defined cubic crystals ranging from 50 to 150 μm in size (Supporting Information, Figure S4). The final yield was calculated to be 78%, based on cobalt. Elemental analysis results were consistent with the expected composition, showing agreement with the calculated values for C27H18CoN3O15.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), H3BTC (0.210 g, 1 mmol), and HBO3 (0.062 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 80 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at 494.9 K for 424.1 minutes, after which it was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant blue octahedral crystals were collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and left to dry in air. The yield was approximately 52% (based on H3BTC). Elemental analysis for Cu3(BTC)2·(DMF)2: Calculated: C, 41.03, H, 3.62, N, 5.72. Found: C, 41.15, H, 3.54, N, 5.80. The MOF structure was confirmed by X-ray diffraction, which indicated high crystallinity. The synthesized MOF was subsequently activated by immersing it in methanol for 24 hours, followed by heating under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 hours to yield the desolvated framework, designated as MOF-E.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.245 g, 0.84 mmol), H4bta (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol), and ethylenediamine (0.20 g, 3.3 mmol) was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then filled with 15 mL of methanol and sealed. The solution was heated at 105.2 °C for 432.56 minutes, after which it was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting pink needle-shaped crystals were collected by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried, yielding 0.282 g (68%) of the pure product. Anal. Calcd. for C14H16CoN2O8 (Mr = 431.22): C, 38.96, H, 3.74, N, 6.49. Found: C, 39.12, H, 3.61, N, 6.35. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3398(s), 2948(m), 1620(s), 1480(m), 1380(s), 1292(w), 1140(m), 892(w), 754(m), 667(w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.298 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and NaOH (0.080 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (12 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, adjusting the pH to approximately 7.5. The vessel was sealed and heated at 483.28 K for 53 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, colorless block-shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 0.215 g, corresponding to 68% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of a single crystalline phase. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1605, 1504, 1416, 1362, 1258, 1104, 866, 755, 675, 564. Analytical data calculated for ZnC8H4O4: C, 39.36%, H, 1.65%, Zn, 27.12%. Found: C, 39.15%, H, 1.72%, Zn

Compound [Fe3(BTC)2(H2O)12] was synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction using FeCl3·6H2O (0.162 g, 0.6 mmol) and trimesic acid (BTC) (0.063 g, 0.3 mmol) in deionized water (15 mL) with the addition of 1 mL of concentrated HBF4. The mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated to 314 K for 193.4 minutes. The reaction was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow cubic crystals were isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with distilled water. Yield: 72 %. Elemental analysis calculated for [Fe3(BTC)2(H2O)12] (C18H12Fe3O24): C, 26.14, H, 1.46, found: C, 26.11, H, 1.48. IR (KBr): ν(cm–1) = 3412 (s), 2925 (w), 1675 (m), 1543 (s), 1384 (vs), 1245 (m), 778 (m) (see Figure S3, Supporting Information). The compound's structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and further supported by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 1 mmol, 0.210 g), and water (20 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated to 526.834 K for 473.74 minutes, after which it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. Pale yellow crystalline frameworks of the product were obtained with an approximate yield of 45% based on BTC. Elemental analysis for the MOF (C18H6N2O12Zn): calcd (%): C, 41.23, H, 1.15, N, 5.34. Found: C, 41.10, H, 1.27, N, 5.29. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1): 3436(s), 1678(m), 1605(s), 1489(m), 1385(vs), 1244(m), 1128(w), 1039(w), 835(m), 754(s), 679(w), 609(w), 553(w), 434(w).

Synthesis of MOF-X1: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.120 g, 0.41 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.065 g, 0.31 mmol) was combined with 68-12-2 (12 mL) as the reaction medium in a 25 mL round-bottom flask. Sodium acetate (0.035 g, 0.42 mmol) was introduced as an additive to facilitate crystallization. The flask was sealed and placed in a preheated oven maintained at 155 °C for a duration of 150.98 minutes. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting blue, octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration and repeatedly washed with additional 68-12-2 to remove any unreacted starting materials. The yield was quantified at approximately 80% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Structural integrity of MOF-X1 was corroborated through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), with patterns aligning closely to the simulated data for this MOF. The porosity of the synthesized material was confirmed by N2 adsorption experiments at 77 K, revealing a BET surface area of approximately 704 m²/g, indicative of a highly porous framework. Furthermore, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) demonstrated stability up to 320

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.625 mmol) and H2bdc (0.104 g, 0.625 mmol) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (10 mL) under magnetic stirring for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 513.8 K for 84.233 minutes. Following the thermal treatment, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Green needle-like crystals of the target metal-organic framework were collected through filtration, rinsed with THF, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 65%, elemental analysis (%) calcd for C16H10CuO8: C 39.60, H 2.08, found: C 39.42, H 2.01. A single crystal suitable for X-ray diffraction was isolated, and its analysis confirmed the anticipated coordination framework.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.3 mmol) and H3BTC (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in water (20 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was tightly sealed and maintained at 305 K for 121.56 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the vessel was slowly cooled to room temperature, allowing the formation of blue crystalline solids. The crystals were harvested by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried to yield the copper-based MOF in 68% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis showed (calculated): C 39.12%, H 2.76%, N 5.98%, (found): C 38.95%, H 2.69%, N 5.87%.

For the synthesis of the MOF, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.172 mmol) and H3BTC (35.0 mg, 0.166 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL) with hexafluoroacetylacetone (150 μL, 0.943 mmol) as an additive. The reaction mixture was sealed in a 20 mL glass vial and allowed to react at 40 °C for 242.3 hours. Upon completion, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature, after which purple cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried to yield 63% based on H3BTC. CHN elemental analysis (%) yielded C 38.67, H 2.45, N 7.53. This closely matches the theoretical values for C21H12CoN3O9: C 38.58, H 2.32, N 7.50. The purity of the product was further corroborated by comparison of its X-ray powder diffraction pattern with the simulated pattern based on single-crystal X-ray data, confirming the identical phase (Fig. S2). IR data (cm−1): 1690(s), 1625(m), 1543(w), 1448(m), 1390(s), 1085(w), 980(m), 870

In a 25 mL glass vial, 150.4 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 75.0 mg of terephthalic acid were dissolved in 5.0 mL of DMSO under mild stirring. The mixture was transferred to a pre-heated oil bath where it was maintained at 95 °C for 163.60 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, resulting in the formation of pale yellow rhombic crystals. The crystallized product was isolated by vacuum filtration and rinsed with cold ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The yield was quantified as 72% based on zinc content. The purity of the final compound was confirmed using X-ray diffraction analysis and infrared spectroscopy, indicating successful formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol), H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and a few drops of 1 M HCl in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL) was prepared and stirred for 15 minutes. The homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 169.564 °C for 225 minutes. Following the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless rectangular crystals were collected via filtration and subsequently washed with dimethyl acetamide to remove any unreacted material. The yield was 74%, based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3434, 2948, 1664, 1574, 1486, 1402, 1108, 1022, 924, 823, 735, 682. Elemental analysis calculated (found) for C16H14O8Zn: C, 48.29 (48.11), H, 3.55 (3.68), Zn, 16.41 (16.59).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g), H2BDC (0.25 mmol, 0.042 g), and hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.05 mmol, 0.012 g) was prepared in 5 mL of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone at ambient temperature. The mixture was stirred for 30 minutes and then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 433.248 K for 211.17 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, transparent crystals of the metal-organic framework were obtained. The crystalline product was isolated via filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and subsequently dried under vacuum. The yield was 58% based on the zinc salt. The resulting MOF exhibited negligible solubility in water and common organic solvents. Elemental analysis for C36H34F12N2O10Zn2 revealed the following: calcd. C 39.22, H 3.09, N 2.54 %, found C 39.37, H 3.02, N 2.58 %. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr pellet) showed characteristic bands at 3440 (w), 1654 (vs), 1602 (m), 1428 (s), 1268 (m), 108

Synthesis of [Zn(BDC)(py)2]·4THF (Complex A): To synthesize Complex A, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 0.089 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.3 mmol, 0.050 g), and pyridine (0.6 mmol, 0.048 g) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 10 mL) within a sealed 30 mL glass vial. The reaction vial was heated at 72 °C for precisely 498.72 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the resultant solution was cooled to ambient temperature, leading to the formation of colorless crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with THF, followed by drying under reduced pressure. Yield: 65%. Anal. Calcd for C26H34N2O8Zn (576.95): C, 54.07, H, 5.94, N, 4.86. Found: C, 54.02, H, 5.85, N, 4.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 3075 (m), 1610 (s), 1578 (m), 1448 (s), 1379 (vs), 1254 (m), 113

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35 mg, 0.12 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (26 mg, 0.16 mmol) was dissolved in 7 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL) and subjected to a temperature of 371.58 K under autogenous pressure for 246.594 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless block-shaped crystals were obtained. The yield of the MOF was approximately 72% based on the metal source. Anal. Calcd for C16H12N2O8Zn: C, 47.30%, H, 2.98%, N, 6.89%. Found: C, 47.25%, H, 3.02%, N, 6.85%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (vs), 2935 (w), 1708 (s), 1601 (s), 1485 (m), 1384 (s), 1220 (m), 1060 (m), 939 (w), 778 (m), 620 (w).

A mixture containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.058 g), terephthalic acid (H2BDC) (0.15 mmol, 0.025 g), and ethylenediamine (0.3 mmol, 0.018 g) was dissolved in H2O (10 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 397.06 K for 117.77 minutes. The reaction vessel was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale-green crystalline solids were obtained by filtration, thoroughly washed with deionized water, and air-dried. Yield: 75%. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H12N2NiO4: C 34.03%, H 4.29%, N 9.92%. Found: C 34.11%, H 4.27%, N 10.01%. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3371 (m), 3175 (w), 1615 (s), 1567 (m), 1444 (s), 1395 (m), 1281 (s), 1157 (w), 1098 (w), 802 (m), 712 (m).

Synthesis of {[Zn4(BTC)2(4,4'-bipy)2]·CH3OH}n: A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.298 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy) (0.156 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol (CH3OH). Acetic acid (AcOH, 0.1 mL) was added as an additive to the solution. The resultant mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 331.077 K for 123.0 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting clear solution was filtered to yield colorless crystalline blocks of the MOF product. These were isolated and washed with methanol, providing the product with a yield of approximately 65% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C48H34N4O16Zn4: C 51.48, H 3.06, N 5.00. Found: C 51.12, H 3.19, N 5.14. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3428 (m), 159

Synthesis of [Zn4(BTC)3(H2O)6]∙(C2H5OH) (1): Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 g, 1.68 mmol) and trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.24 g, 1.14 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) in a 50 mL glass reaction vessel. The mixture was stirred for 30 minutes before adding tetrafluoroboric acid (0.1 mL, 48% wt). The vessel was sealed and subjected to heating at 174.8 °C for 230 hours in a pre-heated oven. The reaction mixture was subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h−1. The resulting pale-yellow crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 0.30 g (45%). Elemental analysis calcd for C24H26O18B3Zn4: C 25.16, H 2.29, found: C 25.08, H 2.32. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3485 (br, H2O OH), 1690 (s, C=O stretch), 1530 (m, asymmetric COO− stretch), 1360 (vs, symmetric COO− stretch), 1105 (m), 850 (

A mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O 0.074 g (0.25 mmol), H2BDC-NH2 0.030 g (0.20 mmol), and 8 mL of dimethylacetamide was prepared in a 20 mL vial. To this, hexafluoroacetylacetone 0.012 g (0.05 mmol) was added while continuously stirring at room temperature until complete dissolution was achieved. The vial was then sealed and the reaction mixture was subjected to a heating regimen at 480 K for 357 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, pale yellow crystalline solids formed, which were subsequently filtered and washed with ethanol to remove residual solvents. The collected crystals were dried under vacuum (15 min) to yield the desired MOF in 42% yield based on Zn(II). Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity and crystallinity of the synthesized product. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3430 (s, N–H), 2928 (m), 1684 (s, C=O), 1601 (m, C=C), 1482 (w), 1242 (s, C–F). Elemental analysis revealed C = 38.57%, H = 2.24%, N = 11.46%, which closely agrees with the calculated values.

A novel metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized by reacting H2BTB (0.180 g, 0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), and NaNO3 (0.085 g, 1 mmol) in diethanolamine (15 mL) with the addition of sodium acetate (0.082 g, 1 mmol) to the reaction mixture. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL capacity), sealed, and heated at 96 °C for 116 hours. Upon completion, the system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h−1, resulting in dark red needle-like crystals of the Co-based MOF. These crystals achieved a yield of approximately 50%, calculated based on the amount of cobalt used. The structural integrity and phase purity of the obtained product were verified through X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), which showed a good correlation between the experimental and simulated patterns depicted in Fig. S5.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.514 mmol) and trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.07 g, 0.334 mmol) was dissolved in 8.0 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) to form a homogeneous blue solution by stirring for several minutes. The solution was carefully transferred into a Teflon-lined 25 mL stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 424.915 K for 327.459 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting pink crystalline material was collected via filtration and further washed with MeCN to remove any residual impurities. Elemental analysis was performed on the resulting complex, giving satisfactory results corresponding to the calculated values: Anal. Calc. for C18H12O6N2Co: C, 57.84, H, 3.24, N, 7.49. Found: C, 57.89, H, 3.21, N, 7.53. The infrared spectrum of the MOF exhibited characteristic peaks at 2923 (m), 1625 (s), 1365 (s), 745 (m) cm−1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the framework crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and consists of paddle-wheel type Co2(COO)4 secondary building units linked by BTC

For the synthesis of the MOF species, Co(NO3)2⋅6 H2O (0.178 g, 0.61 mmol) and H2TCA (0.070 g, 0.21 mmol) were combined in DMSO (15 mL) inside a 25 mL glass vial. The reaction mixture was subjected to a controlled temperature of 323 K and maintained for 430.060 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, yielding purple octahedral crystals. The isolated crystals were washed with ethanol and dried under a vacuum. Yield: 0.210 g, based on Co(NO3)2⋅6 H2O. Anal. Calcd for [Co(H2TCA)2(DMSO)2]·0.5DMSO: C, 52.05, H, 5.36, N, 6.03%. Found: C, 51.89, H, 5.29, N, 6.10%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1) 3420, 2925, 2850, 1687, 1608, 1449, 1377, 1260, 1147, 1085, 920, 763, 698.

To synthesize the desired MOF, 0.080 g (∼0.5 mmol) of copper(II) acetate monohydrate (Cu(OAc)2·H2O) and 0.056 g (∼0.3 mmol) of 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) were dissolved in 7.5 mL of N,N-diethylformamide. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes, resulting in a homogeneous pale blue solution. This solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 20 mL, which was securely sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 205.87 °C for 63.4 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded pale blue crystalline solids, which were collected by filtration, rinsed thoroughly with fresh N,N-diethylformamide (3 × 20 mL), and left to dry under ambient conditions.
