The crystalline phase was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. The yield was determined to be 52% based on the initial copper(II) acetate monohydrate.

In a glass vial, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 g, 1.68 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.25 g, 1.51 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CH2OH (15 mL), to which hexafluoropropene (50 μL) was added as an additive to the reaction mixture. The vial was tightly sealed and maintained at a temperature of 31.9 °C using a thermostatic water bath for 134 minutes. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. White needle-like crystals of the resultant MOF were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and air-dried to achieve an overall yield of 63% based on Zn. Elemental analysis: calculated for C8H6F6O4Zn: C, 26.32, H, 1.65, found: C, 26.45, H, 1.72%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed peaks at 3455 (s), 2935 (w), 1680 (s), 1600 (m), 1460 (s), 1270 (w), 1020 (m), 820 (w), 675 (m).

To synthesize the MOF using the established conditions, combine 0.250 g of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), 0.300 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), and 20 mL of 1,4-dioxane in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. Add 0.050 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to the mixture to achieve an initial pH of 9.21. The resulting solution is transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and then heated at 361.2 K for precisely 153.7 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, violet block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh 1,4-dioxane, and dried under vacuum. The crystalline yield reached 70% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis (%) for [Co(BDC)(OH)]·0.5DIOX: Calc. C, 45.23, H, 3.40, N, 0.00. Found: C, 45.01, H, 3.45, N, 0.05. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3425(b), 2923(m), 1687(s), 1602(m), 1505(w), 1388(m),

To synthesize the desired MOF, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.75 mmol), and sodium acetate (20.5 mg, 0.25 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of acetonitrile (CH3CN). The resulting solution was stirred for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) and heated at 248.2 °C for 90 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, pale blue needle-shaped crystals formed, which were collected by filtration, washed with fresh acetonitrile, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was determined to be 60% based on Co(NO3)2. Elemental analysis calculated for the compound, C18H16CoN3O8·CH3CN (%): C, 42.11, H, 3.65, N, 9.68. Found: C, 42.03, H, 3.59, N, 9.74. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3402 br, 2925 w, 1607 s, 1562 m, 1412 s, 1385 vs, 1270 m, 1183 w, 1095 m,

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol), biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (0.087 g, 0.36 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.062 g, 0.39 mmol) was combined with CH3CN (8 mL) and potassium iodide (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was stirred until homogenous, then sealed and heated at 128.561 °C for 392.54 hours. After cooling to room temperature, pink cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with CH3CN twice, and air-dried (yield: 74%, based on the organic ligand). Elemental analysis for C26H20CoN2O4: Calculated (%): C, 65.32, H, 4.22, N, 5.86. Found: C, 65.54, H, 4.18, N, 5.79. The structural integrity was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis demonstrated thermal stability up to 498 K with a weight loss of 15.67%, consistent with the release of lattice water molecules (calculated 15.62%).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.200 g, 0.82 mmol) and H2bdc (0.150 g, 0.90 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL). To this solution, hydrofluoric acid (0.1 mL, 47 wt% in water) was added dropwise while stirring. The resulting homogeneous mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20 mL) and sealed. The autoclave was then heated at 445 K for 214 minutes under autogenous pressure, followed by cooling to ambient temperature. The formed blue crystalline material was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and then immersed in methanol for guest exchange over 3 days with regular refreshing of the solvent. Finally, the product was dried under vacuum at 323 K for 6 hours. The yield was found to be 0.180 g, corresponding to 78% based on Cu(bdc)(H2O)6. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C16H20CuO12: C, 40.60, H, 4.26, N, 0.00. Found: C, 40.47, H, 4.55, N, 0.00%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet cm−1): 3425 (broad), 171

To synthesize the novel MOF-47, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 18.6 mg, 0.088 mmol) was combined with zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 43 mg, 0.144 mmol) in 3 mL methanol (MeOH). To this solution, 20 μL concentrated nitric acid (HNO3) was added as an additive. The resultant mixture was thoroughly stirred at room temperature for 10 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. This clear solution was then transferred into a 25 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was tightly sealed and maintained at a steady 29 °C for 370.30 minutes to facilitate the formation of the MOF framework. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The product was collected by filtration, washed with MeOH, and air-dried. The procedure yielded white crystalline MOF-47, with a yield of 22 mg (∼82% based on H3BTC). The structure was verified by X-ray diffraction, revealing a robust framework suited for gas adsorption applications. Additionally, the product demonstrated stability in both air and common organic solvents, including methanol and ethanol.

ZrOCl2·8H2O (0.256 g, 0.80 mmol) was combined with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.138 g, 0.65 mmol) and water (15 mL) in a 30-mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide [(CH3)4NOH] (0.980 g, 0.90 mmol) was then added, and the mixture was stirred until homogeneously mixed. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 432.50 K for 264.81 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with additional water, and then acetone to remove residual impurities. The crystals were further dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 hours, yielding white cubic crystals with a purity of 87% by weight based on the reactant 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Anal. Calcd for [Zr6O4(OH)4(C9H3O6)6]: C, 31.21, H, 1.28. Found: C, 31.08, H, 1.22. Characterization by powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of the expected MOF structure, exhibiting peaks consistent with

A novel MOF, designated as MOF-XYZ, was synthesized by combining 0.50 g (1.5 mmol) cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate and 0.25 g (1.0 mmol) benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) in 10 mL of ethanol as a solvent. To this solution, 1 mL of triethylamine (N(Et)3) was added to facilitate deprotonation of the organic ligand. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 40 mL glass vial, sealed, and heated in an oil bath at a controlled temperature of 62.411 °C for 147 minutes. After the specified heating period, slow cooling to room temperature proceeded over a span of 6 hours. Upon completion, blue crystalline materials of MOF-XYZ were obtained, which were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum for 24 hours. The yield was 72%, based on cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate. Characterization by PXRD confirmed the crystalline structure, with key peaks observed at 2θ = 8.1°, 12.3°, and 25.4°. The IR spectrum revealed characteristic bands at 3410 (m), 1610 (s), 1435 (m), and 1108 (s) cm−1, as shown in Figure S1 of the supplementary information

A sample synthesis was carried out using a solvothermal method, combining 25 mg (0.1 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 30 mg (0.15 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid in 10 mL of ethanol (C2H5OH) along with an additive of 20 mg (0.19 mmol) Na2CO3 to adjust the pH. This mixture was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, tightly sealed, and heated to a temperature of 372.183 K (99 °C) for 336 minutes. After the reaction period, the system was slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a controlled rate. The resulting blue crystalline material was separated by filtration, washed with ethanol several times to remove unreacted components, and dried under vacuum. Yield was recorded at 72% based on the initial copper content. Elemental analysis was performed using a Thermo Scientific FLASH 2000 elemental analyzer. Calculated for C16H10CuO9: C, 44.44, H, 2.33. Found: C, 44.37, H, 2.40. Characterization was further supported by FT-IR spectroscopy on a Bruker TENSOR 27, and major absorption bands were observed at 1655 s, 1590 m, 1440 vs, 1250

Compound 4b: A mixture of 0.250 g (0.75 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 1.5 mL of DMAc was prepared. To this solution, 1 mL of ammonium hydroxide was carefully added dropwise while stirring continuously, followed by the addition of 0.150 g (0.60 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, pre-dissolved in 2 mL of DMAc. The resulting solution was sonicated for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The entire mixture was transferred into a sealed Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a static temperature of 102.723 °C for 435.57 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline structures were formed. These crystals were harvested by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 65% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Cu(BDC)(DMAc)]·(H2O)2: C, 43.36, H, 4.87, N, 7.21. Found: C, 43.42, H, 4.90, N, 7.18.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 0.045 g) and terephthalic acid (0.075 mmol, 0.012 g) was dissolved in benzene (8 ml) with the addition of acetic acid (3 drops) in a glass vial. The vial was then sealed and subjected to heating at 157.5 °C for 33.858 minutes. The reaction vessel was subsequently cooled to ambient temperature at a controlled rate. The process yielded pink needle-like crystals with a 52% yield. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C12H10CoO6: C, 44.52, H, 3.11. Found (%): C, 44.47, H, 3.15. The IR spectrum (in KBr, cm−1) includes the following bands: 3421(b), 1630(s), 1570(m), 1442(w), 1360(s), 1281(m), 1180(w), 1105(b), 1001(w), 804(m), 733(s).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and H2bdc (0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reaction mixture was heated under autogenous pressure at 230 °C for 285 hours, followed by cooling to room temperature over 18 hours. Pale yellow block-shaped crystals were collected through filtration, rinsed with THF, and dried under vacuum, yielding 0.1230 g of the product (68% yield based on Zn(NO3)2). The synthesized framework was characterized by its resistance to dissolution in water and other common solvents. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H8N4O8Zn (%): C, 44.88, H, 1.88, N, 13.09. Found: C, 44.76, H, 1.92, N, 12.98. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1): 3427 m, 3096 m, 2945 w, 2345 w, 1671 s, 1553 m, 1479 m, 1398 s, 1286 m, 1179 w, 1059 w, 963 m, 882 m, 807 s, 741 w, 635 m, 537 w,

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol, 120.5 mg) and H2BDC (terephthalic acid, 0.5 mmol, 83.1 mg) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 8 mL) in a 20 mL screw-capped glass vial. To this solution, hexafluoropropene (0.2 mL) was added as an additive to facilitate crystal growth. The vial was securely capped and placed in an oven at 147.527 °C for 70.9 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the formed blue crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed thrice with DMF to remove any unreacted starting materials and residual solvents. The crystalline material was then dried under reduced pressure, yielding 160 mg (66% based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis for the Cu-BDC framework was performed, revealing values consistent with the expected formulation: for C8H4O4Cu (found: C 38.7%, H 2.0%, Cu 34.5% vs. calcd: C 39.1%, H 2.0%, Cu 34.3%). The IR spectrum of the product displayed characteristic peaks at 1604(s), 1439(s), 1364(m), and 754(m) cm−1, indicative of successful MO

The synthesis of the MOF material [Zn3(BTC)2]·DMF was carried out by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 85 mg, 0.4 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (5 mL) with ethylenediamine (0.5 mL) added as a modulator. This mixture was sealed in a 50 mL glass vial and subjected to heating at 526 K for 490 hours in a convection oven. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool to ambient temperature, yielding yellowish, block-like crystals. These were isolated by filtration and washed with anhydrous ethanol to remove residual solvent and unreacted starting materials. Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) validated the incorporation of DMF within the MOF framework, with a solvent content of DMF, 22.3% as determined by TGA. The final product was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction, confirming the anticipated crystal structure with a cell parameter of a=18.460 Å. The isolated yield was 65%, consistent with elemental analysis results: Calcd. for C18H28N4O13Zn3: C 34.38, H 4.49, N 8.90

To synthesize the MOF compound, a mixture of 0.0350 g (0.10 mmol) of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate and 0.0240 g (0.15 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide in a 25 mL glass vial. To this solution, 0.1 mL of tetrafluoroboric acid was added to facilitate the reaction. The resulting mixture was heated in an oven at 110 °C for 93.928 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature, leading to the formation of blue crystalline materials. The crystals were carefully collected by filtration, washed with diethyl ether, and dried in air, yielding 45.8 mg of the final compound (78% yield based on the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the crystalline nature of the compound, with the patterns matching closely with those calculated based on single-crystal data. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H8O8Cu2: C, 44.01, H, 2.31. Found: C, 43.88, H, 2.29.

To synthesize [Cu2(BDC)2(4,4'-bpy)]n, copper(II) nitrate hemipentahydrate (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in benzene (10 mL). Potassium iodide (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was added as an additive to the solution, followed by the gradual addition of 4,4'-bipyridine (0.031 g, 0.2 mmol). The mixture was sonicated for 10 minutes and transferred to a 20 mL glass vial, which was then sealed. The sealed vial was heated at 146.931 °C for 382 hours, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. Blue crystalline product was obtained and thoroughly washed with benzene (3×5 mL). The yield of the crystalline product was 0.056 g (0.099 mmol, 49.5%). IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm–1) showed significant peaks at 3440 (br), 1610 (s), 1384 (s), 756 (w), and 540 (m). Elemental analysis calculated for CuC32H22N4O8: C, 55.10%, H, 3.18%, N, 8.03%.

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.105 g, 0.40 mmol) and H2bcdc (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 5 mL) and manually stirred for 15 minutes. The resulting solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated in an oven at 527 K for 342 hours. The autoclave was then allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Green crystalline solids were isolated by filtration with a yield of 68% based on H2bcdc. Anal. Calcd for C14H10NiO8: C, 47.17, H, 2.83%. Found: C, 47.32, H, 2.79%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3432 m, 3075 w, 2974 w, 1660 s, 1602 s, 1445 s, 1417 m, 1328 s, 1180 m, 956 w, 836 m, 754 s.

A mixture composed of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.17 g, 1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF, 12 mL), and concentrated ammonia (NH3, 1 mL) was prepared and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. This was then subjected to heating at 383.26 K for 68.8 minutes under autogenous pressure, followed by a controlled cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 10 °C h−1. The process yielded colorless needle-like crystals of a crystalline metal-organic framework, designated as compound 3. The isolated compound was recovered in 72% yield based on zinc. Structural elucidation through single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed the porosity and framework topology characteristic of the MOF architecture. Further elemental analysis was performed, with results consistent with the expected formulation: Calcd for C16H14ZnN2O4: C, 55.72, H, 4.10, N, 7.82. Found: C, 55.68, H, 4.13, N, 7.80. The influence of ammonia as an additive was observed to enhance the deprotonation of H2BDC, facilitating the coordination with zinc ions and promoting crystal growth of the framework structure. The

A synthesis of Zn-based metal-organic framework was performed by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.136 g, 0.5 mmol) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.090 g, 0.5 mmol) in 5 ml of the solvent 68-12-2. The mixture was stirred for 20 minutes at ambient conditions to promote dissolution and homogeneity. The solution was subsequently transferred into a glass-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated to 434.289 K for 161 minutes. Following a slow cooling process to room temperature, yellow needle-like crystals formed with approximately 62% yield based on 2-aminoterephthalic acid. Elemental analysis results indicated: calculated C, 45.72%, H, 3.85%, N, 4.43%, and found C, 45.65%, H, 3.71%, N, 4.50%. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns confirmed the pure phase of the synthesized MOF, as shown in Figure 2. IR spectra exhibited characteristic peaks at 3400 (m), 1695 (s), 1570 (s), 1375 (s), 1180 (m), 937 (w), and 675 (m) cm^-1, indicating the successful incorporation of the organic linker in the framework.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.33 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.037 g, 0.22 mmol), and pivalic acid (0.05 mL) was dissolved in 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL). The solution was thoroughly stirred for 1 hour before it was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then heated at 468 K for 471.2 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the vessel was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting product, white crystalline blocks, was collected through filtration, washed with copious amounts of ethanol, and dried in air. The yield of the crystalline material was approximately 70% based on the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H20N2O10Zn (509.76): C, 42.41, H, 3.95, N, 5.50. Found: C, 42.38, H, 3.99, N, 5.47. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3417(m), 1708(s), 1583(vs), 1388(s), 1262(m), 1083(w),

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) (12 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The components were homogeneously mixed while being stirred vigorously. The reaction mixture was then tightly sealed and heated statically at 514.85 K for 338.166 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. Blue octahedral crystals of the MOF were isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with fresh NMP. The resultant crystals were air-dried, yielding 0.185 g (74% yield based on Cu). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H10CuO6: C, 48.49, H, 3.39, N, 0.00. Found: C, 48.22, H, 3.57, N, 0.00. IR (KBr pellet): ν = 3440 (br), 1602 (vs), 1510 (m), 1406 (s), 1234 (m), 1098 (w), 967 (m), 870 (w), 772 (m

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.075 g, 0.25 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.042 g, 0.20 mmol), and 2-aminopyrimidine (0.019 g, 0.20 mmol) was prepared in 8 mL of DMSO. Benzoic acid (0.030 g, 0.25 mmol) was added as an additive to the solution. The resulting mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 248 °C for 106.7 hours. The system was then cooled to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow crystalline material was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol and acetone, and then air-dried. Yield: 56% based on H3BTC. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(m), 3105(w), 2924(w), 1703(s), 1587(s), 1500(m), 1404(s), 1358(m), 1251(m), 1112(w), 998(m), 914(w), 869(w), 781(m), 623(m). Anal. The compound 2 was synthesized as pale yellow crystals via a solvothermal method using Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and H2BDC (20 mg, 0.10 mmol). These were dissolved in THF (2.5 mL) within a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The vessel was heated to 476.098 K for 258 hours. Post reaction, the solution was cooled to room temperature to yield the crystalline product, which was collected by filtration and dried in air, providing a 45% yield based on the H2BDC ligand. The analytic elemental results were consistent, calcd for ZnC16H14O8: C, 45.57%, H, 3.34%, found: C, 45.49%, H, 3.29%. The crystalline structure was further corroborated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S2), while additional characterization was performed using infrared (IR) spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The thermal stability of compound 2 was analyzed, revealing its stability under ambient conditions.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (180 mg, 0.75 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (84 mg, 0.4 mmol) was combined with 7 mL of diethanolamine in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 192 °C for 367.648 hours. After the autoclave was cooled slowly to room temperature, deep blue crystalline frameworks of {[Cu3(BTC)2(DEOA)2]·H2O}n were obtained in 58% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd for C24H30Cu3N2O20 (Mr: 880.19): C, 32.73, H, 3.43, N, 3.18%. Found: C, 32.60, H, 3.45, N, 3.14%. IR (KBr pellet, cm^-1): 3350 br, 1602 s, 1449 m, 1360 s, 1125 w, 1018 w, 760 m, 650 w, 450 w.

A synthesis was conducted using 428 mg of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2 mmol) and 178 mg of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.5 mmol), which were dissolved in 12 mL of methanol inside a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was stirred for 15 minutes before sealing and heating at 134.189 °C for 493.366 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, yielding a crystalline blue product. The solid was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and subsequently vacuum-dried at 15 Torr, resulting in a 210 mg (75%) yield of blue crystals. FT-IR (neat), νmax/cm−1: 3380 (m, br), 2924 (w), 1685 (s), 1589 (s), 1435 (m), 1380 (s), 1145 (w), 1010 (w), 835 (m), 753 (s). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9Cu2O12: C 41.29, H 1.73, Cu 24.26, found C 40.98, H 1.85, Cu 24.05%. This material exhibited thermal stability up to 280 °C

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.21 g, 1.0 mmol) in pyridine (10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 353 K for 386 hours. Subsequently, the reaction was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant product consisted of reddish block-shaped crystals, which were isolated by filtration, washed with pyridine, and dried in air, yielding 0.17 g (63% based on Co). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18O9Co: C, 49.16%, H, 4.13%, N, 0.00%. Found: C, 49.08%, H, 4.19%, N, 0.00%. The phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3395 (m), 2920 (w), 1605 (s), 1533 (s), 1385 (s), 1253 (w), 1116 (w), 755 (w), 642 (m).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.116 g, 0.4 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of C2H5OH. This mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated for 146.683 hours at 398.55 K. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, green crystalline needles of the metal-organic framework were isolated with an approximate yield of 48% based on Ni. A combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.058 g) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.2 mmol, 0.042 g) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL) and stirred at 304 K for 78.6 minutes. The resulting solution was then transferred to a 15 mL glass vial, which was sealed and kept at the same temperature for the entire duration. Upon completion, the solution was cooled to room temperature, yielding pale pink needle-shaped crystals. These were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried to give a yield of 0.025 g, 48% based on Co. Anal. calcd for C18H12O18Co4: C, 27.43, H, 1.54%. Found: C, 27.35, H, 1.60%. IR (cm−1): 3408 (br), 2930 (w), 1605 (s), 1387 (m), 1254 (w), 1089 (m), 867 (w), 754 (m), 692 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 mmol, 14.9 mg), H2bdc (0.050 mmol, 8.3 mg), and 2-amino-1-butanol (3 mL) was placed into a 15 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 460 K for 53.13 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature over a period of 12 hours, colorless cubic crystals were formed and were isolated by filtration, followed by air drying. The yield of the obtained crystals was 61% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H12N2O6Zn (Mr = 345.60): C, 34.76, H, 3.50, N, 8.11. Found: C, 34.89, H, 3.42, N, 8.02. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (300 mg, 1.01 mmol), H2BDC (166 mg, 1.00 mmol), and potassium iodide (83 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in diethanolamine (5 mL) to form a homogeneous solution. This solution was then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 147 °C for 129.286 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 47% (based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis was performed, with calculated values for C16H14ZnO8: C 45.85, H 3.37, found: C 45.74, H 3.32. The FT-IR spectrum showed characteristic peaks at 3448, 2975, 1680, 1580, and 1395 cm−1, confirming successful coordination and structural integrity of the framework.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58 mg, 0.20 mmol), H2bdc (33 mg, 0.20 mmol), and NaOC2H5 (21 mg, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in isobutanol (15 mL) and transferred into a sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL). The reaction mixture was maintained at 49.9 °C for 277.89 minutes. Upon completion, the system was slowly cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 1 °C min−1, resulting in the formation of pale pink prism-shaped crystals. The yield was calculated to be 65% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calc. for C16H14CoN2O8 (Mr = 425.22): C, 45.16, H, 3.32, N, 6.57. Found: C, 45.08, H, 3.41, N, 6.49%. IR (cm−1): 3432(m), 2922(m), 1713(s), 1608(s), 1538(m), 1395(s), 1254(m), 1156(w), 1074(w), 887(m), 751(m), 663(w), 534(m). Further characterization was performed, revealing a crystalline

A 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave was loaded with 0.200 g (0.55 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.150 g (0.75 mmol) of H3BTC in 20 mL NMP. The sealed autoclave was then heated at 139.56 °C for 421 hours and allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. The resultant product was collected by filtration to yield pale blue crystalline solids with a yield of 60.5% based on H3BTC. The purity and phase of the product were verified by PXRD analysis. Elemental Anal. Calcd for C18H12ZnN3O12 (515.68): C, 41.86, H, 2.34, N, 8.14%. Found: C, 41.72, H, 2.41, N, 8.22%. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, ν/cm−1) displayed peaks at: 3428 (m), 2923 (w), 1662 (s), 1583 (s), 1448 (m), 1348 (w), 1273 (w), 1135 (m), 1031 (w), 957 (w), 787 (s), 645 (m), 511 (m).

A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.121 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.5 mmol, 0.083 g), and NaOH (0.1 mmol, 0.004 g) was dissolved in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide under continuous stirring for 20 minutes at ambient temperature. The homogeneous mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 346.8 K for 446.78 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature over a period of 48 hours. The resultant blue crystalline material was filtered and washed with DMF and ethanol to remove any unreacted ligand or metal salt, then air-dried. The crystals obtained were analyzed, yielding 45% based on copper nitrate. Anal. Calcd. for Cu3(C8H4O4)3·H2O (%): C, 52.76, H, 3.14, N, 0.00. Found: C, 52.68, H, 3.02, N, 0.10. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1645(s), 1590(s), 1504(m), 1392(s), 1217(w

Synthesis of {[Co2(bpdc)2(bpy)2]⋅xH2O}n (1): A mixture comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.86 mmol), 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (bpdc) (0.20 g, 0.79 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) (0.15 g, 0.96 mmol) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (15 mL) with the addition of ethylenediamine (0.05 mL, 0.75 mmol). The resulting solution was transferred into a 35 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 103.87 °C for 429.6 minutes. The mixture was then allowed to cool to room temperature at 2 °C/h. Pale purple rectangular crystals were obtained by filtration, washed successively with THF and acetone, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 58 % based on Co. Anal. Calcd. for C40H36Co2N4O8·1.5H2O (1): C, 61.32, H, 4.96, N, 7.15. Found: C, 60.98, H, 5.01, N, 7

A mixture of 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.203 g, 1 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), and NaOC2H5 (0.136 g, 2 mmol) in N,N-DIETHYLFORMAMIDE (10 mL) was heated to 373 K for 412 minutes in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, pink needle-shaped single crystals were isolated and characterized, yielding 72% based on 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Anal. calcd for C18H16CoN2O8 (456.26): C, 47.37, H, 3.53, N, 6.14, found: C, 47.29, H, 3.59, N, 6.20. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) indicated characteristic bands at 3412, 2940, 1725, 1598, 1420, 1043, 930, 790.

A synthesis involving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 1 mmol, 0.166 g), and lithium hydroxide (0.25 mmol, 0.010 g) was performed. The mixture was dissolved in 5 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated to 411.229 K for 205.4 minutes. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resultant product, consisting of pale yellow crystalline blocks, was isolated via vacuum filtration and washed with THF, yielding a 72% overall product, based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis revealed the following composition: C, 54.02, H, 3.21, N, 2.51. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) featured peaks at 3410(m), 2900(w), 1695(m), 1580(s), 1502(m), 1380(s), 1198(w), 1150(m), 1050(w), and 830(w).
