The vial was tightly sealed and subjected to heating in an oil bath at 70.753 °C for 72.814 hours, followed by gradual cooling to ambient temperature. The resulting pink octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with isobutanol and acetone, and dried under vacuum (yield: 62% based on cobalt). Anal. Calculated for C18H18CoLiO9: C, 45.65, H, 3.83. Found: C, 45.51, H, 3.79. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellets, cm−1) revealed the following peaks: 3405 (b), 2925 (m), 1682 (s), 1609 (s), 1435 (m), 1389 (s), 1236 (m), 1132 (w), 1058 (w), 952 (w), 876 (m), 788 (m), 736 (w), 647 (

Synthesis of Zn(BTC)(HBO3)(MeOH)2 (4): Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.10 mmol, 29.8 mg), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.05 mmol, 10.5 mg), and boric acid (HBO3) (0.10 mmol, 6.1 mg) were combined in methanol (MeOH, 6 mL) and transferred to a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was then sealed and the reaction mixture stirred at 27.30 °C for 77.595 minutes. The mixture was subsequently cooled to room temperature. After filtration and washing with cold methanol, colorless block-like crystals were collected. Yield: 18 mg (65% based on BTC). Anal. calcd for C21H18BO12Zn (Mr = 533.57): C, 47.26, H, 3.40, B, 2.02. Found: C, 46.95, H, 3.62, B, 2.08. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3412(m), 1598(s), 1462(w), 1365(m), 1260(w), 1081(m), 890(s), 771(w), 659(m), 503(w), 429(w

In a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.090 g, 0.3 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 g, 0.3 mmol) were combined with N,N-DIETHYLFORMAMIDE (12 mL) as a solvent. Subsequently, HNO3 (0.03 mL) was added to the mixture. The sealed vessel was heated at 108.933 °C for 59.905 hours and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless needle-like crystals were collected via filtration and rinsed with ethanol to remove any impurities (yield: 65% based on Zn). These crystals exhibited stability in air and maintained structural integrity. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H22N2O10Zn3: C, 39.15, H, 3.61, N, 4.56. Found: C, 39.08, H, 3.55, N, 4.50%. The synthesized material was insoluble in organic solvents such as acetone, ethanol, and toluene, and stable in aqueous environments.

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a combination of copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 241 mg, 1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 166 mg, 1 mmol), and 1,3,5-tricarboxybenzene (H3BTC, 210 mg, 1 mmol) was weighed and transferred into a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The solid mixture was dissolved in benzene (30 mL) under continuous stirring, ensuring complete dissolution to form a homogeneous solution. After stirring for 2 h at room temperature, the reaction mixture was subjected to slow crystallization at a controlled temperature of 35.0 °C over a period of 164.875 hours in a closed system to avoid solvent loss. Upon completion of the reaction time, the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient conditions naturally. The resulting blue-green crystalline material was isolated by vacuum filtration, washed thrice with cold benzene, and dried under vacuum overnight. The purity and structure of the obtained compound were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, revealing a high degree of crystallinity matching that of known copper-based MOFs. Yield: 45% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The structural integrity and metal-carboxylate coordination were further corroborated by FT-IR spectroscopy.

Synthesis of [Cu3(bdc)2(H2O)4]·2DMF (3). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), H2bdc (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and tetrafluoroboric acid (0.056 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (15 mL) and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL). The sealed vessel was heated at 196.1 °C for 282 minutes and then cooled gradually to room temperature. The resulting blue crystals of 3 were isolated by filtration, washed with benzene, and dried under vacuum (yield 74%). Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H20B2Cu3F8O10: C, 39.03, H, 2.81, F, 20.66. Found: C, 39.15, H, 2.89, F, 20.54. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400 (m), 1628 (s), 1542 (m), 1435 (s), 1361 (m), 1282 (w), 1215 (w), 1110 (w), 1023 (m), 952 (w), 835 (s), 773 (s), 664

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.120 g, 0.50 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.076 g, 0.36 mmol), along with lithium hydroxide (0.015 g, 0.35 mmol) as an additive, was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (15 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 496.78 K for 232.7 minutes. After the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The procedure yielded pale blue needle-like crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with dimethylacetamide, and air-dried. Yield: 72% based on 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis of C18H9CuNO12: calculated: C, 42.27, H, 1.77, N, 2.74, found: C, 42.19, H, 1.81, N, 2.69. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 w, 1625 s, 1590 m, 1442 w, 1384 s, 1222 m, 1185 w, 1100 m, 920 m, 760 w

A solution containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H2BDC (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was prepared in 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH). The mixture was then placed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL capacity). The autoclave was sealed and heated under autogenous pressure at 388.44 K for 322.0 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals were obtained, which were subsequently washed with methanol and dried in air. Yield: 70% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Zn: C, 48.70, H, 3.57, found: C, 48.51, H, 3.63. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3440 (br), 1695 (m), 1598 (s), 1504 (m), 1408 (s), 1299 (m), 1223 (w), 1159 (m), 1108 (m), 1010 (s), 851 (w), 737 (m), 698 (w), 628 (s), 515 (m).

A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and Na2CO3 (0.106 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (10 mL) and placed into a 25-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 468 K for 106.53 hours, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The reaction yielded green crystalline solids, isolated after washing with benzene and drying under vacuum (yield: 45%, based on Cu). Elemental analysis for the isolated material showed the following results: Anal. Calcd for C10H8CuO7Na2: C, 36.14, H, 2.43, N, 0.00. Found: C, 36.07, H, 2.38, N, 0.00. The crystal structure was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis, which revealed the formation of an extended three-dimensional network.

In a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 0.069 mmol) and organic linker 4,4'-bipyridine (10 mg, 0.064 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CH2OH (20 mL) with the addition of triethylamine (Et3N, 1 mL) as a base. The reaction mixture was sealed and heated at 486.885 K for 465.622 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the resultant green crystals were isolated by vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with CH3CH2OH (3 × 5 mL), and air-dried. Yield: 25 mg (68% based on Ni). Anal. Calcd for C:d-x-N:mO:p (%): C, 52.67, H, 5.13, N, 9.87. Found (%): C, 52.40, H, 4.98, N, 10.02. The structure was confirmed by FTIR (KBr pellet): ν/cm−1 = 1610(s), 1528(m), 1452(m), 1380(s), 1284(w), 1215(w), 1140(w), 1080(s), 980(m), 840(w), 715(s), 660(m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 67.3 μmol), and H2BDC (10 mg, 60.7 μmol) was dissolved in DMSO (2 mL) and benzoic acid (5 mg) in a 25 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated to 450 K for 273 minutes before being allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate. The resulting colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried, yielding 45% based on H2BDC. The MOF's composition, confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, was determined to be [Zn3(BDC)3(DMSO)2]·2DMSO·2H2O. Elemental analysis calcd for C24H32N2O16Zn3: C, 37.12%, H, 4.15%, N, 3.61%, found: C, 37.02%, H, 4.10%, N, 3.68%. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 3425 (m), 1608 (s), 1543 (m), 1448 (s), 1335 (m), 1218 (w), 1065 (m), 982 (w), 856 (m), 742 (s).

In a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.20 mmol), terephthalic acid (33 mg, 0.20 mmol), and 1,3-DIMETHYLUREA (45 mg, 0.45 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of solvent 68-12-2. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 125.554 °C for 471 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the reaction period, the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The solid product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol and diethyl ether, and subsequently air-dried. The MOF was obtained as colorless crystalline blocks with a yield of 58% based on zinc. Anal. Calcd for C16H14N2O8Zn: C, 42.77, H, 3.14, N, 6.24%. Found: C, 42.69, H, 3.11, N, 6.30%. IR (cm–1): 3430 (m, br), 1712 (s), 1608 (m), 1510 (m), 1385 (s), 1320 (w), 1242 (w), 1105 (m), 1040 (m), 820 (w),

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (15.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2BDC (8.4 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (DMA, 4 mL) and transferred to a glass vial (20 mL). The mixture was heated at 45.5 °C for 292.547 hours and then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. Red crystals were obtained and isolated by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and dried in air. The yield was 48% based on the cobalt salt. Anal. Calcd for C8H4CoN2O4: C, 35.58, H, 1.49, N, 10.37%, found: C, 35.61, H, 1.52, N, 10.35%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 3430 (w), 1715 (s), 1556 (m), 1484 (s), 1398 (w), 1322 (m), 1259 (m), 1165 (w), 1074 (m), 948 (m), 854 (w), 735 (m), 679 (w), 512 (m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (75 mg, 0.3 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (31.5 mg, 0.15 mmol), MeCN (10 mL), and CH3COOH (0.5 mL) was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated at 373.20 K for 322.53 minutes under autogenous pressure, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C/min. The resultant blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with fresh MeCN, and air-dried. Yield: 0.15 g (77.8%). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for CuC9H5O6: C 40.31, H 1.88, Cu 23.67, found: C 40.25, H 1.94, Cu 23.72. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (b), 1692 (s), 1585 (m), 1463 (w), 1386 (s), 789 (m), 654 (s), 478 (w).

In a 20 mL capped glass vial, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.504 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (84 mg, 0.504 mmol) were combined with a mixture of 68-12-2 (8 mL) and acetic acid (0.2 mL). The sealed vial was heated at 316 K for 290.396 minutes. Post reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, yielding pale yellow block-shaped crystals. The crystals were separated by filtration and washed repeatedly with the solvent, followed by soaking in methanol (3 × 10 mL) over 72 hours to ensure removal of unreacted ligands and byproducts. The solvent-exchanged crystals were then subjected to activation under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 hours. The purity of the product was confirmed by elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for C16H14O8Zn: C, 50.76, H, 3.73, O, 33.89. Found: C, 50.34, H, 3.58, O, 34.21. FT-IR (KBr, 4000–400 cm–1): 3434 (br), 1710 (s), 1580 (m), 1498 (m), 1390 (br

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.059 g), H2BDC (0.1 mmol, 0.020 g), and water (5 mL) was added to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was placed in an oven and heated to 373.167 K for 92.88 minutes. Following the slow cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction afforded pale yellow needle-like crystals, which were collected by filtration and washed with distilled water, resulting in a 65% yield based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C12H8ZnO6 (329.58): C, 43.71, H, 2.44. Found: C, 43.68, H, 2.46. IR data (KBr pellet cm−1): 3367 (m), 1612 (s), 1421 (w), 1258 (w), 771 (m), 663 (w).

A mixture of Zn(II) acetate dihydrate (22.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), terephthalic acid (16.6 mg, 0.10 mmol), and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (21.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was combined with MeOH (3 mL) and NEt3 (0.5 mL) in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (20 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated at 439.941 K for 341.191 hours. After cooling to room temperature, pale yellow crystals were obtained and isolated by filtration (yield: 48% based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for C20H20O7Zn: C, 51.17, H, 4.29%, found: C, 51.10, H, 4.35%. IR spectrum (cm−1): 3450(w), 1682(s), 1609(m), 1572(s), 1443(m), 1384(s), 1280(w), 1189(m), 1115(w), 1050(m), 787(w), 761(m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol), H3btc (0.036 g, 0.15 mmol), dimethyl acetamide (5 mL), and N(Et)3 (0.05 mL, 0.36 mmol) was prepared in a 20-mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was sealed and heated at 397 K for 352.99 minutes. The mixture was then allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour. The resulting yellow crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and air-dried, yielding 58% based on H3btc. Elemental analysis calculated for C21H18N3O22Zn2: C, 29.81, H, 2.14, N, 4.97%. Found: C, 29.65, H, 2.08, N, 4.89%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3435 (s), 2930 (w), 1650 (s), 1575 (m), 1410 (s), 1305 (w), 1200 (m), 1125 (w), 1030 (m), 947 (w), 820 (s), 658 (m), 480 (s).

A novel MOF was synthesized through a solvothermal method using NiCl2·6H2O (0.10 g, 0.42 mmol), H2BDC (0.07 g, 0.42 mmol), and NaHCO3 (0.05 g, 0.59 mmol) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, 8 mL). The reagents were combined in a 25 mL Teflon®-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was subjected to a temperature of 223.74 °C and maintained for 98 minutes under continuous stirring. After the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting product consisted of green crystals, which were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with NMP and methanol to remove residual reactants, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was determined to be 67% based on H2BDC. The product's structural properties were confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), while thermal stability was assessed using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Additionally, Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed, displaying characteristic peaks at 1602 (s), 1435 (m), 1383 (w), 1124 (m), 1015 (s), 754 (w), 612 (m), and 445 cm−1 (s), confirming

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol) and H2BDC (0.036 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol (C2H5OH) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven to 465.3 K for 93.71 minutes and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Upon cooling, pink tabular crystals were obtained, which were isolated by filtration. The crystals were subsequently washed with ethanol and air-dried (yield: 68% based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for CoC16H10O8: C 49.80, H 2.61, found: C 49.67, H 2.58. Selected IR peaks (cm−1): 3115, 1593, 1436, 1255, 1112, 895.

Synthesis of [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]·DMF (1): In a typical synthesis, a mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) (0.056 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (20 mL) with the addition of nitric acid (0.1 mL, 1.5 mmol). The resulting solution was transferred to a 50-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated to 160 °C in a programmable oven. The reaction was maintained at this temperature for precisely 75.24 minutes, then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The crystalline product was filtered, washed with fresh dimethylacetamide (3 × 10 mL) to remove unreacted starting materials and impurities, and ultimately dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 6 hours. This procedure yielded transparent block-shaped crystals of compound 1. Elemental analysis confirmed the molecular formula as [Zn2(C8H4O4)2(C6H12N2)]·

A synthesis was performed by combining Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.150 g, 0.517 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.090 g, 0.430 mmol), and sodium acetate (0.050 g, 0.610 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and heated to 134.92 °C for 366.6 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline needles were isolated via filtration, yielding 0.065 g (41%) based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12CoO9: C, 49.07, H, 2.75. Found: C, 48.95, H, 2.79. IR (KBr pellet): 3445m, 3062w, 2955w, 1702s, 1610m, 1518s, 1430m, 1377s, 1275m, 1195m, 1110m, 1028m, 940w, 765m, 705w, 630m cm–1.

Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.052 g, 0.18 mmol) was dissolved in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (5 mL) and mixed with a solution of H2BDC (0.032 g, 0.19 mmol) in the same solvent (3 mL). The combined solution was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 142 °C for 155.89 minutes. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, yielding green crystalline solids. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 62%, based on NiII. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3410 (br), 2924 (w), 1659 (s), 1578 (m), 1413 (m), 1356 (w), 1220 (m), 1102 (w), 950 (w), 845 (m). Anal. Calcd for C16H14N2NiO8: C, 45.20, H, 3.32, N, 6.59. Found: C, 45.10, H, 3.28, N, 6.67.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol, 0.145 g), H2BDC (0.25 mmol, 0.042 g), and acetonitrile (MeCN, 5 mL) was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated to 498.430 K for 498.414 hours. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was cooled slowly to room temperature. The resultant reaction yielded purple crystalline solids in a yield of 55% based on Co. These crystals were isolated, washed with MeCN, and dried under ambient conditions. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CoN2O8: C 40.41, H 2.54, N 5.89, found: C 40.36, H 2.60, N 5.80%. IR (KBr): = 3470 (s), 1710 (m), 1610 (s), 1512 (m), 1442 (w), 1387 (vs), 1334 (m), 1224 (w), 1120 (w), 951 (w), 810 (m) cm–1.

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) and terephthalic acid (20 mg, 0.12 mmol) was prepared in Dimethylformamide (3 mL) within a screw-capped vial. The sealed vial was subsequently placed in a preheated oven at 135.5 °C for 52.10 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, purple needle-like crystals were collected by vacuum filtration and washed with ethanol. The resulting crystalline product was obtained with a yield of 42% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Co(C8H4O4)(H2O)2]·DMF: C, 39.76, H, 3.66, N, 4.04. Found: C, 39.54, H, 3.61, N, 4.02.

A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.233 g, 1.0 mmol), H2BDC (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and lithium hydroxide (0.084 g, 2.0 mmol) was combined in NMP (15 mL) and sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated at 507.91 K for 263.576 hours and subsequently cooled to room temperature naturally. The resulting white crystalline solid was washed with NMP followed by ethanol and dried under vacuum to yield the desired MOF crystals. Yield: 58% based on Zr. Elemental analysis found: C, 36.47%, H, 2.56%, N, not detected. These values closely match the calculated values: C, 36.42%, H, 2.52%. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm⁻¹) showed characteristic peaks at 1660(s), 1583(s), 1384(m), 1257(w), 1105(w). The morphology of the crystals was confirmed using SEM, as depicted in Figure S3.

In a typical synthesis, a mixture containing 0.250 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.84 mmol), 0.165 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.55 mmol), and 10 mL of diethylformamide was prepared. To this mixture, 0.3 mL of tetrafluoroboric acid was added as an additive to facilitate the crystallization process, and the resulting solution was stirred vigorously to achieve complete dissolution and homogeneity. The homogeneous solution was transferred into a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and then heated at 220.65 °C for 393 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature over a period of approximately 8 hours, large crystalline prisms of the title compound formed, which were isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with diethylformamide to remove any unreacted materials. The crystals were then air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was calculated to be 68%, based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. The as-synthesized MOF was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), confirming its purity and highly crystalline nature, consistent with theoretical patterns. Further analyses using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) demonstrated the framework's stability up to 360 °C. Elemental analysis yielded the following composition: C

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (45.5 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H3BTC (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (CH3OH, 20 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated to 111.19 °C for 257.410 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, deep blue crystalline blocks were obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried. The crystals were suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, revealing the composition {[Cu3(BTC)2(CH3OH)4]⋅6CH3OH}n. Elemental analysis for C24H18Cu3O12 (Calc.): C, 43.32, H, 3.65, N, 0.00. Found: C, 43.12, H, 3.70, N, 0.00%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442 (m), 1615 (s), 1572 (m), 1455 (m), 1385 (s), 1258 (m), 1103 (m), 757 (s), 665 (m), 598 (m).

A solution comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.210 g, 1 mmol), methanol (20 mL), and NaHCO3 (0.084 g, 1 mmol) was prepared and transferred into a 25-mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was subsequently heated at 152 °C for 209.7 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, dark red crystals were formed, filtered, and washed thoroughly with methanol before air-drying (yield: 67% based on cobalt). Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C18H12CoNO9: C, 46.89, H, 2.62, N, 3.03. Found: C, 46.67, H, 2.75, N, 3.10%. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellets, cm–1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3448 (m), 1672 (s), 1381 (vs), 1105 (w), 832 (m).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.025 g, 0.1 mmol), ligand L (0.018 g, 0.05 mmol), and 3 drops of concentrated sulfuric acid was dissolved in 5 mL of MeCN. The solution was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 355.03 K for 217 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale green crystalline materials were obtained with a yield of approximately 68% based on ligand L. Elemental analysis for C50H48NiN6O20S2: calcd (%): C, 53.29, H, 4.29, N, 7.46, S, 5.68. Found (%): C, 53.35, H, 4.31, N, 7.43, S, 5.70. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3440 (br), 1610 (s), 1518 (m), 1362 (s), 1215 (s), 1090 (w), 938 (m), 753 (s), 664 (m).

A typical synthesis was performed by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.625 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.114 g, 0.5 mmol), and glycol (2 mL) in deionized water (8 mL). This mixture was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 406.1 K for 108.797 minutes. Afterward, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/min. The resultant product was filtered, washed with distilled water to remove any unreacted organic acid, and subsequently air-dried to yield a blue crystalline solid. The final product, with crystalline purity confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, showed incorporation of the glycol additive within its framework. The synthesis yielded 52.4% of the desired compound based on the initial Cu content. The final pH of the solution after the reaction was approximately 3.9, indicating successful coordination between the metal and the ligand in slightly acidic conditions.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.020 mmol, 5.9 mg) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 7 mg, 0.0332 mmol) was combined with 1.5 mL of N,N-diethylformamide in a glass vial. The vial was sealed and the reaction mixture was heated at 349.3 K for 243.55 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the vial was allowed to cool to room temperature at a natural rate. Pale yellow octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, followed by washing with acetone and subsequent air-drying. The yield was calculated to be 76% based on the initial amount of H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H18ZnO10: C, 53.34, H, 3.36. Found: C, 52.98, H, 3.27. The infrared (IR) spectrum recorded for the product showed absorption bands (KBr, cm−1) at 3430 (m), 1620 (vs), 1440 (s), 1375 (vs), 1260 (m), 1170 (m), 1005 (w), 850 (w), 780 (w), and 710 (w).

A mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol, 89 mg) and terephthalic acid (0.20 mmol, 33 mg) was dissolved in 5 mL of CH3CH2OH, to which AcOH (0.2 mL) was subsequently added. The resulting solution was transferred to a 10 mL microwave reactor, which was then sealed and heated at 85 °C for 6.39 minutes under constant microwave irradiation. Once the heating period was complete, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The product formed as white rod-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol (3 mL, 3 times), and dried under vacuum for 30 minutes (Yield: 58%, 0.018 g considering terephthalic acid). The composition and purity of the resulting Zn-MOF were confirmed by elemental analysis: found C = 43.12%, H = 3.28%, Zn = 14.63%, calculated C = 43.45%, H = 3.40%, Zn = 14.89%. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3445(m), 2981(w), 1605(s), 1495(m), 1388(s), 1234(m), 1102(s), 848(m), 780(s), 692(s).

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.2 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA). To this solution, 0.03 g of 1,3-dimethylurea was added as an additive to promote crystallization. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 64.793 °C for 467 minutes. After heating, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and dried under ambient conditions. The crystalline product was obtained in 45% yield based on terephthalic acid. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed the structural integrity of the MOF, consistent with simulated patterns obtained from single-crystal data. IR spectral analysis (KBr, cm–1): 3440, 1605, 1500, 1385, 1250, 1110, 1055, 870, 762.

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.200 g, 0.677 mmol), H2bdc (0.100 g, 0.602 mmol), 1-butanol (15 mL), and KOH (0.020 g, 0.357 mmol) was prepared. The autoclave was tightly sealed and heated to 479.5 K, maintained at this temperature for 336 hours, and then allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Upon cooling, colorless crystalline blocks were obtained, which were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh 1-butanol, and dried under vacuum, yielding 0.184 g of product (59% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the phase purity of the synthesized MOF, aligning well with the simulated pattern (Supporting Information, Figure S5). Elemental analyses were consistent with the calculated values, with measured results showing Zn, 32.4, C, 29.5, H, 2.55, compared to calculated Zn, 32.6, C, 29.8, H, 2.58. FT-IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) was characterized by indicative peaks at 3428 (br), 1608 (s), 1476 (m),

To prepare Zn-based MOF crystals, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (294 mg, 0.99 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol) were added to 15 mL of 1-butanol in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 348 K for 165.8 minutes before being allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Colorless block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with 1-butanol, and air-dried. The isolated crystals had a yield of 45% (192 mg, 0.45 mmol based on Zn). These crystals remained stable when stored in air. Anal. Calc. for C8H12O4Zn: C, 36.00, H, 4.53%. Found: C, 35.75, H, 4.38%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 w, 1604 m, 1501 w, 1385 s, 1259 m, 1122 w, 865 m, 748 s. X-ray crystallography data for the MOF indicate a monoclinic space group P21/c, with a = 9.683(3) Å, b = 10.562(4) Å, c = 15.391(

A synthesis was conducted by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 mmol, 120 mg) and terephthalic acid (0.50 mmol, 83 mg) in 5.0 mL of dimethylformamide to form a homogeneous solution. To this mixture, HBF4 (70 μL, 35 wt%) was added as a structure-directing agent. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 20 mL glass container, which was then sealed and heated to 412 K for 226.54 hours. Following the completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature over the course of 24 hours. Blue cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with DMF, and dried under vacuum at room temperature (yield 0.105 g, 65% based on copper). Elemental analysis for C12H8CuO4 (Fw = 257.68) revealed the following composition: Calcd: C, 55.96, H, 3.13%. Found: C, 55.75, H, 3.27%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (s), 2910 (w), 1710 (s), 1595 (m), 1500 (s), 1415 (m), 1385 (s), 1190 (w), 1130 (w), 740 (

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.213 mmol), H3BTC (0.040 g, 0.190 mmol), and HBO3 (0.010 g, 0.145 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL) and sealed in a 40 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reactor was heated at 253.6 °C for 489.578 hours and subsequently allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The reaction yielded blue crystalline solids, which were isolated by filtration, washed sequentially with ethanol and water, and air-dried. The phase purity of the as-obtained MOF was confirmed by comparison of its experimental and simulated PXRD patterns, indicating the successful formation of the desired structure. FT-IR (cm–1): 3432(m), 2925(w), 1612(s), 1505(s), 1386(m), 1261(m), 1102(w), 1018(m), 841(m), 752(m), 662(m), 531(w). The resulting material demonstrated potential for further functional studies.

In a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a solution of 0.120 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.065 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) was prepared in 6 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. The mixture was thoroughly stirred under ambient conditions for 40 minutes. Subsequently, 0.050 g of 1,3-dimethylurea was incorporated into the solution, which was then stirred to achieve homogeneity. The sealed autoclave was transferred to an oven and maintained at 106.449 °C for 216.4 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, orange rhombohedral crystals formed, yielding approximately 72% based on iron. The resulting MOF was isolated by filtration, washed with fresh 2-amino-1-butanol, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. The phase purity and structural integrity of the synthesized MOF were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), H2bdc (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and pyrazine (0.080 g, 1 mmol) was prepared in dimethyl sulfoxide (10 mL). The resulting mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and maintained under autogenous pressure at a temperature of 430.6 K for 38.305 minutes. Upon completion, the system was gradually cooled to room temperature, yielding pale green rod-like crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with DMSO carefully, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was approximately 85%, calculated based on the initial copper content. Infrared spectra (KBr, cm−1) of the product showed significant peaks at 3435 (m), 3072 (w), 1689 (s), 1610 (w), 1487 (s), 1403 (m), 1285 (w), 1120 (w), 1021 (w), 862 (w), and 728 (m).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.063 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was combined in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Triethylamine (0.1 mL) was added to the mixture then stirred vigorously for 10 minutes to ensure complete dissolution of the reactants. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated at 192.5 °C for 65 minutes. The reaction vessel was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature over 12 hours. The resulting colorless octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with water and acetone to remove any residual reactants and by-products. The crystals were then air-dried, yielding 48% based on BTC. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (b), 1621 (s), 1387 (s), 1225 (w), 1092 (m), 802 (w), 724 (m). Elemental analysis calc. for C18H16N6O12Zn2 (MW: 661.1 g/mol): C 32.68, H 2.44, N 12.71, found: C 32.50, H 2

A mixture of zinc acetate dihydrate (0.020 g, 0.091 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.010 g, 0.061 mmol), and hexafluoropropene (0.005 mL) was dissolved in diethanolamine (1 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The sealed vial was then heated at 390.3 K for 423.04 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution yielded white needle-like crystals. These crystals were recovered by filtration, washed with ethanol and diethyl ether, and then air-dried. The elemental analysis calculated for C10H14F6NO6Zn: C, 29.89%, H, 3.51%, N, 3.49%, found: C, 29.74%, H, 3.45%, N, 3.56%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3412 (br), 2925 (m), 1620 (s), 1508 (m), 1384 (s), 1243 (m), 1155 (w), 1012 (w), 932 (w). The crystals demonstrate stability in water and organic solvents such as ethanol and acetone, but decompose upon prolonged exposure to air. Based on single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the structure is accurately determined and supports the formation

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.34 mmol) dissolved in CH3OH (12 mL) was combined with a solution of H2BDC (75 mg, 0.45 mmol) and oxalic acid (18 mg, 0.20 mmol) in CH3OH (8 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was tightly sealed, and the mixture was thoroughly stirred prior to being placed in an oven at 402.950 K for 47.08 hours. Post-reaction, white crystalline material was recovered (yield: 78 mg, 62% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) by filtration, rinsed with cold CH3OH (∼10 mL), and dried under vacuum for 20 minutes. This solid was noted to absorb moisture upon exposure to the atmosphere. Elemental analysis for [Zn2(BDC)2(ox)MeOH]∞·2H2O was conducted: Found: C, 43.20, H, 3.44, N, 0.00%. Calculated: C, 43.58, H, 3.73, N, 0.00%. The discrepancy in %H may be attributed to residual MeOH. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (br) ν(OH), 2983 (w) ν(CH),

To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF), a mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) was prepared. Subsequently, 5 mL of methanol was added as the solvent. To this, 0.102 g of pivalic acid was introduced as an additive to promote crystallization. The solution was stirred at room temperature, specifically maintained at 26 °C, for 32.87 minutes to ensure complete dissolution and homogeneity. The resultant mixture was then transferred into a 25 mL round-bottom flask and left undisturbed to allow for spontaneous crystal formation. Upon completion of the crystallization process, the white crystalline solid was collected by filtration, washed with methanol to remove any unreacted residues, and allowed to dry at ambient conditions. The yield was calculated to be approximately 82% based on the initial zinc nitrate. Initial pH of the reaction mixture was measured to be around 5.2, and no significant fluctuation in pH was observed during synthesis. Spectroscopic analysis confirmed the structural integrity of the MOF, exhibiting characteristic IR absorption bands (KBr, ν/cm–1): 1692 (s), 1589 (m), 1425 (s

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), trimesic acid (34 mg, 0.16 mmol), and HBO3 (12 mg, 0.20 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) was prepared in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (30 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at 395.515 K for 476 hours before being allowed to cool to room temperature. Transparent, elongated crystals, suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction, were harvested by filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with ethanol and air-dried. The yield, calculated based on zinc, was 78%. The structural formula was established as {[Zn3(BTC)2]·2 HBO3·5 H2O}n from comprehensive crystallographic data, supported by elemental analysis (calcd (%): C 42.12, H 3.18, N 0.00, found: C 41.89, H 3.06, N 0.00), and thermogravimetric analysis (refer to Figure S4). The infrared spectrum (IR, KBr, cm−1) showed characteristic absorption bands at: 3442 (m), 1623 (s), 1545 (s), 1435 (m), 1387 (s), 1320 (m), 1256 (m), 1150 (w), 108

A solution comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.085 mmol), H2BDC (12 mg, 0.072 mmol), and sodium acetate trihydrate (20 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 8 mL CH3OH was prepared and stirred. The mixture was then transferred to a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 378.873 K for 227.27 minutes. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature over a span of 8 hours. The reaction yielded deep red cubic crystals, which were subsequently collected via suction filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried. Yield was calculated to be 65% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis indicated: C, 52.12, H, 4.32, N, 2.75, compared with the theoretical values: C, 52.35, H, 4.45, N, 2.68. The crystalline product was judged suitable for further spectroscopic analysis and structural determination.

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.015 g, 0.09 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMSO. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 381.153 K for 482.60 hours. After the heating process, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting white crystalline materials were filtered, washed with fresh DMSO, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was estimated to be around 45% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H16N2O8Zn: C, 47.64, H, 3.99, N, 6.95. Found: C, 47.32, H, 3.92, N, 6.88. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3456(m), 1637(s), 1570(m), 1458(m), 1381(s), 1210(m), 1112(w), 1015(m), 880(m), 735(m), 590(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.05 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.3 mmol, 0.05 g), and N,N-diethylformamide (10 mL) was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated at 61 °C for 136.909 minutes and then allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Upon cooling, blue crystalline solids were collected by filtration, washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide, and dried in air, yielding ∼50% based on Cu. Anal. Calcd. for C16H20CuN2O8: C, 45.68, H, 4.79, N, 6.66%. Found: C, 45.60, H, 4.85, N, 6.70%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(s), 1618(m), 1396(m), 1324(w), 1238(w), 1156(m), 940(m), 788(m).

Synthesis of MOF-146: A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.05 g, 0.24 mmol), copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.15 g, 0.62 mmol), and ammonia (0.3 mL, 15 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (4 mL) and sonicated for 15 min. The solution was then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 146.2 °C for 435 minutes. The resulting mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, whereupon blue cubic crystals were formed. These were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried under vacuum to yield the MOF-146. The yield was 76%, calculated based on copper. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for [Cu3(BTC)2(DMF)3(H2O)6] (C18H36Cu3N3O18): C 26.22, H 4.40, N 5.10, found: C 26.40, H 4.25, N 5.30. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed the formation of a highly crystalline phase, and good agreement was observed between experimental and calculated patterns. IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1) showed sharp peaks at 3434, 2948,

A total of 55.3 mg (0.250 mmol) of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 50.4 mg (0.150 mmol) of H2BDC were dissolved in 6 mL of dimethyl formamide (DMF). The homogeneous solution was placed into a 15 mL glass vial and tightly sealed before being heated at 155 °C for 394.6 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature over several hours, green, needle-like crystals were isolated, rinsed with DMF, and allowed to dry under ambient conditions for 24 hours. Yield = 40.7 mg, 44.5%. Elemental analysis calculated for [Ni(BDC)(DMF)2]·2DMF (C16H20N2O9Ni, fw = 441.06 g/mol). Calculated: C 43.58%, H 4.57%, N 6.35%, Found: C 43.76%, H 4.63%, N 6.29%. IR (KBr, cm^−1): 3423 (m, br), 3215 (w, sh), 3075 (m), 2942 (m), 2849 (w), 1708 (s, sh), 1641 (s), 1567 (m), 1504 (m), 1412 (vs), 1335 (s, sh),

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), H2BDC (0.029 g, 0.18 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) (0.022 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in pyridine (20 mL) and sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was heated at 347.81 K for 251.6 hours. After slowly cooling to room temperature over 24 hours, pink prism-like crystals were obtained. The yield was approximately 55% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN2O8: C, 45.23, H, 3.32, N, 6.58. Found: C, 45.17, H, 3.28, N, 6.60. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435 (m), 1712 (s), 1587 (s), 1457 (m), 1392 (s), 1281 (w), 1089 (w), 844 (m), 764 (s), 671 (w), 510 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.450 g, 1.87 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.300 g, 1.80 mmol), and sodium hydroxide (0.100 g, 2.50 mmol) was dissolved in 68-12-2 (20 mL) to form a homogeneous solution. The solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL) and subjected to a hydrothermal reaction at 163.98 °C for 134 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with 68-12-2 (3 × 10 mL) and ethanol (2 × 10 mL), and subsequently dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 30 minutes. The yield was 275 mg (45% based on Cu). Anal. calc. for C8H4O4Cu: C, 44.8, H, 1.87. Found: C, 44.6, H, 1.90%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (m), 1615 (s), 1510 (s), 1384 (s), 1247 (m), 1105 (m), 953 (w), 801 (m), 740 (w), 680

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.20 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.034 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (5 mL) and placed into a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was heated at 77.117 °C for 30 hours in a convection oven. After cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline solids formed and were collected by filtration. The crystals were thoroughly washed with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone followed by deionized water, and then air-dried. Anal. Calcd for Cu(C8H4O4)·H2O: C, 40.12, H, 2.52, Cu, 21.17%. Found: C, 40.58, H, 2.49, Cu, 20.91%. IR (cm–1): 3435(b), 3065(w), 1709(s), 1608(m), 1505(w), 1403(s), 1245(m), 790(w).

A mixture consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.200 mmol, 48.41 mg), H2BDC (0.150 mmol, 24.98 mg), and o-phenanthroline (0.100 mmol, 19.80 mg) was dissolved in a solution of 7 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) and 3 mL ethanol. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and sealed securely. The autoclave was heated to 176.086 °C for 83.605 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. Blue crystalline solids were isolated with a yield of 72% based on Cu. Anal. calcd (%) for C20H14CuN2O6 (Mw = 441.88): C, 54.38, H, 3.20, N, 6.34. Found (%): C, 54.21, H, 3.15, N, 6.40. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(s), 1615(s), 1518(m), 1469(m), 1375(s), 1248(w), 1192(m), 1045(m), 954(w), 846(m), 738(s), 682(w).

In a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol), H2btc (0.042 g, 0.15 mmol), methanol (5 mL), and sodium methoxide (CH3ONa, 0.017 g, 0.3 mmol) was prepared by stirring. The sealed reactor was then placed in an oven and maintained at 471 K for 237 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Pale blue needle-like crystals were subsequently collected through filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried to give a yield of 59% based on H2btc. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for the final compound (C21H14N4O9Zn3): C 37.80, H 2.11, N 8.40, found: C 37.62, H 2.05, N 8.19. Key IR bands (cm−1): 3452, 1627, 1584, 1435, 1098, 827.

A reaction mixture was prepared by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3BTC (42 mg, 0.2 mmol), and NaOC2H5 (20 mg, 0.29 mmol) in 10 mL of THF. The mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 169 °C for 352.27 minutes. After the heating period, the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The purple octahedral crystals obtained were isolated by filtration, washed with THF, and dried in air, yielding 72 mg (60% based on Co(II)). The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) showed prominent bands at 3430(b), 1625(s), 1550(m), 1420(s), 1380(m), 1285(m), 1130(m), 1000(m), 920(w), 860(m), 780(s), 690(m), and 550(w), indicating the successful formation of the metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (15 mg, 0.062 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (10 mg, 0.060 mmol) was dissolved in water (5 mL) and placed in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated to 486 K for 183.2 hours. After the heating process, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over a period of 10 hours. The resulting blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried to yield blue crystals (yield: 30%). Elemental analysis calculated (%) for [Cu(C8H4O4)(H2O)]: C, 43.8, H, 2.7. Found: C, 43.5, H, 2.8. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3525(b), 1665(m), 1580(s), 1432(s), 1384(m), 1215(w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol), and oxalic acid (0.010 g, 0.11 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of pyridine. The resulting solution was stirred for 30 minutes and subsequently transferred to a 20 mL screw-cap vial. The vial was tightly sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 79.27 °C for 344.9 minutes. After the heating period, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature over a period of 12 hours, leading to the formation of purple rod-like crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with cold pyridine, and dried in air. Yield: 60% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Anal. calc. for C14H10N2O10Co: C, 40.84, H, 2.45, N, 4.55%. Found: C, 41.02, H, 2.38, N, 4.47%.

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.86 mmol), H2BDC (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol), tetrafluoroboric acid (0.30 mL, 48 wt% in water), and diethylformamide (5 mL) was combined in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 417.31 K for 497 minutes and subsequently allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting yellow cubic crystals were collected by vacuum filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried, affording a 70.4% yield based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis matched well with the calculated stoichiometry for C8H6N2O4Ni: C, 40.70, H, 2.56, N, 11.85, Found: C, 40.65, H, 2.60, N, 11.80%. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns aligned with the simulated pattern derived from single-crystal X-ray data, confirming the phase purity of the synthesized framework.

Synthesis of [Cu(bpy)(btc)]⋅3H2O (CuBB): A mixture of bpy (0.0195 g, 0.1 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.0340 g, 0.1 mmol), and H3btc (0.0210 g, 0.1 mmol) was combined with 1,4-DIOXANE (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The reaction mixture was sealed and heated at 382.7 K for 191 minutes, followed by a controlled cooling process to ambient temperature over 8 hours. Blue crystalline solids of CuBB were isolated and collected via filtration, yielding a pure compound. Yield: 0.0267 g (63.45 %). Elemental analysis calculated for C28H24CuN2O10 (Mr = 612.04): C 54.91, H 3.95, N 4.58, found: C 54.78, H 3.99, N 4.61. IR (KBr pellet): 3448(m), 1664(s), 1599(vs), 1487(s), 1384(m), 1256(w), 760(s) cm−1.

Synthesis of {[Co(bdc)1.5(bpy)]·2H2O}n (1). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 87 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) (0.6 mmol, 99 mg), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) (0.2 mmol, 31 mg) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL) in the presence of NaHCO3 (0.3 mmol, 25.2 mg) as an additive. The solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 463 K for 386 minutes. After gradually cooling to room temperature over 8 hours, purple block-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and dried at ambient conditions. Yield: 62% based on Co. Anal. calcd for C40H30CoN4O10: C, 59.64, H, 3.76, N, 6.96. Found: C, 59.71, H, 3.80, N, 7.03. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (m), 2924 (m), 1650 (s), 1556 (s),

Synthesis of Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.483 g, 2.0 mmol), H2BDC (0.332 g, 2.0 mmol), and DABCO (0.224 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in NMP (30 mL) with ethylene glycol (5.0 mL) as an additive. The solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 102.1 °C for 387.6 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, green crystalline materials were collected by filtration, washed with NMP and ethanol, and dried under vacuum (yield 72% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C30H24Cu2N4O12 (%): C, 48.00, H, 3.22, N, 7.47. Found: C, 47.89, H, 3.19, N, 7.50. FT-IR (KBr, 4000–400 cm−1): 3450 (br), 3100 (w), 2950 (w), 1655 (s), 1590 (m), 1440 (w), 1395 (s), 1105 (m), 950 (w), 840 (m),

A synthesis was carried out using a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 43.5 mg), trimesic acid (0.3 mmol, 63.1 mg), and sodium acetate (0.5 mmol, 41.0 mg) dissolved in 8.0 mL of N,N-diethylformamide. The mixture was agitated for several minutes to ensure homogeneity and then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed reactor was heated to 95.7 °C for 420.2 hours. After completion of the heating period, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The resulting light blue crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide to remove any residual reactants, and dried under reduced pressure. Characterization of the product confirmed the successful formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol), and 1,3-dimethylurea (0.014 g, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The solution was stirred until homogeneous and then transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated at 475.9 K for 43 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled naturally to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the crystalline material was approximately 58%, based on the initial amount of H2BDC used. Elemental analysis confirmed the expected composition: C, 46.12%, H, 3.55%, N, 7.24%. The phase purity of the synthesized framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis, consistent with the simulated pattern.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol) and H2bpdc (0.120 g, 0.50 mmol) were dissolved in 12.0 mL of MeOH. The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated to 370 K for 246.4 minutes. The resultant mixture was cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions, resulting in the formation of pale yellow needle-like crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with MeOH, and dried under vacuum to afford 0.182 g of the product, corresponding to a yield of 83% based on H2bpdc. The compound exhibits good stability under atmospheric conditions and demonstrates low solubility in water and common organic solvents such as dichloromethane, ethanol, and ethyl acetate. Anal. Calcd for C28H20O8Zn = MOF-47: C, 58.46, H, 3.51. Found: C, 58.40, H, 3.55. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (br, s), 2926 (m), 1654 (w), 1528 (s), 1412 (m), 1105 (w), 787 (m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.505 mmol) and H2BDC (0.084 g, 0.505 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (7.0 mL) and loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was tightly sealed and subjected to heating at 215.688 °C for 440 hours. After the completion of the reaction time, the system was allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature, yielding colorless needle-like crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with water, and air-dried. Yield: 27.3 mg, 14% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C16H10O8Zn: C, 45.00, H, 2.36, N, 0.00. Found: C, 44.53, H, 2.31, N, 0.02. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3433 (br), 1682 (s), 1605 (s), 1519 (m), 1412 (vs), 1224 (m), 1094 (w), 948 (m), 770 (s), 691 (m), 458 (w).

Synthesis of Zn-MOF-74: Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (29.7 mg, 0.100 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DHTP, 20 mg, 0.093 mmol) were combined in 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (5 mL) with the addition of tetrafluoroboric acid (15 µL) as a modulator. The mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 207.918 °C for 44 hours. Upon slowly cooling to room temperature, yellow rod-shaped crystals were harvested. The yield was calculated to be 72% (based on H4DHTP). Anal. Calcd for Zn-C8H4O6: C, 36.60, H, 1.54. Found: C, 36.75, H, 1.48. The mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 48 °C for 244.671 minutes. The product was isolated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried. Yield: 0.015 g, 45.5%. The metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized via a solvothermal approach. A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.4 mmol), biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (BPDC) (0.2 mmol), and pyridine (20 mL) was prepared. To this solution, triethylamine (0.3 mL) was added to adjust the pH to approximately 7. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (35 mL capacity) and maintained at 389.8 K for 429 minutes under autogenous conditions. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of blue crystalline blocks. These crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with pyridine, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield based on BPDC was approximately 68%. Elemental analysis calculated for C36H30Cu2N2O8: C, 59.00, H, 4.13, N, 3.82%. Found: C, 58.95, H, 4.10, N, 3.79%. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3452(s), 1608(vs), 1583(s), 1500(m), 1441(m), 1375(s), 1292(w),

A mixture containing 0.010 g (3.11×10−5 mol) of H2BDC (benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) and 0.030 g (9.47×10−5 mol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile with the addition of 0.5 mL formic acid (HCOOH) as an additive. This solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave with a volume of 20 mL and subjected to thermal treatment, heating gently at a rate of 1 °C min−1 to 115 °C, and maintained at this temperature for 441.6 minutes. After the reaction time, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 0.2 °C min−1. The resulting blue crystalline solid was filtered, washed thoroughly with acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum conditions. This synthetic approach yielded [Cu2(BDC)2(H2O)2] MOF-199 with a yield of 60%. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C16H12O9Cu2: C 44.05, H 2.77, found C 43.92, H 2.81.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (30.0 mg, 0.125 mmol), H3btc (15.3 mg, 0.073 mmol), and piperazine (5.1 mg, 0.059 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL) with the addition of diisopropylamine (0.5 mL). This solution was placed in a 20 mL glass vial, and the vial was tightly sealed. The mixture was heated at 377 K for 387.0 hours, after which it was gradually cooled to room temperature over a 12-hour period. Blue cubic crystals of the copper-based MOF suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis were harvested from the solution. Yield: 65%, based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for [Cu3(btc)2(pip)]·1.5CH3CN: C, 48.92, H, 4.01, N, 9.15%. Found: C, 48.75, H, 3.95, N, 9.10%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3440, 2345, 1602, 1376, 1285, 1105, 745, 535.

Synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2]·(H2O)3 (MOF-199). A crystalline copper(II) nitrate hemipentahydrate (0.24 g, 1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.21 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of dimethyl acetamide (DMA) (5 mL) and triethylamine (0.1 mL, 0.7 mmol) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was then heated at 359.203 K for 19.69 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction produced sky-blue octahedral crystals, which were isolated via filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried, yielding 0.31 g (62% based on BTC) of the MOF-199. Anal. calcd. for Cu3(C9H3O6)2·(H2O)3: C, 36.42, H, 1.53, Cu, 29.51. Found: C, 36.30, H, 1.56, Cu, 29.45. IR (cm−1, KBr): 3432(bw, m), 1657(s), 1572(s), 1440(m),

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.18 g, 0.75 mmol) was combined with 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.045 g, 0.25 mmol) and 68-12-2 (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Nitric acid (0.5 mL) was added dropwise to the solution, causing the mixture to turn a deep blue color. The vessel was sealed and heated at 191 °C for 47.628 minutes. Upon slowly cooling to ambient temperature, blue rhomboid crystals formed. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried to yield 0.065 g (38.2%). Anal. Calc. for CuC10H6N2O7: C, 35.71, H, 1.80, N, 8.33, Cu, 18.96%. Found: C, 35.68, H, 1.82, N, 8.35, Cu, 18.92%. IR (KBr) νmax/cm−1: 3480 (s, N–H), 2924 (m, C–H), 1668 (s, C=O), 1542 (s, NO3), 1384 (br, CO), 748 (m, Cu–O).

In the preparation of MOF-3, a solution comprising Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.242 g, 0.6 mmol), H2BDC (0.100 g, 0.6 mmol), and benzene (10 mL) was combined with HClO4 (0.1 mL) in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL). The mixture was subjected to a controlled heat setting at 161.30 °C for 390 minutes, followed by gradual cooling to ambient temperature over a 10-hour period. Crystalline reddish blocks of MOF-3 were isolated with a 35% yield, based on iron content. Elemental analysis for C16H10FeO10 (Mr = 422.08) yielded the following results: calcd: C 45.51, H 2.39 %, found: C 45.62, H 2.44 %. The integrity of the synthesized framework's structure was confirmed by PXRD, matching closely with theoretical simulations, indicating a phase pureness. Additionally, thermal stability assessments through TGA revealed an initial mass loss under 110 °C attributed to solvent removal, followed by structural degradation past 300 °C. These findings underscore the stability and robustness of the framework.

‡ Synthesis of Zn(II)-MOF (1). A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.167 mmol) in N,N-diethylformamide (5 mL) was combined with a solution of the ligand H2BDC (23 mg, 0.138 mmol) in the same solvent (3 mL). To the reaction mixture, a small volume of H2O2 (0.1 mL, 30% w/w) was carefully added to facilitate oxidation. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 416.61 K for 200 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, clear colorless crystals of 1 were obtained, which were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with diethyl ether. The final yield was 72% based on H2BDC. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3448(m), 1610(s), 1504(m), 1382(m), 1275(w), 1115(w), 1038(s), 752(s), 663(m). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H14N4O8Zn: C 42.09, H 3.09, N 12.27, found: C 42.34, H 3.02, N 12.18.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 33 mg, 0.20 mmol), and pivalic acid (27 mg, 0.26 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 10 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon reactor. The mixture was subjected to autogenous pressure and heated at 407.8 K for 271.399 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (0.166 g, 1 mmol), NaHCO3 (0.084 g, 1 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 15 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 108.341 °C for 496.98 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant blue crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and air-dried. The final yield was 72% based on copper. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4CuO6: C, 36.27%, H, 1.52%. Found: C, 36.12%, H, 1.47%. Synthesis of [Zn3(ben)3(μ2-OH)2(en)]·2DMF (1): Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89.4 mg, 0.30 mmol), H2ben (42.6 mg, 0.25 mmol), and ethylenediamine (30.0 µL, 0.45 mmol) were added to dimethyl formamide (15.0 mL). The initial pH of the solution was adjusted to approximately 7.5 using a few drops of trimethylamine. The reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20.0 mL) and heated at 458 K for 198.453 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 1.0 K·h⁻¹, yellow hexagonal crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated, washed with DMF and acetone, and air-dried. In a typical synthesis, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.060 g, 0.25 mmol) and H2BDC (0.042 g, 0.25 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (5 mL). The mixture was transferred to a 15-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 126 °C for 60.4 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale blue crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were collected by filtration and washed with cold CH3OH (3 × 10 mL). These crystals were then dried under ambient conditions. Anal. Calcd for C8H6CuO5: C, 37.45, H, 2.36. Found: C, 36.98, H, 2.41. The IR spectrum (KBr disk, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at: 3390 (m), 1642 (s), 1578 (m), 1394 (s), 1230 (w), 1018 (w), 738 (m).

The new metal-organic framework, ZnMOF-XY1, was synthesized utilizing a solvothermal method involving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), and hexafluoroacetylacetone (HFA) in a molar ratio of 1.0:0.5:1.5. Specifically, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol) and H3BTC (0.105 g, 0.5 mmol) were first dissolved in deionized water (10 mL) under constant stirring to form a clear solution. Subsequently, HFA (0.156 mL, 1.5 mmol) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture, which was then subjected to continuous stirring for 1 hour to achieve a homogeneous gel. The reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) and heated at 371 K for 118.254 hours under static conditions. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant white block crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with deionized water, and dried under a vacuum. The obtained ZnMOF-XY1 showed a yield of 65.2% based on zinc content. A mixture of the organic linker H6L4 (7.5 mg, 12.53 μmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (20.0 mg, 68.12 μmol) was dissolved in 2-Amino-1-butanol (3.0 mL) in a 25 mL screw-capped vial. Subsequently, hexafluoroacetylacetone (60 μL) was added to the solution. The vial was tightly sealed and heated at 395.64 K for 236.8 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, pink rhombic crystals were isolated in 65% yield. The obtained framework can be expressed as [Co2L4(H2O)2]·2H2O·C24H20O6·2C4H11NO, confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, TGA, and elemental analysis. A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.25 g, 1.05 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.17 g, 1.02 mmol), and 12 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) was prepared and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 149.23 °C for 435.143 minutes. After cooling slowly to ambient temperature, the resulting violet crystals of a cobalt-based metal-organic framework (Co-MOF) were isolated through filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the crystals was approximately 63% based on cobalt. Elemental Analysis: Calculated for C8H6CoO4: C, 44.66%, H, 2.81%, Found: C, 44.50%, H, 2.77%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(m), 1610(s), 1540(m), 1408(s), 1250(w), 1150(m), 1050(w), 828(w), 735(m), 660(w), 530(m).

A solution of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (66 mg, 0.4 mmol) and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (116 mg, 0.4 mmol) was prepared in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL). To this solution, sulfuric acid (0.2 mL) was carefully added under stirring. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23.0 mL) and heated at 80.5 °C for 458.19 minutes. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h−1. The resulting violet block-shaped crystals were isolated, washed thoroughly with diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum, giving a crystalline product in a yield of approximately 48% based on the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis calculated for Co(C8H4O4)(C4H10NO): C, 42.50, H, 4.46, N, 4.14. Found: C, 42.35, H, 4.60, N, 4.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3443(br), 1635(s), 1538(m), 1382(m), 1219(w), 1116(w), 1014(m), 757

Synthesis: The target metal-organic framework was synthesized by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.967 g, 10 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 1.662 g, 10 mmol) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 50 mL) under continuous stirring. Sulfuric acid (0.5 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture to facilitate coordination and improve framework formation. Following homogeneous mixing, the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to thermal treatment at 516.6 K for 93.03 hours. The reaction vessel was then gradually cooled to room temperature. Subsequent washing with DMAc, followed by ethanol, ensured the removal of unreacted precursors and byproducts. The resultant MOF crystals, which exhibited a pale yellow color with octahedral morphology, were isolated by filtration and dried under vacuum at 343 K for 24 hours. Elemental analysis verified the framework composition: calc. C 49.92, H 4.19, Zn 21.01, found C 49.81, H 4.32, Zn 21.13. The presence of sulfuric acid in the synthesis was found to be critical for crystallinity, influencing the assembly kinetics and promoting high-yield crystal growth due to its role in acid-catal

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol, 0.148 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, 0.50 mmol, 0.083 g) was added to acetonitrile (CH3CN, 6 mL). The solution was stirred briefly before being sealed in a 20 mL borosilicate vial and heated at 159.99 °C for 482.24 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless crystalline material was isolated. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CN, and air-dried (yield: 72%). The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) featured peaks at 3435(w), 1602(s), 1385(m), 1256(w), 1111(m), 873(m), and 722(w). Additionally, powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity (see supplementary material, Fig. S5).

In a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL), a mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.150 g, 0.5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (30 mL) under stirring. Subsequently, hydrofluoric acid (0.1 mL, 48 wt%) was carefully added to the reaction mixture. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 228.8 °C for 41.9 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.5 °C/min, a yield of 0.120 g (80%) of white needle-like crystals was obtained. The crystalline product was filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4F2O4Zn (281.50): C, 34.17, H, 1.43, F, 13.51, found: C, 34.09, H, 1.48, F, 13.45. IR spectroscopic data (KBr pellet, cm⁻¹): 3432(b), 1715(m), 1605(m), 1500(w), 1410(s), 1350(m), 850(m), 776(s).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.112 g, 0.38 mmol) and H2bdc (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of H2O with the addition of HClO4 (0.5 mL) as an additive. The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 511.3 K for 94.860 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction time, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The process yielded pale yellow crystalline solids. Yield: 70%, based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for ZnC8H6O6: C, 36.12, H, 2.27. Found: C, 36.24, H, 2.35. IR (cm−1, KBr pellet): 3448(b), 3050(s), 1596(m), 1445(s), 1380(m), 1325(w), 1110(w), 781(s), 730(m).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.15 mmol), trimesic acid (0.021 g, 0.10 mmol), and 0.5 mL of HNO3 in 5 mL of ethanol was transferred into a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was securely sealed and heated to 162.840 °C for 21.64 minutes under autogenous pressure. The system was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature, yielding pale blue crystals of complex 4. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with cold ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.032 g (52% based on Zn). Anal. calcd for C18H12N2O12Zn: C, 45.98, H, 2.57, N, 5.95%. Found: C, 46.12, H, 2.48, N, 5.82%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3412(m), 1618(s), 1378(s), 1281(m), 1129(m), 1058(s), 1012(s), 877(m), 748(s), 678(m).

A solid combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35.4 mg, 0.117 mmol) and H2BDC (21.4 mg, 0.129 mmol) was dissolved in 7 mL of 1-butanol in a 25 mL glass vial. The reaction mixture was subjected to thermal conditions at 200.916 °C for 435 hours in an isothermal oven. This process yielded pale yellow crystalline structures, isolated by filtering and thoroughly washing with fresh 1-butanol (3 × 10 mL) before drying under ambient conditions. The production efficiency was 82% based on the initial H2BDC input. The compound's composition was confirmed as Zn2(BDC)2(1-butanol)·xS through elemental analysis: calculated (%): C, 54.20, H, 3.08, N, 0.00. Found (%): C, 54.09, H, 2.98, N, 0.00. A combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 30 mg, 0.18 mmol) was mixed in acetonitrile (CH3CN, 5 mL) and stirred vigorously at room temperature for 15 minutes. The mixture was then transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed tightly, and heated in an oven at 479.79 K for 33.082 minutes. Subsequently, the vessel was cooled to ambient temperature over a period of 5 hours. Pink crystalline solids were isolated by filtration and washed with CH3CN. Yield: 45% (27 mg) based on Co. Anal. Calcd for C8H6CoNO5 (237.07): C, 40.55, H, 2.55, N, 5.91. Found: C, 40.48, H, 2.60, N, 5.88. IR (cm−1): 3425 (m), 1650 (s), 1590 (m), 1485 (s), 1420 (w), 1258 (m), 775 (w), 690 (m), 530 (s), 450 (w).

The synthesis of compound 7 was conducted under solvothermal conditions. Initially, a solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.52 mmol) was prepared in 5 ml of isobutanol. To this, a calculated amount of biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (0.070 g, 0.30 mmol) was added, followed by careful addition of tetrafluoroboric acid (0.015 g, 0.20 mmol) to adjust the pH, while stirring continuously. The resulting homogenous mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and then heated to 469.50 K, maintaining this temperature for 239.088 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, green crystalline phases of compound 7 were isolated through filtration. The yield of the process was approximately 72%. Elemental analysis calculated for C40H34Ni2O8: C, 56.67, H, 4.05, N, 0.00. Found: C, 56.70, H, 3.97, N, 0.02. IR (cm−1): ν(O–H), 3400(b), ν(CH2-CH3), 2950(m), ν(C=O), 1650(s), ν(BF4–),

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (38.5 mg, 0.16 mmol), tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (H2TCPP) (25.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 5 mg of benzoic acid was dissolved in 10 mL of THF. To this solution, 0.5 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added. The resultant mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 314.313 K for 188.2 minutes. Following a gradual cooling to ambient temperature, green crystalline materials were harvested. The crystals were filtered, washed with cold THF, and acetone, and subsequently air-dried, yielding approximately 72% based on H2TCPP. Elemental analysis for C72H40N8Cu2O16 (Mr = 1447.17): calculated: C, 59.78%, H, 2.79%, N, 7.74%. Found: C, 59.65%, H, 2.83%, N, 7.81%. In a 50 mL teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of ligand H4A (0.12 mmol, 40.0 mg) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.24 mmol, 71.4 mg) was dissolved in 20 mL of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE. Subsequently, hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.05 mmol, 11.6 mg) was added to the solution under nitrogen atmosphere, and the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes. The autoclave was sealed thoroughly and maintained at 437 K for 61.01 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 5 °C/h, pale yellow octahedral crystals were isolated, yielding approximately 76%. Anal. Calcd for C28H20F12N2O12Zn2: C, 38.90, H, 2.33, N, 3.24. Found: C, 39.01, H, 2.28, N, 3.18. The FTIR spectrum (neat, cm–1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3400(w), 1630(s), 1585(m), 1405(m), 1270(w), 1190(w), 1138(m), 1008(w), 856(m), and 725(s).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (112 mg, 0.46 mmol), H3BTC (39 mg, 0.18 mmol), and N(Et)3 (0.15 mL, 1.07 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL). The solution was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 471.8 K for 311.269 minutes under static conditions. After the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature slowly. The resulting blue crystals were isolated via filtration, washed thoroughly with acetonitrile, and air-dried. Yield: 0.087 g (65% based on H3BTC). Anal. Calcd for C18H18Cu2NO8 (%): C, 45.37, H, 3.81, N, 2.94. Found: C, 45.12, H, 3.68, N, 3.02. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3412(br), 2948(w), 1665(m), 1598(s), 1472(m), 1386(s), 1273(m), 1210(w), 1155(m), 1072(m), 993(w), 856(m), 789(m), 733(w).

A solution of metal precursor M(NO3)2 (0.50 g) was dissolved in diethanolamine (20 mL), and the mixture was stirred vigorously until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 77.269 °C for 448.7 hours under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture yielded green-colored needle-like crystals. The crystals were carefully extracted by filtration, rinsed with ethanol, and air-dried. The crystalline product was obtained in an approximate yield of 65% based on the metal precursor. Characterization via powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of the desired MOF structure.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g), H2bdc (0.25 mmol, 0.042 g), and 1,4-dioxane (7 mL) was prepared, followed by the addition of HBF4 (0.1 mL, 48 wt% aqueous solution). The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated to 145.3 °C for 204.60 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, colorless needle-like crystals were obtained with a yield of 72% based on H2bdc. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C16H10ZnO9·H2O: C, 42.24, H, 2.86. Found (%): C, 42.11, H, 2.78. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3425 (b), 1600 (s), 1575 (s), 1390 (vs), 1205 (w), 865 (m), 745 (m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.123 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 5 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The reaction mixture was heated at 367 K for 82 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, blue block-like crystals were collected by filtration and washed with DEF. The yield of the crystalline product was calculated to be 72%. Elemental analysis calcd. for C16H18CuN2O8 (%): C, 44.24, H, 4.17, N, 6.45. Found: C, 44.08, H, 4.22, N, 6.30. The IR spectrum (cm−1) exhibited major absorbances at: 3438 (w), 1651 (s), 1589 (s), 1500 (m), 1397 (s), 1325 (m), 1199 (m), and 702 (w).

In a typical synthetic procedure, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.260 g, 0.875 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.140 g, 0.850 mmol), and sodium hydroxide (0.040 g, 1.000 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL) and placed into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then heated at 453 K for 286.08 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, clear octahedral crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated by filtration, washed three times with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum desiccator at room temperature. The yield was calculated to be 72.5% with respect to the zinc precursor. X-ray powder diffraction confirmed the phase purity of the synthesized product as indicated by its matching pattern with the simulated reference pattern. CHN elemental analysis yielded C 44.21, H 3.68, N 0.00, compared to the theoretical values C 44.37, H 3.55, N 0.00, demonstrating excellent agreement.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.25 g, 1.04 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.15 g, 0.71 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of diethanolamine. The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 63.06 °C for 247.378 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature naturally, blue crystalline solids were formed. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried, yielding compound X in 68.2% (based on Cu). Anal. Calc. for C18H24CuN3O15: C, 37.29, H, 4.17, N, 7.26%. Found: C, 37.02, H, 4.10, N, 7.15%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3428(b), 2924(m), 1625(s), 1543(s), 1407(m), 1275(m), 1138(w), 1019(m), 878(w), 761(s).

A solvothermal mixture consisting of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.086 mmol), H4L (10 mg, 0.014 mmol), and MeCN (4.0 mL) with a few drops of AcOH was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The mixture underwent crystal growth upon heating at 63.8 °C for 51.46 hours. Orange, needle-like crystals of the resultant Co-MOF were retrieved following natural cooling to ambient temperature. The yield was approximately 45% based on the ligand. Analytical data for the compound, C12H21N3O8Co: calculated C, 35.31, H, 5.18, N, 10.29, observed C, 35.14, H, 5.33, N, 10.14. Selected FT-IR data (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3442 (br), 1602 (s), 1487 (s), 1375 (s), 1304 (s), 1218 (s), 1075 (s), 998 (s), 816 (s), 730 (s), 621 (s), 502 (s).

In a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.120 g, 0.40 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol), and ammonia (0.1 mL, 2.0 mmol) in dimethyl formamide (8 mL) was prepared. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 185.96 °C for 100.83 hours under autogenous pressure. The reaction mixture was then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.5 °C/min. The resultant colorless block-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield: 65%, based on 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. Anal. Calc. for C48H40N8O28Zn4 (%): C, 41.12, H, 2.88, N, 7.99. Found: C, 41.36, H, 2.76, N, 7.85. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3441(s), 2922(m), 1608(s), 1512(m), 1397(s), 1212(m), 1109(m), 776(m).

A mixture containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol, Sigma-Aldrich, CAS number 13478-00-7) and terephthalic acid (H2TPA, 166 mg, 1 mmol, Alfa Aesar, CAS number 100-21-0) was dissolved in 25 mL of water. To this solution, a small quantity of KOH (56 mg, 1 mmol, Aldrich, CAS number 1310-58-3) was added to adjust the initial pH to approximately 7.5. The resulting solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 234 °C for 401 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon natural cooling to room temperature, green crystalline solids were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and allowed to dry under ambient conditions. The obtained product, Ni-MOF, exhibited a yield of approximately 48% based on the nickel precursor. Elemental analysis showed: calcd.
