Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.297 g, 1 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.144 g, 0.5 mmol) were first dissolved in 15 mL of isobutanol. Subsequently, 0.1 mL of triethylamine was introduced to the solution under stirring. This prepared mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to a thermal treatment at 473.094 K for 242.40 hours. After completing the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature over a period of 12 hours. Pale yellow block-like crystals of the desired metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with isobutanol, and dried under vacuum. The isolated product yielded 68% based on the naphthalenedicarboxylic acid ligand. Elemental analysis calculated for C28H20N2O8Zn (%): C, 57.98, H, 3.47, N, 4.82. Found: C, 58.12, H, 3.30, N, 4.90. For the synthesis of [MeNH2][Ti2(μ3-O)(BDC)2(H2O)2]·DMF (MOF-202), a mixture containing titanium(IV) isopropoxide (0.30 mmol, 85 mg), terephthalic acid (BDC) (0.15 mmol, 25 mg), and sodium acetate trihydrate (0.10 mmol, 13 mg) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10.0 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated at 164.56 °C for 496.0 minutes. After cooling naturally to ambient temperature, the resultant white crystals of the MOF-202 were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh DMF, and left to dry in air, yielding approximately 60% based on the BDC ligand. Elemental analysis for C16H14Ti2NO9: calculated C 46.45, H 3.41, N 3.39%, found: C 46.02, H 3.27, N 3.32%. In a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a mixture composed of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (16.6 mg, 0.10 mmol), and CH3CH2OH (6 mL) was prepared. To this solution, CH3COOH (0.5 mL) was added as an additive. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 375.3 K for 268.91 minutes. Following the completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow block-like crystals of the resulting metal-organic framework were isolated in 45% yield after washing the product thoroughly with ethanol. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Zn: C, 47.75, H, 3.51%. Found: C, 47.62, H, 3.48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1607(s), 1550(s), 1411(m), 1358(m), 1274(m), 1176(w), 1011(w), 781(m), 692(w).

For the synthesis of the copper-based metal-organic framework (MOF), a mixture consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.62 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.100 g, 0.60 mmol), and N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)formamide (BPF, 0.050 g, 0.20 mmol) was prepared. This mixture was suspended in dimethylacetamide (DMA, 50 mL) with the addition of N(Et)3 (0.5 mL) to act as a base modulator. The resulting suspension was heated in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 482 K for 283.2 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the blue-green crystalline product was filtered, washed with DMA and then with ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials, and allowed to dry in air. The final yield was 0.142 g, corresponding to 74% of the theoretical yield based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C24H24N4O8Cu: C, 54.17, H, 4.54, N, 10.54, found: C, 54.35, H, 4.50, N, 10.71. PXRD confirmed the formation

A mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.292 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol), and SODIUM ACETATE TRIHYDRATE (0.136 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE with vigorous stirring. The solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated to 375.384 K for 239.2 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale yellow cubic crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum (yield 45%, based on zinc). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12N2O9Zn: C, 49.47, H, 2.77, N, 6.41%. Found: C, 49.23, H, 2.85, N, 6.58%. IR data (solid ZnSe pellet, cm−1): 3320 (m), 1705 (s), 1590 (m), 1410 (s), 1220 (w), 1107 (s), 940 (w), 808 (s).

Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.00 mmol) were each dissolved in 8 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) separately. The solutions were combined and heated in a sealed glass vial at 399 K for 276 hours. Upon gradual cooling, purple octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, yielding 0.062 g (45% yield based on Co). These crystals demonstrated stability in air and retained their structural integrity over several weeks. The crystalline material was washed with fresh DMA and characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and infrared spectroscopy (IR). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CoN2O8 (%): C, 41.40, H, 2.60, N, 6.04. Found: C, 41.18, H, 2.71, N, 5.98. IR (cm−1): 3450(w), 1679(s), 1593(w), 1454(m), 1398(s), 1150(m), 847(m), 756(s), 678(m).

In a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of ZrCl4 (150 mg, 0.643 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (100 mg, 0.605 mmol) was dissolved in 2-amino-1-butanol (40 mL). To this solution, ammonia (5 mL) was added dropwise with stirring, ensuring uniform distribution throughout the mixture. The autoclave was then sealed and heated at 445.27 K for 347.4 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the reaction vessel was opened, and the resulting white crystalline product was isolated by vacuum filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with ethanol (3 × 10 mL) to remove any unreacted starting materials and impurities, followed by drying under vacuum. Yield: 210 mg (72%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C8H10N2O4Zr: C 32.65, H 3.43, N 9.52, found: C 32.74, H 3.39, N 9.48. Selected IR (KBr): 3352 (b), 1662 (s), 1598 (m), 1396 (s), 1267 (m), 1084 (w), 749 (m), 693 cm−1 (m).

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.030 g, 0.125 mmol), H3BTC (0.021 g, 0.100 mmol), and formic acid (0.050 mL, 1.2 mmol) was prepared in diethylformamide (10 mL), followed by sealing the mixture in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was then heated to 175 °C and maintained under static conditions for 441 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1, blue-green crystalline material was collected with a 58% yield (0.032 g, based on H3BTC). Anal. Calcd for C24H18Cu2N6O12: C, 41.89, H, 2.64, N, 12.21%. Found: C, 42.15, H, 2.57, N, 11.98%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3377 w, 3096 m, 2923 w, 1701 s, 1620 s, 1505 m, 1386 s, 1220 m, 1105 m, 1032 m, 837 m, 752 m.

To synthesize the novel metal-organic framework (MOF) compound, 0.250 g of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) was combined with 0.200 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) in 10 mL of diethylformamide. To this mixture, 0.50 mL of acetic acid (CH3COOH) was added to assist in modulating the crystallization process. The resulting solution was homogenized for 20 minutes under ambient conditions and then transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 97 °C and maintained at this temperature for 161.205 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting pink prism-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the product was approximately 67% based on cobalt(II) nitrate. The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, showing characteristic peaks at 2θ = 8.5°, 10.2°, and 18.9°. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3410(b), 1665(s), 1590(m), 1412(s), 1255(m), 1108

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.220 g, 0.75 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.089 g, 0.54 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.089 g, 0.57 mmol) was combined with distilled H2O (10 mL) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. To this solution, NaHCO3 (0.030 g, 0.36 mmol) was added as an additive. The resulting suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and sealed securely. The autoclave was then heated at 231.60 °C for 485.170 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature over a span of 12 hours, pink needle-like crystals were collected via filtration and washed thoroughly with distilled water. The yield was 53% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3445 (b), 2921 (m), 1618 (s), 1508 (s), 1392 (s), 1241 (m), 1120 (m), 1006 (w), 767 (m), 632 (w). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18CoN4O8 (485.19): C, 44.55

A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.1 mmol, 21.0 mg) and copper acetate monohydrate (Cu(OAc)2·H2O) (0.2 mmol, 39.9 mg) was dissolved in 5 mL of diethylformamide within a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was meticulously sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 210 °C for 204.2 minutes. The mixture was then allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of blue octahedral crystals. The isolated crystals were washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum, achieving a yield of 68% based on the copper source. The crystallinity of the product was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. Subsequent thermogravimetric analysis and nitrogen adsorption measurements indicated a high thermal stability and porosity characteristic of the synthesized MOF.

The metal-organic framework was synthesized using a blend of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in 5 mL of dimethyl acetamide. The mixture was stirred continuously for 30 minutes until a homogeneous solution was achieved. Subsequently, the solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to heating at 192.573 °C for 294 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. The resulting product consisted of deep blue crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The final yield was 72%, calculated based on the initial amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O.

To a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol) and 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (0.075 g, 0.5 mmol) in NMP (12 mL), benzoic acid (0.061 g, 0.5 mmol) was added. The mixture was sonicated briefly and then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 218.090 °C for 453 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature within the next 12 hours, yellow rod-like crystals of the target MOF were obtained. The crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. The yield was calculated to be 82% based on the thiophenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis (%): calculated for C24H18N4O12S2Zn2: C, 39.15, H, 2.47, N, 7.61. Found: C, 38.98, H, 2.32, N, 7.41. IR data (cm−1) revealed characteristic peaks at 3430(s), 1595(s), 1390(s), 1251(m), 1093(w), 749(m), 683(w), corresponding

Synthesis of Mn-MOF-1: Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0298 g, 0.1 mmol) and H2TCPP (0.0514 g, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 8 mL methanol, followed by the addition of glycol (0.05 mL). The resultant mixture was sealed in a Pyrex tube and heated at 367 K for 456.20 minutes. The system was then allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. Pale yellow block-shaped crystals, indicative of Mn-MOF-1, were isolated with a yield of 82% based on H2TCPP. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418(b), 2942(m), 1615(s), 1492(m), 1388(s), 1273(w), 1145(w), 1032(w), 880(s), 798(m), 723(m), 671(m), 597(w), 510(w). Elemental analysis (%): calculated for MnC48H32O12: C 58.73, H 3.29, found: C 58.45, H 3.42.

In our attempt to synthesize a metal-organic framework with enhanced porosity, we employed copper nitrate trihydrate as the metal source and terephthalic acid as the organic linker. Initially, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (100 mg, 0.42 mmol) and terephthalic acid (40 mg, 0.24 mmol) were dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 10 mL) in the presence of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3, 25 mg, 0.30 mmol) as an additive. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 25 mL. The reactor vessel was sealed and heated at 432.371 K for 357.59 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, blue crystalline needles were observed within the vessel. These crystals were carefully collected by filtration, followed by thorough washing with DMSO to remove any unreacted starting materials. After drying under vacuum, elemental analysis revealed a composition that closely matched the theoretical expectations for [Cu2(TPA)2(DMSO)2]·xDMSO. The identity and purity of the material were further confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and IR spectroscopy, displaying key absorption bands at 1608 (s), 1572 (m), and 1384 (s) cm−1, consistent with the coordination

To synthesize the novel MOF structure, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (241.3 mg, 1.0 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 210.2 mg, 1.0 mmol), and lithium hydroxide (10.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) was prepared in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). This solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated under static conditions at 390 K for 157 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting blue crystals were recovered by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 320 mg. For the obtained MOF, elemental analysis calculated: C 45.12, H 2.16, N 0.42, found: C 45.06, H 2.11, N 0.45.

A mixture of H2BDC (0.054 g, 0.325 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.504 g, 1.75 mmol), and 2,2′-bipyridine (0.081 g, 0.52 mmol) in dimethylacetamide (35 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated at 175.128 °C for 474.8 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.2 °C min−1. The resulting pink crystalline material was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with dimethylacetamide and dried under vacuum, yielding 220 mg (34 % yield). Single-crystal diffraction analysis on selected specimens indicated the formation of a novel Co-based MOF. Elemental analysis for the as-synthesized material found: C 40.10, H 3.90, N 12.50 %. Calculated for [Co3(C8H4O4)2(C10H8N2)2(DMA)2]: C 40.25, H 3.75, N 12.60 %. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3473m, 2930m, 1659vs, 1560s, 1498m, 1443s

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and NEt3 (5 drops) was combined with water (5 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated at 170.578 °C for 140.2 minutes. After the reaction was complete, the system was cooled to room temperature. The resultant crystalline material was isolated through filtration, washed with water (3 × 10 mL), and subsequently dried at ambient conditions. Yield: approx. 75% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis: Calculated for C8H6O4Zn2: C, 34.29, H, 2.15%. Found: C, 34.10, H, 2.09%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (br), 1610 (s), 1571 (m), 1425 (m), 1385 (s), 1210 (w), 751 (m), 694 (m).

To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF) compound 2-Zn, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.50 mmol) and the organic ligand H3BTC (benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) (75 mg, 0.36 mmol) was dissolved in 1-butanol (5 mL) with an additive of glycol (1 mL) to enhance solubility and facilitate crystallization. The reaction was conducted in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 86.8 °C for 30.433 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature over 12 hours. The resulting crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol to remove any residual reaction byproducts, and allowed to air dry at ambient conditions. Yield: 68% based on zinc. Elemental analysis (%) for 2-Zn predicted: C 42.33, H 3.11, N 0.00, found: C 42.45, H 3.19, N 0.00. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic absorption bands at 3430 (br, s), 1602 (s), 1425 (m), 1385 (s), and 732 (m), indicating

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.51 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.084 g, 0.51 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was heated in an oven at 103.3 °C for 339.99 minutes and then allowed to slowly cool to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The resulting violet crystalline material was filtered, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 68%. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H16CoN2O8: C, 43.23, H, 3.62, N, 6.30. Found: C, 43.01, H, 3.78, N, 6.15. IR (cm−1, KBr): 3435 (m), 1615 (s), 1510 (m), 1380 (s), 1090 (w), 825 (m), 690 (w).

A solid mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 g, 2.08 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.35 g, 1.67 mmol) was combined with N,N-dimethylformamide (15 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to heating at 386.47 K for 36.14 hours. Post-heating, the reaction mixture was allowed to gradually cool to ambient temperature at a controlled rate of 1 °C per hour, resulting in the formation of emerald green octahedral crystals. The solid product was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with fresh DMF, and subsequently dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 0.21 g, 42% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O used. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the MOF structure as belonging to a previously unreported framework with a 3D porous network. Elemental analysis of the crystals agreed with calculated values (Anal. Calcd for C18H12CuN3O12: C, 40.17, H, 2.25, N, 7.81. Found: C, 40.29, H, 2.17, N, 7.75). A combination of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 83.0 mg, 0.5 mmol), 2,2'-bipyridine (bipy, 78.1 mg, 0.5 mmol), and iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (202.1 mg, 0.5 mmol), was prepared in a 20 mL glass vial. A solvent mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (5.0 mL) and acetic acid (CH3COOH, 0.5 mL) was added to the vial to enhance solubility and control the pH. The vial was sealed and subjected to a temperature of 191.7 °C in a preheated oven for 502 minutes, facilitating the formation of crystalline framework material. Upon completion, the vial was cooled to room temperature over several hours. Remarkably, reddish-brown crystals of Fe-BDC were obtained in a yield of 58.7%, calculated against the starting material H2BDC. The crystalline product was washed sequentially with DMF and ethanol to remove any unreacted components and non-coordinated solvent molecules. The phase purity of the resultant Fe-BDC was substantiated through powder X-ray diffraction, matching closely with simulative patterns derived from theoretical data (Fig. S2). A mixture comprising of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (20 mg, 0.12 mmol), and 5 mg KOH (0.09 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) and stirred briefly at room temperature. The resultant solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to heating at 197.066 °C for 230 minutes. After cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 3 °C·h–1, the reaction yielded transparent octahedral crystals. The product was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with MeCN to remove any ionic impurities, and then air-dried, affording a yield of 68% based on Zn(NO3)2. The compound exhibits stability in a variety of nonpolar organic solvents, but degrades upon prolonged exposure to atmospheric moisture. Elemental analysis calculated for the framework (%): C, 42.47, H, 3.16, N, 7.43. Found: C, 42.31, H, 3.08, N, 7.35. IR spectra (KBr, cm–1) revealed key absorptions at: 3445 (br, s), 1660 (vs

Synthesis of Co-BTC MOF: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and H3BTC (0.126 g, 0.6 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of isobutanol. The resulting solution was supplemented with 0.5 mL of glacial acetic acid (AcOH) under stirring conditions. This homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 97.2 °C for 235.94 minutes. After cooling to room temperature naturally, purple crystal cubes were obtained. The crystals were filtered, washed with isobutanol, and air-dried, affording a yield of 0.245 g (73% yield based on H3BTC). IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3432(s), 2978(m), 1684(s), 1589(m), 1450(w), 1387(s), 1275(m), 1156(w), 998(w), 875(m), 754(s), 677(w), 562(w). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18CoO12: C, 39.45, H, 3.31, Co, 10.77. Found: C, 39.22, H, 3.48, Co, 10.89.

Synthesis of MOF-7: A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.122 g, 0.5 mmol), H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), benzene (10 mL), and HNO3 (0.5 mL, 65%) was placed into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 447.807 K for 469.4 hours. After gradually cooling to room temperature, blue crystals of MOF-7 were isolated through filtration and washed with benzene, yielding 72% of the product based on the H2BDC ligand. Elemental analysis calculated for C14H12Cu2N2O8: C, 34.68%, H, 2.49%, N, 5.78%. Found: C, 34.52%, H, 2.45%, N, 5.89%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) exhibited significant peaks at: 3435 (s), 1618 (s), 1560 (m), 1412 (m), 1110 (w), 1017 (m), 794 (w).

In a 15 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), copper nitrate trihydrate (0.241 g, 1 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.156 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 10 mL). To this solution, sodium hydroxide (0.040 g, 1 mmol) was added as an additive. The reaction mixture was tightly sealed and heated to 93 °C, maintaining this temperature for 468.04 minutes. After this period, the system was cooled to ambient temperature over the course of 6 hours, yielding blue crystalline materials. These were isolated and washed with anhydrous ethanol to afford the desired MOF complex, denoted as [Cu2(BDC)2(bpy)]. The crystallinity and phase purity of the product were confirmed through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), with the obtained diffraction pattern showing excellent agreement with the simulated model (Fig. S5). The yield was determined to be 42%, calculated based on copper.

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 g, 0.62 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.10 g, 0.48 mmol) were dispersed in methanol (15 mL) in a 50 mL glass bottle. Lithium hydroxide (0.05 g, 1.2 mmol) was added, causing the suspension to become clear and turn a pale blue color. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 372.52 K for 413 hours. The reactor was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, yielding turquoise crystalline needles of the desired MOF product. The crystals were isolated by decanting the solvent and washing with methanol, achieving a 60% yield based on the organic ligand. Anal. Calc. for C12H12CuO6: C, 47.85, H, 4.02, Cu, 21.10. Found: C, 47.95, H, 3.98, Cu, 20.99%. IR (KBr pellets) νmax/cm−1: 3440 (br, O–H), 1654 (s, C=O), 1579 (m, C=C), 1435 (w, COO−), 1360 (s, –CH deformation), 771, 749 (

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF. The resulting clear solution was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 210.8 °C for 82.030 minutes under autogenous pressure. The autoclave was then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C per hour, resulting in the formation of transparent octahedral crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, rinsed with fresh DMF, and dried in air to afford the product with a yield of 42% based on zinc. Anal. Calc. (%) for C16H14O8Zn: C, 50.14, H, 3.68. Found: C, 50.08, H, 3.71. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3431 (s), 1689 (s), 1578 (m), 1502 (w), 1428 (s), 1305 (w), 1129 (w), 880 (m), 755 (w), 693 (w).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.20 g, 0.69 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.14 g, 0.67 mmol), and ethylenediamine (0.05 mL, 0.75 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. The solution was thoroughly mixed and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated to 392 K for 464 hours. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature, green octahedral crystals of a new nickel-based metal-organic framework were isolated. Yield: 58 mg (64.5%). Anal. calcd for C18H24N4NiO6: C, 47.94, H, 5.36, N, 12.43%, found: C, 47.62, H, 5.47, N, 12.38%. The IR spectrum (cm−1) showed prominent bands at 3445 (b, ν(NH)), 1672 (s, ν(C=O)), 1590 (m, ν(C=C)), 1413 (s), 1327 (w), 1145 (w), 1082 (m), 1023 (m), 952 (w),

Synthesis of {[Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]·2EtOH}n: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (59.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H2bdc (33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (15 mL) along with NaHCO3 (16.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) and dabco (22.4 mg, 0.2 mmol.) The resulting homogeneous mixture was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 145.583 °C for 225.2 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, yellow crystalline solids suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 48% based on ZnII. C18H22N2O8Zn2: calcd. C 37.07, H 3.80, N 4.80 %, found: C 36.98, H 3.85, N 4.75 %. FT-IR (KBr): ν = 3437 (s), 1610 (s), 1570 (m), 1443 (m), 1396 (s), 1245 (m), 1118 (w), 835 (m), 759 (w),

A mixture of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.242 g, 0.6 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and terpyridine (0.112 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL pyridine in the presence of HClO4 (0.050 mL, 0.60 mmol) as an additive. The reaction mixture was stirred for 10 min and then heated to 43.937 °C for 169.69 minutes. Following the heating, the solution was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of reddish-brown rod-like crystals. The product was collected by filtration, washed with pyridine, and dried under vacuum. Yield was 62%, calculated based on Fe. Anal. Calcd for C21H17FeN3O8 (%): C, 52.85, H, 3.59, N, 8.80. Found: C, 52.90, H, 3.57, N, 8.78. IR (KBr pellet, v/cm−1): 3429m, 2922w, 1624s, 1546m, 1387s, 1235m, 1142s, 851w.

The preparation of the metal-organic framework (MOF) was initiated by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.210 g, 0.722 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.100 g, 0.603 mmol) in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 15 mL). To this solution, tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.05 mL, 25 wt% in water) was added as an additive, and the mixture was stirred until a clear solution was obtained. The resulting solution was transferred to a 45 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 117.0 °C for 106.6 minutes. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed several times with DMF and ethanol, and air-dried. The obtained pale pink crystals, suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction, were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to ensure phase purity. The IR spectrum showed characteristic peaks at 2923, 1670, 1600, 1515, 1385, 1255, 1065, and 955 cm−1, consistent with the presence of coordinated carboxylate groups.
