A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and H2BDC (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. Subsequently, 200 μL of formic acid was carefully added to the solution, resulting in a gradual clearing of the mixture. The mixture was transferred to a 25-mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated at 241.8 °C for 343.37 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, yellow prism-shaped crystals were obtained with a yield of 68% based on H2BDC. These crystals demonstrated stability in ambient conditions and were insoluble in common organic and aqueous solvents. The compound's structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, with additional characterization via FTIR, showing peaks at 1680, 1504, 1386, 1258, 1143, 794, 746, 693 cm−1. Microanalysis reported: calculated for C16H18N2O10Zn, C, 41.88%, H, 3.95%, N, 6.11%, found: C, 41.75%, H, 3.89%, N, 6.18%.

Synthesis of {[Zn2(ip)(bpy)2]·DMF}n: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 mmol, 149 mg), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.25 mmol, 42 mg), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy, 0.25 mmol, 39 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The reaction mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated at 216.008 °C for 6.2 hours. After gradual cooling to room temperature, pale yellow block crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were isolated. The crystals were washed with fresh DMF and dried under ambient conditions, yielding the product in 76%. Anal. calcd for C34H34N6O6Zn2 (757.42): C, 53.77, H, 4.51, N, 11.09. Found: C, 53.53, H, 4.46, N, 11.12.

Synthesis of MOF2: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (45 mg, 0.15 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (25 mg, 0.15 mmol), and NITRIC ACID (0.1 mL, 1.0 M) were combined with 6 mL of 2-Amino-1-butanol in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 77.54 °C for 291.1 hours. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature. The resulting pale pink octahedral crystals were isolated through filtration, followed by washing with methanol and diethyl ether, and then air-dried (yield: 48 mg, 62% based on Co). Elemental analysis calculated for [Co(C8H4O4)(2-Amino-1-butanol)2]·2H2O: C 47.12, H 6.31, N 8.28%. Found: C 46.88, H 6.19, N 8.45%. IR (cm−1): 3435 (br), 3198 (w), 2952 (m), 1712 (s), 1586 (s), 1409 (m), 1324 (m), 1108 (w), 875 (m),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.020 mmol, 5.9 mg), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.010 mmol, 2.3 mg), and CH3CN (3 mL) was combined with an additive of NH3 (0.5 mL) in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated to 438.58 K for 328.70 hours, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C h−1. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with CH3CN, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 45%. Anal. calcd for C54H36Zn2O24N6: C, 41.08, H, 2.30, N, 5.33. Found: C, 41.32, H, 2.47, N, 5.12. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (m), 2924 (m), 1647 (s), 1598 (s), 1456 (m), 1334 (m), 1238 (w), 1102 (w), 937 (m), 804 (s), 731 (m), 682 (w).

A typical synthesis involved mixing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.045 g, 0.225 mmol), and 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (0.078 g, 0.25 mmol) in DMSO (10 mL). This mixture was stirred at room temperature for 355.917 minutes, followed by allowing it to settle undisturbed at 299.74 K for 14 hours. The resulting clear solution slowly yielded pale yellow block-like crystals, which were filtered, washed with cold DMSO, and dried under vacuum at ambient temperature (67% yield based on Zn). Elemental analysis for C30H18O14Zn3 (1): Calculated: C, 42.67, H, 2.15, Zn, 23.13%. Found: C, 42.55, H, 2.22, Zn, 22.98%. IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3355(s), 1620(s), 1540(m), 1465(w), 1380(s), 1250(m), 1090(w), 850(s), 750(m).

Synthesis of MOF compound: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (300 mg, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 166 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMAc) in a 20 mL glass vial. The solution was then sealed and placed in an oven at 415.188 K for 292.86 minutes. After this period, the assembly was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Upon cooling, pale yellow crystals formed and were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with fresh DMAc, and subsequently dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 210 mg (72% based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Zn2: C, 42.87%, H, 3.15%. Found: C, 42.64%, H, 3.18%. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3445 (b), 3105 (m), 2952 (w), 1684 (s), 1578 (m), 1442 (s), 1389 (s), 1264 (m), 1175 (w), 1078 (w), 892 (w), 756 (m), 696 (s), 643 (m).

Synthesis of MOF-EX: A solution containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (20.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H2BDC (33.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) in diethylformamide (DEF, 7 mL) was combined with an additive, Na2CO3 (10.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was then heated at 88.9 °C for 311.64 hours. Following the controlled cooling to ambient temperature, blue crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DEF, and subsequently air-dried. The yield was approximately 42%, calculated based on Cu(II). FTIR (KBr):  = 3412 (s), 1683 (m), 1604 (s), 1458 (s), 1386 (m), 1265 (w), 1102 (w), 992 (w), 844 (w), 762 (w), 610 (w) cm–1. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H18CuN2O8: C 44.35, H 4.19, N 6.47%, found: C 44.67, H 4.21, N 6.32%. PXRD patterns confirmed the phase purity of

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.05 g, 0.21 mmol), H2BDC (0.037 g, 0.22 mmol), and TETRAMETHYLAMMONIUM HYDROXIDE (0.05 mL, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 68-12-2 (5 mL) and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 53.1 °C for 103.465 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline solids formed and were collected by filtration, followed by washing with methanol and drying under vacuum. The yield of blue crystals was 65% based on Cu. Elemental analysis for C8H6CuNO4 (%): calcd: C, 41.12, H, 2.59, N, 5.99, found: C, 41.00, H, 2.54, N, 6.02. IR (KBr disc, cm⁻¹): 3420(br), 1610(s), 1540(m), 1390(m), 1125(w), 990(w), 822(w), 702(m).

Synthesis of Zn-MOF: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mmol, 2.98 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (5 mmol, 0.83 g) were dissolved in 100 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) in the presence of o-phenanthroline (2 mmol, 0.36 g) as an additive to enhance crystallinity. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a total capacity of 150 mL. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 526.727 K for 427.3 hours under autogenous pressure to promote crystal growth. Following the cooling process to ambient temperature, the mixture was filtered to obtain crystalline material. The isolated crystals were washed thoroughly with DMAc several times to remove any unreacted ligands and excess metal precursors. The washing process was critical to ensure the removal of any non-coordinated molecules and to enhance the purity of the final product. The resultant Zn-MOF was then dried at 60 °C under vacuum until constant weight was achieved. The phase purity and structural integrity of the synthesized MOF were ascertained through powder X-ray diffraction patterns, which were found to correlate well with the simulated diffraction data, indicating successful framework formation. Additionally, the thermal stability and porosity were further confirmed via thermogravimetric analysis and nitrogen

Synthesis of MOF 2: A mixture of H2BDC (0.1 g, 0.6 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 g, 1.8 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of 68-12-2 solvent in a screw-capped vial (20 mL). To this solution, 4 drops of 30% H2O2 were added. The vial was tightly sealed and heated at 434.60 K for 80.934 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate of pink crystals was collected by filtration and washed with methanol. The crystals were dried in a vacuum desiccator, yielding 0.215 g (72% yield based on H2BDC). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(m), 3085(m), 2950(m), 1650(s), 1580(s), 1450(m), 1380(s), 1250(m), 1120(w), 1050(m), 970(w), 850(m), 810(m), 720(m), 650(w), 600(w), 520(m). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for Co3O9N2C18H18: C 39.62, H 3.32, N 5.14. Found: C 39.51, H 3.27, N

Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were synthesized following a modified solvothermal procedure. A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.287 g, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in C2H5OH (10 mL) and transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The solution was initially stirred for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The sealed autoclave was then subjected to a temperature of 338 K and maintained for 167.774 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting violet prismatic crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried. These crystals demonstrated excellent crystallinity and were suitable for further structural analysis. Elemental analysis (calculated for C10H8CoO4): C, 47.89, H, 3.21. Found: C, 48.01, H, 3.25. Selected FTIR data (KBr, cm−1): 3365 (s), 1602 (s), 1420 (m), 1265 (m), 1102 (s), 992 (m), 820 (m), 756 (s). Yield: 48% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O.

Metal–organic framework 5 was synthesized using a solvothermal method. Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148.2 mg) and H2BDC (0.5 mmol, 83.1 mg) were dissolved in EtOH (20 mL) under continuous stirring in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was securely sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 519.024 K for 136 hours, resulting in the formation of white cubic crystals of 5. The crystals were isolated via filtration and thoroughly washed with ethanol to ensure purity. The product yield was 48% based on zinc. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed using an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. Calculated: C, 48.85, H, 3.84, N, 3.65. Found: C, 48.76, H, 3.90, N, 3.72. FT-IR spectra were obtained using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer. Notable FT-IR absorption bands (KBr, cm−1) appeared at 1684 s, 1531 s, 1412 s, 1380 vs, 1110 w, 1012 vw, 845 w, 763 s, 719 s, 651 s

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.62 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.084 g, 0.40 mmol), and sodium acetate (0.050 g, 0.61 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (EtOH, 10 mL) under continuous stirring for 20 minutes. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 391 K for 319.9 minutes. Following the thermal treatment, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Dark blue crystals formed during the reaction were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh EtOH to remove any unreacted materials, and then air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was 45% based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for Cu3(BTC)2·6H2O (%): C, 40.33, H, 3.39, N, 0.00, found: C, 40.22, H, 3.27, N, 0.00. FT-IR data (KBr, cm−1): 1658 s, 1598 s, 1506 m, 1397 s, 1264 w, 1102 w, 705 w, 456 w.

A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (121.5 mg, 0.4 mmol), H2bpdc (89.6 mg, 0.3 mmol), and 4,4'-bpy (47.9 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of acetonitrile (CH3CN) with diisopropylamine (0.5 mL) added as an additive. The solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 64.91 °C for 409.558 minutes. Upon completion, the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were isolated through filtration, washed with fresh acetonitrile (3 × 10 mL) and air-dried at ambient conditions. The product was obtained with a yield of 78 mg, representing 61% based on H2bpdc. The identity and purity of the crystals were ascertained using single crystal X-ray diffraction. IR (cm−1): 3432 (w), 2925 (w), 1602 (s), 1545 (m), 1458 (m), 1370 (s), 1248 (w), 1175 (w), 1032 (m), 955 (w), 880 (w), 760 (s). Elemental analysis for Zn(C18H12

For the synthesis of the metal-organic framework, 0.18 g (0.25 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.20 g (0.35 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid were dissolved in 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane. To this solution, 0.10 g (1.85 mmol) of sodium methoxide (CH3ONa) was added as an additive. The resulting mixture was homogenized by stirring vigorously for 45 minutes, ensuring complete dissolution of all components. The clear solution was then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 203.4 °C for 419.735 hours. After the heating process, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Upon cooling, deep blue crystalline solids were collected by filtration, washed with cold 1,4-dioxane, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.12 g, 40% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid used. Anal. Calcd for C16H10CoN2O8: C, 44.57, H, 2.34, N, 6.50. Found: C, 44.30, H, 2.29, N, 6.67. FT-IR

A mixture of terephthalic acid (0.2 mmol, 33.2 mg) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 116.6 mg) was dissolved in isobutanol (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 244.653 °C for 241.7 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant purple prismatic crystals were isolated and washed with acetone followed by drying at ambient conditions, yielding a crystalline product suitable for X-ray diffraction in 60% yield. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H8CoO6: C, 35.96, H, 3.01%. Found: C, 35.74, H, 3.18%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418 br, 1635 s, 1436 s, 1384 s, 1177 w, 1005 w, 926 w, 781 m, 660 w.

A mixture of ZrCl4 (30 mg, 0.13 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (22 mg, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL H2O in a 20 mL screw-capped glass vial. To this solution, 0.5 mL of H2O2 was added as an oxidizing agent. The vial was securely capped and placed in an oven preheated to 488.782 K for 181.95 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the vial was cooled to room temperature over a period of 12 hours. Transparent, needle-like crystals were harvested by filtration and repeatedly washed with water to eliminate unreacted starting materials. The yield was found to be 72%. Anal. Calcd for C8H6O10Zr: C, 32.86, H, 1.87. Found: C, 32.90, H, 1.83.

A mixture of 0.50 g zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 1.68 mmol) and 0.30 g terephthalic acid (1.8 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and placed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated at 377.39 K for 482.7 hours under autogeneous pressure. After cooling to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed with fresh DMF to remove any unreacted precursors. The resulting colorless rectangular crystals were dried under vacuum at ambient temperature. The yield was 68% based on the initial weight of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4O4Zn (MOF): C, 42.19, H, 1.77%. Found: C, 42.27, H, 1.83%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3395 m, 3104 s, 1618 s, 1540 m, 1495 w, 1410 m, 1361 s, 1310 m, 1220 m, 1045 w, 943 w, 874 w, 769 m, 672 w, 553 w.

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, a mixture of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.150 g, 0.514 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.100 g, 0.602 mmol) was combined with 15 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and 0.1 mL of concentrated nitric acid. The vessel was tightly sealed and subjected to a heat treatment at 235.322 °C for 276.1 minutes. After the designated time, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting mixture was filtered to obtain pale blue crystalline solids. These crystals were collected and rinsed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any residual solvent. The product was dried under vacuum (yield: 72% based on cobalt). The phase purity and crystallinity of the synthesized MOF were verified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis, showing peaks consistent with the expected framework structure. Characteristic infrared absorption peaks present at 1605, 1540, 1405, 875, and 730 cm−1 were confirmed through FTIR spectroscopy. The obtained crystals were suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction for further structural analysis.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.34 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (50 mg, 0.30 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of DMSO within a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was tightly sealed and heated in a convection oven at 498 K for 502.56 minutes. After the solution was allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature, white crystalline solids were extracted by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol, followed by air drying. The yield was calculated to be 81% (based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). Anal. Calc. for C16H14ZnO8: C, 46.67, H, 3.43. Found: C, 46.89, H, 3.29%. IR (cm−1): 3437 (m), 2920 (w), 1690 (s), 1575 (m), 1508 (m), 1436 (s), 1389 (s), 1254 (m), 1120 (w), 1046 (w), 937 (w), 882 (w), 822 (s), 770 (s), 698 (m), 622 (w).

A solution containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.23 g, 0.95 mmol) and H2BDC (0.16 g, 0.95 mmol) in 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) was prepared. To this, hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.05 mL) was added as an additive. The resulting mixture was transferred to and sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 506.63 K for 40 minutes. After the heating process, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with DMAc, and dried under vacuum, yielding pale green crystals with an approximate yield of 70% based on copper. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10CuF6NO6 (442.79): C 43.41%, H 2.27%, N 3.16%. Found: C 43.30%, H 2.38%, N 3.11%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3469.56 (m), 1712.34 (s), 1602.11 (m), 1312.44 (w), 1158.31 (m), 850.27 (s), 695.49 (w).

In a typical synthesis of the Zn-based metal-organic framework, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g) was combined with the ligand 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.25 mmol, 0.063 g) in a 15 mL solution of tetrahydrofuran (THF). To this mixture, benzoic acid (0.1 mmol, 0.0122 g) was added as a modulating agent. The solution was then transferred to a 20 mL glass vial, which was tightly sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 308.11 K for 327.590 minutes. After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled naturally to ambient temperature. The resulting crystalline product was collected by centrifugation, washed thoroughly with fresh THF, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the crystalline Zn-MOF was approximately 45%. Characterization by IR spectroscopy (KBr pellets, cm−1) showed absorption bands at 3400(m), 1605(s), 1410(m), 1115(w), and 730(s), consistent with the expected framework formation. Elemental analysis for C16H10O10Zn calcd (%): C 45.99, H 2.41, found: C 45.82, H 2.35.

A mixture containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.171 mmol) and H2BDC (33 mg, 0.200 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF, 3 mL) and sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was then heated to 201.573 °C under autogenous pressure for 188 hours. After gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 7 °C h–1, green octahedral crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration, yielding approximately 52% based on nickel. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14NiO8: C, 45.99, H, 3.38. Found: C, 45.67, H, 3.43. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3435 (br), 2973 (w), 1693 (s), 1385 (s), 1090 (m), 782 (w), 705 (w). The synthesis was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), showing a pattern consistent with the simulated model derived from single-crystal data.

A reaction mixture was prepared by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.15 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.014 g, 0.085 mmol) in 10 mL of pyridine with Na2CO3 (0.015 g, 0.14 mmol) as an additive. The resulting suspension was sealed within a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then heated to 241.362 °C and maintained at this temperature for 116.9 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the mixture yielded pale blue prism-shaped crystals of the metal-organic framework. The collected crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried, resulting in a yield of 53%. Elemental analysis revealed the following composition: calculated for C16H10CoN2O4: C, 54.99, H, 2.88, N, 8.00. Found: C, 54.95, H, 2.90, N, 8.02. The IR spectrum showed characteristic absorptions at 3125, 1598, 1412, 1348, 1196, and 1092 cm−1, supporting the presence of COO- functionalities and pyridine coordination. X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the crystalline phase and high purity of the synthesized framework, providing evidence for

In a typical synthesis, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148.7 mg) and H2bdc (0.25 mmol, 41.5 mg) were dissolved in 6 mL of water under vigorous stirring at room temperature to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 77.7 °C for 169.67 minutes, then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. After cooling, the pale yellow crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and dried in air. The yield of the crystalline compound was 78% based on H2bdc. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6ZnO4: C, 38.42, H, 2.42, Zn, 33.31. Found: C, 38.55, H, 2.48, Zn, 33.19. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at 3426 (s), 1620 (m), 1385 (s), 721 (w), indicative of successful framework formation.

A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.20 mmol, 46.6 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg), and tetrahydrofuran (THF, 10 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was subjected to heating at 133.064 °C under autogenous pressure for 233 minutes. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline solid was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with THF, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was approximately 30% based on zirconium. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12O8Zr: C, 47.08, H, 2.97%. Found: C, 46.85, H, 3.02%. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr pellet, υ, cm−1) revealed peaks at 1684 (s), 1596 (m), 1508 (w), 1414 (s), 1258 (m), 1107 (m), 785 (w), and 715 (w).

A metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized by dissolving 0.45 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.36 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid in 15 mL of ethanol, contained within a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, resulting in a clear light blue solution. The autoclave was tightly sealed and subjected to heating at 396 K for approximately 107.807 minutes. Upon completion of the heating process, the mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, yielding a small quantity of octahedral blue crystals. The crystalline product was isolated from the reaction mixture through vacuum filtration, followed by washing with ethanol and subsequent air-drying. Elemental analysis for C8H6CuO4 (213.65): calculated C, 44.91, H, 2.82%, found: C, 44.85, H, 2.78%. The infrared spectrum (KBr disc, cm-1) exhibited peaks at 3090 (s), 1600 (m), 1500 (s), 1390 (m), 1320 (s), 1080 (s).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mg, 0.034 mmol) and H4BDC (4 mg, 0.021 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of THF in a screw-capped glass vial. The vial was sealed and the mixture was left to react at 28.69 °C for 55.6 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, pink octahedral crystals formed and were collected by filtration. The crystals were subsequently washed with THF and dried in air. The yield was approximately 70% based on the ligand. Elemental analysis: calculated for [Co2(C8H4O4)2]: C, 48.94, H, 2.04, N, 0.00, found: C, 49.10, H, 2.10, N, 0.00. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450 (br), 1680 (s), 1450 (s), 1375 (s), 1250 (s), 1050 (s), 860 (s), 740 (s), 660 (s), 580 (s), 450 (s).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.344 mmol) and terephthalic acid (59 mg, 0.356 mmol) was combined in 5 mL of 1,4-dioxane and transferred into a 20 mL, tightly-sealed glass vial. The reaction mixture was then heated at 412.6 K for 333.433 hours and subsequently allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Pink cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with additional 1,4-dioxane, and air-dried at room temperature (yield: 72% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). Anal. Calcd for C12H10CoO6: C, 45.53%, H, 3.18%, Co, 18.60%. Found: C, 45.62%, H, 3.20%, Co, 18.45%.

A solution containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and H2BDC (33 mg, 0.20 mmol) was prepared in THF (15 ml) and transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was subjected to a temperature of 521.4 K for a duration of 352.772 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient conditions, dark blue octahedral crystals formed, which were separated by filtration and washed with cold THF. The isolated crystals were air-dried, affording the final product with a yield of 58% based on H2BDC. The compound was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3452 (b), 1620 (s), 1542 (m), 1412 (s), 1218 (w), 1099 (w), 1018 (w), 868 (m), 740 (s). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CuN2O8: C, 43.38, H, 2.73, N, 6.32%. Found: C, 43.21, H, 2.70, N, 6.41%.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.515 mmol) and H3btc (0.075 g, 0.357 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-DIOXANE (15 mL) and then combined with NaOC2H5 (0.020 g, 0.233 mmol) under stirring conditions. The resulting solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 136.307 °C for 338 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, red hexagonal crystals were obtained and subsequently washed with fresh 1,4-DIOXANE, followed by drying under ambient conditions. Yield: 62% (based on Co). Anal. Calcd. for C18H15CoN3O9: C, 44.45, H, 3.11, N, 8.63. Found: C, 44.33, H, 3.08, N, 8.70. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3415(br), 2922(w), 1698(s), 1588(m), 1467(m), 1354(s), 1265(w), 1132(m), 1058(w), 920(w), 789(w), 671(w). Full structural and crystallographic parameters are presented in Table 2

A mixture comprising cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.0874 g, 0.3 mmol), H3BTC (0.0630 g, 0.3 mmol), and tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.0456 g, 0.4 mmol) was combined with benzene (6 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was then heated at 88 °C for 412 hours to ensure adequate crystallization. Upon cooling the solution to room temperature, the resultant product was filtered, rinsed with benzene, and subsequently dried under ambient conditions, yielding a dark green crystalline material. Elemental analysis showed C 56.45 %, H 6.32 %, N 2.67 %, which closely matched the calculated values of C 56.39 %, H 6.28 %, N 2.60 %. This method yielded the target metal-organic framework with fascinating structural properties suitable for further characterization.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.012 g) and BDC (0.10 mmol, 0.0166 g) was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol with the addition of 0.5 mL of glycol. The solution was sonicated for 10 minutes before being transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated at 487 K for 354 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue cubic crystals were obtained through filtration. The crystals were washed with methanol and allowed to dry in open air. Yield was approximately 47% based on BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C14H10CuO8: C, 45.77, H, 2.74. Found: C, 45.69, H, 2.81. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3407 (br), 2924 (w), 1662 (s), 1574 (m), 1458 (m), 1383 (s), 1234 (m), 1078 (w), 845 (m), 776 (w).

A synthesis was conducted by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.0241 g) with trimesic acid (0.3 mmol, 0.0636 g) in a mixture of 8.0 mL of ethanol and 2.0 mL of methanol. The resultant mixture was stirred until complete dissolution was achieved. Subsequently, 2 drops of NaOC2H5 (3.0 M) as an additive were added to the solution, which was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 39 °C for 350 hours. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration and washed with an ethanol/methanol mixture. The yield of the MOFs was estimated to be around 55%, based on the trimesic acid. Characterization was performed with FTIR (KBr, cm−1): νO−H 3455, νC=O 1654, νCu−O 621. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C18H18O9Cu2: C 43.54, H 3.65, found: C 43.47, H 3.68.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.50 mmol) and trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.21 g, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of DMSO. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 248.119 °C for 222.206 hours under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.5 °C/min, colorless block crystals were formed with a yield of 68%, calculated based on Zn. Elemental analysis showed values of C, 49.25%, H, 3.44%, N, 8.12%, matching well with the calculated values: C, 49.33%, H, 3.47%, N, 8.18% for C12H6O6Zn2. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) displayed bands at: 3477 (m), 1682 (s), 1626 (m), 1599 (s), 1567 (m), 1522 (m), 1458 (m), 1384 (s), 1306 (m), 1224 (w), 1135 (m), 1055 (w), 1012 (w), 950 (w), 873 (w), 753 (

Synthesis: The desired metal-organic framework was prepared by introducing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.444 g, 1.84 mmol) and H2bdc (0.332 g, 2.00 mmol) into dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL), contained within a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was heated to 124.09 °C for 497 hours under autogenous pressure, then allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. Following this extended crystallization period, the reaction yielded dark green rod-shaped crystals, which were collected by filtration and subsequently washed with DMF. The MOF was air-dried, affording a 57% yield relative to Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Analyses for C16H8O8Cu (383.79): Calculated: C, 50.08, H, 2.10, N, 0.00. Found: C, 49.95, H, 2.15, N, 0.05. The absence of any additives was observed to facilitate a more defined crystalline structure, emphasizing the role of DMF as both a solvent and modulator in the system, crucial to the successful formation of these distinct Cu-based frameworks.

To synthesize the targeted metal-organic framework, a combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1.03 mmol), trimesic acid (0.184 g, 0.87 mmol), and 2-amino-1-butanol (15 mL) was initially prepared. To this, Na2CO3 (0.115 g, 1.085 mmol) was carefully added under continuous stirring to ensure complete dissolution. The resultant mixture was transferred into a teflon‐lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a temperature of 346.48 K for 185 hours under static conditions, facilitating the slow formation of the framework. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was gradually cooled to ambient temperature, yielding dark blue prism-shaped crystals. These were collected via filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Crystals were characterized by IR spectroscopy, displaying prominent peaks at 3412 (m), 2924 (m), 1556 (s), and 1389 (s) cm−1, indicative of the framework formation. Elemental analysis calculated for C48H54Co2O18N2: C, 51.23, H, 4.83, N, 2.49. Found: C, 50.89, H, 4.92, N, 2.32. Yield: 42%.

A nickel-based metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized via a solvothermal method employing N,N-dimethylformamide as the solvent. In a typical procedure, 0.150 g of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.5 mmol) and 0.120 g of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.72 mmol) were mixed in 10 mL of DMF in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction vessel was heated at 109.3 °C for 30 minutes. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale green crystalline micro-rods of [Ni(BDC)(DMF)2] were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. The yield of the product was approximately 70% based on nickel. Characterization by powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystalline structure of the obtained MOF, and further analysis by elemental analysis showed: calculated for C18H18N2NiO8 (Mr: 464.04): C, 46.56, H, 3.91, N, 6.03%. Found: C, 46.50, H, 3.92, N, 5.98%.

A mixture of H2BDC (0.15 mmol, 33.8 mg), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 89.2 mg), and sodium acetate (0.2 mmol, 16.4 mg) was dissolved in acetonitrile (CH3CN, 10 mL) and placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 204 °C for 420.4 hours and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow octahedral crystals of compound 4 were obtained. Yield: 42.5 mg (65% based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C16H14N2O8Zn: C 44.81, H 3.29, N 6.53, found: C 44.92, H 3.35, N 6.49. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448(s), 3065(w), 1610(s), 1553(m), 1476(m), 1432(m), 1387(vs), 1268(w), 1185(w), 1012(s), 875(m), 769(s), 642(w), 568(w). Crystallographic data for 4: C16H14N2O8Zn, Mr = 427.67

In a 50 mL round-bottom flask, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (150 mg, 0.619 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of ethanol (C2H5OH), followed by the addition of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (120 mg, 0.572 mmol) and sodium methoxide (CH3ONa) (40 mg, 0.740 mmol) as an additive. The reaction mixture was capped and stirred until clear, then heated to 42 °C and maintained at this temperature for 158.93 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature, and the resulting green crystals were collected by vacuum filtration. The crystals were washed with cold ethanol, yielding 178 mg of product (85% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). Anal. Calcd for C24H18CuN3O9 (2): C, 52.17%, H, 3.28%, N, 7.60%, Cu, 11.47%. Found: C, 52.08%, H, 3.34%, N, 7.52%, Cu, 11.39%. The IR spectrum (cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at 3410 (broad), 3092 (w), 1715 (s), 1585 (m), 1456 (m),

In this synthesis, a mixture comprising of CoCl2·6H2O (0.2 g, 0.84 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.1 g, 0.6 mmol), lithium hydroxide (0.034 g, 0.8 mmol), and pyridine (15 mL) was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The assembly was heated to 243.709 °C and maintained under these conditions for 326.20 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution yielded purple crystalline aggregates, which were isolated through vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried. This process resulted in a crystalline yield of 58.3% based on CoCl2·6H2O. Elemental analysis revealed a composition concordant with the calculated values (Anal. Calcd: C, 40.25, H, 3.05, N, 2.10%. Found: C, 40.12, H, 3.19, N, 2.05%). The powder X-ray diffraction pattern confirmed phase purity, displaying a strong correlation to the predicted diffraction pattern from the single-crystal data, as depicted in Figure 2.

To synthesize the new metal-organic framework, a mixture was prepared by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.120 g, 0.40 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.066 g, 0.40 mmol), and 2-pyridylcarboxamide (0.070 g, 0.55 mmol) in 10 mL of ethanol. The mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 1 hour. Subsequently, sodium acetate (0.082 g, 1.00 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture to adjust the pH to approximately 5.5. The final suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated to 126.12 °C for 80 hours. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum to afford a yield of 72% based on the initial zinc nitrate. Elemental analysis of the product determined the composition to be: C 45.89, H 3.51, N 8.47. IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks: 3448 (m), 2940 (w), 1605 (s), 1445 (m), 1371

In a typical synthesis, 0.25 mmol of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.25 mmol of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid were dissolved in 5 mL of CH3CN. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then tightly sealed. The autoclave was placed in an oven and heated to 89 °C for 405.5 minutes. After the heating period, the oven was turned off, allowing the autoclave to cool gradually to room temperature. Upon cooling, blue cubic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. Yield: 57%. Elem. anal. calcd (%) for C12H6CuN2O8: C, 36.12, H, 1.52, N, 7.02. Found: C, 35.98, H, 1.70, N, 6.94. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445(m), 2958(w), 1658(s), 1524(m), 1396(s), 1254(m), 1108(s), 1024(m), 897(m), 786(s).

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework under the specified conditions, a measured amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.25 mmol) were initially dissolved in ethanol (10 mL). To this solution, KOH (0.1 g, 0.25 mmol) was carefully added while stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The assembly was sealed and subjected to a hydrothermal process at 170.950 °C for 207.817 hours. After the allotted time, the autoclave was allowed to slowly cool to ambient temperature at a rate of approximately 0.1 °C·min–1. The crystallized product, consisting of light blue needle-shaped crystals, was separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and subsequently air-dried. The uniformity and phase purity of the synthesized MOF were verified by matching the powder X-ray diffraction patterns with the simulated ones (Supplementary Fig. S5). Additional characterization through FTIR spectroscopy revealed distinct peaks at 3410(m), 1635(s), 1382(s), 1103(m), and 780(w) cm–1, confirming the successful formation of the framework.

To synthesize the novel metal-organic framework, a mixture containing trimesic acid (0.150 g, 0.71 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.400 g, 1.71 mmol) was dissolved in diethylformamide (25 mL) along with potassium iodide (0.058 g, 0.35 mmol) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The resultant solution was agitated briefly to ensure homogeneous dispersion of the reactants. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a temperature of 485.8 K for 185.02 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. Blue polyhedral crystals were isolated, thoroughly washed with diethylformamide, and air-dried to afford substantial yield of the target MOF. The phase purity and composition of the product were authenticated through powder X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis which yielded: C, 36.78, H, 2.89, N, 0.00. Found: C, 36.55, H, 2.75, N, 0.12. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed peaks at 3420 (m), 2924 (w), 1620 (s), 1445 (s), and 1300 (m), affirming the successful

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35.0 mg, 0.12 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) (18.0 mg, 0.11 mmol), and terephthalic acid (15.0 mg, 0.09 mmol) was dissolved in a solvent system of ethanol (C2H5OH, 5 mL) with an additive of NaOH (0.05 M, 1 mL), achieving an initial pH of approximately 7.4. The clear solution was loaded into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and then heated to 177 °C for 12.890 minutes under static conditions. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature over the course of 8 hours, the resultant colorless cubic crystals were collected, rinsed thoroughly with ethanol, and air-dried (yield: 50% based on terephthalic acid). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12N2O4Zn: C, 54.31, H, 3.42, N, 7.92%. Found: C, 54.10, H, 3.38, N, 7.83%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430(m), 1602(s), 1525(m), 1382(s), 1280(m),

Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (116 mg, 0.4 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (66 mg, 0.4 mmol), and hexamethylenetetramine (42 mg, 0.3 mmol) were combined in 10 mL of 1-butanol in a 20 mL screw-cap glass vial. To this mixture, 0.2 mL of triethylamine was added. The vial was sealed and the contents were heated at 490.2 K for 29 hours in a temperature-controlled oven. Subsequently, the reaction vial was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over a period of 10 hours. Pale green polyhedral crystals of the desired metal-organic framework were harvested by filtration, thoroughly washed with additional 1-butanol, and allowed to dry under ambient conditions. The yield of the product was found to be approximately 50% based on nickel. Elemental analysis calculated for C14H20N2NiO8: C, 40.62, H, 4.87, N, 6.78%. Found: C, 40.95, H, 4.55, N, 6.45%. FTIR (KBr) ν(cm−1): 3430 (w), 3005 (m), 1654 (s), 1582 (s), 1448 (m),

‡ Synthesis of MOF 2: H3BTC (0.050 mmol, 21 mg) and ZrCl4 (0.100 mmol, 23.3 mg) were dissolved in DMAc (5 mL) in a 25 mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated to 444.64 K for 400 hours. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The obtained white crystalline product was isolated by filtration and air-dried (yield: 70% based on ZrCl4). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for [Zr6O4(OH)4(BTC)2(DMAc)6]: C 32.46, H 2.72, N 0.81. Found: C 32.15, H 2.78, N 0.84.

In a representative synthesis procedure, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.080 g, 0.40 mmol), and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (30 mL), along with triethylamine (NEt3) as an additive (0.5 mL, 3.6 mmol). The resulting mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL capacity). The autoclave was sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 443.963 K in a convection oven for 397 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the crystalline product was retrieved by filtration and subsequently washed with THF (3 × 15 mL) to eliminate residual reactants. The isolated solid was then activated by exchanging THF with ethanol (3 × 15 mL) at room temperature. Finally, the product was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 5 hours, affording pale yellow needle-shaped crystals of the Zn-based MOF. The yield was determined to be 70% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for the MOF: C 45.67,

A mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-phenylenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of MeOH, and a few drops of CH3COOH were added to the solution to assist in the coordination process. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes before transferring to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was tightly sealed and heated at 402.7 K for 492.652 hours. After cooling slowly to ambient temperature, yellow crystalline solids were separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with MeOH, and dried under vacuum (yield: 62% based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for ZnC18H16N2O8: C, 47.64%, H, 3.56%, N, 6.17%. Found: C, 47.58%, H, 3.62%, N, 6.12%. Selected infrared (IR) peaks (cm−1): 3420 (broad), 1685 (s), 1600 (s), 1430 (m), 1300 (m), 1150 (w), 825 (

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.49 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.088 g, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylacetamide (6 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 162.103 °C for 433.8 hours. Afterward, it was allowed to cool to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were collected by filtration, washed with dimethylacetamide, and air-dried. The resulting product was obtained with a yield of 38.5% based on zinc. The crystalline material was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3298 (w), 1610 (s), 1578 (m), 1490 (m), 1405 (s), 1255 (w), 1102 (s), 895 (m), 823 (m), 740 (w), 612 (w). Anal. Calcd for C16H14O8Zn: C, 48.99, H, 3.59. Found: C, 49.12, H, 3.45. The compound exhibits stability under ambient conditions and insolubility in water and common organic solvents such as ethanol, acetonitrile, and chl

In a 20 mL Pyrex glass vial, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (15 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2BDC (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) were combined with 10 mL of ethanol, resulting in a clear solution. The vial was tightly sealed and subjected to heating at 380 K for 457.21 minutes in an oven. Afterward, the solution was gradually cooled to room temperature at a controlled rate of 2 °C h-1, allowing the formation of colorless needle-like crystals. The crystals were carefully filtered, rinsed with ethanol, and air-dried to yield 18 mg (45% based on Zn) of the desired MOF. Anal. Calcd. for C16H12O8Zn: C, 49.31, H, 3.10. Found: C, 49.68, H, 2.98. IR (KBr disc): 3433 (m), 1595 (s), 1412 (m), 1100 (w), 780 (m), 665 (w) cm-1.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (15.6 mg, 0.064 mmol), H3BTC (20.0 mg, 0.095 mmol), and EtOH (5 mL) was transferred into a glass reaction vial. The solution was heated to 325 K for 90.050 minutes. The resultant blue crystalline product was collected via vacuum filtration, yielding 33% based on Cu. Anal. calc. for C18H12CuN2O10 (Mr = 475.84): C, 45.41, H, 2.54, N, 5.88. Found: C, 45.37, H, 2.57, N, 5.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3415(s), 2932(m), 1687(w), 1604(m), 1452(s), 1384(m), 1307(m), 1256(w), 1124(s), 1050(m), 960(m), 898(w), 846(w), 775(m), 722(m), 638(s), 560(m), 480(m).

A hydrothermal synthesis was carried out with DMBDC (12.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (23.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), and water-glycol mixed solvent (4:1, v/v, 10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated to 493.231 K for 14.7 minutes and then rapidly cooled to ambient temperature. Upon filtration, blue crystalline products were isolated and washed with water and ethanol. The yield of the obtained MOF was approximately 68%, calculated based on the consumption of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellet) displayed characteristic peaks at 3432(s, br), 1632(m), 1384(m), 1080(s), 949(m), 734(w) cm^−1. Elemental analysis calculated for C32H32CuN4O12 (%): C, 47.86, H, 4.02, N, 6.97, found: C, 47.57, H, 4.01, N, 7.02.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.212 g, 0.8 mmol), H2BDC (0.073 g, 0.4 mmol), and 4,4'-bpy (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was combined with 4 mL of 68-12-2 and 1 mL of CH3COOH in a sealed reaction vessel. The mixture was subjected to magnetic stirring for 30 minutes, followed by heating at 36.910 °C for 171.69 hours. After cooling the solution to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals of the resulting MOF were collected via vacuum filtration and washed with 68-12-2 to remove any residual reactants. The crystalline product was dried under vacuum and stored in a desiccator. The chemical composition of the synthesized MOF was confirmed through elemental analysis. (Anal. Calcd: C, 55.24, H, 3.04, N, 8.11. Found: C, 55.18, H, 3.08, N, 8.05%) and IR spectroscopy, which revealed characteristic vibrational bands at 3412, 1598, 1513, and 1381 cm-1, indicating successful coordination of the organic ligands to the metal center.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.25 mmol, 0.060 g), H2BDC (0.15 mmol, 0.026 g), NMP (4 mL), and benzoic acid (0.05 mmol, 0.006 g) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The system was heated to 143.698 °C and maintained at this temperature for 69.45 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 0.2 °C/min, blue crystalline products were obtained, washed with fresh NMP, and dried under vacuum. The yield was 58% based on H2BDC. Anal. Calcd for C18H12CuNO8 (%): C, 48.15, H, 2.69, N, 3.12. Found: C, 48.10, H, 2.65, N, 3.09. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3435 (br), 1596 (s), 1550 (m), 1498 (m), 1392 (s), 1285 (w), 1140 (w), 1045 (w), 810 (m), 745 (w).

A reaction mixture containing H2bdc (0.02 g, 0.12 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 g, 0.17 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (7.0 mL). This mixture was transferred to a glass vial (20 mL capacity), which was then sealed and heated at 37 °C for 322.2 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, orange prism-like crystals were retrieved through filtration, rinsed with DMF, and subsequently air-dried. The overall yield was approximately 58%, calculated based on the H2bdc ligand. Anal. Calcd. for C36H28Co2N2O12: C, 52.60, H, 3.43, N, 3.41%. Found: C, 52.48, H, 3.39, N, 3.35%. The infrared spectrum (cm−1) displayed characteristic absorptions at 3430 (broad), 2925 (m), 1693 (s), 1588 (s), 1386 (m), 1254 (m), and 1090 (m).

To synthesize the MOF under investigation, a mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.17 mmol, 40.5 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of isobutanol in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Subsequently, 0.5 mL of ammonium hydroxide was added as an additive to promote crystal formation. The autoclave was sealed tightly and subjected to solvothermal conditions at 427.958 K for 195.0 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting blue rectangular crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with isobutanol to remove unwanted impurities, and air-dried under ambient conditions. The crystalline product was analyzed to confirm its structure and composition, yielding 85 mg, which corresponds to a 78% yield based on H2BDC.

The synthesis of the desired MOF was carried out by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 mmol, 0.036 g), H4BDC (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol), and PYRIDINE (5 ml) in a 10 ml glass vial. To this mixture, NEt3 (0.1 ml) was added as an additive to assist the reaction. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 139.3 °C for 349.4 minutes in a preheated oven. Upon completion of the heating regime, the system was allowed to cool gradually to ambient temperature. The resultant blue crystalline product was isolated through vacuum filtration and thoroughly washed with excess pyridine to ensure purity. The yield of the crystalline framework was determined gravimetrically to be 58%. Elemental analysis calculated for Cu2C24H16N2O8 (C 47.92, H 2.68, N 4.65) found: C 47.85, H 2.75, N 4.58. The identity of the compound was confirmed by IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 s, 1721 m, 1604 s, 1550 m, 1444 w, 1383 s, 1130 m, 1042 m, 912 w, 765 m.

A mixture of H2BDC (0.30 mmol, 58.2 mg) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.45 mmol, 108.5 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of MeOH, and 25 mg of sodium acetate was added. The resulting solution was thoroughly mixed and transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The container was sealed and subjected to heating at 498.80 K for 375.30 minutes, followed by a controlled cooling to room temperature. The formation of pale blue crystals was observed, which were subsequently isolated by filtration, washed with MeOH, and air-dried to afford a 60% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Cu2(BDC)2(OAc)2]: C 44.33, H 2.23, Cu 29.74, found: C 44.11, H 2.34, Cu 29.63. IR (solid KBr pellet): ν = 3562.1 (s), 2975.7 (m), 1652.3 (m), 1600.4 (m), 1524.1 (w), 1452.9 (w), 1380.5 (m), 1259.8 (w), 1094.4 (w), 964

Synthesis of MOF Material X: A mixture consisting of 0.25 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.86 mmol), 0.20 g of H2BDC (0.98 mmol), 5 mL CH3CN, and 0.05 g NaOH (1.25 mmol) was stirred at ambient temperature for 1 hour to ensure dissolution. The resultant mixture, with an initial pH of 8.45, was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 67.610 °C for 445.5 hours. After the completion of the reaction cycle, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate. Pale blue crystalline product was obtained and collected by filtration, with a yield of 58.6% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis gave the following values: Calcd for C16H10CoN2O8: C, 44.35, H, 2.33, N, 6.47, Co, 13.54. Found: C, 44.28, H, 2.40, N, 6.53, Co, 13.60%. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3420(m), 1620(s), 1538(m), 1365(w), 1240(w), 1082

Synthesis of [Zn3(L2)2(OH)2]·3 Benzene: A mixture of H4L2 (15 mg, 0.050 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (15 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 362.620 K for 76.2 minutes and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow needle-shaped crystals of the MOF were collected by filtration, washed with fresh benzene, and air-dried. Yield: 68%, IR (KBr pellet): ν = 3452 (w), 2927 (m), 1615 (s), 1550 (w), 1385 (s), 1310 (m), 1122 (m), 1024 (w), 902 (w), 756 (m), 674 (s), 590 cm−1 (w), elemental analysis calculated for C24H36N4O10Zn3: C 39.27, H 4.94, N 7.64%, found: C 38.95, H 4.77, N 7.53%. The material was found to be stable in both benzene and ethanol.

A solvothermal reaction was conducted by dissolving Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (1.00 mmol) in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The resulting solution was combined with H2O2 (200 μL) as an oxidizing agent and placed in a 25-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was maintained at 153.51 °C for 448.6 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the reaction yielded light blue needle-like crystals. The crystals, isolated via filtration, exhibited a yield of 0.085 g (72% yield based on Cu). These crystals were sensitive to ambient moisture, hence, they were immediately transferred to a desiccator for storage. Elemental analysis calculated for C26H20N4O4Cu: C, 62.54%, H, 4.04%, N, 11.22%. Found: C, 62.48%, H, 4.02%, N, 11.18%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430(br), 1632(s), 1502(m), 1398(s), 1285(m), 1108(w), 1020(m), 745(m).

Synthesis of {[Cu(L)(DMSO)(H2O)2]·2H2O}n. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.30 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy, 0.30 mmol), and H2L (0.30 mmol) in isobutanol (8 mL) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon‐lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 239.31 °C for 359.09 minutes. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature over 10 hours. Light blue crystalline blocks were obtained by filtration, washed with isobutanol, and left to dry in air at ambient temperature. Yield: 65% (based on Cu). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H24CuN2O8S: C, 42.56, H, 4.77, N, 5.52. Found: C, 42.32, H, 4.68, N, 5.61. IR (KBr): 3402 (m, br), 2936 (w), 2862 (w), 1648 (s), 1598 (s), 1475 (m), 1381 (s), 1222 (w), 1145 (w), 1059 (w), 973 (m),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and pyrazine (0.040 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in pyridine (7 mL) and sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was then heated to 101.265 °C for 141 hours. After cooling slowly to room temperature, the reaction yielded pale yellow cubic crystals of the Zn-based MOF with a yield of 72% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10N2O8Zn: C, 47.69%, H, 2.50%, N, 6.95%. Found: C, 47.65%, H, 2.52%, N, 6.97%. The framework integrity was further confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis, showing a weight loss of 5.3% correlating to the release of coordinated solvent molecules below 120 °C.

For a typical synthesis, copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (242 mg, 1.00 mmol), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (HO2C-C6H4-CO2H, 166 mg, 1.00 mmol), and 2-methylimidazole (82 mg, 1.00 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (20 mL) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The solution was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 15 minutes to ensure complete dissolution of the reactants. The mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated in an oven at 168.01 °C for 191 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant blue crystalline product was subjected to repeated washing with fresh methanol (25 mL) for three cycles to remove any unreacted ligands or metal salts. The isolated product was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 6 hours, resulting in pure copper-based MOF labeled Cu-BDC-MeIm, with a yield of 0.358 g corresponding to a 78% yield based on copper nitrate trihydrate starting material. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3427s, 1607s, 1560s, 1504m, 1448m

A solution was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.030 g, 0.10 mmol) and the organic linker H2L (0.010 g, 0.05 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) with the addition of triethylamine (100 μL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was tightly sealed and subjected to heating at 136 °C for 140.364 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, colorless block-shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with ethanol, yielding a 57% yield based on the organic linker. Elemental analysis of C20H22N2O8Zn, calculated (%): C, 46.68, H, 4.31, N, 5.44. Found (%): C, 46.59, H, 4.35, N, 5.50. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448 (m), 2923 (w), 1651 (s), 1514 (s), 1404 (s), 1242 (m), 1153 (w), 904 (m), 754 (s), 612 (w).

In a typical synthesis for the preparation of the metal-organic framework, a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL). Concurrently, H2BDC (83 mg, 0.5 mmol) was also dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL) and combined with the zinc solution. The homogeneous mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated to 233.17 °C for 131 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, transparent crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh 1,4-dioxane (10 mL), and air-dried. The dried product yielded 92 mg, corresponding to a yield of 78% based on H2BDC. The composition and integrity of the MOF were confirmed by elemental analysis calculated for C16H12O8Zn: C, 44.48, H, 2.80%. Found: C, 44.50, H, 2.77%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (w) ν(OH), 2924 (m) ν(CH), 1682 (s) ν(CO), 1565 (m) νas(COO), 1420 (s) νs(COO),

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.059 g, 0.2 mmol), H2BDC (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) (0.036 g, 0.2 mmol), and isobutanol (10 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was then placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 134.920 °C for 478.58 minutes, followed by a gradual reduction in temperature over a 10-hour period. Pale yellow crystalline solids were collected by filtration and washed with isobutanol before being air-dried, resulting in the formation of the MOF specimen. This was obtained with a yield of 60% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C8H6O4Zn (%): C, 43.24, H, 2.72, Zn, 29.40. Found: C, 43.18, H, 2.75, Zn, 29.36. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3065(m), 1600(s), 1510(m), 1415(w), 1340(s), 1240(m), 1115(w), 1018(w), 870(w), 758(m), 660(w).

A reaction mixture containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (296.5 mg, 1.23 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (158.7 mg, 0.95 mmol) was prepared in acetonitrile (10 mL) and transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated to 368.0 K in an oven for 457.142 hours. After gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 2 K·h–1, the resulting blue crystals were collected, washed with fresh acetonitrile, and dried under ambient conditions. The isolated yield was 44% based on the copper salt. Elemental analysis of the as-synthesized compound indicated: C, 46.72, H, 3.17, N, 8.56%. The molecular formula was determined to be [Cu(BDC)(H2O)2]·(CH3CN)0.5. IR spectra (KBr, cm–1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 1675 (s), 1591 (m), 1388 (w), 1254 (s), 1108 (m), and 755 (w).

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (729 mg, 2.5 mmol), H2Tz (274 mg, 1 mmol), and glycol (500 μL, 1.5 mmol) was prepared by dissolving in NMP (25 mL) under stirring for 10 min. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 103 °C for 486.3 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the mixture yielded red crystalline material, isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with NMP. The crystals were dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 2 hours, yielding [Co(H1Tz)(NO3)(glycol)] (5) as the final product. Yield: 68% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calcd for C14H18CoN5O8 (457.25): C, 37.00, H, 3.99, N, 15.30. Found: C, 37.13, H, 4.02, N, 15.12. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3500 (br), 1620 (s), 1380 (s), 1120 (w), 985 (w), 745 (m), 670 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0650 g, 0.220 mmol) and H2BDC (0.0450 g, 0.180 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (15 mL), and the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to heating at 314.35 K for 277.59 hours. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of pale yellow crystalline products. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions, yielding 0.0892 g of the Zn-MOF, corresponding to a yield of 72.5% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C48H48N6O24Zn3: C, 44.62, H, 3.75, N, 6.51%. Found: C, 44.58, H, 3.79, N, 6.54%. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 3428 (br, υ(O–H)), 1691 (s, υ(C=O)), 1605 (vs, υ(C=C)), 1413 (m, υ(C–O)), 1235 (m, υ(C–N)), 1038 (w, υ(N–O

To synthesize the desired MOF, a mixture containing 0.105 g (0.25 mmol) of H2L ligand, 0.107 g (0.25 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.034 g (0.25 mmol) of sodium acetate trihydrate was dissolved in 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane. The solution was thoroughly mixed and then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 348.3 K and maintained at this temperature for 141 hours. Upon completion of the heating process, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting product consisted of deep blue prismatic crystals harvested by filtration and subsequently washed with 3 × 10 mL of methanol to remove any unattached organic matter. The crystals were air-dried to obtain a yield of 45% based on the initial H2L ligand. Elemental analysis for CoC24H16O10N4 yielded calculated values of C 46.12%, H 2.58%, N 8.97%, the observed values were C 45.89%, H 2.73%, N 8.83%. The FTIR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm–1) exhibited prominent peaks at 3445 (w), 1658 (s), 154

A solution consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (35 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H2BDC (20 mg, 0.12 mmol) was prepared in 12 mL of NMP. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 179.9 °C for 497 hours under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to room temperature at a uniform rate of 1.0 °C h−1, pale yellow crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with NMP, and air-dried, yielding approximately 55% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C16H14N2O8Zn: C 48.72, H 3.58, N 7.11, found: C 48.76, H 3.60, N 7.08%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445(s), 3080(s), 1640(s), 1598(m), 1498(w), 1420(s), 1345(s), 1289(w), 1190(m), 1010(w), 820(m), 755(s), 620(m).

A solution comprising Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.24 g, 1 mmol) and trimesic acid (0.06 g, 0.3 mmol) was prepared in a mixture of ethanol and water (7 mL, v/v=3:4) in a 30 mL glass vessel. To this, 1 mL of 1.0 M NaOH solution was added under constant stirring to adjust the pH, followed by the introduction of the reaction mixture into a Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 387.94 K for 227.158 minutes. Subsequent gradual cooling to room temperature facilitated the formation of blue needle-like crystals. The crystals were harvested via filtration, thoroughly rinsed with ethanol, and dried in ambient air. The yield, determined based on Cu(II), was 52%. Elemental analysis calculated for C9H3CuO6: C, 38.13, H, 1.07. Found: C, 38.08, H, 1.04%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3410 (b), 1657 (s), 1620 (m), 1448 (m), 1385 (s), 1105 (w), 720 (m).

To a solution of Al(NO3)3·9H2O (375 mg, 1.0 mmol) in 5 mL of diethanolamine was added 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol) under continuous stirring, resulting in a homogeneous mixture. This solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a heating process at 493.682 K for 118.017 hours. The system was gradually cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 1 °C/h. Upon cooling, the resulting white crystalline material was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with diethanolamine, and dried under vacuum to remove any residual solvent. The resultant yield was 180 mg, corresponding roughly to 45% based on Al(NO3)3·9H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for the formula C10H14O8Al (1): C, 44.78, H, 5.27, O, 35.64, Al, 14.31. Found: C, 44.85, H, 5.33, O, 35.59, Al, 14.20. Key IR data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1600(s), 1410(s), 1220(m), 925(w), 755(m), 685(w).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (290 mg, 1.0 mmol), 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (168 mg, 1.0 mmol), and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (182 mg, 0.8 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL). The autoclave was then sealed and heated in an oven at 501.735 K for 408.94 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, green octahedral crystals of the metal-organic framework were harvested by filtration and washed with DMF. The yield was approximately 40% based on Ni. Elemental analysis was performed for C17H11N2NiO7 (Mr = 419.98), and results showed: calcd (%): C, 48.67, H, 2.65, N, 6.68. Found: C, 48.79, H, 2.58, N, 6.60. Vibrational spectroscopy in the IR region (KBr, cm–1) revealed characteristic bands at 3400 (b), 2950 (m), 1703 (vs), 1520 (s), 1398 (s), 1254

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.4 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.1 mmol, 16.6 mg), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.1 mmol, 15.6 mg) were dissolved in 3 ml of dimethylacetamide. To this solution, hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.05 ml) was added as an additive. The mixture was transferred to a 50 ml Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 368.053 K (approx. 95 °C) for 97.7 minutes. After allowing the autoclave to cool slowly to room temperature, blue-green crystals of the MOF were collected by filtration and washed with ethanol and acetone. The yield of the crystalline product was 64%. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N showed: C, 45.67 (calculated), 45.54 (found), H, 3.92 (calculated), 3.88 (found), N, 8.36 (calculated), 8.29 (found)%.
