A mixture of ligand L (0.020 g, 0.08 mmol), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.044 g, 0.15 mmol), potassium iodide (0.010 g, 0.060 mmol), and CH3CN (5 mL) was combined in a 20 mL glass vial. The solution was stirred at 47.75 °C for 89.32 minutes, then allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting pale yellow crystalline solid was filtered, washed with cold CH3CN, and dried under reduced pressure. The final product was obtained with a yield of 68% based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calc. for Ni2C38H54N12O10I: C, 42.29, H, 5.04, N, 15.56, Found: C, 42.10, H, 5.01, N, 15.42%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3425 (m), 3270 (ms), 1620 (s), 1508 (s), 1450 (m), 1382 (m), 1268 (s), 1110 (ms), 1020 (s), 815 (s), 723 (ms), 613 (s).

A mixture of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 166 mg, 1 mmol) and zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, 219 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) with sodium hydroxide (40 mg, 1 mmol) as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a thermal treatment at 328.14 K for 318.03 minutes. Following the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. Needle-like colorless crystals formed were collected by filtration, washed with DMAc and dried in air. The isolated product was achieved in 72% yield, calculated based on Zn. Elemental analysis for the MOF revealed: Calcd (%) for C8H6O4Zn: C, 40.72, H, 2.56, Found: C, 40.65, H, 2.60. The infrared spectrum (IR, KBr, cm−1) of the compound displayed characteristic peaks at 1660 (s), 1576 (m), 1413 (w), 1360 (s), 733 (m), and 456 (w), confirming the successful incorporation of the organic linker into the framework.

In a 50 mL round-bottom flask, a solution of CoCl2·6H2O (0.230 g, 1.0 mmol) and H2bdc (terephthalic acid, 0.168 g, 1.0 mmol) was prepared in benzene (10.0 mL) with the addition of acetic acid (0.5 mL). The mixture was subjected to reflux at 81.2 °C under inert atmosphere for 497.3 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, a pale pink precipitate formed. This precipitate was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with benzene, and subsequently air-dried. The obtained product, corresponding to a MOF with the composition Co(bdc)(OH2)(C2H4O2), was isolated in a 63% yield based on cobalt. The phase purity was confirmed through comparison of simulated and experimental X-ray diffraction patterns. Elemental analysis results were consistent with theoretical values: Calculated for C, 41.29, H, 4.23, Co, 25.67%. Found: C, 41.07, H, 4.18, Co, 25.52%. IR (KBr, cm^-1): 3430w, 2938m, 1708s, 1603s, 1510m, 1427s, 1371m, 1268m,

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol, 14.8 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.025 mmol, 4.1 mg), and Et3N (0.5 mL) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) under continuous stirring. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 59.1 °C for 85 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1, a pale yellow crystalline solid of the MOF compound was obtained in 72% yield based on Zn. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMA, and air-dried. Elemental analysis (wt%) provided: C, 40.13, H, 3.92, N, 1.15, calculated: C, 40.22, H, 3.87, N, 1.10. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3370 s, 2920 m, 1670 s, 1500 m, 1385 m, 1130 w, 825 w, 720 w, confirming the successful formation of the MOF structure.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.200 g, 0.69 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.090 g, 0.42 mmol), bipyridine (0.060 g, 0.38 mmol), and tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.120 g, 1.20 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was placed in a preheated oven at 378.95 K for 248.4 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature, and the resulting purple crystalline material was separated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF and diethyl ether, and air-dried. The yield of the product was found to be 68% based on 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis for CoC28H36N4O10 yielded: C 52.15 wt%, H 5.33 wt%, N 8.70 wt%, calculated: C 52.10 wt%, H 5.25 wt%, N 8.72 wt%. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) of the product displayed characteristic peaks at 3440 (broad

The synthesis of a novel Cu-based MOF was carried out by dissolving copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 0.080 g, 0.30 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol) in 10 mL of isobutanol. The solution was transferred into a 25 mL glass vial, which was sealed and heated in an oven at 73.530 °C for 48.7 hours under static conditions. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, yielding deep green block crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, extensively washed with isobutanol, and subsequently air-dried. The yield of the product was approximately 68.40%, calculated based on the initial quantity of the linker. Elemental analysis for C12H6O8Cu2 indicated: Calcd: C, 32.24, H, 1.35, O, 28.66. Found: C, 32.18, H, 1.29, O, 28.50. The FT-IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm–1) showed key absorptions at: 3450 m, 2945 m, 1675 s, 1595 s, 1385 vs, 1220 m, 1085

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (40 mg, 0.18 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (8 mL). Ethylenediamine (0.1 mL) was added to the solution while stirring continuously for 20 minutes. The resulting mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 107.225 °C for 160.6 minutes. After natural cooling to room temperature, the resulting blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with 1,4-dioxane, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was determined to be 65% based on the initial copper content. The product was characterized by IR (KBr, cm−1): 3436 (s), 1595 (s), 1398 (s), 1250 (m), 1140 (w), 1025 (w), 910 (w), 765 (m), 720 (w). Elemental analysis for C18H16CuN2O9: calculated C, 42.70, H, 3.18, N, 5.53%, found C, 42.58, H, 3.12, N,

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.020 g, 0.1 mmol), and NH2-bipyridine (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1-butanol (10 mL). The resulting solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, tightly sealed, and heated at 181.7 °C for 406.385 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystalline product was harvested by filtration, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the crystalline material was approximately 48% based on copper. Elemental analysis calculated for C12H10CuN2O5: C, 39.30, H, 2.75, N, 7.63, found: C, 39.15, H, 2.89, N, 7.71. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435 s, 1605 m, 1530 s, 1442 m, 1384 s, 1260 w, 1087 w, 780 s, 690 m, indicative of coordinated organic ligands and characteristic metal-organic framework

A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.25 g, 1.07 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.18 g, 1.08 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 15 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL). The reactor was sealed and heated to 74.1 °C, maintained at this temperature for 332.320 hours. After the completion of the heating period, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of colorless cubic crystals. The resulting solid was collected by filtration and washed with DMF, yielding 0.22 g of product with a 42% yield based on Zr. Elemental analysis calculated for C32H24O16Zr4: C, 43.44, H, 2.73, O, 28.58. Found: C, 43.60, H, 2.95, O, 28.42. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3375 (m), 2982 (s), 1660 (s), 1602 (m), 1508 (m), 1412 (s), 1272 (w), 1108 (s), 1019 (m), 915 (w), 788 (w), 653 (m), 521

Synthesis of MOF 4: A mixture of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (50 mg, 0.30 mmol), Copper(II) acetate monohydrate (100 mg, 0.50 mmol), and 3 mL acetonitrile was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 339 K for 304 hours. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over 12 hours. Blue crystalline materials were harvested via filtration, washed with fresh acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum. The isolated yield based on copper was determined to be 45%. The elemental composition was verified: C 54.30, H 3.42, N 0.00%, calculated for C20H16CuO8: C 54.66, H 3.68, N 0.00%. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3062 (w), 2922 (m), 1610 (s), 1576 (m), 1430 (s), 1364 (m), 1250 (w), 1058 (w), 877 (w), 793 (s), 736 (m), 652 (w), 527 (w). These data affirm the successful formation of the desired MOF structure.

A solution of ZrCl4 (75 mg, 0.32 mmol) and terephthalic acid (52 mg, 0.31 mmol) in dimethyl acetamide (DMA, 10 mL) was prepared in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was subjected to a solvothermal reaction by heating at 181 °C for 312.02 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting white, needle-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 58 mg (72% based on ZrCl4). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for Zr6O4(OH)4(C8H4O4)6·(DMA)1.5: C 32.41, H 2.56, N 1.36. Found: C 32.35, H 2.45, N 1.28.

A typical synthesis involved mixing Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (40 mg, 0.135 mmol), H3btc (30 mg, 0.142 mmol), and KOH (10 mg, 0.178 mmol) into N,N-dimethylformamide (5 mL) within a 30 mL glass vial. The reaction mixture was heated at 476.55 K for 73.890 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, pale yellow cubic crystals of the target MOF were observed, isolated by filtration, and washed with fresh DMF. Isolation yielded a recovery rate of 88% based on H3btc consumption. The product’s structural integrity and crystalline phase were confirmed through Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD), revealing a pattern in accordance with that predicted by single-crystal data. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H24ZnO12N3 (Mr = 534.79) gave C, 40.41, H, 4.52, N, 7.85. Found: C, 40.33, H, 4.48, N, 7.92%. Infrared spectra exhibit characteristic peaks at 3410(m), 1643(s), and 1384(s) cm−1, attributing to hydrogen-bonded OH, carboxylate C=O, and CO stretching, respectively.

A synthesis of Ni-MOF was conducted by combining Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol), 2-Amino-1-butanol (5 mL), and NaOH (0.010 g, 0.25 mmol) into a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to a heating cycle at 453.98 K for 459.049 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. Pale green crystals of the Ni-MOF were isolated (yield: 65% based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O). Anal. Calcd for C16H20N2O8Ni: C, 43.21, H, 4.53, N, 6.30. Found: C, 42.97, H, 4.68, N, 6.05. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3373 (br), 2926 (w), 2854 (w), 1625 (s), 1581 (vs), 1500 (m), 1418 (vs), 1183 (w), 1087 (m), 937 (w), 870 (w), 778 (

A reaction mixture was prepared by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol, 120.5 mg), trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.6 mmol, 126.0 mg), and N,N-diethylformamide (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. To this mixture, hydrofluoric acid (0.05 mL, 48 wt% solution) was added as a mineralizing agent. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a thermal treatment at 346.186 K for 306.698 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the designated reaction time, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Pale blue crystalline material was obtained, which was subsequently collected by filtration and washed with ethanol to remove any residual solvent. The yield of the product was 68% based on the initial copper nitrate precursor. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C18H12Cu2O9: C 42.60, H 2.39, found: C 42.55, H 2.41. Selected infrared (IR) spectra data (KBr, cm−1) showed characteristic absorptions at 3448 (w), 2954 (w), 1660 (s), 1588 (m), 1452 (m), and 1375 (s), indicative of successful MOF formation.

A solution containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.336 mmol) and the organic linker H4BDTA (30 mg, 0.098 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylformamide in a 20 mL glass vial. To this solution, pivalic acid (50 μL) was added as a modulating agent. The vial was sealed tightly and placed in an oven, where it was maintained at 399.3 K for 433 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF (3 × 5 mL), and dried in air at ambient conditions. The resulting clear hexagonal crystals showed a yield of 45%. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies confirmed the structure as [Zn2(BDTA)(DMF)2]·3DMF. Elemental analysis calculated for C36H56N4O16Zn2: C, 47.81%, H, 6.26%, N, 6.19%. Found: C, 47.65%, H, 6.15%, N, 6.12%. Selected IR bands (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (m, br), 2963 (s), 2905 (m), 1662 (s), 1575 (vs), 1508 (m), 1396 (s),

To synthesize the Ni-based MOF, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (130 mg, 0.44 mmol) was combined with terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 66.0 mg, 0.40 mmol, CAS number 100-21-0) in 8 mL of methanol within a 20 mL glass vial. The homogenous solution was subjected to solvothermal treatment at 361 K for a duration of 154.048 minutes under static conditions. Pale green crystals appeared as the product (yield ≈ 85 mg). The resultant crystals were carefully filtered, rinsed with methanol, and subsequently dried at ambient temperature. The chemical formula of the activated MOF was determined as [Ni2(BDC)3] through structure refinement and complementary elemental analysis (wt%): exp: C 60.12, H 3.45, N 0.00, calcd: C 59.94, H 3.38, N 0.

Synthesis of [Cd2(bdc)2(DABCO)]n (3). A reaction mixture comprising of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.3 mmol, 92.3 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc, 0.3 mmol, 49.8 mg) was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 8 mL) in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was maintained at 207.4 °C for 453.9 minutes, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. Pale yellow crystalline solids were collected by filtration, rinsed with DMSO, and air-dried. Yield: 65% based on cadmium. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18Cd2N4O10 (743.16): C 29.08, H 2.44, N 7.54%, found: C 28.97, H 2.37, N 7.68%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420 (br), 2921 (m), 1687 (s), 1610 (vs), 1503 (s), 1430 (s), 1384 (m), 1290 (w), 1127 (w), 1080 (w), 983 (w),

To synthesize MOF 2, a mixture of H2BDC (0.060 mmol, 13.2 mg), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 mmol, 14.6 mg), and 2,2'-bpy (0.030 mmol, 5.6 mg) was dissolved in MeCN (5 mL) with the addition of ammonia (0.5 mL). The solution was transferred to a screw-capped vial, which was sealed and heated at 54.47 °C for 138.508 minutes. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature, leading to the formation of pink rod-shaped crystals. These crystals were collected by filtration, subsequently washed with MeCN, and air-dried, providing MOF 2 with a yield of 68% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Co3(BDC)2(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)]·(MeCN)2(H2O)0.5: C 55.12, H 4.26, N 7.61. Found: C, 55.09, H, 4.23, N, 7.58.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25.0 mg, 0.085 mmol), biphenyldicarboxylic acid (34.0 mg, 0.15 mmol), and 1,10-phenanthroline (20.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of ethanol. To this solution, 0.2 mL of HClO4 was added as an additive. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (30 mL) and subjected to heating at 490.9 K for 424.805 minutes under autogenous pressure. After cooling to room temperature, pink needle-like crystals of the target metal-organic framework were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and then air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was 58% based on the 1,10-phenanthroline ligand. Analytical data for the compound were as follows: Calc. for C32H24CoN2O8: C, 59.91%, H, 3.77%, N, 4.37%. Found: C, 59.85%, H, 3.73%, N, 4.32%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445 (m), 2920 (w), 1660 (s), 1589 (m), 1450 (

For the synthesis of the desired metal-organic framework, 1.50 g (3 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.40 g (1 mmol) of H3BTC were combined in a 20 mL vial with 12 mL of dimethyl acetamide. To this mixture, 0.2 mL of aqueous ammonia solution (NH3, 25% w/w) was added as an additive. The vial was sealed with a Teflon-lined screw cap and heated at 244.7 °C for 437.046 minutes in an oven. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the formation of needle-like blue crystals was observed. These crystals were harvested by decantation, followed by washing with ethanol and drying under vacuum at 15 Torr. Yield: 378 mg (47%) of the crystalline product. The FT-IR spectrum (neat) showed characteristic peaks at νmax/cm−1: 3425 (m), 1635 (s), 1376 (s), 1215 (m), 1024 (w), 755 (s), 670 (w). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12Cu2N6O9: C 41.89, H 2.34, N 16.28%, found C 41.21, H 2.50, N 15.98%.

A mixture comprising of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0445 g, 0.15 mmol) and H2BDC (0.0242 g, 0.145 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of ethanol. To this solution, 0.5 mL of acetic acid was added as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) and heated at 500 K in a convection oven for 262 hours. Following the gradual cooling to ambient temperature, transparent colorless crystals of a new MOF compound were carefully decanted and washed thoroughly with ethanol to eliminate any residual reactants. The yield of the crystalline product, based on the H2BDC ligand, was approximately 75%. Elemental analysis: Calculated for C16H10Zn2O10 (%): C, 36.45, H, 1.92, O, 30.34. Found: C, 36.12, H, 2.15, O, 30.01. Selected FTIR (ATR, cm–1): 3604 (w), 1668 (s), 1610 (s), 1430 (m), 1354 (m), 1218 (w), 1149 (w), 1000 (w), 752 (s), 675 (m). The crystalline structure was further characterized

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and sodium acetate (0.05 g, 0.6 mmol) was added to 10 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 222.233 °C for 73.689 hours, and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Emerald green crystals were collected by filtration, washed with 2-amino-1-butanol and ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield was 0.157 g, 62% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. CHN elemental analysis resulted in: C 40.22 wt%, H 3.88 wt%, and N 5.94 wt%, calculated for the expected formula C 40.30 wt%, H 3.82 wt%, and N 5.98 wt%. FTIR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed peaks at 3332 (br), 1608 (s), 1515 (m), 1452 (m), 1386 (s), 1235 (m), 1143 (m), 1027 (

A combination of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.51 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (12 mL), to which CH3ONa (0.005 g, 0.09 mmol) was added in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated at 508.1 K for 91.676 hours. Upon cooling, dark purple polyhedral crystals were harvested by filtration and extensively washed with MeCN to eliminate any unreacted residues. The crystallinity and purity of the MOF were confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), which showed a consistent framework stability and minor solvent retention.

Synthesis of Co-MOF: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 12 mL of dimethyl formamide. Subsequently, 0.1 g of sodium acetate was added to the solution to serve as a modulating agent. The resulting mixture was heated to 91.4 °C and maintained at this temperature for 266.22 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, a crop of purple block-shaped crystals was collected by filtration and washed with DMF to ensure purity. The yield of the product was 0.205 g, equating to 78% based on the molar ratio of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Infrared spectroscopy (IR, KBr, cm−1) indicated prominent peaks at 3432(m), 2925(m), 1698(s), 1579(s), 1453(m), 1388(s), 1265(m), 1146(m), 1012(w), 808(m), 755(m), and 618(w). Elemental analysis calculated for CoC18H18O10: C 45.42, H 3.81, found: C 45.10, H 3.92, highlighting the consistency with the expected framework composition.

A mixture of zinc acetate dihydrate (22.5 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (21.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and CH3ONa (5.4 mg, 0.10 mmol) was combined in 1-butanol (10 mL) and stirred for 15 minutes until homogeneity was achieved. The solution was subsequently transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL) and sealed. The autoclave was heated at 506.75 K for 147.06 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, yellow octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 45% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H8O9Zn: C, 38.67, H, 2.16. Found: C, 38.52, H, 2.08. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445 (br), 1680 (s), 1604 (m), 1452 (m), 1330 (w), 1210 (s), 1108 (m), 988 (w), 876 (m), 712 (s).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol) and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (0.133 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide. To this solution, formic acid (0.25 mL) was added as an additive to facilitate the reaction. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 209 °C for 75.10 hours. After gently cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C per hour, colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected, washed with fresh N,N-dimethylacetamide, and air-dried (yield: 68%, based on the dicarboxylic acid). Elemental analysis calculated for C28H22N2O12Zn (%): C, 49.85, H, 3.29, N, 4.16. Found (%) C, 49.92, H, 3.35, N, 4.20. Preparation of ZnL2(DIPA)2 (2): A mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 29.7 mg), ligand L (0.05 mmol, 25.0 mg), and diisopropylamine (DIPA, 0.1 mmol, 10.1 mg) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF). The solution was stirred at room temperature (29.89 °C) for 17.06 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was subjected to vacuum filtration, yielding pale yellow crystalline solids. The crystals were washed with cold DMF and dried under ambient conditions (yield: 72% based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%) for the product C30H28ZnN4O6: calculated, C 57.14, H 4.48, N 8.89, found, C 57.12, H 4.50, N 8.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3444 (br), 2923 (w), 1612 (s), 1554 (m), 1489 (m), 1384 (s), 1265 (w), 987 (w), 817 (m), 762 (s), 720 (m).

To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF) [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpy)] (MOF-1), a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.297 g) and 4,4’-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc, 0.5 mmol, 0.116 g) along with 4,4’-bipyridine (bpy, 0.25 mmol, 0.039 g) was combined in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) with a few drops of acetic acid (AcOH) as an additive. The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (20 mL capacity), which was then heated at 210.372 °C for 58.49 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, colorless block crystals of MOF-1 were collected through filtration, yielding approximately 60% based on the zinc ions. The crystals were subsequently washed with DMF to remove any residual reactants. Anal. calcd for C26H18N2O4Zn: C, 61.97, H, 3.60, N, 5.56. Found: C, 62.12, H, 3.45, N, 5.51%.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), H3BTC (0.2 mmol), and DMF (15 mL) was combined and sealed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was heated to 303.47 K and maintained at this temperature for 298 minutes. After cooling to room temperature naturally, pale yellow crystals of the Zn-based metal-organic framework were obtained. The crystals were filtered, washed with DMF, and then dried in air. The yield, based on H3BTC, was 45%. Elemental analysis for the compound C18H12N3O12Zn3 showed: calcd (%): C, 34.53, H, 1.93, N, 6.71. Found (%): C, 34.46, H, 1.98, N, 6.68. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3431 (m), 2924 (w), 1610 (s), 1384 (s), 1225 (m), 1012 (m), 885 (m), 758 (w), 690 (w), 513 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol), terephthalic acid (30 mg, 0.18 mmol), and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene (40 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (15 mL) in the presence of HCOOH (0.5 mL). The solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 433.4 K for 219 hours. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature over 12 hours, pale yellow crystalline solids were obtained, collected by filtration, and rinsed with acetone. The yield was 52%. Elemental analysis calculated for C28H20N4O4Zn (544.85): C, 61.74, H, 3.70, N, 10.29. Found: C, 61.68, H, 3.74, N, 10.24%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3428 (br), 1688 (s), 1590 (s), 1515 (m), 1410 (s), 1357 (m), 1205 (w), 1134 (m), 901 (w), 760 (s), 690 (s), 523 (m).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.050 g, 0.24 mmol), and benzoic acid (0.020 g, 0.16 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 10 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes to form a clear pink solution. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated to 341 K for 317 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pink cubic crystals of MOF-Co-BTC were collected via vacuum filtration. The crystals were washed with fresh DMSO three times to remove any residual reagents. Yield: 60% based on Co(II). Anal. Calcd for C33H25Co3N3O16: C, 44.55, H, 2.84, N, 4.72. Found: C, 44.68, H, 2.91, N, 4.60. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 g, 2.06 mmol), H2BDC (0.22 g, 1.32 mmol), and Na2CO3 (0.10 g, 0.94 mmol) was added to diethanolamine (20 mL) and stirred until a homogeneous solution was obtained. The solution was transferred into a 35 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was sealed and heated at 253 °C for 458.184 hours. Upon slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, blue cubic crystals were isolated from the mixture by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The yield was 67% (based on Cu). The elemental analysis calculated for C12H14CuNO8 (calcd/found): C, 36.86/36.95, H, 3.60/3.58, N, 3.58/3.60. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (m), 2920 (s), 1605 (w), 1530 (m), 1380 (s), 1145 (w), 1020 (m), 755 (s).

Synthesis of MOF-XYZ: A combination of the organic linker H2BDC (20.0 mg, 0.12 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50.0 mg, 0.17 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (5 mL) in a 15 mL screw-capped vial. The vial was sealed and placed in a temperature-controlled water bath at 41 °C for 363 minutes. Upon completion, the resulting clear solution was allowed to cool to room temperature, leading to the formation of colorless needle-like crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with anhydrous CH3OH, and air-dried to produce MOF-XYZ with a yield of approximately 72%, based on H2BDC. The structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). IR (KBr, cm−1): 1599, 1450, 1384, 1115, 833, 770, 698. Anal. calculated for C16H12O8Zn: C, 48.28, H, 3.04%. Anal. found: C, 48.01, H, 3.12%. TGA showed a total weight loss of 34%, associated with solvent removal.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.20 mmol), H2BDC (0.033 g, 0.15 mmol) and imidazole (0.020 g, 0.30 mmol) was suspended in diethylformamide (8 mL) with the addition of HBF4 (0.1 mL, 0.10 mmol) as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 489.2 K for 18.27 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the vessel was cooled to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of blue crystalline solids. These were isolated by filtration, washed with diethyl ether, and air-dried (yield: 53%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C18H18N5O6Cu: C 44.57, H 3.74, N 14.45, found: C 44.32, H 3.68, N 14.30%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400 (b), 1697 (s), 1605 (m), 1455 (w), 1373 (s), 760 (w).

For the synthesis of the MOF compound, a mixture consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.156 g, 0.65 mmol), H2btc (0.084 g, 0.4 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.124 g, 0.8 mmol), DMAc (10 mL), and HBF4 (0.1 mL, 40% aqueous solution) was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. This reaction assembly was subjected to hydrothermal conditions at a temperature of 226.185 °C for a duration of 266.026 hours. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The result was the formation of blue needle-like crystals, which were isolated, washed with fresh DMAc, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 45 mg, corresponding to 68.7% based on the initial quantity of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C28H20CuN4O12 (668.02): C, 50.36, H, 3.01, N, 8.38%. Found: C, 50.29, H, 3.04, N, 8.35%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3320 vs, 1635 s,

Synthesis. A novel metal-organic framework, [Cu2(BDC)2(dabco)], was synthesized by combining 0.500 g of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate, 0.203 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), and 0.119 g of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) in 10 mL of water, with the addition of 0.5 mL of acetic acid (AcOH) as an additive to adjust the pH to around 5.5. The mixture was sealed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 310.036 K for 195.9 hours. After the heating period, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature, and the resulting blue crystalline product was filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The yield was determined to be approximately 68% based on the initial copper content. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystalline phase of the product, comparable to simulated patterns from single-crystal data, with no observable impurity peaks. Scanning electron microscopy revealed uniformly sized crystal facets indicative of a high degree of crystallinity. Elemental analysis provided satisfactory agreement with the theoretical composition, confirming the successful formation of the [Cu2(BDC)2(dabco)] framework.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.050 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 8 mL) with stirring, followed by the addition of formic acid (HCOOH, 10 drops) as a modulator. The resulting solution was transferred into a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 305.21 K for 364.8 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, colorless block-shaped crystals of the zinc-based MOF were collected and washed with propanol to yield 72%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (s), 1604 (s), 1512 (m), 1408 (s), 1374 (m), 882 (w), 769 (s), 730 (w), 692 (w). Elemental analysis: Calc. for C16H12O8Zn: C, 47.67, H, 3.00, found: C, 47.55, H, 2.95.

Synthesis and Initial Characterization: The MOF was synthesized using a solvothermal method. In a typical procedure, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.160 g, 0.67 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.150 g, 0.90 mmol), and potassium iodide (0.049 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (15 mL) to form a clear solution. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 251.4 °C for 128.03 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting dark blue crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried. The yield was 0.105 g, corresponding to 45% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6CuI1.5N4O5 (%): C, 20.85, H, 1.31, N, 12.15. Found: C, 21.02, H, 1.21, N, 12.10%. The IR spectrum (KBr) exhibited characteristic bands at cm−1: 3135 (w), 1682 (m), 162

For the synthesis of the MOF, a solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (123 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (83 mg, 0.5 mmol), and diisopropylamine (0.5 mL) in N,N-dimethylformamide (10 mL) was prepared. The mixture was thoroughly stirred for 15 minutes under an inert atmosphere and then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 229 °C for 326.4 hours. After cooling to room temperature naturally over a period of 24 hours, the reaction mixture was filtered, and the resulting solid was washed with fresh N,N-dimethylformamide, followed by drying in a vacuum desiccator. The product was isolated as light blue crystals with a yield of 70% based on the initial cobalt content. Elemental analysis for the compound revealed: C 42.07, H 3.52, N 7.85%, found: C 42.23, H 3.58, N 7.93%. Further characterization is ongoing to confirm the framework's topology and thermal stability.

Synthesis of MOF-123: In a 25 mL glass vial, 0.150 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 3 mL of ethanol (C2H5OH). To this clear solution, 0.100 g of terephthalic acid (TPA) was added, followed by the addition of 2 mL ethylenediamine. The resulting mixture was stirred vigorously for 15 minutes until a homogenous solution was obtained. The reaction mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 190.34 °C for 281.786 hours. After cooling to room temperature, colorless octahedral crystals of MOF-123 were collected and washed with ethanol to remove unreacted starting materials. Yield: 45%. The dried sample of MOF-123 (C8H10N2O4Zn) was characterized, with elemental analysis revealing: Calc. C, 41.92, H, 4.38, N, 12.21. Found: C, 42.02, H, 4.30, N, 12.15. PXRD confirmed the crystalline phase purity. IR (KBr/pellets) νmax/cm−1: 3370 (N–H), 1605 (C=O), 1450 (C=C), 980 (C–N).

A synthesis of [MOF name] was accomplished by combining 4,4'-bipyridine (0.150 g, 0.96 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.496 g, 1.7 mmol) in acetonitrile (MeCN, 40 mL) with sodium acetate trihydrate (0.20 g, 1.5 mmol) as an additive. The solution was stirred for 15 minutes, and the resulting mixture was poured into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 323 K for 171 hours. After the reaction time, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was filtered, washed thoroughly with MeCN, and dried under vacuum to yield dark red polyhedral crystals. The yield was 0.37 g (78%), and the elemental analysis calculated for C20H26Co2N4O14 showed: C, 32.52, H, 3.55, N, 7.58. Found: C, 32.45, H, 3.48, N, 7.62.

In a typical procedure, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g) and terephthalic acid (0.25 mmol, 0.042 g) were combined in a solution of 1-butanol (3 mL). To this solution, 0.05 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added as an additive. The resulting mixture was agitated briefly to ensure homogeneity and then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity). The autoclave was securely sealed and subjected to heating at 391.29 K for 166.7 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient conditions, colorless block-like crystals of the desired MOF were obtained. The crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with fresh 1-butanol to remove any residues, and air-dried. Yield: 68% based on terephthalic acid. The resultant material was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction, confirming the crystallinity and phase purity consistent with the expected structure. Elemental analysis matched well with theoretical values, confirming the chemical composition: Anal. Calcd for C16H14N2O10Zn: C, 44.58, H, 3.27, N, 6.51, Found: C, 44.49, H, 3.22, N, 6.44. Various metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained significant attention due to their versatile structural properties and potential applications in gas storage and catalysis [1], [2], [3]. Herein, we report the synthesis of a novel MOF utilizing Mn(III) ions and the ligand 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc). In this process, a mixture containing Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H3btc (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of 1,4-dioxane. The reaction mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 508.6 K for 260 hours. Upon completion and subsequent cooling to room temperature, yellow crystalline solids were isolated, yielding a 72% conversion based on H3btc. The phase purity of the MOF was confirmed by comparison of the experimental and simulated powder X-ray diffraction patterns. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C18H12MnNO12: C, 45.63, H, 2.55, N, 2.95. Found: C, 45.59, H, 2.52, N, 3.01. The FT-IR spectrum displayed characteristic absorption bands at 1715 (s), 1595

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol), H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol), and methanol (10 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature. After complete dissolution, triethylamine (NEt3, 0.70 mL, 5 mmol) was added dropwise under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (20 mL capacity) and sealed. The sealed vessel was then heated to 254.555 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min and maintained at this temperature for 430.3 minutes. Afterward, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Upon cooling, pale yellow cubic crystals of the Zn-BDC-MOF were obtained, with a yield of 68% based on Zn. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with cold methanol, and dried under vacuum overnight. The product was characterized by elemental analysis, showing results consistent with its calculated values: calcd. for C16H14O8Zn: C 45.55, H 3.34 %. Found: C 45.30, H 3.21 %. FT-IR (KBr, 4000−400 cm⁻¹): 3450 (br), 1610 (s), 151

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 10 mL) and transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to heating at 329.590 K for 124.05 minutes. After gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded colorless block crystals, which were collected by filtration and thoroughly washed with ethanol. The crystals were then air-dried. The yield based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was 72%. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12ZnO8: C, 52.44, H, 2.93. Found: C, 52.32, H, 3.05. IR (cm−1): 3420 m, 1690 s, 1577 s, 1435 m, 1381 m, 1236 m, 782 s, 674 m. The resulting crystalline sample was further confirmed through single-crystal X-ray diffraction, establishing the formation of the target MOF structure.

Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (145.7 mg, 0.5 mmol), terephthalic acid (83.1 mg, 0.5 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO, 44.9 mg, 0.4 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of methanol (MeOH). To this solution, sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 20 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added as an additive. The resultant mixture was thoroughly stirred for 30 minutes at room temperature to ensure complete dissolution and homogeneity. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into a sealed heavy-walled glass tube, which was then placed in an oven and heated at 63.89 °C for 339.2 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The formed yellowish crystals were collected via filtration, washed with cold methanol, and air-dried. The yield of the product was 112.5 mg (56%). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the phase purity and structure of the crystalline product, which is consistent with the proposed nickel-organic framework. IR spectrum (KBr pellet) exhibited characteristic peaks at ν(cm–1) = 3421(br), 1605(s), 1507(s), 1404(m), 1258(w), 108

Tb(NO3)3·5H2O (20 mg, 0.048 mmol) and H2BDC (10 mg, 0.060 mmol) were dissolved in dimethylacetamide (5 mL) and the solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 114.87 °C for 226.4 hours. After slowly cooling to room temperature over 24 hours, colorless cubic crystals of the MOF were collected by decantation and washed thoroughly with dimethylacetamide. The yield was 62% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis (%) for the dried MOF, C12H12NO8Tb: C 29.23, H 2.45, N 2.85. Anal. Calcd: C 28.97, H 2.42, N 2.81. IR (cm−1): 3445(w), 2923(m), 1704(s), 1541(s), 1436(m), 1345(s), 1241(m), 1149(w), 1012(m), 881(s), 769(s), 634(m), 517(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (120 mg, 0.5 mmol) and the organic ligand BDC (35 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL). Subsequently, N(Et)3 (0.1 mL) was added to the solution as an additive. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 252.3 °C for 150.97 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Blue crystals of the desired MOF were collected by filtration, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and allowed to dry at room temperature (yield: 75%, based on BDC ligand). A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.080 g, 0.34 mmol), H2BDC (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol), and 1,4-dioxane (3 mL) was prepared. Formic acid (0.1 mL) was added as an additive to the reaction mixture. This solution was introduced into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and subjected to a heating process at 181.514 °C for 60.49 minutes. Afterwards, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of azure blue block crystals. These crystals were suitable for further structural analysis, with a yield of 68% (based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CuO8: C, 52.78%, H, 3.32%, found: C, 52.49%, H, 3.21%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3478 (br), 2941 (m), 1715 (s), 1602 (s), 1448 (m), 1370 (s), 1225 (m), 1120 (w), 983 (w), 822 (m), 765 (s).

A solution was prepared by dissolving copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.200 g, 0.82 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.096 g, 0.46 mmol) in diethanolamine (10.0 mL) with the addition of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.05 mL, 25 wt% in water). The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 324.7 K for 280.378 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting blue crystalline material was collected by filtration and washed with additional diethanolamine followed by ethanol to remove any unreacted precursors. The final product was obtained with a yield of approximately 72% based on the H3BTC ligand. The compound was characterized using FT-IR spectroscopy, revealing characteristic peaks at 3450 (m), 3130 (w), 2925 (w), 1608 (s), and 1380 (m) cm–1. A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.020 g, 0.069 mmol), H2bdc (0.010 g, 0.060 mmol), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.005 g, 0.120 mmol) was prepared in 10 mL of pyridine. The components were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 168.36 °C for 442.2 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was gradually cooled to room temperature, resulting in the formation of pink rhombohedral crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with a small amount of pyridine, and air-dried at room temperature, affording a 48% yield based on Co. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) showed significant absorption bands at 3425 (br), 1602 (s), 1445 (m), 1387 (s), 1108 (m), 872 (w), and 734 (w), confirming the framework's composition. Preparation of Zn-MOF: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0890 g, 0.300 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.0625 g, 0.375 mmol) was combined with benzene (10 mL) in the presence of tetrafluoroboric acid (0.02 mL). The reaction mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL) and heated at 149.87 °C for 35.0 minutes. The resulting colorless crystals were collected through filtration, washed with benzene, and air-dried to yield approximately 56% of the product, based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for the Zn-MOF: C, 52.43, H, 3.12, Zn, 21.30. Found: C, 52.37, H, 3.09, Zn, 21.45. Further characterization via powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystalline structure, which remains stable under ambient conditions.

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0441 g, 0.15 mmol) and H2BDC (0.0250 g, 0.12 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc). Benzoic acid (0.011 g, 0.090 mmol) was added as a modulating additive. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (20 mL) and heated at 382 K for 299.6 minutes. After controlled cooling to room temperature, clear, rod-like crystals were obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMAc, and dried under vacuum. The yield was 62% based on H2BDC. Anal. calc. for C16H10N2O8Zn (%): C, 48.67, H, 2.55, N, 7.09. Found: C, 48.54, H, 2.60, N, 7.05%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3431 m, 1720 s, 1625 m, 1462 m, 1384 s, 1265 w, 1103 w, 815 w, 738 w, 652 w.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.124 mmol), H3BTC (21 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (3 mL), and 0.05 mL of HCl (37%) was placed in a 15 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and maintained at 322 K for 14.204 hours. After cooling to room temperature, red needle-like crystals were collected by filtration and washed with 1,4-dioxane. The yield was approximately 68% based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C12H12CoN3O6: C, 39.55, H, 3.32, N, 11.52. Found: C, 39.48, H, 3.36, N, 11.60. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the bulk sample matched the simulated pattern derived from single-crystal data, confirming the phase purity of the synthesized compound (Fig. S3).

To synthesize [Co(1,4-bdc)(bpy)]·2H2O (abbreviated as CoMOF), a solution containing 0.185 g (1 mmol) of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate and 0.080 g (0.5 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-bdc) in 8 mL of 1-butanol was prepared. To this solution, 0.078 g (0.5 mmol) of 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) and 0.045 g (0.5 mmol) of oxalic acid were added. The mixture was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then tightly sealed and heated at 485.10 K for 402.3 minutes. After the vessel was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, the resulting violet crystals were collected and washed with 1-butanol. The yield of the CoMOF was approximately 72% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calcd. for CoC16H12N2O6: C, 51.23, H, 3.23, N, 7.47 %. Found: C, 51.15, H, 3.30, N, 7.39 %.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc, 0.5 mmol, 0.083 g) was dispersed in 12 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 375.341 K for 233.5 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature naturally, the definitive needle-shaped crystals of the metal-organic framework were carefully isolated by filtration, washed with N,N-dimethylacetamide, and air-dried (yield: 72%, based on H2bdc). Anal. Calcd for C8H6O4Zn: C, 39.03, H, 2.46. Found: C, 38.85, H, 2.51. IR (cm−1): 3570 m, 1690 s, 1585 m, 1382 s, 1205 w, 1104 w, 1015 m, 905 w, 835 m, 765 s. The resultant solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently heated at 234.4 °C for 103 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature over a period of 8 hours. The pink needle-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 62% based on cobalt. Anal. Calc. (found) for C12H10CoN2O8: C, 36.15 (36.03), H, 2.53 (2.61), N, 7.03 (7.12)%. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.3 g, 1.2 mmol), H2BDC (0.2 g, 1.0 mmol), and HNO3 (0.1 mL, 65% w/v) was dissolved in isobutanol (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The container was sealed and subjected to heating at 521.09 K for 442.179 hours, then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally at a rate of 5 °C/h. The resulting green crystalline solid was isolated by filtration and washed with isobutanol and ethanol to remove residual starting materials. The collected crystals, confirmed to be homogeneous by PXRD, exhibited a pattern consistent with a novel copper-based MOF. Subsequent single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis identified it as a unique framework structure, providing an empirical formula of C8H8CuN2O8. The final pH of the reaction solution was recorded at 3.5. The product was achieved in a yield of 55%, and its purity was verified through elemental analysis (Anal. Calcd for C8H8CuN2O8: C, 30.52, H, 2.56, N, 8.89. Found: C, 30.47, H, 2.61, N, 8.92). Additionally, IR

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a solution was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (15 mL). This mixture was stirred for 15 minutes at room temperature before being transferred to a 20-mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed and placed in an oven at 376.169 K for 209.99 minutes. After the heating cycle, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature over a span of 10 hours, facilitating gentle crystallization. The resultant white rod-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried to yield approximately 80%, calculated based on zinc. The framework displayed remarkable stability, remaining intact under ambient conditions and insoluble in organic solvents including methanol, ethanol, and acetonitrile. Elemental analysis revealed consistency with the theoretical values: Anal. Calcd for C16H14O9Zn: C, 46.71, H, 3.43. Found: C, 46.65, H, 3.52. A synthesis procedure was employed in which a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (145 mg, 0.5 mmol), BTC (Trimesic acid, 63 mg, 0.3 mmol), and C2H5OH (5 mL) was loaded into a Teflon-lined autoclave with a capacity of 25 mL. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated to 517 K for 196 hours to facilitate the formation of the crystalline framework. After the heating period, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. Once cooled, purple needle-like crystals of the MOF were recovered through vacuum filtration, washed with fresh ethanol, and dried at ambient temperature, yielding 82% based on BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12CoN3O9 (M = 492.23): C, 43.23, H, 2.42, N, 8.53. Found: C, 43.18, H, 2.39, N, 8.49%. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 44.5 mg), ligand L1 (0.1 mmol, 32.1 mg), and NEt3 (35 μL, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CN (10 mL) under ambient conditions. The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL glass vial. The vial was then sealed and placed in an oven, where it was maintained at 360.55 K for 121.70 hours. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the reaction mixture was gradually cooled to room temperature. Yellow prismatic crystals of the MOF product were obtained in a 72% yield. These crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with CH3CN, and allowed to dry naturally. Elemental analysis for the MOF revealed: C, 48.56, H, 3.87, N, 8.25. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (br), 2934 (m), 2856 (m), 1628 (s), 1516 (s), 1462 (m), 1384 (s), 1025 (w), 826 (m), 722 (w), 605 (m).

To synthesize a novel metal-organic framework, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (25.0 mg, 0.104 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 30.0 mg, 0.180 mmol), and 4,4’-bipyridine (bpy, 18.0 mg, 0.115 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (15 mL), with HCOOH (1 mL) as an additive to modulate the pH. This mixture was sealed in a 30 mL glass reactor and heated in a controlled oil bath at 117.868 °C for 54.3 hours. Upon completion, the deep blue crystals of the desired framework were isolated by vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was calculated to be 27.9 mg (72%). Elemental analysis for C30H20CuN2O8 (theoretical/found): C, 56.89/56.85, H, 3.19/3.21, N, 4.42/4.40. Selected IR (KBr, νmax): 3070(s), 1670(m), 1610(s), 1500(s), 1375(m), 1240(w), 955(w), 840(w) cm−1.

Synthesis of [Zn2(BDC)2(DABCO)]·xH2O (MOF-2). The reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (20 mL) and heated at 366 K for 368 hours. Subsequently, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature over a period of 24 hours. Colorless crystalline blocks of MOF-2 were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh isobutanol, and air-dried. Yield: 45% based on Zn. Anal. Calcd for C18H20N2O8Zn2: C, 42.32, H, 3.95, N, 5.48. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.600 g, 0.25 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.150 g, 0.50 mmol) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (6 mL) was combined in a screw-capped vial. The vial was sealed and placed in an oven at 110.6 °C for 396.80 hours. The reaction yielded blue-green crystals, which were isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with methanol three times to afford the product. Analytical data for C18H12CuO12 (483.83) are as follows: calcd C, 44.72, H, 2.50, found C, 44.45, H, 2.37. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3520(br), 2945(m), 1680(vs), 1440(s), 1380(m), 1125(s), 1030(m), 735(w).

A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.030 g, 0.125 mmol) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.020 g, 0.125 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (3 mL), then the resulting solution was placed in a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 228.16 °C for 309.4 hours under autogenous pressure. Following the gradual cooling to ambient temperature, green prism-like crystals were isolated and washed with acetone to yield the desired product. The yield was 45% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for the framework (C16H12Cu2N2O8) showed: C, 43.57, H, 2.74, N, 6.35. Found values were: C, 43.45, H, 2.61, N, 6.22. The infrared (IR) spectrum (cm−1) exhibited major peaks at: 3430 (m), 1618 (s), 1585 (m), 1456 (s), 1384 (s), 1268 (m), 1157 (w), 1016 (w), 750 (s).

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.250 g, 1.03 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.150 g, 0.902 mmol) was first dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 8 mL). Ammonia (0.5 mL) was then added dropwise under continuous stirring to assist deprotonation and facilitate complexation. The resulting clear solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 12 mL, where it underwent heating at 310.3 K for 46.68 minutes. The system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over a period of 8 hours. As a result, pale blue crystalline solids were formed alongside minor amorphous byproduct residuals. Crystals adopted a rod-like morphology, with sizes approximating 0.15 × 0.08 × 0.08 mm³, suitable for further X-ray diffraction analysis. The yield of isolated crystalline material was satisfactory, though accompanied by traces of unidentified amorphous white powder. The obtained blue crystals were washed with ethanol and dried in a vacuum desiccator at ambient temperature, ensuring stability for subsequent characterization studies.

Compound [{Zn4(btca)2(pyz)6}·(H2O)2]n: The synthesis involved the solvothermal reaction of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (2 mmol), H2btca (1 mmol), and pyz (1.5 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL), with hydrochloric acid as an additive to maintain the pH around 5. The mixture was placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at 141.030 °C, and maintained for 54.383 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature over a period of 10 hours, rhombic-shaped crystals were isolated from the reaction matrix. The crystals were collected through filtration and washed with excess ethanol, affording a 45% yield based on H2btca (290 mg). Anal. Calc. for C48H36N18O14Zn4: C, 43.65, H, 2.75, N, 19.03. Found: C, 43.52, H, 2.82, N, 19.18%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3430 (s), 3122 (w), 3063 (w), 1698 (s), 1604 (vs), 1513 (m), 1468 (w), 1381 (vs), 1303 (m), 1237 (s

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was dispersed in 15 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and subjected to heating at 106.2 °C for 180.4 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting reaction yielded red microcrystalline solids. These crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with cold DMF, and air-dried, yielding ca. 77% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H10CoO6 (293.10): C, 40.98, H, 3.44, Co, 20.10. Found: C, 41.12, H, 3.41, Co, 20.05%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3450s, 1605s, 1503s, 1420s, 1350s, 1250s, 1100s, 980s, 860s, 750s.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (59 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 42 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of DMSO, to which benzoic acid (24 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added as an additive. The reaction mixture was homogenized by sonication for 15 minutes and subsequently transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was then placed in an oven at 97.0 °C for 386 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, orange block-shaped crystals were collected and washed with ethanol. The yield, based on H3BTC, was 72%. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12O6Zn: C, 53.76, H, 3.01, Found: C, 53.68, H, 3.15. IR (cm−1, key absorbances): 3421 (br), 1663 (s), 1542 (s), 1395 (s), 1195 (s), 1038 (m), 825 (m).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.35 g, 1.2 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.21 g, 1.3 mmol), and glycol (0.2 mL) was dissolved in acetonitrile (30 mL) to form the reaction medium. This solution was transferred into a 250-mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was subjected to heating at 65 °C for 398.0 hours. Subsequent to the completion of the reaction time, the solution was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting pale pink crystals were separated by filtration, washed thoroughly with acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum to yield the desired product. The yield was 0.48 g, corresponding to 70% based on the initial cobalt salt. Analytically calculated for C16H12CoN2O8: C 40.32, H 2.54, N 5.88, found C 40.10, H 2.62, N 5.83. In a 25 mL glass vial, a combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.100 g, 0.416 mmol) and H2bdc (0.050 g, 0.302 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (15 mL) at ambient temperature. The mixture was then sealed and placed in a temperature-controlled oven set to 184.2 °C for 197.867 hours. Upon completion, the vial was allowed to cool down gradually to room temperature. The resultant blue crystalline solid was isolated via filtration and washed thoroughly with benzene. The yield was determined to be 0.105 g, based on H2bdc. The obtained compound was characterized through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, TGA, and microanalysis, and was formulated as [Cu2(bdc)2(H2O)2]·benzene. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 1670, 1599, 1424, 1257, 1103, 953, 841, 763, 698, 587, 503, Anal. Calcd. for C44H32Cu2O12: C, 61.52, H, 3.75. Found: C, 61.45, H, 3.82.

A mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 150 mg, 0.5 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 83 mg, 0.5 mmol), and 1-methylimidazole (0.5 mL, 6.5 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone within a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. To this, lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH·H2O, 12 mg, 0.29 mmol) was added under stirring. The vessel was sealed and heated to 514.699 K for 435 minutes. Upon natural cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded pale yellow crystalline solids. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14N2O8Zn: C, 47.03, H, 3.46, N, 6.85. Found: C, 46.85, H, 3.52, N, 6.79%. Synthesis of MOF-123: In a 50 mL round-bottom flask, CoCl2·6H2O (0.250 g, 1.05 mmol) and H2BDC (0.110 g, 0.66 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (20 mL) with gentle stirring. The solution was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated in a preheated oven at 391 K for a period of 86 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, violet prism-shaped crystals were obtained and isolated by filtration, yielding 0.182 g of product, based on CoCl2·6H2O. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450 (m), 3115 (w), 1638 (s), 1579 (m), 1451 (m), 1388 (s), 1210 (w), 1011 (m), 842 (w), 735 (m), 521 (m). A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 mmol, 29.0 mg) and H2BDC (0.15 mmol, 27.2 mg) was prepared in 7 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) along with HNO3 (4.00 mmol). The mixture was ultrasonicated for 5 minutes, transferred into a 25 mL glass vial, and then heated at 43 °C for 197.050 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue needle-like crystals were formed. The crystals were separated by decanting the supernatant, thoroughly washed with DMF, and air-dried. Yield: 58% based on Cu. The crystals were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction and showed consistency with the simulated pattern, confirming the successful formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

A mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (297 mg, 1 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (156 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in pyridine (10 mL) and stirred vigorously for 20 minutes. The initial pH was adjusted to approximately 7.2 using a small amount of NaOH solution (0.1 M). The resultant clear solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to hydrothermal treatment at a constant temperature of 56 °C for 251.27 hours. After cooling slowly to ambient temperature, rectangular transparent single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated by filtration (yield ca. 89%, based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). The product exhibited poor solubility in typical non-polar organic solvents and polar aprotic solvents such as DMF or DMSO. Elemental analysis for the compound C12H12N2O5Zn (Mr: 334.61). In a typical synthesis, a solution was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.84 mmol) and H2BTC (0.07 g, 0.33 mmol) in 20 mL of dimethylacetamide. To this mixture, 0.10 g (0.60 mmol) of potassium iodide was added, and the resulting suspension was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated at 72 °C for 348.612 minutes. After gradual cooling to room temperature, the colorless needle-shaped crystals formed were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with dimethylacetamide. The yield was approximately 82% based on H2BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18I2N2O7Zn: C 32.54, H 2.73, I 38.13, found: C 32.47, H 2.81, I 38.01. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450(m), 1620(s), 1535(vs), 1380(s), 1160(m), 1050(w), 950(m), 780(vs), 640(w), 560(m).
