Blue crystalline solids were retrieved by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried (yield 68% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd. for the Cu-MOF: C, 36.74%, H, 3.29%, N, 0.00%. Found: C, 36.70%, H, 3.32%, N, 0.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440 (b), 2923 (m), 2851 (m), 1608 (s), 1512 (s), 1387 (vs), 1251 (m), 1115 (m), 829 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.149 g, 0.5 mmol), H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and a solvent system of DMF (6 mL) and EtOH (6 mL) was placed into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 423.176 K for 190.0 minutes. After cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 5 °C h−1, clear prismatic crystals of a new MOF, annotated as compound 3, were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with EtOH. The yield of the crystals was calculated to be 72% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Analytical data for C16H12ZnN2O8 (Mr = 429.65) were as follows: Calcd: C, 44.73, H, 2.81, N, 6.52. Found: C, 44.55, H, 2.75, N, 6.61. The IR spectrum (cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks: 3417(s), 3058(m), 1625(s), 1512(s), 1387(m), 1270(w), 1118(w), 951(w), 847(m), 763(s), 701(m),

A solution containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.5 mmol), H2BDC (0.084 g, 0.5 mmol), and 1.0 mL of MeOH was prepared. Subsequently, NaOH (0.020 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to the solution to facilitate deprotonation. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and sealed before being heated at 144.25 °C for 251.95 minutes. The autoclave was then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, yielding colorless crystals. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with MeOH to remove any unreacted starting materials. The yield was determined to be 70% based on zinc. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12O8Zn: C, 46.99, H, 2.96. Found: C, 46.87, H, 2.85. The FTIR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm–1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3435(w), 2961(w), 1693(s), 1587(m), 1448(m), 1386(s), 1240(w), 1060(m), 892(m), 731(s), 685(w), 558(w).

A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.075 g, 0.32 mmol), H2BDC (0.049 g, 0.29 mmol), and 1,3-dimethylurea (0.010 g, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (8 mL) and loaded into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was heated at 127.4 °C for 71.760 minutes and then gradually cooled to ambient temperature. Pale yellow needle-shaped crystals were isolated through vacuum filtration and washed with DMF (2 × 5 mL), followed by diethyl ether (2 × 5 mL). The yield was found to be 42% based on H2BDC. The product's elemental analysis indicated: C20H16N2O8Zr (495.58): calcd. C 48.57, H 3.26, N 5.65 %, found: C 48.54, H 3.27, N 5.68 %. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) showed absorptions at 3235 (m), 1595 (s), 1497 (m), 1392 (s), 1287 (w), 1106 (w), 920 (s), 850 (m), 761 (w), 695 (w).

A mixture of terephthalic acid (34 mg, 0.20 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (48 mg, 0.20 mmol), and Et3N (0.1 mL) was dissolved in 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide. The resultant solution was transferred into a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated to 135 °C for 130.283 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature, the solution produced blue crystalline material, which was isolated by filtration. The crystals were washed with fresh solvent and air-dried, yielding 45.6 mg of the copper-based metal-organic framework (MOF). The yield was 82% based on the copper content. Elemental analysis found: C, 45.12%, H, 3.56%. Calculated for C16H14CuO8: C, 45.17%, H, 3.32%. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed peaks at 3410 (vs), 1632 (s), 1591 (m), 1442 (s), 1386 (vs), 1210 (m), 1080 (m), 841 (m), and 730 (w), confirming the expected structure. Microscopic examination by a Leica DVM6 digital microscope indicated the absence of amorphous phases

Synthesis of the MOF: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 59 mg), H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (0.1 mmol, 16.6 mg), and KOH (0.05 mmol, 2.8 mg) was dissolved in 6 mL of MeCN in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated at 427.14 K for 128.21 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature, white needle-like crystals were obtained and collected by filtration. The crystals were washed with MeCN and dried under vacuum, yielding 68% of the desired MOF based on zinc. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4O4Zn (ZnBDC): C, 34.94, H, 1.47%. Found: C, 34.91, H, 1.50%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450 (b), 1608 (s), 1505 (m), 1398 (s), 1250 (w), 1105 (w), 1015 (m), 750 (s).

A quantity of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) were combined in a round-bottom flask with 5 mL of methanol (CH3OH) and 50 μL of tetrafluoroboric acid. The mixture was stirred to ensure homogeneous dispersion and then transferred to a tightly sealed glass vessel. The reaction was left undisturbed at a controlled temperature of 27.541 °C for 330 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature. Pale blue cubic crystals were harvested by filtration, washed with cold methanol, and air-dried, presenting a yield of approximately 65% based on H2bpdc. The product was further characterized by IR spectroscopy (KBr, ν max, cm−1): 3410 (w), 1725 (s), 1572 (m), 1395 (w), 1274 (m), 1104 (s), 909 (m), and 754 (w). Elemental analysis calculated for ZnC28H18BF4: C 60.15, H 3.24, Zn 11.69, found: C 59.84, H 3.35, Zn 11.50.

A synthesis of the metal-organic framework [Cu2(abdc)2(bpy)] was accomplished by reacting Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 mmol, 36 mg) with H2abdc (0.15 mmol, 27 mg) and bpy (0.10 mmol, 15.6 mg) in isobutanol (10 mL) with an additive of sodium acetate (0.20 mmol, 16.4 mg). The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 209.13 °C for 205.22 minutes, followed by gradual cooling to room temperature. The resulting green crystals were separated by filtration, washed with isobutanol (3 × 10 mL), and air-dried. The yield was approximately 67% based on H2abdc ligand. Anal. Calcd for C40H30Cu2N4O8: C, 57.42, H, 3.61, N, 6.69%. Found: C, 57.26, H, 3.54, N, 6.80%. IR (KBr): ν̃ = 3405 (m), 2925 (w), 2853 (w), 1683 (s), 1618 (s), 1510 (m), 1383 (s), 1247 (m), 113

The synthesis of [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]·2.5 DMAc was accomplished through solvothermal methods using zinc nitrate hexahydrate and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (bdc) in the presence of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) as a linker. Initially, 0.500 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate was dissolved in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc). Then, 0.250 g of bdc was added to the solution, followed by 0.100 g of dabco. To this mixture, 0.050 g of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) serving as an additive was introduced to adjust the pH. The reaction mixture, with a molar ratio of Zn:bdc:dabco:NaHCO3 of 1:1:0.25:0.1, was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 386 K for 84.95 hours. Upon completion, the resulting colorless crystalline solid was isolated through vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. The material was obtained in a yield of ∼85% based on zinc nitrate. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the crystalline nature and phase purity of the compound. Elemental analysis showed close agreement

A synthesis procedure was conducted using Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.250 g, 0.84 mmol) and H2BDC (0.139 g, 0.84 mmol) as starting materials. These were fully dissolved in 15 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture remained unstirred, was sealed, and then heated at 466.867 K for 354.80 minutes in a temperature-controlled oil bath. Following the heating period, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The resulting colorless crystalline product was isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with cold MeCN, and air-dried, yielding 60% of the crystalline compound based on Zn(II). The phase purity of the crystals was confirmed through powder X-ray diffraction, showing consistency with the simulated pattern derived from the crystal structure data. The product is stable upon exposure to air and is insoluble in polar solvents such as methanol and dichloromethane. Elemental analysis results for C, H, and N were found to be in good agreement with the calculated values.

Synthesis of MOF-2: A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (374 mg, 1.28 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (210 mg, 1.00 mmol) was prepared in 68-12-2 (20 mL), followed by the addition of HNO3 (0.5 mL). The resulting mixture was placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 413.1 K for 334.2 hours. After allowing the autoclave to cool slowly to ambient temperature, the purple crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with fresh solvent (68-12-2, 5 mL) and air dried, yielding 0.82 g of MOF-2 (yield 68% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). The elemental analysis for C21H9CoO9 (M = 453.22): Calc.: C, 55.63, H, 2.00, N, 0.00. Found: C, 55.45, H, 1.98, N, 0.00%. FT-IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3432 (m, br), 2978 (w), 1663 (s), 1571 (s), 1456 (m

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (2.326 g, 8.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (1.336 g, 8.0 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 80 mL). The solution was magnetically stirred for 30 minutes under ambient conditions before being transferred into a 120 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 426.787 K for 352.34 minutes. After the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting product consisted of pink hexagonal crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with anhydrous DMSO, and dried under vacuum. The yield was recorded at 68% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H20CoN6O12 (%): C, 42.95, H, 2.96, N, 12.53. Found: C, 42.75, H, 3.01, N, 12.70. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3420(s), 1592(m), 1441(m), 1384(s), 1277(m), 1111(w), 1018(m), 846(s), 730(m), 515(w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC, 0.186 g, 1 mmol), and CH3COOH (0.057 mL, 1 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-DIMETHYLACETAMIDE (10 mL) and transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 153.85 °C and maintained at this temperature for 273.1 hours. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, rod-like colorless crystals of the metal-organic framework were collected by filtration, washed with DMA, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 40% based on H2NDC. Anal. Calc. for C18H16N2O8Zn (455.71): C, 47.46, H, 3.54, N, 6.15%. Found: C, 47.50, H, 3.52, N, 6.18%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3067 (w), 1637 (s), 1568 (m), 1436 (w), 1378 (s), 1252 (w), 1115 (w), 1038 (m), 925 (w), 840

In a one-pot solvothermal synthesis, a mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.297 g, 1 mmol) and 1-butanol (10 mL) was combined with terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.166 g, 1 mmol). The solution was thoroughly mixed before being transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was then heated to 112.17 °C and maintained at this temperature for 243 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting clear, prism-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield of the MOF product, based on zinc, was 82%. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14O8Zn2: C, 43.15, H, 3.17%. Found: C, 42.91, H, 3.10%. IR (cm–1, KBr): 3440 (s), 1605 (m), 1502 (m), 1412 (s), 1240 (w), 1105 (w), 935 (m), 780 (s), 705 (w), 668 (m).

In a typical synthesis, compound 5 was prepared by solvothermal methods. A mixture of ZrCl4 (0.250 g, 1.07 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.150 g, 0.90 mmol), and acetonitrile (8 mL) was combined in a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The solution was acidified by adding two drops of HNO3 (65%, aq) to achieve optimal conditions for crystallization. The sealed vessel was then heated at 342.43 K for 152 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting pale yellow crystals were collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried (yield 42% based on Zr). Elemental analysis for C8H6O4Zr (219.32): Calcd: C, 43.75, H, 2.75, Zr, 41.56. Found: C, 43.62, H, 2.80, Zr, 41.42. IR (KBr pelleted sample): 3445 (b), 2923 (m), 1600 (s), 1510 (m), 1370 (s), 1132 (w), 1014 (m), 751 (m), 675 (w

Synthesis of complex A: In a 40 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (0.256 g, 0.6 mmol), H2bpydc (0.152 g, 0.5 mmol), pyridine (15 mL), and oxalic acid (0.1 g, 1.1 mmol) were combined to form a homogenous solution. The mixture was subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 200.8 °C for 249.9 hours before cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour. Pale green crystals of A were isolated, achieving a yield of 47% based on Cr(NO3)3·9H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C14H12CrN2O10 (%): C, 39.44, H, 2.84, N, 6.57. Found (%): C, 39.38, H, 2.79, N, 6.49. IR spectroscopy (KBr pellets, ν/cm−1) showed bands at 3445(br), 3065(m), 1678(s), 1623(s), 1580(w), 1415(m), 1350(m), 1036(w), 931(w), 766(m), 722(w). The structural integrity of complex A was confirmed by PXRD analysis, revealing a pattern

A solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) in 10 mL of dimethyl formamide was combined with 0.2 mL of triethylamine. The mixture was then transferred into a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated statically at 66 °C for 385.7 minutes under autogenous pressure. Following the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting solid was isolated by filtration, followed by successive washing with DMF and ethanol, and subsequently air-dried to yield light-green cubic crystals of the new MOF material with a yield of approximately 64% based on nickel. The elemental analysis of the as-synthesized framework gave the following results: C, 48.92, H, 4.41, N, 7.56%. The calculated values are C, 49.22, H, 4.53, N, 7.68%. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet) exhibited band maxima at 3378 (br), 1612 (s), 1534 (m), and 1396 (s) cm⁻¹, confirming the successful coordination of the

[Zn2(btc)(H2O)2]·2H2O (4): A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.50 mmol), H3btc (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol), and THF (6 mL) with hexafluoropropene (0.030 mL) as an additive was heated in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave at 188 °C for 43.8 minutes. The reaction yielded clear octahedral crystals of 4, with an isolation yield of approximately 54%. Upon washing with THF and drying under ambient conditions, the compound was characterized. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C18H20O14Zn2: C, 33.59, H, 3.13. Found: C, 33.62, H, 3.09. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3428 (b), 1627 (m), 1508 (s), 1384 (w), 1126 (m), 981 (w), 748 (m), 626 (m).

A mixture of 0.15 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O (43 mg) and 0.12 mmol H2BDC (27 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of 2-Amino-1-butanol in a 25 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 341.99 K for 283 minutes. Upon successful cooling to room temperature, purple octahedral crystals of the resultant complex were collected by vacuum filtration and rinsed with fresh 2-Amino-1-butanol. The crystals were allowed to dry in air at room temperature. The yield was calculated to be 72% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN4O10: C, 36.71, H, 2.69, N, 10.71. Found: C, 37.02, H, 2.91, N, 10.88. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3425 (br), 3060 (w), 1605 (s), 1520 (m), 1410 (s), 1130 (m), 980 (w), 750 (s), 700 (m), 568 (w), 485 (w).

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (44.6 mg, 0.15 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 21 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 2-methylimidazole (16.5 mg, 0.2 mmol) were combined in a glass vial. DMAc (5 mL) was used as the solvent, with pivalic acid (0.1 mL) added as an additive to modulate the structure growth. The sealed vial was subjected to a controlled heating protocol at 359.140 K for 34 hours. Upon completion, the vial was gradually cooled to room temperature over a period of 4 hours. The resulting material, comprising needle-like crystals, was isolated by filtration and washed thrice with DMAc to remove residual impurities. The yield was determined to be 65%, calculated based on the initial amount of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) of the compound gave: C 42.31, H 5.12, N 9.17, experimental results found: C 42.28, H 5.08, N 9.20.

To synthesize a novel metal-organic framework (MOF), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.25 mmol) were combined in a solution of pyridine (15 mL) and N(Et)3 (2 mmol). The homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated at 366.7 K for 309 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in the formation of dark red, block-like single crystals. These crystals were harvested by filtration, washed with pyridine, and subsequently dried under vacuum. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the phase purity of the crystalline product, with excellent matching between the experimental pattern and the theoretical PXRD simulated from single-crystal data. Elemental analysis indicated a Co:C ratio consistent with the anticipated MOF structure, and thermogravimetric analysis revealed stability up to 350 °C. FT-IR spectra showed characteristic bands, confirming the successful coordination of pyridine and carboxylate groups to the cobalt centers.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.34 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.045 g, 0.27 mmol), methanol (4 mL), and N(Et)3 (50 μL) was thoroughly stirred at ambient conditions for 15 minutes in a 20 mL glass vial. The solution was then sealed and heated at 92.028 °C for 142.733 minutes in a drying oven. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless crystalline product was isolated by filtration and washed with methanol. Yield: 25% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. The crystals were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy, which displayed peaks at 3375 (s), 2930 (w), 1690 (m), 1575 (s), 1408 (vs), 1095 (m), 877 (w), 761 (m) cm−1. Anal. calcd. (%) for C12H10O8Zn: C, 41.54, H, 2.91, Found: C, 41.12, H, 3.02.

A DMSO solution (20.0 mL) containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.250 g, 0.85 mmol) and H2BDC (0.142 g, 0.85 mmol) was combined with N(Et)3 (0.025 g, 0.25 mmol) in a 35 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated to 160.907 °C for 204.10 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled slowly to room temperature over 24 hours. The resulting pale blue octahedral crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMSO, and subjected to guest exchange using acetone. The crystals were dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 8 hours. The yield of the crystalline product was 0.197 g, corresponding to 69% based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis found: Calcd. for C16H14N2NiO8: C, 43.74, H, 3.21, N, 6.37. Found: C, 43.31, H, 3.09, N, 6.18%.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.112 g, 0.385 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.065 g, 0.390 mmol), and 1,10-phenanthroline (0.078 g, 0.432 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of solvent 68-12-2. The resulting solution was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 317 K for 342.0 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Purple octahedral crystals were collected in 47% yield based on cobalt. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C24H20CoN2O6: C 58.05, H 4.06, N 5.64. Found: C 57.91, H 4.11, N 5.52. FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3065 m, 1665 s, 1590 s, 1500 w, 1385 s, 1250 m, 1135 m, 1040 m, 825 s, 750 m, 695 w, 605 m, 540 w.

A novel cobalt-based metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized using cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate as the cobalt source. In a typical synthesis, 0.128 g of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.44 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of diethanolamine, ensuring complete dissolution through vigorous stirring for 45 min at room temperature. The homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 40 mL PTFE-lined autoclave and subjected to a prolonged reaction at 495.23 K for 217.091 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction mixture yielded pale blue crystalline materials. These crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol and deionized water to remove any unreacted starting materials, and subsequently dried in vacuo at room temperature. The isolated yield was approximately 82% based on the initial cobalt content. The morphological examination revealed well-defined prismatic single crystals. The initial pH of the solution was found to be 9.1, with negligible variation observed throughout the synthesis.

To synthesize the MOF, 0.250 g (0.87 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of diethanolamine. Subsequently, 0.120 g (0.6 mmol) of benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid was added to the solution and stirred for 10 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting homogeneous mixture was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 409.7 K for 261.359 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient conditions, purple-colored crystalline products were retrieved by filtration, extensively washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield was determined to be 67%, calculated based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analyses for C10H14CoN2O8 (353.17): calculated (%): C, 34.00, H, 4.00, N, 7.93. Found (%): C, 34.05, H, 3.98, N, 7.96. IR spectra (cm−1): 1690(s), 1624(s), 1508(m), 1448(w), 1385(s), 1207(w), 1104(s), 850(w), 757(m), 681(w), and 520(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (67.8 mg, 0.35 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (58.3 mg, 0.35 mmol), and 1,10-phenanthroline (39.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethyl formamide. An additional 1 mL of acetic acid was added as a modulating agent. The final solution was transferred to a 20 mL glass vial and maintained at 35.67 °C for 94 hours to allow crystallization. Blue needle crystals were harvested in a yield of 68% based on Cu. Anal. calcd for C22H16CuN2O8: C, 55.20%, H, 3.37%, N, 5.85%. Found: C, 55.08%, H, 3.50%, N, 5.76%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3430(w), 3061(w), 1683(s), 1550(s), 1482(m), 1413(m), 1365(s), 1247(m), 1134(w), 1102(m), 960(m), 898(w), 836(m), 780(w), 731(w), 656(w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2910 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.1660 g, 1.0 mmol) was added to a solution of dimethyl formamide (DMF, 5 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 0.1060 g, 1.0 mmol) was introduced as an additive to the reaction mixture. The mixture was stirred gently for 30 minutes at room temperature to ensure complete dissolution. The sealed vial was then heated at 311.0 K for 376 hours, allowing for the formation of the metal-organic framework. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, pale pink crystalline structures were recovered by filtration and thoroughly washed with fresh DMF. The resulting framework was dried under vacuum at room temperature before further characterization by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis to confirm the composition and structural integrity.

Synthesis: The MOF was synthesized through a solvothermal method by reacting Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 g), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.15 g), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH·H2O, 0.05 g) in ethanol (15 mL) as the solvent. Initially, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol with continuous stirring at room temperature. Subsequently, BTC was added to the solution, followed by the addition of lithium hydroxide, which acted as a deprotonating agent, ensuring a better coordination environment for the metal ions during framework formation. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and sealed tightly. The autoclave was placed in an oven and heated to 129 °C for 411 minutes. After the reaction time elapsed, the autoclave was cooled naturally to room temperature. The resulting green crystalline MOF was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any residual reactants, and air-dried. The purity and crystalline structure of the MOF were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis, which matched well with the theoretical pattern based on single-crystal data.

Synthesis of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n: An equimolar mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.24 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) (0.17 g, 1.0 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) (0.16 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in a solution of 1-butanol (20 mL) containing KOH (0.056 g, 1.0 mmol) as an additive. The mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was then sealed and heated at 157.2 °C for 262.4 hours. After naturally cooling to room temperature over the course of 24 hours, blue rod-like crystals of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n were formed and subsequently collected by suction filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with 1-butanol and dried in air. The yield was 72% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C32H24N2O8Cu2: C 55.89, H 3.52, N 4.07, found: C 56.02, H 3.49, N 4.15

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was then heated to 425.95 K and maintained at this temperature for 326.53 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, pink crystalline solids were collected by filtration and thoroughly washed with fresh N,N-dimethylacetamide to remove any unreacted species. The product was further dried under vacuum at room temperature for 12 hours, yielding the Co-MOF in 63% yield based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H22CoN4O10 (C, 39.32, H, 4.54, N, 11.47, Co, 16.13), found: C, 39.28, H, 4.57, N, 11.44, Co, 16.10%. All chemical reagents employed were of high purity and analytical grade. The metal-organic framework was synthesized by combining zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) in the presence of the solvent methanol and the additive hexafluoropropene. Typically, 0.300 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.01 mmol) and 0.160 g BDC (0.63 mmol) were dissolved in 15 ml methanol with vigorous stirring. Subsequently, 2 ml of hexafluoropropene was added dropwise to the reaction mixture under continuous stirring at ambient temperature. The resultant solution was transferred to a 25 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, occupying approximately 65% of its volume capacity, ensuring a well-sealed environment. The autoclave was then heated at 172.820 °C for 307.14 minutes under autogeneous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was cooled slowly to room temperature. The formed colorless cube-like crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with methanol, and air-dried. The final product was obtained in a yield of 70% based on BDC. Elemental analysis was consistent with the calculated composition of [Zn(BDC)(H2O)·(C3F6H2)n

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.145 g, 0.49 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.04 g, 0.49 mmol) were dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 10 mL) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. To this solution, 0.02 g of sodium hydroxide was added as an additive to facilitate deprotonation. The reaction mixture was stirred vigorously at 25.3 °C for 196.356 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and centrifuged to separate the solid product. The precipitate was washed multiple times with ethanol and water to remove any residual solvent and unreacted components. The resulting white powder of zinc-based MOF was collected with an isolated yield of 78% based on the initial amount of zinc nitrate. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the crystalline structure of the MOF, and FTIR spectroscopy revealed characteristic peaks at 3200m, 2920w, 1660s, 1380m, and 1120w cm−1, indicating successful coordination between the zinc ions and organic ligands.

In this study, we report the hydrothermal synthesis and structural elucidation of a novel copper-based MOF. The self-assembly of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) in the presence of tetrafluoroboric acid under hydrothermal conditions led to the formation of a new framework denoted as [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3] · 2H2O (Compound 3). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (48.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3BTC (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and tetrafluoroboric acid (0.5 mL, 40% in water) was dissolved in 12 mL of acetonitrile, placed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and subjected to heating at 250.8 °C for 434.614 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, deep blue crystals of Compound 3 were isolated, rinsed with fresh acetonitrile, and obtained with a yield of approximately 60% based on H3BTC. Synthesis of MOF-2: A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (295 mg, 1 mmol) and H3btc (210 mg, 1 mmol), dissolved in diethylformamide (15 mL) with the addition of hexafluoroacetylacetone (153 mg, 0.75 mmol), was introduced into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 116.63 °C for 404.01 minutes under autogenous pressure, followed by a natural cooling process to ambient temperature. Yellow crystalline blocks of MOF-2 were harvested through filtration, yielding 72% based on Zn. Elemental analysis provided a formula of C18H12F6N3Zn2O9 (Mr = 673.66). Calculated (%): C 32.10, H 1.80, N 6.24, Found: C 32.01, H 1.89, N 6.15. The IR spectrum (KBr) displayed characteristic peaks: 3410 (m), 1658 (s), 1573 (m), 1468 (m), 1385 (s), 1314 (w), 1198 (w), 1074 (w), 1021 (m), 852 (w), and 710 cm−1 (m). The metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized via a thermal reaction process. A mixture comprising 0.150 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.100 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, and 5 mL of solvent 68-12-2 was prepared. To this mixture, 0.50 mL of formic acid was added as an additive to assist the reaction, and the solution was stirred at ambient temperature for 20 minutes. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 518.16 K for 147 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the thermal reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The solid product was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried in air at room temperature, yielding needle-shaped crystals with a yield of 65% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for the MOF: C 47.23, H 3.58, N 2.45. Found: C 46.95, H 3.72, N 2.31%. Selected IR bands (cm−1): 3420 (w), 1685 (vs), 1508 (s), 1432 (m), 1301 (m),

[Zn3(BDC)3(DMF)4.5]∙2DMF (5) was synthesized via a solvothermal method. Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O (1.0 g, 3.36 mmol) was dissolved in the solvent 68-12-2 (20 mL) and stirred until a clear solution was obtained. 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.50 g, 3.01 mmol) was then added, and the reaction mixture was further stirred for 8.954 minutes. The solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 36.462 °C for the required time period. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals were collected by filtration, washed with solvent 68-12-2, and dried under vacuum. The product yield was 65% based on Zn. Characterization was performed using IR spectroscopy, revealing bands at 3448 (s), 3088 (m), 1640 (s), 1580 (w), and 1384 cm⁻¹ (s). A solution of FeCl3·6H2O (0.027 g, 0.1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) was prepared in 8 mL of DMSO and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 225 minutes. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature over several hours. Yellow crystalline solids were subsequently isolated via filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried, yielding the product with a 68% yield based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calcd for C8H4O6Fe (242.97 g mol−1): C, 39.56, H, 1.66%. Found: C, 39.42, H, 1.73%. IR (cm−1): 1735(s), 1602(m), 1494(m), 1392(s), 1163(w), 882(w), 775(m), 680(w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.3 mmol) and H2BDC (0.049 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 8 mL) in a 25 mL glass vial. Na2CO3 (0.032 g, 0.3 mmol) was added to the solution as an additive. The vial was tightly sealed and heated in an oven at 516.4 K for 127.094 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per minute. The resulting white microcrystalline solid was isolated by filtration and washed with THF. Yield: 58% based on Zn. The product was characterized by FTIR, displaying significant peaks at 1720, 1600, 1578, 1500, 1445, 1410, 1385, 1089, 1020, 857, 746 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis showed a weight loss consistent with the removal of coordinated and lattice THF. Calculated for C16H10O8Zn·2THF: C, 52.14, H, 4.85, matched experimental values of C, 51.97, H, 4.78.

A novel metal-organic framework, MOF-7, was synthesized through a solvothermal reaction involving ZrCl4 (0.175 g, 0.75 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 0.99 mmol) in a solution of dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 50 mL). To this mixture, glacial acetic acid (5 mL) was added as a modulating agent. The resultant solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 108.34 °C for 274.61 minutes. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The white crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 hours. Elemental analysis gave the following results: Calcd for C16H14O8Zr: C, 42.22, H, 3.10, Found: C, 42.18, H, 3.12 %. The Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum (KBr) exhibited characteristic peaks at 1697 (s), 1504 (m), 1395 (s), 1249 (m), 1108 (w), and 972 (w) cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns confirmed the crystalline phase, consistent with previously reported structures. Full

Synthesis of [Cu(4,4'-bpy)] (2): A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.145 g, 0.60 mmol) and 4,4'-bpy (0.093 g, 0.60 mmol) was dissolved in THF (3.0 mL). Na2CO3 (0.064 g, 0.60 mmol) was then added to the solution with gentle stirring to ensure complete mixing. The resulting suspension was left to react at 321.26 K for 77.2 minutes in a sealed reaction vessel. After cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered and the solid product was washed with THF to remove any unreacted ligands. Pale blue crystals were obtained following vacuum drying (yield: 0.025 g, 30% based on Cu). The crystalline structure was confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis, indicating a pure framework formation. Elemental analysis gave values of C, 45.32, H, 3.42, N, 8.23%, in good agreement with calculated values for C16H12CuN4O4. IR spectrum (ATR, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3060 (s), 2925 (m), 1632 (vs), 1578 (s), 1492 (m), 1428 (m), 1385 (s), 1260

The field of metal-organic frameworks has witnessed significant advancements through the integration of various novel ligands to generate complex architectures with enhanced properties. Herein, we report the synthesis of a novel Zn(II)-based MOF utilizing a combination of aromatic ligands to achieve a structurally intriguing network. The synthesis involved dissolving ZnCl2·4H2O (27.3 mg, 0.2 mmol) and the chelating ligand, trimesic acid (19.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), in 5 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF). To this, a catalytic amount of sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 2 drops, 2 M) was added to assist in deprotonating the ligand, thereby facilitating metal coordination. The resultant mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at a temperature of 416.10 K for 92.45 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, orange block crystals were collected and thoroughly washed with ethanol to remove unreacted materials. The crystals were then dried under ambient conditions, yielding a 62% net product based on trimesic acid. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for (C54H40Zn2O14): C, 57.97, H, 3.60. Found: C, 57.82, H, 3.52. The infrared spectrum (ATR-IR, cm−1

For the synthesis of MOF2, a reaction mixture was prepared by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.172 mmol) and trimesic acid (0.030 g, 0.143 mmol) in diethanolamine (5.0 mL) in the presence of o-phenanthroline (0.010 g, 0.050 mmol) as an additive. This solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 85.107 °C for 501.6 minutes. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, orange block-shaped crystals formed, which were isolated by filtration and air-dried to afford 0.034 g (70% yield based on trimesic acid). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for Co3(BTC)2·3H2O: C 32.55, H 3.11, N 0.00. Found: C 32.70, H 3.22, N 0.05. IR (cm−1): 3398(br), 1608(s), 1421(vs), 1384(s), 1265(m), 1110(w), 721(m), 548(w).

A mixture of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.150 g, 0.9 mmol) and chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, 0.400 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 15 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was then heated at 241.3 °C for 472 hours under static conditions. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting deep green octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with fresh NMP to remove unreacted starting materials. The crystals were air-dried to afford a yield of 42% based on chromium. Elemental analysis calculated for Cr(C8H4O4)(C5H9NO)2: C, 45.02, H, 5.37, N, 10.44, found: C, 44.89, H, 5.22, N, 10.31. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm–1): 1670 vs, 1608 s, 1475 m, 1380 m, 1250 w, 1150 w, 870 m, 750 s.

A 3 mL solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (34.8 mg, 0.12 mmol) was combined with 3 mL of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) in a 10 mL reaction vial. The nanoporous composite was synthesized using 2-amino-1-butanol as the solvent. The reaction mixture was subject to a temperature of 355 K for 11.21 minutes under continuous stirring. Upon completion, the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, and light green crystalline solids of the MOF were collected. The product was isolated by filtration, yielding the crystalline phase with a purity suitable for structural analysis and subsequent application testing.

The metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized via a solvothermal method using dimethyl acetamide (DMA) as the solvent and triethylamine (Et3N) as the additive. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.210 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in DMA (12 mL) to form a clear solution. Subsequently, Et3N (0.5 mL) was added dropwise under constant stirring to adjust the pH to approximately 6. The homogenous mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 376.180 K for 358.2 hours under static conditions. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue cubic crystals were obtained, washed with fresh DMA, and then air-dried. The crystals were characterized using X-ray diffraction, confirming their crystalline structure. Elemental analysis found C = 48.67%, H = 3.89%, N = 4.32%, consistent with the calculated values for C18H14CuN2O8. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (s, b), 1628 (vs), 1549 (s), 1405 (vs), 1234 (w), 1105 (

Synthesis of [Zn2(L3)(OH)2]·3 C2H5OH: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.50 mmol), H2L3 (0.05 g, 0.20 mmol), and ammonium hydroxide (2 mL) in C2H5OH (25 mL) was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The assembly was sealed and heated to 115.60 °C for 234 minutes under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals of the MOF were isolated by filtration, rinsed with distilled ethanol, and air-dried. Yield: 68%. IR (KBr pellet): 3435 (m), 1598 (s), 1425 (m), 1380 (w), 1105 (m), 1010 (m), 840 (w), 770 cm−1 (w), elemental analysis calcd (%) for C21H25NO12Zn2: C 35.78, H 3.57, N 1.99, found: C 35.69, H 3.63, N 2.05. PXRD patterns confirmed the phase purity of the crystalline product.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (58.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (42.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL), along with pivalic acid (17.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) as an additive. The solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to heating at 453.810 K for 154.315 hours. Following the heating period, the reaction mixture was allowed to slowly cool to room temperature within the autoclave. Pale-yellow crystalline rods were collected via filtration, subsequently rinsed with fresh 1,4-dioxane, and air-dried, yielding a 45% recovery based on zinc nitrate. Elemental analysis (%) for C24H18N2O10Zn (559.80): calculated C 51.47, H 3.24, N 5.00, found C 51.42, H 3.31, N 4.98. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3600 (m), 2930 (w), 1715 (vs), 1620 (s), 1400 (m), 1325 (w), 1165 (m), 895 (

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.072 g, 0.3 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. Sodium acetate (0.036 g, 0.4 mmol) was added to the solution under continuous stirring until a clear solution was obtained. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 127.0 °C for 243 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with water, and air-dried, yielding approximately 55% based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis for C18H12Cu2O12, calculated: C 36.25, H 2.03 %. Found: C 36.05, H 1.95 %. PXRD confirmed the phase purity of the product (see Supporting Information for details).

Synthesis. The metal-organic framework [MOF-123] was synthesized through solvothermal methods by combining metal precursors and organic linkers. In a 50 mL Schlenk flask, 0.500 g (1.0 mmol) of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and 0.200 g (1.5 mmol) of terephthalic acid were dissolved in 20 mL of acetonitrile to form a homogeneous solution. Subsequently, 0.050 mL (0.3 mmol) of HBF4 was added dropwise with continuous stirring to stabilize the intermediate species and enhance crystallinity. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated to 434.2 K for 37.09 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool down to room temperature naturally. Pale pink crystals of MOF-123 were isolated by filtration, washed with additional acetonitrile, and dried under vacuum. The crystalline product was obtained in a yield of 75%, confirmed to be phase-pure by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis of the product indicated satisfactory agreement with the calculated values, confirming the stoichiometry and integrity of the framework. The crystals exhibited robust structural features with high thermal stability as indicated by thermogravimetric analysis.

A crystalline metal-organic framework was synthesized by dissolving 0.60 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) and 0.50 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) in 20 mL of methanol. To this solution, 0.10 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) was added as an additive to promote crystallization. The reaction mixture was placed in a 50 mL glass vial and maintained at 62.46 °C for a duration of 351 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, resulting in the formation of clear, colorless MOF crystals. The solid product was then collected by filtration and washed with methanol to remove any residual impurities. The yield of the MOF was approximately 55% based on the initial amount of Zn(II). Infrared spectroscopy confirmed the successful coordination of zinc and the organic linker, showing characteristic peaks at 1600 cm−1 and 1400 cm−1 corresponding to the carboxylate groups. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis indicated a highly crystalline structure, consistent with the expected MOF topology.

Synthesis. To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 43.5 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.30 mmol, 49.8 mg), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 15 mL), and potassium hydroxide (0.10 mmol, 5.6 mg) was prepared. The components were combined in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and stirred continuously for 30 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The resultant mixture had a pH of approximately 9.5, owing to the incorporation of KOH. The autoclave was then sealed and subjected to a hydrothermal process by heating at 355 K for 333 minutes. Post-heating, the suspension was allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting purple crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried, yielding a product with a mass of 0.275 g, corresponding to a 55% yield based on cobalt. Elemental analysis of the compound revealed the following values in wt %: C, 51.02 (calcd 51.45), H, 4.23 (calcd 4.32), N, 3.92 (calcd 4.02). X-ray diffraction

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of the ligand H2BDC (benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, 50 mg, 0.30 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89 mg, 0.30 mmol) was combined in dimethylacetamide (10 mL) within a 20 mL glass vial. An additive, 1,3-dimethylurea (25 mg, 0.25 mmol), was introduced to the solution to facilitate crystal growth. The vial was sealed tightly and subjected to controlled heating at 36.29 °C for 33.393 hours. Afterward, upon returning to ambient temperature slowly over several hours, the crystalline product was isolated via filtration and rinsed with methanol to remove residual solvent. The resulting colorless crystals were identified as the desired MOF with framework formula [Zn4O(BDC)3]·(DMF) and were isolated in 68% yield. X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the structural integrity and phase purity. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1605, 1508, 1401, 1310, 1256, 1103, 1020, 804, 742, 670, 612. A solution was prepared by dissolving CoCl2·6H2O (230 mg, 0.964 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol) in THF (20 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 hours to ensure homogenous distribution of reactants. Subsequently, the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave with a capacity of 50 mL. The autoclave was sealed and placed in an oven set to 419.174 K, where it was maintained for 500 hours without disturbance. After cooling to ambient temperature naturally, deep blue crystals of the desired MOF were retrieved by filtration and thoroughly rinsed with methanol. The final product was air-dried for 48 hours, yielding 0.263 g, which corresponds to a 52% yield based on cobalt. The structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) verified phase purity, while its chemical integrity was assessed by IR spectroscopy: 3386 (m), 1635 (s), 1578 (m), 1440 (s), 1257 (w), 1110 (m), 1002 (w), 886 (w), 760 (s), 642 (m) cm⁻¹. Elemental analysis calculated for CoC10H8O4: C, 47

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2000 g, 0.675 mmol), H2BDC (0.0900 g, 0.5 mmol), and N-methyl imidazole (0.0410 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of dimethyl acetamide along with 1 mL of ammonia in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15 minutes to ensure uniformity before sealing. The autoclave was then heated to 246 °C and maintained at this temperature for 179.6 hours. Following cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless octahedral single crystals were harvested by filtration and rinsed with dimethyl acetamide. The crystalline product was subsequently dried in a vacuum desiccator for 24 hours. The yield was determined to be 25 mg, representing a 65% yield based on H2BDC. The phase purity of the obtained MOF was confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) in KBr pellets showed characteristic peaks at 3436 (m), 1702 (s), 1575 (m), 1455 (m), 1248 (w), 944 (m), 875 (m), 772 (m), and 504 (m) cm^-1.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), H2bdc (0.029 g, 0.17 mmol), and Sodium Hydroxide (0.013 g, 0.32 mmol) was dissolved in 1-butanol (5 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The solution was heated to 347.92 K and maintained for 29 minutes under constant stirring. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless needle-shaped crystals of the MOF were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (yield 58% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental Analysis (%) calculated for C16H14O8Zn: C, 49.04, H, 3.60, Zn, 16.71. Found: C, 48.95, H, 3.72, Zn, 16.65.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0483 g, 0.2 mmol) and H2BDC (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (5 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 331.07 K for 333 hours. After the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale blue block crystals were isolated through filtration, washed with fresh 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (3 × 10 mL) to remove any residual reactants or by-products, and dried under ambient conditions. The crystalline product was characterized by elemental analysis, with calculated values (%) for C12H8CuN2O6: C, 40.17, H, 2.25, N, 7.82. Found: C, 39.94, H, 2.33, N, 7.65. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (br), 1682 (s), 1505 (m), 1364 (w), 1270 (w), 1142 (w), 950 (w), 787 (w).

A solution was prepared by dissolving Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.200 g, 0.830 mmol) and H2bpdc (biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid) (0.175 g, 0.780 mmol) in DMSO (5 mL, 70.47 mmol). The mixture was stirred, and glycol (0.5 mL) was added to the solution. The reaction mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave, filling it to 50% capacity, and then it was subjected to solvothermal conditions at 503.746 K for 362.4 minutes. After completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate. The resulting blue crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol and acetone, and dried at room temperature under vacuum. The yield was calculated to be 78% based on Cu. Elemental analysis for C22H18CuO6: C, 56.32, H, 3.87 (calcd: C, 56.21, H, 3.92). The X-ray powder diffraction pattern confirmed the phase purity of the compound, and additional characterization was supported by FTIR spectroscopy, which showed characteristic peaks at 3420 (s), 3068 (m), 1679 (w), 1543 (s), and

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of 0.25 g (0.50 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·4H2O and 0.20 g (0.40 mmol) of H2BDC was dissolved in 10 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The solution was carefully transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was securely sealed and subsequently heated at 130 °C for 322 hours. Upon completion of the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting transparent octahedral crystals were collected and rinsed with fresh NMP to remove any residual starting materials. The crystals were then air-dried for three days. The yield of the obtained MOF was 0.15 g, 45% based on the initial amount of H2BDC. Anal. calcd for [Zn(BDC)(H2O)2]◦NMP: C, 48.27, H, 4.92, N, 5.50. Found: C, 48.44, H, 5.01, N, 5.62. Selected IR peaks (cm–1): 3428 (s), 1654 (m), 1541 (m), 1430 (vs), 1362 (m), 1205 (w), 110

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.086 mmol) and H3L (10 mg, 0.034 mmol) was dissolved in 3 mL of 1-butanol with 0.5 mL of Et3N in a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and placed in a pre-heated oven at 460 K for 147.16 minutes. After the reaction was complete, the system was cooled to room temperature, yielding pale pink, prism-shaped crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, rinsed with cold 1-butanol, and allowed to air dry. The yield was approximately 65% based on the ligand. In a typical synthesis, 0.320 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.07 mmol) was combined with 0.150 g of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.83 mmol) in a glass vial. The mixture was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water with gentle stirring until a homogeneous solution was obtained. Subsequently, 0.5 mL of HClO4 (0.1 M) was carefully added to the solution as an additive to adjust the pH to 1.5. The vial was sealed and placed in an oil bath, maintaining a constant temperature of 307.11 K for a duration of 273 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, needle-shaped crystals of the Zn-MOF were obtained. These crystals were filtered, thoroughly washed with deionized water, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the high purity and crystalline nature of the MOF, with patterns matching well with simulated diffraction data. The thermal stability of the synthesized MOF was evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis, indicating a weight loss consistent with the release of guest water molecules below 150 °C and demonstrating robust framework stability up to 300 °C. All chemicals used were of analytical grade and used without further purification. A new metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized from a mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), terephthalic acid, and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) in the presence of dimethylformamide (DMF) as a solvent. Approximately 0.5 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.25 g of terephthalic acid were dissolved in 15 mL DMF, followed by the addition of 0.1 g DABCO and a catalytic amount of hexafluoropropene. The mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature until a homogeneous solution was achieved. Subsequently, the solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was filled to 60% of its total volume capacity. The vessel was then sealed and heated to 125 °C for 128.74 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature. Colorless, needle-shaped crystals of the MOF were collected via filtration, washed with DMF, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the product was approximately 45% based on the initial zinc content. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes before being transferred to a capped vessel. The vessel was then maintained at a temperature of 302.046 K for a duration of 6.615 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, blue rod-like crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained with a yield of 52% based on Cu. The crystals were washed with THF and allowed to dry in the air overnight. The composition of 2 was confirmed by elemental analysis as [Cu2(μ2‐OH)2(BTC)(H2O)2]·(THF)1.5: calcd. C 40.21, H 3.52, O 29.96 %, found C 40.09, H 3.43, O 30.12 %. Selected IR data (cm–1): 3435 (broad, s), 2924 (w), 1649 (s), 1578 (m), 1468 (m), 1384 (s), 112

[Zn2(BDC)2(DABCO)]n. A mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.50 g, 1.68 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.24 g, 1.44 mmol), and DABCO (0.10 g, 0.89 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (MeCN, 10 mL) in the presence of potassium iodide (0.12 g, 0.72 mmol) to facilitate crystallization. The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated at 242.413 °C for 199 minutes. After naturally cooling to room temperature, transparent block-shaped crystals were harvested by filtration, rinsed thoroughly with MeCN, and air-dried (yield 75% based on zinc). The chemical composition was confirmed by elemental analysis: calculated for C16H14N2O4Zn2 (433.07): C, 44.35, H, 3.26, N, 6.46%. Found: C, 44.10, H, 3.34, N, 6.28%. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 g, 1.35 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.2 g, 0.95 mmol) was dissolved in 25 mL of methanol (MeOH) under vigorous stirring until a clear solution was obtained. The solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave without any additive and sealed tightly. The autoclave was heated to 209.071 °C and maintained at this temperature for 388.84 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were collected by filtration and washed with fresh MeOH to remove any residual impurities. The product was then air-dried. The composition of the synthesized framework was determined as [Zn3(BTC)2]·xMeOH based on single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C18H12O12Zn3: C, 43.90, H, 2.45. Found: C, 43.75, H, 2.68. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 3396 (br), 1598 (s), 1445

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol) and H3BTC (0.042 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (7 mL) under continuous stirring for 30 minutes at ambient temperature. This homogeneous solution was transferred to a 20 mL glass vial, which was then tightly sealed and heated at 356.4 K for 493.6 minutes. After the slow cooling process back to room temperature, purple needle-shaped crystals of the desired MOF were formed and collected by filtration, subsequently rinsed with fresh DMF, and dried under vacuum. The yield was approximately 62%, calculated based on the initial amount of H3BTC. Elemental analysis suggested for C18H12Co3N6O12: C, 31.28, H, 1.73, N, 12.17. Found: C, 31.14, H, 1.69, N, 12.00%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3458w, 2954w, 1627s, 1554s, 1448m, 1385vs, 1257s, 1164w, 987m, 837w, 751m, 676w.

A reaction mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.168 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (64 mg, 0.384 mmol) was prepared in a glass tube by dissolving both reactants in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 12 mL). The solution was thoroughly mixed and then the tube was sealed. The system was placed in a convection oven set to 39.884 °C and maintained under these conditions for 140.247 hours. Upon completion of the heating period, rod-shaped crystals were formed and carefully separated by filtration, followed by washing with fresh DMF (5 mL). The isolated crystals were air-dried under ambient conditions to give a yield of 80 mg (65%). Elemental analysis for C12H10O6Zn (calculated): C, 43.04, H, 3.01. Found: C, 42.83, H, 3.18. The deviations in %C might be attributed to adventitious solvent. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) confirmed the framework’s composition, with key bands observed at 1595 (m, C=O stretch), 1504 (w, C=C stretch), 1387 (s, COO−). The structural identity was further corroborated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, confirming the formation of the anticipated MOF topology.

The solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 424 K for 155.4 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C min^-1, dark purple needle-like crystals were filtered, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (yield: 72% based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C28H26CoN2O6: C, 61.40, H, 4.78, N, 5.11. Found: C, 61.22, H, 4.85, N, 5.05. IR (KBr pellets, cm^-1): 3420 (s), 3052 (w), 1620 (s), 1575 (m), 1450 (s), 1380

Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (40 mg, 0.098 mmol) and H4BDC (25 mg, 0.15 mmol) were combined with 5 mL of diethylformamide in a 15 mL screw-cap glass vial. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating in an oil bath at 51 °C for 57.54 minutes, after which it was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Upon completion of the reaction, red crystalline solids were retrieved. The product was isolated by filtration, extensively washed with diethylformamide, and subsequently air-dried. The yield was determined to be 30 mg, corresponding to a 50% yield based on Fe. Elemental analysis calculated for FeBDC-1: C, 48.56%, H, 3.90%. Found: C, 48.74%, H, 3.68%. The phase purity and structural integrity of the sample were further corroborated by powder X-ray diffraction analysis (see supplementary information). In this study, an innovative zinc-based metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized and characterized. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.147 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (5 mL) in a 25 mL PTFE-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to heating at 423 K for 451.911 hours, followed by slow cooling to ambient temperature over the course of 12 hours. Pale yellow crystalline plates, suitable for single-crystal X-ray crystallography, were isolated in a 68% yield based on BDC. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C16H10O8Zn: C 52.55, H 2.76, found: C 52.82, H 2.69. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1): 3465 (br), 3080 (m), 1678 (s), 1590 (s), 1501 (m), 1405 (v), 1297 (m), 1134 (m), 1021 (s), 899 (m), 755 (s), 689 (m), 540 (w). A solution comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.062 mmol, 18.0 mg) and H2BDC (0.031 mmol, 5.2 mg) was prepared using a solvent mixture of DEF/ethanol (7 mL, 3:1, v/v) in a 25 mL glass vial. The contents were then heated at 387.3 K for 302.780 minutes. Upon cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature gradually over a period of 10 hours, dark red octahedral crystals of the metal-organic framework Co-BDC were isolated. The crystals were subsequently washed with DEF and briefly soaked in chloroform. The solid product was recovered under reduced pressure for 5 hours and further dried in a vacuum oven at 120 °C overnight. The yield of the crystalline material was 70% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis revealed: C, 52.48, H, 3.06, with calculated values of: C, 52.51, H, 3.12. IR bands (cm−1): 3545 br(m, O−H), 2927 w(C−H), 1650 s(C═O), 1575 s(C═C), 1420 m(C−C), 1310 s(C−O), 1160 m(C−O), and 755 w(C−

To synthesize the MOF compound, a mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (300 mg, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (66 mg, 0.4 mmol) was combined in acetonitrile (CH3CN, 6 mL). The solution was thoroughly mixed until homogeneous, then placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 194 °C for 488 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting crystals were collected by filtration, rinsed with fresh acetonitrile, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was 45%, calculated based on the initial amount of Zn. Elemental analysis (%) for the MOF was conducted, yielding results: C 53.25, H 3.23, N 3.55, these values were found to match well with the calculated values: C 53.12, H 3.20, N 3.60. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern confirmed the crystalline nature of the product, indicating a high degree of phase purity and structural integrity.

All starting materials were obtained from commercial sources as analytical grade reagents and utilized without further purification. A mixture for the synthesis of compound X was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.50 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (83 mg, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) in the presence of 1,3-dimethylurea (50 mg, 0.55 mmol) as an additive. The resulting solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 125 °C for 288.2 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, translucent octahedral crystals were collected via filtration, rinsed with MeCN, and air-dried, yielding 70-75% of the product based on the metal salt. The elemental analysis for compound X indicates: C, 48.25%, H, 4.82%, N, 7.58%. Found: C, 48.02%, H, 5.01%, N, 7.32%. A coordination polymer, [Cu3(btc)2]n (btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), was prepared under solvothermal conditions to explore its potential as a metal-organic framework (MOF). In a typical procedure, 0.267 g of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate was dissolved in 8 mL of acetonitrile. Subsequently, 0.147 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was added to the solution, and the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at ambient temperature to ensure homogenization. The homogeneous solution, with the molar ratios of 2:3 copper(II) to btc, was carefully transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 485 K for 443.15 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting blue crystalline solid was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with acetonitrile, and dried under ambient conditions. The crystalline product was obtained in an approximate yield of 75% based on copper(II) nitrate. The composition was confirmed by elemental analysis, calculated (%) for [C18H6Cu3O12]: C, 35.38, H, 0.98. Found: C, 35.32, H, 1.02. IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.84 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.20 g, 0.84 mmol), and nitric acid (0.1 mL, 1.6 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (8 mL). The solution was thoroughly stirred before being transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was then heated at 355 K for 289.9 minutes. Upon the gradual cooling of the reaction mixture to ambient temperature, transparent octahedral crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.16 g, 48% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12ZnN3O12: C, 40.63, H, 2.27, N, 7.89. Found: C, 40.54, H, 2.36, N, 7.81. IR spectrum (cm−1): 3432s, 1717m, 1575s, 1478m, 1384s, 1281m, 1140w, 912w, 827w, 737s, 652m, 505w.

A reaction mixture composed of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (20.0 mg, 68.7 μmol) and H2btc (12.5 mg, 59.9 μmol) was dissolved in methanol (3.0 mL). HNO3 (0.1 mL, 1 M) was added as a reaction additive. The solution was transferred to a 10 mL glass vial, tightly sealed, and heated at 458.6 K for 155 minutes. After allowing the vial to cool to ambient temperature, the dark red crystals were isolated, washed with methanol, and air-dried. Yield: 75% based on Cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C60H50Co3N12O30 (%): C, 41.85, H, 2.93, N, 8.16. Found: C, 41.60, H, 2.78, N, 8.31. Selected FT-IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3435, 1620, 1485, 1358, 1150, 840, 775, 650.

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.84 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.14 g, 0.84 mmol), and methanol (15 mL) was prepared in a glass reaction vessel. Concentrated sulfuric acid (0.5 mL) was carefully added to the solution under continuous stirring to adjust the environment for optimal metal-ligand assembly. The reaction vessel was sealed and subjected to hydrothermal conditions by heating at 185.934 °C for 336.590 hours. Upon completion of the reaction period, the vessel was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature at a rate of 0.2 °C/min. The resulting pale-yellow crystals were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with methanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The yields were calculated to be 58% based on the initial amount of terephthalic acid used. Elemental analysis provided the following results—calculated for C16H12O8S4Zn: C, 35.28, H, 2.22, S, 23.56, found: C, 35.15, H, 2.18, S, 23.65. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns confirmed the crystalline purity and the structural integrity when compared to the simulated pattern from single-crystal analysis (Fig. S3).

A mixture of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.242 g, 0.6 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and ammonium hydroxide (0.5 mL of a 28% solution) was dissolved in 3.5 mL of 1,4-dioxane. The resulting solution was transferred into a 12 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and subjected to heating at 106.568 °C for 418.889 minutes. After the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Yellow needle-like crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried in air, yielding the product (yield: 40% based on Fe). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H10FeO6: C 44.57, H 3.11, Fe 17.28, found: C 44.65, H 3.25, Fe 17.10. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3545 (s), 2921 (m), 1625 (s), 1458 (m), 1374 (s), 1217 (w), 1115 (m), 892 (w), 769 (m), 693 (w).

A mixture of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.10 g, 0.34 mmol), trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.05 g, 0.24 mmol), and sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 0.10 g, 0.94 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol in a 30 mL borosilicate glass vial. The vial was tightly sealed and maintained at 34.8 °C for 377.70 hours in an isothermal oven. Upon completion of the reaction, the suspension was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, resulting in the formation of dark purple crystalline materials. These crystals were filtered, thoroughly washed with ethanol to remove occluded solvent and excess reactants, and subsequently air-dried. The yield was calculated to be approximately 65%, based on cobalt nitrate hexahydrate. Elemental analysis (%) of the obtained product Co3(BTC)2(C6H15NO)2: calculated: C 42.29, H 5.55, N 4.52, found: C 42.35, H 5.50, N 4.50. The synthesis of a novel metal-organic framework (MOF) was carried out under controlled conditions using zinc acetate dihydrate and terephthalic acid as primary reactants. Specifically, 0.296 g (1.35 mmol) of Zn(O2CCH3)2·2H2O and 0.166 g (1.0 mmol) of H2BDC were dissolved in 20 mL of 1-butanol within a standard Schlenk flask. To this mixture, 0.061 g (1.0 mmol) of HBO3 was added as a modulating additive to enhance crystal growth and structural stability. The resulting solution was stirred thoroughly to ensure homogeneity before being transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was tightly sealed and heated to a constant temperature of 361.6 K for 280.293 minutes. After allowing the reaction vessel to cool naturally to ambient temperature, pale white crystals formed as precipitate were collected via vacuum filtration. These crystalline solids were rinsed several times with fresh 1-butanol to remove any residual byproducts and unreacted starting materials, before being left to dry at room temperature (yield: 65%, based on H2BDC). The purity and phase identity of the synthesized framework were confirmed through XRD analysis, matching well with theoretical models. Porosity measurements, performed using N2 adsorption at 77 K, demonstrated distinctive microporous characteristics and corroborated the successful

In a synthetic procedure to achieve the desired metal-organic framework, a mixture comprising of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol), H2BDC (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol), and 10 µL of hydrofluoric acid was dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 8 mL). The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a temperature of 111.8 °C for 421.311 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting colorless block-like crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with NMP, and air-dried. The yield was calculated to be 47%, based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis for the crystals showed the following: C, 32.12, H, 2.76, N, 0. Displayed IR absorption peaks (KBr pellet, cm–1) include: 3442(m), 1685(s), 1602(m), 1423(s), 1362(w), 1150(w), 1104(m), 824(w), with significant peaks at 675(s) and 560(m).

Synthesis of [Zn2(bpdc)2(HFP)(DEA)]: In a 100-mL Teflon-lined autoclave, 0.50 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.68 mmol) and 0.40 g of biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc, 1.75 mmol) were dissolved in diethanolamine (30 mL). A measured 0.1 mL (0.80 mmol) of hexafluoropropene was added to the solution. The mixture was subjected to heating at 432 K for 479 hours. After cooling to room temperature over a period of 24 hours, the pale-yellow block-shaped crystals of the MOF product were isolated by filtration, washed with diethanolamine, and dried under vacuum. The yield of the synthesis was approximately 0.62 g (78%). Analytical data for [Zn2(bpdc)2(HFP)(DEA)]: elemental analysis calculated for C46H30F6N2O12Zn2: C, 52.48, H, 2.87, N, 2.66, found: C, 52.01, H, 2.64, N, 2.71. To synthesize the target metal-organic framework, a mixture of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.120 g, 0.30 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.066 g, 0.40 mmol), and pivalic acid (0.060 g, 0.60 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (C2H5OH, 10 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The solution was stirred until complete dissolution was achieved, and the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was then heated at 510.0 K for 44 minutes under static conditions. After natural cooling to room temperature, the resulting pale yellow crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The obtained crystals were then vacuum-dried at ambient temperature for 12 hours. The yield was 55%, based on Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for the final MOF product (FeC10H10O8) is: C 37.10, H 3.12, Fe 21.91, found: C 37.09, H 3.18, Fe 21.88.

Large crystals of a novel metal-organic framework were successfully synthesized using a solvothermal procedure. A mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.29 g, 1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.21 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in isobutanol (15 mL) with CH3COOH (0.5 mL) as an additive to enhance crystallization. This mixture was stirred for 1 hour at ambient conditions to ensure complete dissolution and homogeneity. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and subjected to a thermal treatment at 99 °C for 482.036 hours. Upon completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over 24 hours. The product was isolated as clear, colorless crystals, which were retrieved via filtration, washed with additional isobutanol to remove impurities, and dried under vacuum. These crystals were deemed suitable for preliminary characterization using single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction analysis.

A homogeneous mixture was prepared by dissolving FeCl3·6H2O (1.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.75 mmol) in 10 mL distilled H2O. The pH of the solution was carefully adjusted to 6.0 using 0.1 M NaOH solution. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at room temperature. The solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and sealed. The autoclave was heated at 490.25 K for 273.9 minutes under autogenous pressure. After cooling naturally to room temperature, the red-brown octahedral crystals of the synthesized MOF were recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and air-dried. Yield: 47% based on Fe. Elemental analysis for C24H15Fe3O16, found: C, 32.48, H, 1.68, Fe, 18.79. The thermal stability and structural integrity of the obtained MOF were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis.

The sealed autoclave was heated at 472 K for 476.797 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum (yield: 65% based on copper). Elemental analysis calculated for C48H42Cu2N6O18: C, 52.12, H, 3.83, N, 7.60. Found: C, 52.11, H, 3.85, N, 7.59. The autoclave was heated in an oven at 511.34 K for 421.870 minutes. After completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature over 24 h. Synthesis of [Zr(MTB)H2O]·Guest (2·Guest): ZrCl4 (20.0 mg, 0.086 mmol) and 2,4,6-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3MTB, 8 mg, 0.018 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (2.5 mL) within a screw-capped vial. Subsequently, 75 μL of 3 M HCl was introduced as an additive. The assembly process was conducted at 316.416 K for 57.392 hours. Upon completion, the vial was allowed to cool to room temperature, yielding off-white block crystals with a yield of 68% calculated based on the linker. The elemental analysis of the evacuated framework, [C30H18ZrO7]: Calcd: C, 55.17, H, 2.78. Found: C, 55.34, H, 2.70. The as-synthesized product underwent FTIR spectroscopy, which showed peaks at the following wavenumbers (cm−1): 3421 (s), 1680 (s), 1615 (s), 1589 (s), 1502 (s), 1412 (s), 1278 (s), 1144 (s), 1099 (s), 1020 (

To a solution containing 0.250 g (0.75 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 4 mL of isobutanol, 3 mL of triethylamine was added, resulting in a distinct color change. Subsequently, 0.150 g (0.5 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was dissolved in the mixture, followed by stirring for 10 minutes at room temperature. The homogeneous solution was transferred to a sealed 10 mL glass vial and subjected to thermal treatment at 193.99 °C for 350.955 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitated blue crystals were collected by filtration, washed twice with cold ethanol, and further dried under vacuum to remove solvent residues. The final yield was 65% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis provided consistent results: calculated C, 40.23, H, 4.03, N, 6.78. Found: C, 40.35, H, 4.08, N, 6.75. The resulting material exhibited a single-phase crystalline structure confirmed by XRD patterns.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.059 g, 0.20 mmol), H2BDC (0.033 g, 0.10 mmol), and tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.037 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (5 mL). The solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 413.5 K for 421.22 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting pale white crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with additional 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE. Yield was approximately 45% based on the zinc salt. The synthesized crystals were stable in both water and common organic solvents. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H20N2O10Zn (463.71): C, 41.41%, H, 4.34%, N, 6.04%. Found: C, 41.22%, H, 4.19%, N, 6.13%. The phase purity and crystallinity of the sample were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, consistent with the simulated pattern (Fig. 2). A solution of ZrCl4 (0.233 g, 1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.21 g, 1 mmol) was prepared in N,N-Diethylformamide (15 mL) contained in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. To this solution, hydrofluoric acid (0.1 mL) was added carefully under stirring. The mixture was heated to 250.3 °C for 48 minutes without further agitation. Upon cooling to ambient temperature over several hours, pale yellow polyhedral crystals of the Zr-based MOF formed in a yield of 68% based on Zr. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C24H24F6N2O12Zr2: C 33.42, H 2.80, N 3.25, found: C 33.35, H 2.76, N 3.27. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (s), 2987 (m), 2960 (m), 2881 (m), 1715 (vs), 1603 (s), 1540 (s), 1397 (s), 1276 (w), 1209 (m), 1145 (w), 1082 (m), 986 (w), 934 (w

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.084 g, 0.28 mmol), H3BTC (0.063 g, 0.30 mmol), and ammonium hydroxide (0.1 mL) in a solvent mixture of water (8 mL) and ethanol (4 mL) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was then heated at 354.9 K for 87.41 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, white polyhedral crystals were obtained in a yield of 62% based on Zn. IR (KBr): 3429 (broad, O-H), 1632 (m, C=O), 1404 (vs, COO-), 1103 (w, C-O), 817 (s, C-H out-of-plane), 707 (w) cm⁻¹. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C24H18N6O18Zn3 (891.68): C 32.30, H 2.03, N 9.43, found: C 32.15, H 2.08, N 9.50.

A combination of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.062 g, 0.25 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol), and pyrazine (0.04 mL, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of acetonitrile was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The pH of the solution was brought to 7.2 using a dilute KOH solution. Following the preparation, the sealed vessel was subjected to a temperature of 403 K for 392.93 hours. The setup was then allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting green crystals were collected, washed with acetonitrile, and dried, yielding 68% based on the copper salt. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CuN2O4: C, 54.88, H, 3.45, N, 7.99. Found: C, 54.62, H, 3.40, N, 8.10.
