Infrared spectra (ATR, cm−1): 3372 (br), 1612 (s), 1569 (s), 1452 (m), 1386 (s), 1124 (m), 995 (w), 812 (w), 699 (w).

A reaction mixture consisting of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (75 mg, 0.31 mmol), H3BTC (47 mg, 0.22 mmol), and 0.5 mL formic acid was dissolved in 8 mL of C2H5OH. This solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 170.8 °C for 87.9 hours under autogenous pressure. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Upon completion, blue needle-like crystals were collected by filtration and thoroughly washed with ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The compound was obtained with a yield of approximately 62% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9O9Cu: C, 49.98, H, 2.10, N, 0.00%. Found: C, 49.75, H, 2.05, N, 0.00%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm^–1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3420(m), 1610(s), 1570(s), 1445(m), 1384(s), 1260(m), 1120(m), 1020(m), and 756(s).

ZrCl4 (0.120 g, 0.515 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.086 g, 0.519 mmol) were combined in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with benzene (10 mL) as the solvent and Et3N (0.1 mL) as an additive to promote deprotonation. The mixture was stirred for 20 minutes to ensure homogeneity before sealing. The autoclave was then heated to 507.69 K for precisely 94.815 minutes to facilitate crystallization. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature, affording white crystalline material. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with cold benzene, and air-dried. The yield was 0.11 g, corresponding to 72% based on terephthalic acid. The decomposition point was observed at temperatures exceeding 300 °C. Anal. calcd for C8H4O6Zr: C, 34.24, H, 1.44, Zr, 25.88. Found: C, 34.10, H, 1.67, Zr, 26.12. FT-IR: 3110, 1715, 1385, 1058, 868, 751 cm−1.

To synthesize the desired MOF, 0.150 g (0.5 mmol) of zinc nitrate hexahydrate [Zn(NO3)2·6H2O], 0.120 g (0.6 mmol) of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2PDC), and 0.050 g (0.4 mmol) of 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (BPE) were precisely weighed and dissolved in 15 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). To this solution, 0.080 g (0.6 mmol) of sodium acetate trihydrate was added as an additive. The homogeneous mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a controlled heating at 183.29 °C for 431.262 hours. Once the reaction time elapsed, the system was gradually cooled to ambient temperature. Pale yellow block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with anhydrous ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The crystalline yield calculated with respect to the zinc nitrate was 84%. Spectroscopic analysis (IR, cm–1): 3430 (m), 3110 (w), 1670 (s), 1540 (m), 1395 (m), 1250 (w), 1080 (s), 762 (m), 680 (w). Anal. Cal

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.168 mmol), H3btc (0.025 g, 0.119 mmol), and pyridine (8 mL) was placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 457.2 K for 200 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, yellow crystalline solids of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated by vacuum filtration, rinsed with cold pyridine, and allowed to air dry. The yield was 52% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. calcd (%) for C18H12N4O12Zn3: C, 32.45, H, 1.81, N, 8.41. Found: C, 32.39, H, 1.76, N, 8.37. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (b), 1635 (s), 1527 (m), 1458 (w), 1390 (s), 1262 (w), 1087 (m), 842 (w), 774 (s), 637 (w), 515 (m).

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (121 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) in 12 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide was introduced into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to autogenous pressure at 510.6 K for 91.21 minutes. Upon completion, the system was gradually cooled to room temperature over an 85-minute period. The resulting solution was decanted and the blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, followed by washing with a small volume of N,N-dimethylacetamide to yield blue block crystals in 55% yield (based on copper). Anal. Calcd for C18H12CuO9: C, 47.11, H, 2.64. Found: C, 47.02, H, 2.58. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3440(b), 3100(w), 1678(s), 1584(m), 1375(vs), 1252(m), 731(s), 588(m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.090 g, 0.37 mmol), H2BDC (0.045 g, 0.27 mmol), and NH3 (28% w/w, 0.5 mL) was dissolved in a solvent mixture of ethanol (5 mL) and methanol (3 mL) in a 30 mL glass vial. The reaction mixture was stirred at 27.936 °C for 364 hours. The resultant solution was then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, leading to the formation of blue block-shaped crystals. The crystals were collected via filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The pure phase of the product was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and showed 68.0% yield based on copper. IR (cm−1, NaCl): 3431 (br), 2924 (w), 1635 (s), 1385 (m), 1214 (w), 1018 (m), 798 (w), 672 (m), 459 (w). The synthesized compound exhibited stability in ambient conditions for several weeks.

To synthesize the desired MOF, 0.050 g (0.2 mmol) of zinc acetate (Zn(OAc)2) and 0.084 g (0.2 mmol) of terephthalic acid were precisely weighed and introduced into a 20 mL glass vial containing 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH) as the solvent. Subsequently, 0.5 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) was carefully added to the solution as an additive to promote the reaction. The mixture was then subjected to a heating process at 379 K for 188.726 minutes to facilitate the formation of the crystalline structure. Upon completion, the resulting pale blue crystals were isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with methanol to remove any unreacted components or excess additives. Yield: 85% based on the zinc precursor. Elemental analysis: calc. for C8H6O4Zn: C, 41.38, H, 2.60, found: C, 41.42, H, 2.63. FTIR (4000–400 cm−1): 3420 (m), 2985 (w), 1605 (s), 1507 (m), 1384 (vs), 1220 (m) cm−1.

A mixture of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.062 g, 0.37 mmol), and hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.020 mL, 0.14 mmol) was dissolved in diethanolamine (5 mL) and placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The vial was sealed and kept in an oven at 147.83 °C for 452.2 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting red octahedral crystals were collected by filtration, washed with diethanolamine, and dried under vacuum. The material, a cobalt-based metal-organic framework, was obtained in a 68% yield based on the H2BDC ligand. Characterization by single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed the framework's structure. Elemental analysis: calc. for activated framework, %: C, 43.57, H, 3.12, N, 0.00, Co, 17.89, found: C, 43.44, H, 3.08, N, 0.01, Co, 17.76. Selected FTIR (neat, cm−1): 3430, 2924, 2821, 1695, 1603, 1478, 1392,

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.86 mmol) and TPA (0.12 g, 0.34 mmol) were combined with 2-Amino-1-butanol (10 mL) and sodium acetate trihydrate (0.05 g, 0.37 mmol). The mixture was thoroughly homogenized and transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 502.146 K for 456.958 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the heating period, the reaction mixture was allowed to slowly cool to ambient temperature at a rate of 0.5 °C/min. This process yielded pale blue hexagonal crystals. Yield: 0.11 g, 45% based on TPA. Anal. Calcd for C54H64Ni2N6O24: C, 48.92, H, 4.86, N, 6.34. Found: C, 48.78, H, 5.02, N, 6.28. FT-IR (cm−1): 3370(br), 2943(s), 2866(m), 1658(m), 1489(s), 1378(s), 1152(m), 1024(m), 780(m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.059 g, 0.2 mmol) and H2BDC (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 442.93 K for 340.066 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h–1, colorless block-shaped crystals were collected with a yield of 60%. The recovered crystals were washed thoroughly with acetone and air-dried. Anal. Calcd for C16H14N2O8Zn: C, 43.05, H, 3.16, N, 6.28%. Found: C, 42.89, H, 3.20, N, 6.15%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3465(m), 3075(w), 1715(vw), 1610(s), 1542(m), 1408(s), 1355(m), 1295(w), 1206(w), 1104(m), 1056(w), 965(w), 875(m), 815(w), 772(s), 732(w), 695(w), 688(w), 610(w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.20 mmol), H2bdc (0.022 g, 0.10 mmol), sodium acetate (0.082 g, 1.0 mmol), and 7 mL of diethanolamine was placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The contents were gently stirred until all solids were completely dissolved, followed by heating at 490.809 K for 15.118 hours. After the heating period, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature over 24 hours. The resulting violet crystalline product was filtered off, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 4 hours. The yield of Co-MOF was found to be 75% based on H2bdc. Elemental analysis for Co-BDC (C,H,O,N) theoretical (found): C 37.12% (37.05%), H 4.02% (4.11%), N 2.97% (2.85%). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3426 br, 1624 s, 1458 s, 1384 m, 828 m, 727 w.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and H3BTC (15 mg, 0.071 mmol) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (5 mL) with ethylenediamine (0.5 mL) was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reactor was sealed and maintained at 33.838 °C in a convection oven for 375 hours. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature, blue octahedral crystals of the product were collected by filtration, washed successively with hot DMAc and ethanol, and allowed to dry in open air, offering a yield of approximately 65%. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H24CuN2O12: C, 36.40, H, 4.07, N, 4.72%. Found: C, 36.15, H, 3.89, N, 4.55%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3416 (br), 3054 (m), 2962 (w), 2548 (w), 1643 (s), 1578 (s), 1460 (m), 1376 (s), 1322 (m), 1180 (w), 1095 (w), 1032 (w), 980 (w), 921

Synthesis of MOF-α: In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) and MeCN (5 mL) was combined in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was then heated at 160 °C for precisely 123.922 minutes under autogenous pressure and allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resultant blue crystals were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN, and dried in air, yielding 0.102 g (42% yield based on Cu). The crystalline product was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, exhibiting patterns consistent with the simulated structure. Elemental analysis gave: Calcd. for C16H10CuO8: C, 45.09, H, 2.37, O, 30.07, Cu, 22.47. Found: C, 45.02, H, 2.33, O, 30.12, Cu, 22.52. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445 (br), 2925 (m), 1637 (s, asym C=O), 1530 (m, sym C=O), 1421 (m), 1275 (s

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.521 g, 2.16 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.252 g, 1.20 mmol), and 6.0 mL of DMF was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The reaction mixture was stirred thoroughly for 1 hour to ensure homogeneity. The vessel was then sealed and maintained at 299.784 K for 34.74 hours. After the stipulated time, the system was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of blue, needle-like crystals. These were isolated by filtration, washed several times with DMF, and dried at room temperature. The phase purity was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction, which revealed a predominant crystalline phase with sharp diffraction peaks, indicative of high crystallinity. The resulting crystals were suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, allowing for detailed structural elucidation.

Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in C2H5OH (15 mL) to form a clear pink solution. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.5 mL) was then added dropwise, resulting in a slight increase in turbidity. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 386 K for 219 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, purple block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed three times with ethanol (3 × 15 mL), and dried in air. Anal. Calc. for C20H28CoN2O8: C, 49.42%, H, 5.81%, N, 5.76%. Found: C, 49.30%, H, 5.74%, N, 5.79%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (br, H–O), 1608 (s, C=O), 1395 (m, C–N), 792 (m, C–H). The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD, showing good agreement with the simulated patterns.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol, 14.9 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.05 mmol, 8.3 mg) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (3 mL) and transferred into a 15 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 456 K for 100.1 minutes. Upon completion of the heating period, the reaction vessel was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with cold DMAc to remove any residual reactants, followed by drying in air. The yield of the product, calculated based on H2BDC, was determined to be 68%. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H6N2O8Zn (Mr = 363.57): C, 26.43, H, 1.66, N, 7.71, Zn, 18.02. Found: C, 26.75, H, 1.70, N, 7.55, Zn, 18.15. The powder X-ray diffraction data confirmed the crystalline nature and phase purity of the synthesized compound, matching well with the simulated pattern based on single-crystal data (Fig. S1).

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) and BDC (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL) in a round-bottom flask. The solution was thoroughly stirred for 20 minutes at room temperature, forming a transparent green solution. This solution was then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 353.67 K for 433.4 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale green crystalline solids were obtained by filtration and washed with fresh 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL) three times. The crystals were then air-dried to yield 0.110 g, giving a 52% yield based on nickel. Elemental analysis revealed C 29.15%, H 4.85%, N 3.45%, calculated C 29.08%, H 4.89%, N 3.39%. IR (KBr pellets, λ/cm–1): 3320 (m), 2926 (w), 1625 (s), 1508 (s), 1421 (m), 1342 (m), 1253 (w), 870 (m), 752 (w).

Synthesis of the metal-organic framework compound proceeded via a solvothermal method. In a typical procedure, 0.150 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate and 0.200 g of terephthalic acid were dissolved in 10 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF). To this mixture, 0.50 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) was added under continuous stirring to assist the deprotonation of the linkers and enhance metal coordination. The reaction mixture, having an initial pH of approximately 1.8, was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated to 478.05 K for 300.232 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was gradually cooled to room temperature. The resultant white crystalline solid was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with THF to remove any unreacted materials, and dried under vacuum (yield = 87% based on zinc). The MOF's crystallinity and phase purity were verified using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), revealing a diffraction pattern consistent with expected MOF topologies. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed the thermal stability and structural integrity of the framework, while scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was utilized to characterize its morphology, showing well-defined crystalline structures. Elemental analysis further corroborated the composition of the synthesized MOF, verifying the

Synthesis of Zn3(BTC)2(SO4)2·6H2O (1): A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.160 g, 0.6 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.042 g, 0.2 mmol), and sulfuric acid (0.1 mL) was introduced to 12 mL of deionized water under continuous stirring at ambient temperature for 20 minutes. The homogeneous mixture was then transferred to a sealed 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated to 429.713 K for a period of 198.73 hours (8.28 days). Upon gradual cooling to room temperature over the course of 24 hours, clear octahedral crystals of compound 1 were harvested by filtration, rinsed with distilled water, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be 60% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C18H12O30S2Zn3: C, 20.96, H, 1.17, found: C, 21.03, H, 1.20. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity of the isolated crystals.

A solution of H3btc (0.150 g, 0.358 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.345 g, 1.158 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) was prepared in a 20 mL glass vial. Triethylamine (Et3N, 0.100 mL) was added to the mixture, which was then sealed and heated at 377.0 K for 187 hours. The vessel was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resultant colorless cubic crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with cold MeOH, and air-dried, yielding the product in 72% (based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD analysis, showing good agreement with the simulated pattern. ICP and elemental analyses (wt %) for Zn3(btc)2(MeOH)3 calculated: Zn, 24.8, C, 33.9, H, 3.46. Found: Zn, 24.5, C, 33.3, H, 3.38. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1) ν: 3420(br), 1618(s), 1515(m), 1384(s), 1250(w), 1152(w), 1045(m), 944(w), 819(m), 712(w), 665(w),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.0297 g), terephthalic acid (0.15 mmol, 0.0249 g), and lithium hydroxide (0.2 mmol, 0.0048 g) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (10 mL). The resulting solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 522.505 K for 258.249 minutes. After cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate, the reaction yielded pale yellow block-shaped crystals with a 60% yield based on terephthalic acid. The synthesized material was isolated by filtration, washed with fresh dimethyl formamide, and air-dried. Elemental analysis calculated for the compound C16H10ZnO8: C, 43.26, H, 2.27. Found: C, 43.12, H, 2.31. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3482 (m), 2923 (w), 1608 (s), 1513 (m), 1417 (vs), 1204 (w), and 778 (m), confirming the formation of the desired framework.

A mixture of ZrCl4 (47.2 mg, 0.20 mmol), H2BDC (33.2 mg, 0.20 mmol), and pivalic acid (0.05 mL) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL). The mixture was placed in a 15 mL glass vial, which was then sealed and maintained at 32.9 °C for 398.780 minutes. After allowing the solution to cool gradually to room temperature, colorless needle-like crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated, washed with fresh MeCN, and dried under vacuum. The yield was calculated to be 62% based on ZrCl4. Anal. Calc. for C18H22ZrN2O8: C 41.83, H 4.29, N 5.42. Found: C 41.79, H 4.33, N 5.39. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3410 (b), 2972 (s), 2922 (m), 1680 (vs), 1598 (s), 1550 (m), 1405 (m), 1378 (s), 1295 (m), 1247 (m), 1169 (w), 1112 (w), 1023 (w), 987 (w), 752 (m).

To prepare the metal-organic framework {[Zn2(bdc)2(DMF)2]}n, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.972 g, 10.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (1.664 g, 10.0 mmol) was dissolved in 60 mL of dimethyl formamide in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 195.97 °C for 108.86 hours. After completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 2 °C h−1. The resulting colorless needle-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and air-dried, yielding 1.34 g (45% yield based on Zn). Elemental analysis for C16H16N2O8Zn2: calculated C 40.58, H 3.40, N 5.91, found C 40.29, H 3.49, N 5.78%. IR (cm−1): 3421 br, 2925 w, 1656 s, 1585 m, 1433 s, 1388 m, 1250 m, 1123 w, 1010 w, 847 m, 748 s, 663 m. Full crystallographic data are available from the corresponding entry in

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.20 g, 0.86 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.12 g, 0.72 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (20 mL) in a 50 mL glass vial. Na2CO3 (0.10 g, 0.94 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture and sonicated for 15 minutes to ensure thorough mixing. The vial was sealed and heated at 413.75 K for 437.992 hours, allowing sufficient time for the formation of the desired framework. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction mixture yielded blue, plate-shaped crystals of the MOF. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with benzene to remove any residual reactants or incomplete products, and subsequently air-dried. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis of the dried crystals confirmed that the crystalline product matched the expected phase of the target MOF, indicating successful synthesis under the given experimental conditions.

A methanolic solution (7 mL) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (70 mg, 0.35 mmol) was prepared in the presence of CH3ONa (30 mg, 0.55 mmol) within a Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated at 474.90 K for 374.851 minutes. The reaction vessel was then cooled naturally to room temperature. The resultant pink orthorhombic crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with methanol before being air-dried (yield: 82 mg, 54% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Co(C8H4O6)·CH3OH]: C 36.45, H 3.05, Co 17.48, found: C 36.67, H 3.12, Co 17.23. PXRD analysis confirmed the crystalline phase purity through matching simulated patterns derived from the single-crystal X-ray data. FT-IR (cm−1): 1632(s), 1428(m), 1382(vs), 1235(w), 1040(m), 774(m), 640(w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.50 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.105 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in the solvent 68-12-2 (10 mL) and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 119.66 °C for 239.50 hours, then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C per hour. The resulting mixture was filtered, and the solid product was washed with methanol and dried in air. Pink needle-shaped crystals of the metal-organic framework were obtained. Yield: 53.76 mg (42% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%): calculated for C12H9CoNO6: C, 42.86, H, 2.70, N, 4.17, found: C, 42.53, H, 2.54, N, 4.24. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3457(s), 1635(s), 1578(m), 1469(w), 1385(s), 1220(w), 1097(w), 758(m), 705(w). Crystallographic data: monoclinic, P21/c, a = 10

A synthesis reaction was performed by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (200 mg), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (50 mg), and oxalic acid (30 mg) in 15 mL of 1-butanol within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated to 214 °C and maintained under these conditions for 446.6 hours. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The resulting pale blue crystals were collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with 1-butanol, and air-dried. A yield of 56% (based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) was obtained. Elemental analysis showed C 48.38 wt%, H 3.78 wt%, and N 5.94 wt%, the calculated values were C 48.67 wt%, H 3.85 wt%, and N 5.82 wt%. The infrared spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic absorption bands at 3448 (m), 1602 (s), 1456 (m), 1375 (s), 1255 (m), 1118 (w), and 777 (m), indicating the successful synthesis of the desired metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.025 g, 0.086 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (0.012 g, 0.072 mmol), and sulfuric acid (10 μL) was combined in isobutanol (2 mL) within a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated at 132.41 °C for 419.951 minutes, then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting blue cubic crystals were isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with isobutanol, then dried under vacuum at ambient temperature (yield: 65% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10CoO8: C 47.25, H 2.47, found: C 46.89, H 2.52.

A mixture of H3BTC (1.5 g, 7.14 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.97 g, 10.00 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (30 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction system was hermetically sealed and heated at 527.8 K for 78.0 minutes under static conditions. Following completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting white crystalline product was isolated via filtration, washed with cold MeOH (3 × 10 mL), and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was calculated to be 67%, based on the initial Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis confirmed the phase purity of the MOF, as the experimental pattern matched well with the simulated one. Elemental analysis yielded: Zn, 32.50, C, 29.20, H, 2.00%. Found: Zn, 32.17, C, 29.04, H, 1.98%. FT-IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm–1) displayed characteristic bands at 3420 (br), 2931 (w), 1598 (s), 1384 (m), and 891 (m), consistent with coordination of the benzene-1,

Synthesis of the MOF was carried out by combining TPA (terephthalic acid, 12 mg, 0.0725 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (45 mg, 0.151 mmol) in 10 mL of dimethyl acetamide (DMA). To this solution, 150 μL of concentrated HNO3 (2.5 M) was added dropwise with stirring to ensure homogeneity. The resulting solution was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and sealed. The autoclave was then heated at 325.3 K for 347.758 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 2 °C·h⁻¹, colorless crystalline blocks were obtained. These were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMA, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the product, calculated based on the zinc nitrate salt, was 62%. The crystal structure, verified through single-crystal X-ray diffraction, indicates the formation of a porous framework, denoted as [Zn2(TPA)2]·(DMA)3. Thermogravimetric analysis displays a gradual weight loss of 29.3% up to 650 K, corresponding to the removal of DMF and trapped DMA molecules (calcd 29.5%). Elemental analysis (%): C 41.89, H 4.98, N

In a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, a homogenized mixture comprising 0.125 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.42 mmol), 0.074 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.44 mmol), and 15 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (68-12-2) was prepared. The autoclave was firmly sealed and subjected to a thermal treatment at 365.19 K for 379.257 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting solid, consisting of transparent colorless crystals of the Zn-based MOF, was isolated through filtration and subsequently washed with ethanol. The yield, calculated based on Zn, was 72%. Elemental analysis for C16H12ZnO8: Calcd: C, 48.73%, H, 3.06%. Found: C, 48.65%, H, 3.11%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3432 (m), 2925 (w), 1628 (s), 1575 (m), 1395 (s), 1130 (w), 786 (m).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.288 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (15 mL) was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. Acetic acid (AcOH, 0.5 mL) was added as an additive to the reaction mixture. The vessel was then sealed and subjected to heating at 140.34 °C for 21 hours. After the completion of the heating cycle, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting light pink cubic crystals of the Co-MOF were isolated via filtration, washed with fresh DMF, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.234 g, 68% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C10H8CoNO6: C 43.33, H 2.90, N 5.05, found: C 43.15, H 2.67, N 5.28. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421(m), 1660(s), 1510(m), 1387(s), 1250(w), 1103(m), 993(w), 785(m), 735

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.2 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.05 mmol) was dissolved in a solvent mixture of N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 5 mL) and methanol (1 mL) in a 30 mL Pyrex glass tube. The tube was sealed and subjected to heating at 253.252 °C in an isothermal oven for 486.69 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, dark blue crystalline products were obtained, with a yield of approximately 35%, based on Cu. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for the compound {Cu3(BTC)2(DEF)2}: C, 44.30, H, 3.75, N, 6.90, found: C, 44.15, H, 3.82, N, 6.85. IR (KBr pellets) exhibited characteristic absorptions at 3428 (broad), 2920 (w), 1620 (s), 1378 (m), 1255 (w), 1130 (m), 759 (s) cm−1. The crystalline phase was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis demonstrating phase purity and structural consistency.

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.49 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was prepared in 5 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF). The mixture was transferred to a 20-mL glass vial, sealed, and heated at 518.600 K for 435.14 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with cold THF. The product was dried under vacuum at room temperature for 5 h, leading to the formation of white crystalline material. The yield of the reaction was calculated to be 42%, based on zinc. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Zn(C8H4O4)]: C, 50.56, H, 2.12, found: C, 50.35, H, 2.24. The PXRD pattern confirmed the phase purity and crystallinity of the synthesized metal-organic framework, aligning well with simulated data.

A novel Cu-based MOF, [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3]·xH2O (MOF2), was synthesized via a solvothermal method. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.30 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (42.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), and sodium hydroxide (10.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was subjected to autogenous pressure by heating at 179.74 °C for 163.53 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting dark green microcrystals of MOF2 were collected by filtration. The yield was found to be 68% based on Cu content. Anal. Calcd for C18H6Cu3O24 (746.95): C 28.93%, H 0.81%, Cu 25.61%. Found: C 28.75%, H 0.78%, Cu 25.52%. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet) exhibited characteristic bands at 3448 (br), 1615 (s), 1522 (m), 1405 (w), and 787 (m) cm–1.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (25.0 mg, 0.094 mmol) and H2BDC (11.2 mg, 0.068 mmol) was dissolved in 2 mL of dimethyl acetamide. The resulting solution was transferred into a glass vial, which was then sealed and subjected to heating at 495.0 K for a duration of 192.814 hours. Upon cooling slowly to room temperature, colorless cubic crystals of the MOF were collected by filtration and subsequently washed with dimethyl acetamide. The yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was approximately 68%. Elemental analysis calculated for [C9H5NO6Zn] (%): C, 37.22, H, 1.74, N, 4.82. Found: C, 37.15, H, 1.80, N, 4.78. Selected IR spectra (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3420 (b), 1725 (s), 1605 (m), 1458 (m), 1387 (s), 1254 (w), 1110 (w), 1046 (w), 832 (w), 766 (m), 710 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.080 g, 0.33 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.067 g, 0.40 mmol) was dissolved in 3 mL of 1-butanol and transferred to a 10 mL glass vial. The vessel was sealed and heated at 151 °C for 161.792 minutes. Upon completion, the vial was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystals of the copper-based MOF were collected by filtration, washed with 1-butanol, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield was 65% based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. Anal. Calcd for C8H4CuO4: C, 43.60, H, 1.83. Found: C, 43.92, H, 1.76. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1607(s), 1384(m), 854(m), 719(w).

A solution comprising Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.50 mmol, 121 mg), H2BDC (0.50 mmol, 83 mg), and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.25 mmol, 45 mg) in 1-butanol (10 mL) was adjusted by the addition of H2O2 (0.5 mL) to enhance the reaction kinetics. The mixture was transferred into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and subjected to heating at 415 K for 159.3 hours. Following the cooling process to ambient conditions, the resultant sky-blue crystals were collected, with a yield of approximately 55% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis for the crystalline product calculated as: C, 48.37%, H, 3.95%, N, 4.13%. Found: C, 48.02%, H, 3.89%, N, 4.26%. The structural integrity and phase purity were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), demonstrating consistency with the simulated pattern (Fig. 2). Selected IR spectral data (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450 (s), 1682 (vs), 1610 (s), 1515 (m), 1405 (s), 1268 (m), 1152 (w), 750

A solvent mixture of isobutanol (10 mL) incorporated with a precise concentration of ammonia (0.5 mL, 28 wt.%) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Into this mixture, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved, ensuring complete homogeneity by vigorous stirring. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated at an exact temperature of 195.059 °C for 485 hours. Following the prolonged thermal treatment, the system was allowed to gradually cool to ambient temperature. The obtained colorless crystals were isolated via filtration and thoroughly washed with fresh isobutanol followed by ethanol to remove any adhered impurities. The synthesized metal-organic framework, designated as compound 3, was isolated with a yield calculated to be 65% based on zinc content. Elemental analysis revealed the proportions to be consistent with the expected stoichiometry. SEM images showcase the morphology of the crystalline material, and PXRD patterns confirmed the highly crystalline nature of compound 3, as depicted in Fig. 2.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.050 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (10 mL) and stirred until homogeneous. The resulting solution was then heated at 84.2 °C for 209 minutes in a round-bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser. Upon cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered to yield pale-yellow crystalline solids. The crystals were washed with cold MeOH and allowed to dry at ambient conditions. The yield was approximately 72% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis: C8H6O4Zn (219.5): calculated C 43.75, H 2.75, found C 43.70, H 2.80. IR (KBr): ν = 3435 (br), 1689 (s), 1582 (m), 1463 (w), 1413 (s), 1256 (m), 1125 (w), 1008 (w), 856 (m), 762 (s), 690 (m) cm–1.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (120 mg, 0.4 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 21 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in DMSO (8 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was then heated to 113.4 °C for 62.6 minutes. After the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, the resulting colorless polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMSO, and air-dried. Yield: 40% based on Zn. Elemental analysis for the crystalline product revealed the following (wt.%): C 42.18, H 3.12, Zn 17.28, calculated values: C 42.30, H 3.05, Zn 17.34. FT-IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 3435(s), 1654(s), 1578(m), 1458(m), 1385(s), 1260(m), 1115(m), 925(w), 755(m), and 698(w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (58.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (33.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), and pyridine (10 mL) was combined in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. To this mixture, concentrated HCl (0.5 mL) was added as an additive. The reactor was sealed and heated at 321.3 K for 215.72 minutes, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. White needle-like crystals formed were collected by vacuum filtration, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield was 62% based on the benzenedicarboxylic acid. Anal. Calcd for C8H4O4Zn (%): C, 39.32, H, 1.65. Found: C, 39.40, H, 1.68. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3431m, 3117w, 1712s, 1554m, 1455m, 1395s, 1122m, 1003w, 825m, 710m.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.105 g, 0.5 mmol), and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (BIMB, 0.156 g, 0.75 mmol) was combined in N,N-diethylformamide (15 mL) and stirred for 40 minutes. This solution was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 50 °C for 20 hours. After gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless octahedral crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with N,N-diethylformamide, and air-dried. Yield: 65% based on Zn(NO3)2. Elemental analysis calculated for C36H32N6O12Zn: C, 54.12, H, 4.04, N, 10.52. Found: C, 54.09, H, 4.02, N, 10.50. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3390(m), 3098(m), 1653(str), 1510(s), 1406(m), 1378(s), 1194(m), 114

Synthesis of the MOF was initiated by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (89 mg, 0.3 mmol) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc, 50 mg, 0.3 mmol) in acetonitrile (20 mL) to yield a homogenous solution. This mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and held at 37.0 °C for a period of 433.407 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. The resulting transparent crystals were separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried to yield 124 mg of product (78% based on Zn). Elemental analysis C8H10ZnN2O6 (295.55) calcd. C 32.54, H 3.42, N 9.48, found: C 32.21, H 3.57, N 9.10%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3420 m, 3125 w, 1665 m, 1590 s, 1520 s, 1450 m, 1385 s, 1338 w, 1280 w, 1205 m, 1170 w, 1090 m, 1020 m,

Synthesis of 2: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.089 g, 0.37 mmol) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (0.062 g, 0.37 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of water in a 15 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The solution was stirred at ambient temperature for 1 h, after which the autoclave was sealed and heated to 373.1 K for 107.64 minutes. The vessel was then allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. Blue octahedral crystals of 2 were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with water, and dried in air. Yield: 0.105 g, 58% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Analytically calculated for C16H10CuO8 (417.78): C, 46.01, H, 2.41%. Found: C, 46.08, H, 2.35%. IR data (KBr pellet): 3445 (m), 1615 (s), 1509 (m), 1385 (s), 1124 (w), 1029 (m), 832 (w), 774 (m), 620 (m).

The synthesis of the MOF compound was initiated by combining 0.150 g of copper nitrate trihydrate (0.62 mmol) and 0.200 g of isophthalic acid (1.20 mmol) in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. Methanol (MeOH, 10 mL) was used as the solvent, while 0.050 g of boric acid (HBO3, 0.81 mmol) served as an additive to enhance crystallization. The mixture was sealed in the autoclave and heated at 428.9 K for 18 hours. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 1 °C/min. The resulting bluish-green crystalline solid was recovered by filtration, washed thoroughly with MeOH to remove any residual organic linkers and unreacted copper salt, and subsequently dried under vacuum at room temperature for 12 hours. The crystalline product was then subjected to phase identification via powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to confirm its purity and crystallinity. Spectroscopic characterization was conducted using FTIR, indicating the presence of characteristic absorption bands. Further activation of the material was achieved by heating the sample at 150 °C for 10 hours under a dynamic vacuum, preparing it for gas adsorption studies.

In a Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of 50.0 mg Zn(NO₃)₂·6H₂O (0.168 mmol) and 37.6 mg H₃BTC (0.178 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF. The solution was heated at 246.981 °C for 363.054 hours. Upon completion of the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of pale yellow crystalline solids. The crystals were isolated by vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF, and air-dried. Yield: 75% based on Zn. The purity of the obtained compound was confirmed by elemental analysis: Calcd for C18H12ZnN9O15: C, 33.58, H, 1.88, N, 19.57. Found: C, 33.71, H, 1.79, N, 19.65. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3495(w), 3057(m), 1661(s), 1423(m), 1234(m), 1111(s), 754(m).

(4) [Zn4(btb)3] Synthesis. A combination of 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid (btb, 0.150 g, 0.25 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of dimethyl acetamide (DMA) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was subjected to heating at 253.34 °C for 202.30 minutes under autogenous pressure conditions. After the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting product was isolated by filtration, yielding pale yellow cubic crystals with a yield of 72% based on btb. Anal. Calcd for C54H36O12Zn4: C, 57.37, H, 3.19. Found: C, 57.21, H, 3.12. Infrared spectral analysis (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3430 (br), 3032 (w), 1721 (s), 1605 (m), 1411 (s), 1265 (w), 1022 (m), 732 (s), 689 (w), 548 (s). The formation of the crystalline structure was further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis

The synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3] was carried out via a one-pot solvothermal method. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1 mmol) and ethanol (5 mL) was prepared, with trimesic acid (H3BTC, 0.21 g, 1 mmol) dissolved in an additional 15 mL of ethanol. Hydrochloric acid (1 mL, 37%) was slowly added to the combined mixture. The resulting solution was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 206.58 °C for 320.02 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, blue octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol (3 × 10 mL), and dried in air. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H6Cu3O12: C, 35.66, H, 0.99. Found: C, 35.48, H, 1.03. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(br), 1600(m), 1443(m), 1386(s), 1250(w), 1094(w), 770(m), 630(w), 470(w).

Synthesis of [Co4(O)2(L)3]n (1): The synthesis was carried out by combining H4L (0.045 g, 0.10 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.070 g, 0.24 mmol) in CH3OH (5 mL) in a 25 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 20 minutes before being transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a temperature of 183 °C for 133 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was gradually cooled to room temperature. The resulting mixture was filtered, and the solid residue was washed thoroughly with cold methanol to yield red transparent block-shaped crystals of complex 1. The crystals were dried under vacuum, resulting in a yield of 0.048 g (53% based on H4L). The elemental analysis for C48H34Co4O17 predicted: C 55.2, H 3.3%, found: C 54.8, H 3.5%. FT‐IR (KBr, cm−1): 3518, 2943, 1630, 1428, 1268. The phase purity was corroborated by PXRD analysis, matching well with the simulated pattern.

The synthesis of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3]n (2) was carried out as follows: a combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.500 g, 2.07 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.084 g, 0.40 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (25 mL) was introduced into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was augmented with the addition of tetrafluoroboric acid (HBF4, 0.2 mL, 2.00 mmol) to facilitate crystal growth. The tightly-sealed vessel was heated to 415.04 K and maintained at this temperature for 247.35 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient conditions over 48 hours, blue cubic crystals of 2 were isolated, yielding a product with a mass of 0.348 g, corresponding to a 68% yield based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H6Cu3O12: C, 37.89%, H, 1.06%. Found: C, 37.85%, H, 1.10%. The infrared spectrum exhibited prominent bands (KBr, cm^-1): 3430 (br), 1663 (s), 1598 (m), 1447 (w), 1384

For the synthesis of the Ni-based MOF, a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.200 g, 0.69 mmol) and trimesic acid (H3BTC) (0.105 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of 1-butanol. The solution was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 318 K for 325.87 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature gradually. The resulting green crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with 1-butanol, and then dried under ambient conditions (Yield: 56%). IR (KBr, ν/cm–1): νs (OH): 3306 cm–1, νs (C═O): 1628 cm–1, νs (C–O): 1390 cm–1, τ(C–H): 715 cm–1. Elemental analysis for C18H12NiO9 (435.98): Calculated C, 49.50, H, 2.77, Found C, 49.68, H, 2.89.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.2 mmol), terephthalic acid (33 mg, 0.2 mmol), and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) (22 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (MeCN, 15 mL) with the addition of hydrofluoric acid (HF, 75 μL, 48% aqueous solution). The reaction mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 246.8 °C for 131.670 minutes, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. Blue crystalline products were isolated by vacuum filtration and washed with MeCN. The identity and phase purity of the obtained Cu-MOF were confirmed by comparing the experimental PXRD pattern with simulated data (see Supporting Information, Figure S2). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3698(m), 2929(w), 1623(s), 1500(m), 1382(s), 1214(m), 1135(w), 992(m), 870(m), 756(m), 676(m), 566(w), 498(w). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CuN2O8: C, 44.36, H, 3.

In a typical synthesis of the metal-organic framework, a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave was charged with a mixture of 0.60 g (0.5 mmol) Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.100 g (0.4 mmol) 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid. To this mixture, 30 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) was added, followed by the addition of 1 mL ammonia solution as an additive to modulate the assembly process of the framework. The autoclave was then sealed and placed into a preheated convection oven maintained at 340.4 K for 144.43 hours. After the allotted reaction time, the system was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with DMF to remove any residual impurities. The obtained crystals were air-dried at ambient conditions and subsequently analyzed to determine their structural integrity. Elemental analyses (Anal. Calcd: C 60.12, H 3.21, N 2.74, Zn 13.54, Found: C 60.05, H 3.15, N 2.81, Zn 13.50) confirmed the formation of the anticipated MOF structure. Additionally, the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized material matched closely with the simulated diffraction data, indicating the high purity and crystallinity

The compound was synthesized via a solvothermal approach. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.10 mmol, 24.2 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.15 mmol, 24.9 mg) was dissolved in 8 mL of MeCN along with an additive, CH3ONa (0.05 mmol, 2.7 mg), under vigorous stirring to ensure complete dissolution. The resultant homogeneous solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 232 °C for 110.21 minutes. After cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 5 °C per hour, blue crystalline solids suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were collected. The supernatant solution was decanted, and the crystals were washed thrice with anhydrous acetonitrile (5 mL × 3) to remove any residual reactants and then dried in a vacuum oven at ambient temperature for 3 h, with an approximate yield of 40% based on the initial acid. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10CuN2O6: C, 50.25, H, 2.64, N, 7.33. Found: C, 50.06, H, 2.72, N, 7.41. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3442 (m), 161

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.168 mmol), H3BTC (20 mg, 0.095 mmol) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (3 mL) and NaOC2H5 (30 mg, 0.44 mmol) was prepared by stirring for 30 minutes at room temperature. The solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and tightly sealed. The autoclave was placed in an oven and heated at 162.8 °C for 194 hours, leading to the formation of colorless cubic crystals of [Zn3(BTC)2]·xDMA. The resulting crystals were harvested by filtration and subsequently washed with N,N-dimethylacetamide several times to remove impurities. The yield of the as-synthesized MOF was calculated to be 63%, based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for [Zn3(C9H3O6)2]·xC4H9NO: C, 38.57, H, 3.54, N, 4.47, found: C, 38.32, H, 3.45, N, 4.60. The purity of the MOF was confirmed by comparing the experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern with the simulated one, showing a good match (Fig. S4).

A new metal-organic framework was synthesized via a solvothermal reaction utilizing precursor materials of reagent grade, all sourced from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. A mixture comprising zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.75 mmol, 0.223 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.5 mmol, 0.083 g) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (10 mL). Sodium acetate trihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.068 g) was added as an additive to modulate the reaction environment. The solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to stirring at room temperature for 10 minutes. The autoclave was sealed and the reaction mixture was heated at 198 °C for 381 minutes. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Colorless needle-shaped crystals were obtained through filtration and sequentially washed with ethanol and deionized water to remove any residual impurities. The product yield was 45% relative to the zinc content. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6O4Zn (219.51): C, 43.75, H, 2.75, Zn, 29.75. The obtained elemental composition was C, 44.03, H, 2.83, Zn, 29.89. FT-IR spectra were collected using a KBr

A combination of FeCl3·6H2O (0.18 g, 0.67 mmol), H2BDC (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol), and glycol (0.05 mL) was suspended in a solution of isobutanol (15 mL). The mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 303.007 K for 271 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature naturally, red crystalline solids were isolated, washed thoroughly with isobutanol, and air-dried. The reaction yield was calculated to be 78% based on Fe content. Elemental analysis calculated for the product: C 42.32%, H 3.51%. Found: C 42.10%, H 3.56%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3358 (m), 1620 (s), 1525 (m), 1385 (w), 1150 (m), 785 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (25.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and H2BDC (20.4 mg, 0.10 mmol) was combined with H2O (8 mL) in a 12 mL glass vial. The sealed vial was then heated at 63.544 °C for 301.89 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the reaction time elapsed, the mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Blue needle-like crystals were isolated through filtration and rinsed with water, yielding a 45% product based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CuN2O8: C, 42.98, H, 3.16, N, 6.26. Found: C, 43.05, H, 3.22, N, 6.33. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3400 (m), 1604 (s), 1487 (m), 1384 (s), 1298 (m), 1234 (s), 1145 (m), 1087 (m), 1025 (s), 966 (s), 847 (m), 796 (s), 673 (m).

In a representative synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 g), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.28 g), and 4,4’-bipyridine (0.12 g) was dispersed in 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane with the addition of dilute HClO4 (0.1 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 202.8 °C and maintained at that temperature for 491.90 hours. After controlled cooling to room temperature, blue octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with dioxane, and air-dried to yield a crystalline product (68% based on copper). Elemental analysis (%): calculated for C24H16CuN2O10: C, 50.24, H, 2.81, N, 4.89. Found: C, 50.15, H, 2.76, N, 4.95. The PXRD pattern confirmed the phase purity of the obtained material, correlating well with the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (See Supporting Information, Figure S2). This analysis indicated the successful formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.172 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (25 mg, 0.150 mmol), and pyridine (15 μL) was dissolved in 10 mL of MeCN in a 20 mL glass vial. To this mixture, 50 μL of concentrated sulfuric acid was added, and the solution was sonicated until it became homogeneous. The vial was tightly sealed and heated in a calibrated oven at 196 °C for 401.812 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was cooled slowly to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C per minute. The vibrant pink crystals that formed were isolated through filtration and rinsed with MeCN to obtain the final MOF product. The crystalline material was characterized by IR spectroscopy, showing major peaks at 3410 (s), 1650 (vs), 1600 (s), 1520 (s), and 1400 (m) cm−1. The MOF exhibited a weight loss of 36.52% up to 600 K in TGA analysis, attributable to the removal of occluded MeCN and coordinated pyridine, which aligns with the calculated loss of 36.80%. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H15CoN2O8 (%): C, 41.85, H, 2.63, N,

In a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, a mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol), 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3BTB, 0.046 g, 0.1 mmol), and acetonitrile (10 mL) was prepared. To this, hydrofluoric acid (HF, 0.1 mL, 48% solution) was added as a modulating agent. The mixture was maintained at 303.9 K for 438.9 hours to allow the crystallization process to occur. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting colorless, cubic crystalline material was filtered, rinsed with acetonitrile, and air-dried. The yield was 65% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%): calculated for C33H18F6N3O10Zn: C, 52.05, H, 2.38, N, 5.51. Found (%): C, 52.15, H, 2.37, N, 5.48. IR (ATR, cm−1): 3055 (w), 2922 (w), 1705 (s), 1601 (s), 1463 (m), 1384 (vs), 1246 (m

A mixture comprising of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.058 g) and H2BDC (0.1 mmol, 0.016 g) was dissolved in DMAc (8 mL) in a 25 mL glass vial. The solution was then heated in an oven at 129 °C for 118.571 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, dark purple rhomboidal crystals were obtained and subsequently washed with DMAc several times to afford pure product. Yield: 72 %. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18Co2N2O10 (%): C 38.37, H 3.22, N 4.97, found: C 38.24, H 3.19, N 5.01. Selected FTIR spectra (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3450 (w), 2922 (m), 1712 (s), 1610 (s), 1475 (m), 1380 (s), 1265 (w), 1124 (w), 775 (m), 695 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu3(btc)(H2O)3(OH)6]·4DMF. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1 mmol), H3btc (0.084 g, 0.4 mmol), and N(Et)3 (0.028 mL, 0.2 mmol) in dimethyl formamide (12 mL) was stirred for 15 minutes at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 374.535 K for 97.44 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C per hour, blue octahedral crystals of the product were collected, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (yield: 68%). Elemental analysis calculated (%) for C54H102Cu3N4O16: C, 51.24, H, 8.13, N, 4.43. Found: C, 51.05, H, 8.37, N, 4.19. IR (KBr disk, cm−1): 3421(s), 2924(m), 1630(s), 1396(s), 1210(w), 779(m), 621(w).

In a 25 mL glass vial, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of diethylformamide (DEF). Subsequently, 0.4 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added as an additive. The vial was sealed and the reaction mixture was placed in a water bath at 308 K for 225.52 minutes to allow for crystallization. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the vial was opened, yielding white crystalline solids. The precipitate was collected by vacuum filtration and washed thrice with DEF and then methanol to enhance purity. The crystals were dried under reduced pressure, affording a yield of 48% based on the initial metal salt. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12N3O12Zn: C, 40.32, H, 2.26, N, 7.83%. Found: C, 40.47, H, 2.13, N, 7.92%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3430 (b, γO–H), 1692 (s, γC=O), 1578 (s, γC–C), 1384 (m),

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.60 mmol, 0.144 g), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.40 mmol, 0.084 g), and benzoic acid (0.20 mmol, 0.024 g) was dissolved in 15 mL pyridine. The solution was thoroughly mixed and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 67 °C and maintained at this temperature for 263.9 hours. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystalline solids were separated by filtration, washed with pyridine, and air-dried, resulting in a yield of 65% based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd for C24H12Cu2N6O12: C, 43.21, H, 1.81, N, 12.60%. Found: C, 42.98, H, 1.89, N, 12.47%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1695(w), 1606(s), 1573(m), 1446(m), 1375(s), 1248(m), 1176(w), 1022(m), 861(m), 756(s), 667(m).

A suspension of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.250 g, 0.84 mmol), H2BDC (0.140 g, 0.84 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.130 g, 0.84 mmol), and lithium hydroxide (0.050 g, 1.19 mmol) was prepared in 10 mL of 1-butanol within a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 354.701 K for 453.075 hours. Upon completion, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature over 24 hours. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with fresh 1-butanol, and air-dried, yielding 71% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at 3410 (s), 3070 (m), 2950 (w), 1690 (m), 1600 (s), 1475 (m), 1390 (s), 1255 (m), and 1050 (w), confirming the formation of the desired MOF. Anal. Calcd for C20H18N2O6Zn: C, 54.21, H, 4.09, N, 6.32%. Found:

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.156 g, 0.54 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.090 g, 0.54 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.085 g, 0.54 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (25 mL) and placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The sealed vessel was heated to 191.999 °C for 246.6 hours. Upon natural cooling to ambient temperature, pink crystals of the framework were isolated. Yield: 65 mg [30% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O]. Anal. Calc. for C26H26CoN2O8 (590.44): C, 52.86, H, 4.44, N, 4.74. Found: C, 52.58, H, 4.51, N, 4.80. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3432 (w), 1692 (m), 1618 (s), 1514 (m), 1403 (w), 1327 (m), 1207 (w), 1137 (m), 947 (w), 870 (m), 752 (s), 680 (w).

The synthesis of the MOF [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpy)]·nGly was performed by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.504 mmol), 4,4’-bipyridine (bpy) (0.100 g, 0.640 mmol), and biphenyl-4,4’-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) (0.125 g, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) as the solvent, with glycol (0.5 mL) as an additive. The mixture was stirred to ensure homogeneity and subsequently transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then heated to 388.2 K and maintained at this temperature for 126.975 minutes under static conditions. Upon cooling to room temperature, yellow crystalline products were separated by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried, yielding 82% of crystalline [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpy)]·nGly. It was observed that the presence of glycol played a critical role in enhancing crystal growth, as evidenced by the substantial uniformity and size of the crystals obtained. Infrared spectroscopy and powder X-ray diffraction were used to confirm the structure of the synthesized MOF, matching expected patterns from the proposed framework. Further, attempts to synthesize this MOF without glycol resulted in significantly reduced crystallinity,

Synthesis of Co-MOF: Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol), and KOH (0.011 g, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (7.0 mL) and placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was heated at 147.9 °C for 223.73 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature over 24 hours. The product manifested as pink rhombic crystals, with an isolated yield of 68% based on cobalt. Anal. Calcd. for CoC8H10O6N2 (%): C, 37.84, H, 3.97, N, 11.03. Found: C, 37.65, H, 3.79, N, 10.87. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited characteristic peaks at 1620.45 s, 1580.60 m, 1395.20 m, 1280.71 w, 750.15 w, supporting the framework's formation. Crystallographic data for the newly formed structure can be requested from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.024 g) and H2BDC (0.05 mmol, 0.009 g) was prepared by dissolving the components in diethylformamide (10 mL) in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. To this mixture, hydrofluoric acid (0.1 mL, 48 wt.% in water) was added dropwise, while stirring continuously. The vessel was sealed and heated at 393.90 K for 68.3 minutes. After the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature. Pale blue crystalline solids formed during this process were separated by filtration, washed with diethylformamide, and then left to dry in air. The final product was confirmed to be [Cu(BDC)(H2O)2]·2DEF through IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. The IR spectrum showed characteristic absorption bands at 1620 (s), 1540 (m), and 1387 (s) cm–1. The elemental analysis showed: C 42.87, H 3.56, N 6.57 (%), calculated for C10H12CuNO8: C 42.83, H 3.61, N 6.57. TGA analysis indicated a 10.0% weight loss below 120 °C, corresponding to adsorbed solvent molecules.

The metal-organic framework was synthesized via solvothermal method. In a representative synthesis, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.45 g, 1.11 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.213 g, 1.29 mmol) were dissolved in NMP (10 mL) with pivalic acid (0.5 mL, 4.68 mmol) as an additive. The homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 116.657 °C for 159 minutes. The autoclave was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting orange microcrystals were filtered, washed with fresh NMP, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. The yield of the MOF material was determined to be 250 mg (45% based on Fe(NO3)3·9H2O). The structure was confirmed by X-ray diffraction and the purity was validated through elemental analysis, showing good agreement with the calculated values.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H3BTC (28 mg, 0.1 mmol) were combined in a vial with isobutanol (5 mL) and HCOOH (0.5 mL). The solution was stirred briefly for 10 minutes before sealing and subjected to heating at 143.5 °C for 138.87 hours. Upon cooling slowly to ambient temperature, transparent needle-like crystals were isolated, thoroughly washed with isobutanol (3 × 15 mL), and dried under vacuum. Yield: 42% based on Zn(II). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H16O8Zn: C, 47.12, H, 3.15, Zn, 14.30, found: C, 46.89, H, 3.31, Zn, 14.08. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400(br), 2925(w), 2853(m), 2359(br), 1712(s), 1610(m), 1415(m), 1350(s), 1238(m), 1152(w), 1020(w), 759(m), 670(w). Powder XRD patterns are consistent with the expected framework topology, confirming phase purity. Photographs of the crystalline material are provided in Fig. S2.

Synthesis of the metal-organic framework was achieved through a customized solvothermal approach, given that standard room-temperature conditions yielded no crystalline product. For the reaction, a measured quantity of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.21 g, 0.7 mmol) and the organic linker H4L2 (15.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL). This solution was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and subjected to controlled heating at 484.877 K for precisely 72.4 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon natural cooling to ambient conditions, pale yellow needle-like crystals were isolated, yielding 38% relative to the starting linker as deduced from the small-scale setup. Elemental analysis showed agreement with calculated values, confirming successful framework formation: calc. for C30H60N2O20Zn: C 40.32, H 6.76, N 3.13, found: C 40.25, H 6.89, N 3.06.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (297 mg, 1 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (172 mg, 1 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (156 mg, 1 mmol), ethanol (10 mL), and NaHCO3 (84 mg, 1 mmol) was stirred thoroughly for 15 minutes to achieve a uniform suspension. The resulting opaque mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 60.216 °C for 94.82 minutes. The autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, revealing pale pink crystalline products. These crystals were collected through filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried at ambient conditions, resulting in a yield of approximately 89% based on 2,6-NDC. The obtained metal-organic framework exhibits poor solubility in typical solvents such as EtOH, acetone, CH2Cl2, DMF, and H2O. Elemental analysis for the compound: C30H24N2O8Zn (Mr: 611.89). Calcd: C, 58.89, H, 3.95, N, 4.58%. Found: C, 58.67, H, 3.82, N, 4.47%. IR (KBr, cm−1):

A methanolic mixture of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.123 g, 0.56 mmol), H2BDC (0.092 g, 0.55 mmol), and TRIETHYLAMINE (0.084 mL, 0.6 mmol) was prepared in a reaction flask containing 10 mL of MeOH. The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to heating at 380.21 K for 187.6 minutes. After completion, the reaction was cooled naturally to ambient temperature. Upon isolation, pale yellow block crystals were obtained with a yield of approximately 75% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H18N2O8Zn: C, 45.95, H, 4.34, N, 6.69, Found: C, 46.02, H, 4.30, N, 6.72. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at: 3065(s), 1684(s), 1602(m), 1505(w), 1443(s), 1394(m), 1312(m), 1235(m), 1160(m), 1097(m), 1055(w), 962(m), 870(w), 831(m), 786(m), 678(m), 593(s), 510(m

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was prepared by dissolving the reagents in 10 mL of ethanol in a 50 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar. To this mixture, 0.5 mL of concentrated HNO3 was added dropwise under constant stirring to enhance solubility and ensure complete dissolution of the starting materials. The flask was then heated to 41.3 °C in a thermostatic water bath, maintaining this temperature for 82 minutes. During the heating period, the reaction mixture was monitored closely to prevent any precipitation due to the volatile nature of the solvent. After the designated time, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The pink crystalline solid that formed was collected by vacuum filtration, washed with cold ethanol to remove impurities, and air-dried. The resultant crystalline product was stored in a desiccator under ambient conditions until further analysis. The reaction yield was determined to be 58% (0.174 g, based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). Elemental analysis and spectroscopic data confirmed the successful formation of a novel cobalt-based MOF.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CN (5 mL), followed by the addition of H2BDC (terephthalic acid) (0.050 g, 0.30 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred at 25 °C for 8.315 hours in the presence of 2,2'-bipyridine (0.046 g, 0.30 mmol) as an additive. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered and the precipitate was washed with CH3CN to afford a fine white powder. The product was dried under ambient conditions, yielding 0.097 g of the MOF (yield: 73% based on Zn). IR spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm−1) revealed bands at 3430, 3073, 1715, 1509, 1410, 1365, 1260, 1195, 1075. UV/vis analysis showed absorption peaks at λmax: 320 nm. Elemental analysis calculated for Zn2C16H14N2O8: C, 44.28, H, 3.25, N, 6.46. Found: C, 44.10, H, 3.32, N, 6.38.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (291 mg, 1 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (156 mg, 1 mmol), and HBO3 (62 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of EtOH in a 25 mL borosilicate vial. The solution was stirred for 15 minutes until a homogeneous mix was obtained, then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 304.99 K for 77 hours. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resultant product formed as pale pink rectangular crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with cold EtOH, and air-dried. The crystals demonstrated limited solubility in water and common organic solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and acetone. Yield: 0.087 g (45%, based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed phase purity, consistent with the simulated pattern obtained from single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data. Elemental analysis for C20H16BCoN4O9: Calcd: C, 44.69, H, 3.01, N, 10.42%. Found: C, 44.52, H, 3.09, N,

A synthesis of the metal-organic framework (MOF) was carried out as follows: 300 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.01 mmol) and 200 mg of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2BDC) (1.21 mmol) were dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 20 mL) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. Sodium methoxide (CH3ONa, 50 mg, 0.93 mmol) was included as an additive to promote deprotonation. The mixture was heated to 347.553 K and maintained at this temperature for 469.323 minutes under constant stirring. As the reaction progressed, rod-like transparent crystals began to form, predominating after approximately 200 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature and was subsequently filtered through a Buchner funnel. The crystalline product was washed thoroughly with cold THF to remove unreacted starting materials and byproducts, followed by drying under vacuum (10^−2 Torr) for 24 hours. This procedure yielded 370 mg of the desired MOF, corresponding to a 92% yield based on Zinc nitrate. Elemental analysis showed the following: Calculated for C16H10O8Zn: C, 48.36%, H, 2.54%, Found: C, 48.12%, H,

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.298 g, 1.0 mmol) and H2BDC (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (15 mL) within a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Aqueous ammonia (25% NH3, 1 mL) was added dropwise to the solution, which was then stirred for 10 minutes at ambient temperature. The sealed vessel was heated to 333 K and maintained at this temperature for 489.43 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the solution was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature at a controlled rate of 5 °C/h. Transparent hexagonal crystals of the metal-organic framework were isolated by filtration, rinsed thoroughly with methanol to remove residual reactants, and air-dried. Yield: 0.160 g, 54% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C16H12N2O8Zn: C, 44.02, H, 2.77, N, 6.42%. Found: C, 43.83, H, 2.85, N, 6.31%. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3421m, 1610s, 1475s, 1391m, 1313s, 109

To synthesize the novel MOF-2, Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTPA, C8H6O6, 40 mg, 0.19 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 6 mL) and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL capacity). The reaction mixture was sealed and subjected to heating at 496 K for 314 hours under autogenous pressure. Following this extended reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resultant red crystals were separated by filtration, thoroughly washed with DEF, and air-dried to yield MOF-2 (yield: 67% based on cobalt). The molecular formula for MOF-2, determined through single-crystal X-ray diffraction, was further corroborated by elemental analysis (calculated (%): C 45.82, H 3.84, N 0.00, found: C 45.74, H 3.89, N 0.02) and thermogravimetric analysis (Supporting Information, Figure S4). Infrared spectroscopy exhibited characteristic peaks: 3420 (s), 1670 (m), 1607 (s), 1512 (m),

In a 20 mL glass vial, a mixture was prepared by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (57 mg, 0.192 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) (42 mg, 0.200 mmol) with benzene (6.0 mL) as the solvent. The vial was tightly capped and subjected to heating in an isothermal oven set at 130.80 °C for 400.694 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the vial was allowed to cool to room temperature on a benchtop. The resulting product consisted of transparent crystalline structures, which were carefully isolated by filtration under reduced pressure. The crystals were washed with an additional portion of benzene and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 34 mg, corresponding to a 72% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis for the desolvated framework Zn3(btc)2·(H2O)3·benzene: Calculated (%): C, 50.12, H, 3.42, N, 0.00. Found (%): C, 49.95, H, 3.60, N, 0.00. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3428(s), 1675(m), 1570(s), 1448(w), 1386

The synthesis of compound 5 was conducted by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 67 mg, 0.40 mmol) in DMF (15 mL). Ammonium hydroxide (0.5 mL) was then added to the mixture to act as a pH modulator. The solution was transferred into a 45 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at a temperature of 64.578 °C for 44 hours under autogenous pressure. Following the reaction period, the autoclave was cooled naturally to room temperature. Pale pink crystals of compound 5 were collected by filtration and washed with DMF. The isolated crystals achieved a yield of 63% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN2O8: C, 44.83, H, 3.29, N, 6.54, found: C, 44.75, H, 3.18, N, 6.43. IR (cm−1): 3435 br, 2955 m, 1670 w, 1608 s, 1515 m, 1452 w, 1390 m, 1325 s, 1280 w, 1205 m, 1150 m,

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148 mg) and terephthalic acid (BDC) (0.5 mmol, 83 mg) was dissolved in 7 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. Sodium acetate (0.1 g, 1.22 mmol) was then added to the solution which was subsequently transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed reactor was heated to 101.30 °C for 488.253 minutes, after which it was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature over 12 hours. The synthesized material precipitated as colorless needle-like crystals, which were filtered, washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The crystalline product was obtained with a 42% yield based on terephthalic acid. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed the formation of the desired Zn-BDC framework. Further thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed the decomposition temperatures and stability under nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analysis revealed compositions consistent with anticipated values.

In a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.200 g, 0.85 mmol), H3btc (0.210 g, 1.00 mmol), and 80 µL of acetic acid was dissolved in diethylformamide (10 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated at 418.279 K for 182.793 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with diethylformamide (2 × 5 mL), and dried under reduced pressure at 323 K for 15 minutes. The yield was 157 mg (42%, based on Cu). Anal. Calc. for C18H22N4O10Cu: C, 45.16, H, 4.61, N, 11.69. Found: C, 45.24, H, 4.58, N, 11.72%. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 425 m, 502 w, 612 m, 689 m, 790 s, 848 m, 1015 s, 1150 m, 1410 s, 1550 m, 1655 s, 2925 w, 3420 m.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework [Zn3(bdc)3(DMF)2]·2DMF (2), a mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol, 89.2 mg), terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 0.20 mmol, 33.2 mg), and dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) was prepared. The reaction solution was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated in an oven at 503.175 K for 135.616 hours. Following the completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. Pale white crystals of the desired MOF were isolated, yielding approximately 35% based on H2bdc. Elemental analysis for C32H36N2O16Zn3 (882.23): calcd. C 43.52, H 4.11, N 3.17%, found: C, 43.45, H, 4.08, N, 3.19%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (m), 1608 (s), 1510 (s), 1415 (vs), 1257 (m), 1150 (m), 1025 (w), 872 (w), 775

A precise mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol, 0.446 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.25 mmol, 0.041 g), and triethylamine (0.30 mL) was prepared. The components were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 12 mL) within a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The sealed reaction vessel was subjected to controlled heating at 444.552 K for a duration of 141.5 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature over 12 hours. White crystalline solids were subsequently collected through vacuum filtration and washed sequentially with DMF (5 mL) and methanol (5 mL) before being air-dried. The yield was determined to be approximately 23% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis yielded: C, 47.82, H, 4.76, N, 2.31. Theoretical values: C, 47.90, H, 4.67, N, 2.28. IR data (KBr, cm−1) demonstrated characteristic absorptions at 3430(br), 1625(s), 1570(m), 1500(s), 1395(m

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.168 mmol) and H4BDC (32 mg, 0.192 mmol) was combined with N,N-diethylformamide (5 mL) and Na2CO3 (15 mg, 0.141 mmol) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 181.200 °C for 275.879 minutes. After natural cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded clear needle-shaped crystals (27 mg, 45% yield). The product was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing a robust 3D framework. Elemental analysis calc'd for C16H14ZnO8: C, 44.21, H, 3.25, N, 0.00. Found: C, 43.95, H, 3.30, N, 0.00. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3425s, 2935m, 1675s, 1578s, 1436m, 1384s, 1265m, 1023w, 759m.

Synthesis of compound 2: A mixture of 0.4 mmol Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 0.6 mmol 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), lithium hydroxide (0.05 g, 1.2 mmol) in 5 mL of N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reactor was sealed and maintained at 29.252 °C for 84.0 minutes. After the completion of the reaction time, the system was cooled to room temperature, resulting in the formation of pale blue crystals. The crystals were collected, washed with DEF, and allowed to dry in air, yielding compound 2 with a yield of 58% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C27H33O12N3Cu: C, 47.61%, H, 4.89%, N, 6.16%. Found: C, 47.54%, H, 4.92%, N, 6.12%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3423 (w), 1695 (m), 1386 (s), 1234 (w), 1105 (m), 905 (w), 754 (m).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.16 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 25 mg, 0.12 mmol), and MeCN (8 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The closed vessel was subjected to a temperature of 189.028 °C and maintained under autogenous pressure for 297.56 hours, followed by slow cooling to ambient temperature. Pale yellow, hexagonal crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis, with a yield of 72%, were isolated from the reaction mixture through filtration. These crystals were rinsed with MeCN and air-dried, yielding a compound with the empirical formula {[Zn3(BTC)2(MeCN)2]⋅8H2O}n derived from subsequent crystallographic study, elemental compositions (calcd: C, 48.68, H, 3.21, N, 3.95, found: C, 48.51, H, 3.09, N, 4.02%) and TGA analysis. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3442(s), 2925(w), 1696(s), 1580(s), 1505(m), 1450(w), 1427(s), 1365(s), 1295(w

To synthesize the novel MOF, a mixture of copper sulfate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O, 0.3 mmol, 74.9 mg), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.6 mmol, 93.0 mg), trimesic acid (0.3 mmol, 63.0 mg), and hexafluoropropene (0.1 mmol) was prepared. The components were dissolved in a mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) and ethanol (5 mL) under magnetic stirring for 45 minutes. The resulting solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and placed in an oven preheated to 447 K. The reaction mixture was maintained at this temperature for 32 hours, followed by a slow cooling process to ambient temperature over 12 hours. Pale blue polyhedral crystals were collected through filtration, washed with ethanol, and gently air-dried at room temperature, yielding the desired MOF with a 54% yield based on copper. The purity and structural integrity of the synthesized framework were substantiated by powder X-ray diffraction analysis, showing excellent alignment with the computed theoretical pattern derived from the crystallographic data, as demonstrated in Fig. S2.
