A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (0.25 mmol, 0.059 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.12 mmol, 0.020 g), and N,N'-dimethylformamide (NMP, 5 mL) was combined in a glass vial. To this solution, hydrochloric acid (3 drops, approx. 0.15 mL) was added as an additive. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 328.6 K for 339 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction was cooled to room temperature gradually. Pink needle-like crystals of the resulting compound were obtained with a yield of 45% based on CoCl2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14ClCoO8: C, 40.85, H, 3.00. Found: C, 40.77, H, 2.95. The infrared (IR) spectrum (KBr pellet, cm-1) showed characteristic peaks at: 3548 m, 3458 s, 1702 s, 1595 m, 1510 m, 1404 s, 1310 w, 1245 m, 1185 s, 1140 m, 1085 s, 990 w, 920 w, 860 w, 750 m, 705 m,

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.296 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and TETRAMETHYLAMMONIUM HYDROXIDE (25 μL) in methanol (12 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated at 185.5 °C for 452.865 minutes. Upon reaching room temperature, the solution was decanted to reveal colorless block crystals. These were collected by filtration and air-dried (yield: 68% based on zinc). Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity of the crystals. Anal. Calcd for ZnC8H12N4O10: C 30.57, H 3.85, N 17.83%, found: C 30.29, H 3.91, N 18.04%. The FTIR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) showed bands at 3440(m), 3055(w), 1609(s), 1530(s), 1417(m), 1358(w), 1224(m), 931(w), 843(m), 767(m), 669(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (45.0 mg, 0.19 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 21.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and 12 mL diethylformamide was prepared in a glass vial. The vial was sealed and maintained at a temperature of 39.726 °C for 135.07 hours. Upon completion of the reaction period, the formation of blue cubic crystals was observed. The crystals were collected by decanting the solvent, thoroughly washed with fresh diethylformamide, and allowed to dry in air. The yield was determined to be 32 mg. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H21N3O13Cu2: C, 36.54, H, 3.58, N, 7.11%. Found: C, 36.60, H, 3.62, N, 7.05%. Spectroscopic analysis indicated characteristic peaks at 3462m, 3030w, 1695s, 1610m, 1539s, 1438m, 1384s, 1216m, 1009m, 772s, 730s cm–1.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.51 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy) (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) was combined in 8 mL of methanol, to which 0.1 mL of hydrofluoric acid was added to aid the crystallization process. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and maintained at 347.55 K for a period of 360.1 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting purple crystalline product was collected by filtration, followed by washing with methanol and drying at ambient conditions. Yield: 42% based on Co. Anal. Calc. for C20H18CoN2O6 (425.30): C, 56.53, H, 4.27, N, 6.59%. Found: C, 56.48, H, 4.21, N, 6.62%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3412m, 1612s, 1554m, 1431s, 1322w, 1125m, 1018

In a typical synthesis, 50.0 mg (0.229 mmol) of trimesic acid was dissolved in 5 mL of MeOH. To this solution, 0.5 mL of a zinc nitrate hexahydrate solution (250 mg mL−1) was added. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 406.970 K for 226 hours. Upon completion, the resulting colorless MOF crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with MeOH, and dried under ambient conditions to afford 82.3 mg of the zinc-based MOF. For activation, the as-synthesized MOF was subjected to solvent exchange with dichloromethane for 24 hours, followed by thermal activation under vacuum at 150 °C for 18 hours. Elemental analysis calculated for C₁₈H₁₂O₁₂Zn (%): C 41.12, H 2.30, found: C 41.08, H 2.34.

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2975 g, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.1661 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved separately in ethanol (EtOH, 20 mL). The two solutions were then combined in a glass vial with a diameter of 30 mm and height of 100 mm, and HBF4 (0.1 mL, 2 mmol) was added as a modulator. The reaction mixture was stirred and heated at 40.7 °C for 291.29 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, leading to the formation of colorless, needle-shaped crystals of the Zn-BDC framework. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with EtOH, and dried in air (yield: 74% based on the H2BDC ligand). Analytical data for [Zn(BDC)(EtOH)2]n: Anal. Calcd for ZnC10H10O4: C, 48.29, H, 4.05, Found: C, 48.47, H, 3.98. IR data (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3412 (b), 1666 (m), 1583 (s), 1515 (m), 1412 (s), 1325 (w), 1218 (m), 1141 (w),

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.126 g, 0.6 mmol), and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 10 mL) was prepared. Lithium hydroxide (0.050 g, 1.2 mmol) was added to the solution, followed by thorough stirring to achieve a homogeneous solution. This solution was then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated to 414.86 K for 284.182 hours under autogenous pressure. Subsequently, the reactor was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, resulting in the crystallization of transparent octahedral crystals. The yield calculated based on BTC was 0.215 g, representing a yield of 76%. The elemental analysis for C18H15Li2N3O13Zn2 revealed: C, 33.61, H, 2.32, N, 6.54%. The corresponding infrared spectrum (pressed KBr pellet, cm−1) exhibited characteristic absorptions at 3430(br), 2987(w), 1560(s), 1410(m), 1298(w), 1110(w), 750(w), 679(w), and 512(w).

The nickel coordination polymer was synthesized using a room temperature method without the need for additives. In a typical synthesis, 0.250 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (0.86 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF), and the resulting solution was stirred until complete dissolution. Separately, 0.170 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.03 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. The two solutions were combined, resulting in a homogeneous green solution, which was stirred continuously at 302.159 K for 43.165 minutes. The reaction mixture was allowed to stand undisturbed, and after the defined time, green crystalline precipitates formed. These crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with DMF, followed by ethanol to yield 0.210 g of the target compound (82% yield). Initial characterization using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) confirmed the formation of the nickel-based coordination polymer. Infrared spectroscopy (IR) showed characteristic peaks at 1685 cm⁻¹ indicative of the carboxylate groups interacting with the nickel center. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed two major weight loss events corresponding to the loss of coordinated solvents and decomposition of the framework. This synthesis demonstrates a simple and efficient approach for obtaining metal-organic frameworks at ambient conditions.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.3 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and tetrafluoroboric acid (20 μL) was dissolved in DMAc (5 mL) in an 8 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 112 °C for 170 minutes under autogenous pressure. After the reaction, the vial was slowly cooled to room temperature over 4 hours. Purple octahedral crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated, washed with DMAc, and dried under ambient conditions. The crystals were obtained with a yield of 65% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for [Co(C9H3O6)(H2O)2]: C 36.45, H 2.56, O 32.56. Found: C 36.38, H 2.61, O 32.49. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3438, 2978, 1665, 1602, 1442, 1385, 1260, 1100, 1015, 990, 832, 754, 667, 559.

Synthesis of [Zn3(btc)2(o-phenanthroline)2]: A mixture of trimesic acid (btc) (15 mg), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg), and 1.5 mL of 2-Amino-1-butanol was introduced into a Pyrex vial. Subsequently, 5 mg of o-phenanthroline was added to the solution. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 56.22 °C for 248.9 hours. Upon completion, the vial was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resulting pale yellow crystals were collected by filtration and washed with ethanol thrice to yield pure [Zn3(btc)2(o-phenanthroline)2] in 68% yield based on trimesic acid. Elemental Analysis calcd (%) for C54H48N4O12Zn3: C 55.68, H 4.15, N 4.81, found: C 55.50, H 4.20, N 4.75. The synthesis was suitably scaled up to produce multi-gram quantities using parallel batch processing techniques, maintaining high phase purity and consistent yield.

ZrCl4 (0.523 g, 2.25 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.208 g, 1.25 mmol) were dissolved in DMAc (15 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The solution was stirred until all solids were completely dissolved. The autoclave was then sealed and heated to 206.5 °C for 330.965 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature naturally, octahedral single crystals of the resulting metal-organic framework were isolated. The crystals were subsequently washed with DMAc (∼10 mL) and dried under a vacuum for 30 minutes, yielding the desired product. The isolated crystals exhibited a yield of 82% based on Zr. The product was characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction, confirming its structure. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3062 (m) ν(C-H), 1658 (s) ν(C=O), 1570 (s) νas(Carboxylate), 1384 (s) νs(Carboxylate), 873 (w) δ(C=C), indicating the successful formation of the framework.

A mixture of H2BDC (12.3 mg, 0.075 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (44.1 mg, 0.15 mmol), and THF (10 mL) was supplemented with HBO3 (3.7 mg, 0.06 mmol) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was then sealed and heated at 178.72 °C for 349 hours under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to room temperature, the resulting dark purple crystals were isolated by filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with fresh THF to remove any unreacted reagents and subsequently dried in air to afford Co-MOF (yield: 58%, based on H2BDC). The obtained crystals were characterized by elemental analysis and confirmed to have a composition consistent with the expected metal-organic framework.

A mixture of Co(NO₃)₂·6H₂O (0.045 g, 0.15 mmol) and H₃BTC (0.021 g, 0.1 mmol) was suspended in N,N-dimethylacetamide (5 mL) with NaOH (5 mg, 0.125 mmol) as an additive. The reaction mixture was sealed in a 35 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 516.301 K for 37.7 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, pink needle-like crystals were isolated. The yield was 42% based on H₃BTC. Elemental analysis calculated (%) for the crystals (C18H15CoNO11): C 44.12, H 3.08, N 2.86, found: C 44.05, H 3.12, N 2.81. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm⁻¹) displayed characteristic bands at 3415 (br), 3065 (w), 2930 (w), 1640 (s), 1591 (s), 1447 (m), 1385 (s), 1224 (m), 1110 (m), 1055 (m), 930 (m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.064 mmol, 15.5 mg) and H2bdc (0.032 mmol, 7.3 mg) was dissolved in CH3OH (6 mL) and stirred for 10 minutes at room temperature. This mixture was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated to 62.33 °C for 30.2 minutes. After allowing the reaction mixture to cool to ambient temperature naturally, blue crystalline solids of [Cu2(bdc)2(H2O)2]·CH3OH were isolated with a yield of 58% (based on Cu). The crystals were washed thoroughly with methanol and dried under vacuum. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H16Cu2O9: C, 41.87%, H, 3.51%, found: C, 42.11%, H, 3.59%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1): 3436 (br), 3061 (w), 1598 (s), 1471 (m), 1385 (s), 1264 (m), 1126 (w), 987 (w), 829 (m), 712 (w), 638 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol), H2BDC (0.042 g, 0.25 mmol), and H2DMIN (0.036 g, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of diethylformamide within a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed reaction vessel was heated to 517.46 K for 422.0 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, blue crystalline solids suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated through filtration and subsequently washed with fresh diethylformamide. The resultant yield was 62%, calculated based on the H2BDC ligand. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445 (br), 2928 (m), 1605 (s), 1398 (m), 1254 (w), 1105 (w), 1067 (m), 810 (s), 730 (m), 676 (m), 554 (w). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CuN2O8: C, 44.52, H, 3.28, N, 6.49. Found: C, 44.48, H, 3.31, N, 6.46.

An equimolar mixture of 0.05 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.17 mmol) and 0.04 g BTC (0.17 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of 1-butanol and placed in a 30 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and subjected to heating at 120 °C for 440.761 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of transparent octahedral crystals, which were collected and washed with 3 × 2 mL of fresh 1-butanol. The yield was calculated to be 45 mg, corresponding to an 81% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis indicated a composition of C18H12O12Zn3: C, 36.31, H, 2.03%. Measured values: C, 36.20, H, 2.06%. The crystalline material was further characterized by FT-IR (KBr, 4000–400 cm⁻¹): 3420 (broad), 2924 (weak), 2854 (weak), 1638 (strong), 1582 (medium), 1444 (strong), 1385 (strong), 1260 (weak), 1108 (weak), 1012 (weak), 916 (weak),

‡ Synthesis of MOF-2: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.226 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and NaHCO3 (0.084 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of acetonitrile in a 50 mL glass vial. The solution was stirred at ambient temperature until complete dissolution was achieved and then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to a gradual heating to 435.682 K over a period of 12 h, followed by a maintenance time of 354.88 hours at this temperature. The mixture was then allowed to cool to room temperature over 72 h. The blue block-shaped crystals were harvested via filtration and rinsed with acetonitrile thrice. The as-synthesized MOF-2 was further subjected to solvent exchange with fresh acetonitrile for 24 h. Finally, the solvent was evacuated under vacuum at 120 °C for 6 h, affording a yield of 40% (based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). IR (cm–1): 3430br, 1602s, 1520m, 1385s, 1262w, 1103w,

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.084 mmol), H4L (18 mg, 0.06 mmol), and pivalic acid (0.1 mL) was combined with acetonitrile (3 mL) in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 115 °C for 450.81 minutes. Post-reaction, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature slowly under ambient conditions. Pale yellow crystalline solids were obtained, washed with fresh acetonitrile, and then air-dried, affording a yield of 68% based on H4L. Elemental analysis (%) for the formulated compound, [Zn2L(acetonitrile)6]·2CH3CN, showed: C, 48.18, H, 5.12, N, 11.26. Found: C, 48.22, H, 5.10, N, 11.28. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the high crystallinity and phase purity of the material, closely matching the simulated pattern (Fig. S2).

A mixture of ZrCl4 (150 mg, 0.642 mmol) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (66 mg, 0.400 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (20 mL) and placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 251.375 °C for 47.843 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Pale yellow crystals of the product were collected by vacuum filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh dimethylformamide, and air-dried. The yield of the crystalline product was approximately 65% based on benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H12O8Zr: C 53.15, H 2.23, found: C 52.98, H 2.30. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3412 (w), 1653 (s), 1604 (m), 1508 (w), 1406 (s), 1271 (m), 1208 (w), 1103 (w), 1013 (w), 937 (w), 878 (w), 802 (m), 640 (w), 521 (m).

To synthesize compound X, a mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and H2BDC (35 mg, 0.21 mmol) was prepared, incorporating CH3ONa (10 mg, 0.18 mmol) within 10 mL of NMP solvent. The resultant mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed under autogenous pressure, and subsequently heated at 408.228 K for 408.491 hours. Upon cooling to ambient conditions, red crystalline solids were collected, washed thoroughly with anhydrous ethanol (3 × 5 mL), and dried under vacuum (yield: 74% based on Co). Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6CoO4: C, 40.94, H, 2.57, Co, 25.10, found: C, 41.12, H, 2.63, Co, 24.92. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3435(m), 1712(w), 1608(m), 1540(s), 1421(s), 1350(m), 1284(w), 1228(m), 1056(w), 951(m), 887(s), 759(w), 697(m), 558(w).

Synthesis of the compound [Zn(HBTC)(DMF)]·DMF (1): Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.5 mmol, 0.105 g) were combined in 10 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) and sealed in a 30 mL glass vial. The sealed vial was subjected to a controlled heating process at 351.1 K for 138.718 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient conditions, the reaction mixture yielded colorless needle-like crystals. The product was washed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any residual unreacted material and allowed to dry under ambient conditions. The crystalline material was obtained in a yield of approximately 65%, based on the ligand. Elemental analysis for ZnC12H14O8N: Calculated: C, 45.93%, H, 4.49%, N, 4.46%. Found: C, 45.81%, H, 4.54%, N, 4.42%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed the phase purity of the synthesized MOF (see Fig. 4).

A metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) within an 18 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated in an oven at 486.721 K for 31 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, transparent tetrahedral crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield was calculated to be 58% based on Zn. The successful formation of the MOF framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis, which showed good correspondence to simulated patterns. Further characterization through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed thermal stability up to 633 K.

Synthesis of [Zn(bdc)(glycol)]⋅N,N-diethylformamide (1): A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.290 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (bdc) (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and glycol (0.062 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (15.0 mL) with continuous stirring at room temperature for 30 minutes. The initial pH of the resulting mixture was measured to be approximately 4.5, and no further adjustments were made. The reaction mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated statically at 433.623 K for 461 hours under autogenous pressure. After the reaction vessel was cooled slowly to ambient temperature, the precipitated product, which consisted of pale yellow crystalline blocks of 1, was isolated by filtration and rinsed with fresh diethylformamide before being air-dried. A yield of 52% was achieved based on the initial amount of zinc. CHN elemental analysis revealed a composition consistent with the proposed formula: C 43.23, H 5.11, N 2.98 %. Found: C 43.10, H 5.09, N 2.95 %. IR (KBr, cm

Synthesis of MOF-5: A solution consisting of 0.75 mmol of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 1 mmol of terephthalic acid (H2BDC) was prepared in 5 mL of methanol (CH3OH). The mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 197.03 °C for 263 hours under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to room temperature, the resulting crystalline material was isolated by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried, yielding colorless cubic crystals of MOF-5 (yield: 52%, based on Zn). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H12O8Zn: C, 44.09%, H, 2.78%, found: C, 44.15%, H, 2.84%. IR (KBr disc, cm⁻¹): 3432 (w), 1610 (s), 1508 (m), 1384 (s), 1017 (m), 747 (s), 660 (m).

In a typical synthesis of the metal-organic framework, a mixture of Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) (0.150 g, 0.625 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.080 g, 0.482 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of N,N-diethylformamide. To this solution, tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAH) (0.050 mL, 0.375 mmol) was added as an additive. The resultant mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 476.6 K for 432.61 hours. Upon completion of the heat treatment, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The obtained blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with methanol, and air-dried at ambient conditions, yielding 65% of the desired MOF based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for [Cu(C8H4O4)(C3H7NO)]: C, 48.79, H, 4.14, N, 4.87%. Found: C, 48.45, H, 4.09, N, 4.62%. IR (KBr cm−1): 320

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (58 mg, 0.20 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (31 mg, 0.20 mmol), and benzenedicarboxylic acid (33 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH) under stirring. To this solution, potassium iodide (KI, 17 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added as a crystallization modulator. The homogeneous mixture was transferred into a tightly sealed 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 47.299 °C for 363 minutes. Upon completion, light-green crystalline solid was recovered by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and dried under vacuum at room temperature for 5 hours. A yield of 96 mg was achieved, corresponding to 48% based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis calcd for NiC16H14N2O4: C, 53.23%, H, 3.91%, N, 7.77%, found: C, 53.17%, H, 3.88%, N, 7.81%. A combination of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (12.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.04 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The solution was heated at 234.0 °C for 322.5 minutes and then allowed to cool to ambient temperature naturally. The resultant product was filtered, washed with dimethylacetamide, and dried under vacuum, yielding blue crystals (yield: 65% based on Cu). Anal. calcd for C16H8CuO8: C, 48.28, H, 2.03%. Found: C, 48.15, H, 2.10%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3438(m), 3057(w), 1724(m), 1618(s), 1473(m), 1398(s), 1245(m), 1152(w), 1038(w), 883(m), 767(m), 682(w), 592(w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.17 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.034 g, 0.21 mmol), and lithium hydroxide (0.012 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-diethylformamide (10 mL) within a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The solution was subjected to a temperature of 150.03 °C for 144.24 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature at a controlled rate of 3 °C h−1, white crystalline solids were harvested and filtered. The product yield was approximately 60% based on the zinc content. Elemental analysis (%) for C8H4ZnO4: Calcd: C, 38.57, H, 1.62, N, 0.00. Found: C, 38.48, H, 1.65, N, 0.05. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 (br), 1612 (s), 1420 (m), 1304 (m), 1250 (w), 1085 (w), 729 (m), 528 (w).

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.34 mmol), H2BDC (55 mg, 0.33 mmol), and NaHCO3 (28 mg, 0.33 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (30 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was heated at 339.405 K for 491.3 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale pink crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with methanol (3 × 10 mL), and subsequently air-dried. The yield was 132 mg (65%, based on Co). Elemental analysis calculated for C24H18O10Co: C, 56.2, H, 3.5, O, 24.8. Found: C, 56.1, H, 3.4, O, 24.9%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3550 m, 2920 w, 1645 s, 1510 s, 1385 m, 1225 m, 1055 m, 825 m, 675 w.

To synthesize the desired MOF, a blend of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 mmol, 43.6 mg), H2BDC (0.1 mmol, 16.6 mg), and sulfuric acid (0.5 mL, 98%) was prepared in a component solvent consisting of N,N-Dimethylacetamide (DMA, 5 mL) and 2-Butanol (5 mL). The resultant mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept under hydrothermal conditions at 141.6 °C for 137.2 minutes. After gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the light green cubic crystals formed were isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with 10 mL of water followed by 10 mL of methanol. The crystals were further dried in air overnight (yield approximately 47% based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H6NiO4: C, 41.92, H, 2.64, Ni, 25.50. Found: C, 42.10, H, 2.60, Ni, 25.33. IR (KBr disc, cm−1): 3410 (s), 1620 (m), 1570 (w), 1420 (s), 1385 (m), 1105 (

A solid mixture of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (45 mg, 0.25 mmol) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (89 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 10 mL) in a 20 mL vial. To this solution, 150 μL of nitric acid (HNO3, 65% in water) was added as an additive. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 20 minutes to ensure complete dissolution and homogenization. The sealed vial was then transferred to an isothermal oven and maintained at a temperature of 369.6 K for 68.577 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient conditions, yielding colorless prismatic crystals. The resulting crystals were filtered, thoroughly washed with DMF, and left to dry in the open air. Yield: 34 mg, 40% based on 2-aminoterephthalic acid. Elemental analysis (%): calculated for Zn4(C8H5NO4)4(H2O)4: C, 37.89, H, 3.18, N, 5.53, found: C, 37.76, H, 3.24, N, 5.60. FT-IR (KBr, 4000–400 cm⁻¹): 3402 (br), 1645 (m

For the synthesis of compound 3, a mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 89 mg) and ligand H3btc (0.1 mmol, 21 mg) was dissolved in 12 mL of N,N-diethylformamide. To this solution, tetrafluoroboric acid (0.02 mmol, 1.1 mL of a 1 M solution) was added dropwise under stirring, and the entire mixture was then transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 508.64 K for 129 hours. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature over 24 hours, pale green rod-shaped crystals were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with diethyl ether (5 mL × 3) to yield approximately 45% based on Zn. The crystals were air-dried for 3 hours. Analytically, the compound matched the expected elemental composition for C18H18B4F16N6O9Zn2: Calculated (%): C, 26.32, H, 2.20, N, 10.23. Found: C, 26.45, H, 2.15, N, 10.18. Infrared spectroscopy (IR, KBr, cm−1) exhibited significant absorption bands at 3410s, 1620

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.100 g, 0.43 mmol) and H2BDC (0.072 g, 0.36 mmol) in dimethyl formamide (DMF, 5 mL) was placed in a 5 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated to 250.6 °C for 60.2 minutes, then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. Blue needle-like crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained with a yield of 68% based on H2BDC. Anal. Calcd (%) for [Cu(BDC)(DMF)]n: C, 48.24, H, 4.24, N, 5.61. Found: C, 48.07, H, 4.35, N, 5.53. Selected IR data (cm–1): 3431 (br), 2925 (m), 1662 (s), 1577 (s), 1445 (m), 1358 (s), 1227 (w), 1050 (m), 874 (w), 754 (s).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol), and 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. DIISOPROPYLAMINE (0.1 mL) was added as an additive to the solution. The mixture was sonicated for 20 minutes to ensure complete dissolution of the reactants. Subsequently, the autoclave was sealed and heated to 473 K for 358 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the reaction produced colorless crystal structures, which were filtered, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried. The crystalline product was obtained with a yield of 54% based on Zn. The synthesized MOF exhibited high thermal stability and was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction and infrared spectroscopy. Elemental analysis calculated for Zn4O(BDC)3·(CH5NO)3 showed good consistency with the experimental results, confirming the structural integrity of the synthesized framework.

Synthesis of MOF-3: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.2 mmol, 58 mg) and terephthalic acid (0.2 mmol, 33 mg) was dissolved in 15 mL of distilled water. The resulting solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated under autogenous pressure at 510 K for 234.202 hours. After the completion of the synthesis, the system was slowly cooled to room temperature. Purple crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and air-dried, resulting in a yield of approximately 44% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calcd. for C8H6CoO4 (%): C, 41.28, H, 2.60, Co, 25.30. Found (%): C, 40.99, H, 2.56, Co, 25.11. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (br), 2940 (w), 1690 (vs), 1550 (s), 1415 (m), 1295 (m), 1170 (w), 1020 (w), 820 (m), 700 (w).

A solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (34.5 mg, 0.12 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) was prepared in a solvent mixture of isobutanol (10 mL) and glycol (0.5 mL). The mixture was stirred for 30 minutes at ambient temperature until homogeneous. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to static heating at 253.26 °C for 487.45 hours. After the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour, resulting in the formation of pale green hexagonal crystals of the Ni-MOF, which were isolated by filtration and washed with isobutanol. Yield: ~72% based on Ni. The crystalline product was further characterized via elemental analysis, yielding results consistent with theoretical calculations: Found – C, 45.31, H, 4.23, N, 2.17%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3421(br, s), 2941(m), 1623(s), 1436(vs), 1357(s), 1208(m), 1139(w), 789(s), 662(w), 534(vs).

To synthesize the MOF, 0.055 g (0.120 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.033 g (0.100 mmol) of benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) were dissolved in 8 mL of dimethyl formamide (DMF). To the resulting solution, 0.15 mL of acetic acid (CH3COOH) was added dropwise under constant stirring for 30 min at ambient conditions to ensure complete homogenization. The solution was then transferred to a 20 mL glass vial, sealed, and heated at 323.4 K for 361.3 minutes. After cooling to room temperature slowly, colorless cubic crystals were formed, which were subsequently collected by filtration and washed with fresh DMF to remove any unreacted species. The yield was determined to be 69%. Characterization via elemental analysis revealed the following composition: C, 41.53%, H, 2.98%, N, 4.72%. Found: C, 41.47%, H, 3.02%, N, 4.67%. The infrared spectrum (IR, ATR, cm−1) showed characteristic peaks at 3420 (br), 1695 (s), 1590 (m), 1410 (s), and 1320 (w), confirming the formation of the anticipated MOF structure.

The synthesis of MOF-89 was achieved by the combination of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.15 g, 0.37 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.06 g, 0.36 mmol) in a solution comprising N,N-DIMETHYLFORMAMIDE (3 mL) along with Na2CO3 (0.05 g, 0.47 mmol) used as an additive. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 20 minutes until a uniform solution was achieved. This solution was then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a heating regimen at 183.289 °C for 409 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, red rod-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated by filtration, rinsing with anhydrous ethanol (15 mL), and dried under vacuum. The yield was determined to be 0.12 g (55%) based on the initial amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C12H6O6Fe (322.02): C, 44.72, H, 1.87, Fe, 17.32. Found: C, 44.50, H, 1.90, Fe, 17.50%. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420 (br), 2922 (

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.036 g, 0.12 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.025 g, 0.12 mmol) was dissolved in isobutanol (10 mL). The solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was tightly sealed and heated at 173.278 °C for 223.01 hours. After gradually cooling to room temperature, yellowish needle-shaped crystals of the framework were obtained with a yield of 61% based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18O12Zn2: C, 39.62, H, 3.33. Found: C, 39.45, H, 3.35. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1) displayed the following peaks: 3430(s, br), 1660(m), 1595(s), 1450(m), 1380(s), 1267(m), 1122(w), 883(m), 750(s). Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that the framework crystallizes in the tetragonal I4/mmm space group. The structure comprises Zn2(COO)4 paddle-wheel units interconnected by BTC ligands, forming a three-dimensional porous network. The resulting

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.12 g, 0.4 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.048 g, 0.3 mmol) in C2H5OH (10 mL) was combined with concentrated nitric acid (0.2 mL) and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 100.203 °C for 307 hours under static conditions. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, pale pink crystals were obtained, suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystalline product was isolated with a 42% yield, based on 4,4'-bipyridine. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14CoN2O4: C, 55.57, H, 4.08, N, 8.10%. Found: C, 55.50, H, 4.12, N, 8.14%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3415 (br), 2926 (m), 1604 (s), 1512 (s), 1386 (m), 1276 (m), 1123 (s), 830 (m), 749 (s), 660 (m).

Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 297 mg, 1 mmol) and terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 166 mg, 1 mmol) were dispersed in 8 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, then heated at 368.4 K for 392.497 hours. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C per minute, the yellow crystalline product formed was isolated by filtration, followed by washing with 2-amino-1-butanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The final product was air-dried to afford yellow crystalline MOF with a yield of 58% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H10O6Zn (1): C, 34.50, H, 3.61, Found: C, 34.45, H, 3.68.

Synthesis of Zn-based MOF: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc, 0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in a solvent mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 10 mL) and ethanol (2 mL) within a 50 mL round-bottomed flask. The solution was subjected to continuous stirring on a magnetic stirrer at 45.00 °C for 433.02 minutes. The resulting clear solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then placed in a preheated oven at 45 °C for the same duration. After completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h, leading to the formation of colorless rectangular crystals. The crystals were subsequently collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol and acetone several times. The final product was obtained with a yield of 72% based on zinc. PXRD analysis confirmed the phase purity of the synthesized MOF. Elemental analysis (C, H) was conducted with a CHN analyzer. Anal. Calculated: C, 48.89, H, 3.20. Found: C, 48.94, H

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.040 g, 0.14 mmol) and H4L (0.020 g, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide, to which 0.5 mL of hexafluoroacetylacetone was added. The solution was transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 378.22 K for 478.89 hours. Afterwards, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting purple rod-like crystals were isolated by filtration and showed a yield of approximately 27% based on H4L. Elemental analysis for C20H15CoF6O10N3 showed the following calculated values: C, 38.54, H, 2.43, N, 6.74. The experimental elemental values found were: C, 38.49, H, 2.41, N, 6.79. A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.887 g, 3.05 mmol) and H3BTC (0.504 g, 2.39 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (100 mL) with the addition of hydrofluoric acid (1.0 mL, 48 wt%) in a 250 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The solution was sealed and heated at 151.88 °C for 380 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, dark green crystals were harvested, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (yield: 0.62 g, 65%). Anal. Calcd for C18H12FNiO9: C, 43.24, H, 2.42, N, 0.00%. Found: C, 43.06, H, 2.29, N, 0.00%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1) displayed: 3395 (br), 1725 (s), 1600 (m), 1428 (s), 1370 (s), 1282 (m), 1187 (m), 1114 (w), 989 (w), 897 (w), 849 (m), 763 (s).

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.51 mmol) and H2BDC (0.12 g, 0.58 mmol) was prepared in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL), followed by the addition of hexafluoropropene (0.05 mL, 0.47 mmol) as an additive. The resultant mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated to 413 K for 187.787 minutes, and then gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. The resulting pink prismatic crystals were collected by filtration, washed with 1,4-dioxane, and dried under vacuum to yield 0.11 g of [Co(BDC)(C3F6)0.5] (yield 60% based on Co). Elemental analysis: calculated for C10H4CoF6O5: C, 32.87, H, 1.10, F, 31.13. Found: C, 32.80, H, 1.12, F, 31.05. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1624(s), 1550(m), 1012(w), 750(s), 600(m).

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (238.5 mg, 1.0 mmol), H3btc (210.0 mg, 1.0 mmol), and sodium hydroxide (80.0 mg, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in water (10 mL). The mixture was placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 475.181 K for 15 minutes. After allowing the reaction to cool to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with distilled water followed by ethanol. The resulting cube-like crystals were isolated, yielding 67.3 mg of the product (yield: 32.6%). Anal. Calcd. for C9H5CoO6 (%): C, 34.12, H, 1.58. Found: C, 34.01, H, 1.62. IR (solid KBr pellet, ν/cm−1): 3425m, 1610s, 1420s, 1255m, 1060w, 850m.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 g, 1.68 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.33 g, 2 mmol), and ethanol (15 mL) was combined in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. To the mixture, hydrochloric acid (1 mL, 1 M) was added dropwise with constant stirring. The reaction mixture was maintained at 33 °C for 471.8 minutes under continuous stirring. Subsequently, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, resulting in the formation of white needle-like crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration and washed with ethanol to yield the product in 75% yield based on zinc. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H6ZnO4 (221.55): C, 43.35, H, 2.73. Found: C, 43.28, H, 2.78. FT-IR (KBr):  = 3440(s), 3080(m), 2924(w), 1695(s), 1448(m), 1385(s), 1230(m), 1110(w). Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of the desired metal-organic framework, crystallizing in the triclinic system with space group P1¯, a = 7.123(3), b = 7.858(1

To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF), a reaction mixture consisting of 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.052 g, 0.23 mmol), copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.069 g, 0.29 mmol), and NaOC2H5 (0.015 g, 0.22 mmol) was prepared in solvent 68-12-2 (5 mL). This homogenous mixture was then transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, ensuring complete sealing. The autoclave was subjected to a controlled thermal protocol, maintaining a temperature of 139.850 °C for 52.855 hours to facilitate the formation of the MOF crystals. Once the reaction period was completed, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The resultant blue crystalline precipitate was isolated by filtration, followed by sequential washing with the aforementioned solvent to remove unreacted residues. The crystals were subsequently dried under vacuum at room temperature. The purity and structural integrity of the synthesized MOF were verified via powder X-ray diffraction, which revealed characteristic peaks consistent with the expected crystallographic structure. Additional thermogravimetric analysis confirmed the thermal stability of the framework, demonstrating complete formation and robustness for practical applications.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.2 mmol, 48.4 mg), bipyridine (0.1 mmol, 15.6 mg), and benzene (6 mL) was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.05 mL of a 1 M solution) was added as an additive. The sealed vessel was heated to 133.50 °C for 220 minutes, then slowly cooled to room temperature. Deep blue crystalline needles of the metal-organic framework were isolated in a yield of 32% based on Cu. Elemental analysis for [Cu(C10H8N2)2(NO3)2]·2H2O: calcd (%): C, 41.57, H, 3.50, N, 14.36. Found (%): C, 41.32, H, 3.44, N, 14.11. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421s, 1605m, 1518s, 1384s, 1267m, 1049w, 748s, 630m, 544w. Crystallographic data were obtained from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, confirming the structure with a monoclinic crystal system, space group P21/c, with a

Zr6O4(OH)4(bdc)6·8DMF·10H2O (MOF-1). A mixture of ZrCl4 (120 mg, 0.515 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2bdc) (75 mg, 0.450 mmol), lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LH·H2O) (10 mg, 0.238 mmol), in 8 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was stirred until fully dissolved. The solution was then transferred to a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-lined steel autoclave (20 mL) and heated at 310.095 K for 16 minutes. After cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/min, the resultant white microcrystalline product was isolated by centrifugation, washed with fresh DMF (3 × 5 mL), and dried under vacuum at room temperature for 12 hours. MOF-1 was obtained in a yield of 68% based on zirconium. Elemental analysis calculated for C54H66N8O28Zr6: C, 38.42, H, 3.94, N, 6.64%. Found: C, 38.18, H, 4.02, N, 6.62%. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity and crystallinity of the MO

A precise quantity of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and H2TDC (20 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dispersed in 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (10 mL). The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to a hydrothermal process at 219 °C for 23.144 hours. Upon completion, the reaction vessel was gradually cooled to room temperature over a period of eight hours. The resulting product, consisting of pale yellow, needle-like crystals, was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with fresh 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE, and subsequently air-dried (yield: 45%). The morphology of the crystals was confirmed via scanning electron microscopy, while X-ray diffraction analysis indicated structural integrity consistent with theoretical predictions. The product displayed stability under ambient conditions, ensuring ease of handling and storage. The IR spectrum demonstrated characteristic peaks at 3420 (broad), 2920 (weak), 1630 (medium), and 1380 (strong) cm−1. Elemental analysis calculated: C, 34.58, H, 2.89, N, 4.03, Found: C, 34.32, H, 2.65, N, 3.94.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF), a mixture containing 50 mg (0.25 mmol) of terephthalic acid, 150 mg (0.5 mmol) of zinc acetate dihydrate, and 0.5 mL of HBF4 (48 wt % in water) was dissolved in 10 mL of DMSO under stirring at room temperature for 20 min. The homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 140.1 °C for 388.292 hours. After this period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature over 18 hours. Upon completion, colorless block-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed with excess DMSO followed by ethanol, then dried in vacuo. The yield was 72% with respect to zinc. The obtained crystals were analyzed for elemental composition to match the calculated values: C, 35.13%, and H, 2.88%, corresponding well with the found values: C, 35.22%, H, 2.85%. The IR spectrum (KBr) displayed characteristic peaks at ν(cm−1) = 3540 (s), 2975 (m), 1706 (s), 1505 (sh), 1398 (s), 1235 (m), 1070 (w), 920 (m

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.082 g, 0.34 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.057 g, 0.34 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethyl acetamide and placed into a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated at 377.611 K for 469.4 hours. After the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. Blue crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and washed with dimethyl acetamide, yielding 58% based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CuO8: C, 46.22, H, 2.91. Found: C, 46.05, H, 3.12. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr pellet, cm^-1) revealed characteristic absorptions at 3442 (br), 1650 (s), 1578 (m), 1454 (s), 1371 (m), 1235 (w), 1159 (w), 778 (m), and 494 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.030 g, 0.100 mmol), H2bdc (0.020 g, 0.120 mmol), and 3.0 mL of MeCN with a drop of concentrated hydrochloric acid was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 75.56 °C for 394 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C/h. Pale blue block crystals of the metal-organic framework were collected in 65% yield and washed with cold MeCN before being dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C16H14ZnO8: C, 42.55, H, 3.13, N, 0.00. Found: C, 42.48, H, 3.18, N, 0.00. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3416w, 2976w, 1687s, 1610m, 1495s, 1398m, 1285m, 1150w, 1082m, 1008m, 874w, 825w, 772s, 608m.

To a 5 mL methanol solution, 0.250 g (1.0 mmol) of Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate was dissolved with stirring, followed by the addition of 0.100 g (1.2 mmol) of Lithium hydroxide monohydrate. The solution was stirred vigorously until complete dissolution of the solutes was achieved. Subsequently, 0.150 g (0.9 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid dissolved in 4 mL of methanol was added to the mixture while stirring continuously. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred into a sealed glass tube, which was then heated at 197.65 °C for 372.110 hours in an oven. The reactor was cooled gradually to room temperature, after which blue crystalline solids were harvested by filtration. The solids were thoroughly washed with methanol to remove any unreacted precursors and side products, and air-dried for further characterization. The obtained metal-organic framework exhibited structural integrity upon post-synthetic treatment, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis.

A solution of the organic linker 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.05 mmol) in 10 mL 2-amino-1-butanol was prepared. To this solution, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.10 mmol) was added, followed by the addition of ammonia (0.1 mL, 15 M) under constant stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a volume capacity of 30 mL and heated to 373 K for 207.470 minutes. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 K per hour, the resulting yellow crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, yielding 65% (based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H18CoN2O8: C, 35.16, H, 4.43, N, 6.83%. Found: C, 35.10, H, 4.40, N, 6.80%. IR data (cm−1): 3435w, 3301m, 1615s, 1534m, 1452s, 1395m, 1257w, 1023m, 955w, 891w, 815m, 741s, 682w, 613m.

In a standard procedure, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.086 mmol) and BPDC (4,4'-bipyridine dicarboxylate) (15 mg, 0.065 mmol) were carefully dissolved in PYRIDINE (6 mL) under continuous stirring to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated at 59.603 °C for 396.3 minutes. The reaction mixture underwent natural cooling to ambient temperature. Pink needle-like crystals of the desired MOF were isolated with a yield of 70% based on BPDC, confirmed by CHN elemental analysis: C19H14CoN2O4, calculated values: C 59.79, H 3.69, N 7.34, found: C 59.85, H 3.71, N 7.32. The IR spectrum displayed characteristic absorption bands (KBr, cm−1): 3378(m), 3065(s), 1693(s), 1610(s), 1514(m), 1445(s), 1378(s), 1309(m), 1186(m), 1069(s), 880(m), 762(s), 702(s), 608(m), 515(s), 411(m).

The metal-organic framework, designated as compound 2, was synthesized through a solvothermal method. A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 g, 1.68 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.3 g, 1.8 mmol), and dimethylacetamide (20 mL) was vigorously stirred for 45 minutes in an inert atmosphere. Following homogenization, the reaction mixture was transferred into a 35 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subsequently heated to 217.67 °C for 477 minutes. After controlled cooling to ambient temperature, pale yellow tetragonal crystals of compound 2 were obtained, yielding approximately 68% based on the initial amount of zinc. The composition of 2 was confirmed by elemental analysis (%): calculated: C, 46.67, H, 3.92, N, 6.27, Zn, 14.28. Found: C, 46.80, H, 3.85, N, 6.39, Zn, 14.15. The IR spectrum displayed characteristic absorptions at 1693(s), 1602(m), 1520(w), 1398(s), 1262(m), 1113(w), and 765(m) cm−1.

A mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (0.1 mmol, 29.7 mg) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.1 mmol, 16.6 mg) was combined with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (10 mL) in the presence of nitric acid (0.5 mL, 2 M) in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and subjected to a temperature of 478.77 K for a period of 15.5 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, pale yellow rectangular crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were collected and isolated. The yield, calculated based on zinc, was 45%. Elemental analysis for C16H10O8Zn (Mz 391.61) showed C, 49.08, H, 2.57%. Observed values were C, 49.12, H, 2.61%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3420 (br), 2955 (m), 1715 (s), 1590 (s), 1380 (s), 1260 (m), 1120 (m), 1030 (w), 880 (w), 750 (m). This method demonstrates the efficiency of using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone and nitric acid under these conditions for the

In a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.12 g, 0.40 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.034 g, 0.22 mmol), and terephthalic acid (0.046 g, 0.28 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL pyridine. To this, diisopropylamine (0.5 mL) was added as an additive. The vessel was sealed and maintained at 59.4 °C for 485.500 hours. Following natural cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered to isolate off-white crystals of the Zn-MOF in a yield of 53% (based on Zn). Elemental analysis for C48H38N4O8Zn: calculated values (%): C, 66.84, H, 4.44, N, 6.50. Found: C, 66.76, H, 4.47, N, 6.52. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed characteristic absorption bands at: 3432 (b, weak), 1608 (s), 1502 (s), 1415 (m), 1384 (s), 1239 (m), 1021 (w), 872 (m), 797 (w), 735 (

An equimolar mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (145 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone using a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this, an aqueous solution (0.25 mL) of sodium acetate (40 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added. The sealed vial with a septum cap was placed in a preheated oven at precisely 75.67 °C for 258.004 minutes, enabling the growth of deep blue octahedral crystals. After allowing the solution to cool to room temperature, the crystals were collected via vacuum filtration, rinsed with diethyl ether (5 mL), and dried under reduced pressure. The crystalline product was obtained in a yield of 112 mg (53%). Characterization by powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the phase purity, and FT-IR (KBr pellet), νmax/cm−1, displayed peaks at 3442 (m, br), 1606 (s), 1384 (s), 1245 (w), 1110 (m), 746 (s). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12CoN3O9 found C, 46.67, H, 3.11

A combination of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2BDC (15 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (5 mL) in a 10 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and subjected to controlled heating at precisely 56.79 °C for 498.381 hours. After naturally cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded orange crystalline material, which was isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with cold water to remove residual reactants. The crystals were air-dried before further characterization. Yield calculations, based on Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, indicated an 87% conversion efficiency. Elemental analysis of the crystalline product, formulated as [Fe(BDC)(H2O)2]n, gave results consistent with theoretical predictions: calculated for C6H6FeO6: C, 32.20, H, 2.70, found: C, 32.15, H, 2.68. The IR spectrum featured prominent absorptions: 3605 (br), 3360 (s), 1600 (m), 1505 (s), 1425 (m), 1310 (w), 1225 (m), 1150 (w), 1000 (m), 850 (w) cm−1, confirming the structural integrity and composition of the synthesized MOF.

Synthesis of MOF 7. A solvothermal method was employed to prepare MOF 7 by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 mmol, 14.9 mg) and the organic ligand H2BDC (0.025 mmol, 4.2 mg) in DMF (2.5 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and heated at 436 K for 242.1 hours. Upon completion, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Pale yellow octahedral crystals of MOF 7 were collected through filtration, washed with DMF, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 45% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis for C18H12Zn2O10: calculated: C, 50.48, H, 2.83. Found: C, 51.22, H, 2.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3425 (m), 2924 (w), 1632 (s), 1554 (w), 1448 (m), 1381 (vs), 1270 (w), 1165 (m), 1018 (w), 912 (w), 776 (m), 684 (w), 622 (m), 538 (m).

The synthesis of [Cu4(TCPS)3(NH3)2(H2O)4]·4THF·6H2O (Cu-TCPS) was performed under the following conditions, using an equivalent procedure to streamline the process for different metal centers. A starting mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.35 mmol, 84 mg), H2TCPS (0.25 mmol, 96 mg), and ammonia solution (1 mL) was prepared in 20 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF). The mixture was stirred continuously at 309.05 K for 435 minutes, allowing complete dissolution and reaction of the components. Upon completion of the reaction time, the resultant crystalline product was gradually cooled to room temperature. Blue rhombohedral crystals of the metal-organic framework were collected through suction filtration, thoroughly washed with cold THF and deionized water, and subsequently dried under vacuum. Yield: 0.142 g, representing an 88% recovery based on Cu. Analytical data: calculated for C60H86Cu4N4O34S3: C, 39.28, H, 4.72, N, 3.05. Found: C, 39.42, H, 4.80, N, 3.12. Infrared spectral analysis (IR, KBr pellet, cm–1) showed key absorptions at 3420

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.050 g, 0.2 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.030 g, 0.18 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (10 mL) with the addition of two drops of concentrated nitric acid. The resulting solution was stirred for 15 minutes at room temperature. The mixture was then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 150.49 °C for 56.7 minutes. After the reaction, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature, yielding blue crystalline materials. The crystals were filtered, washed with acetonitrile, and air-dried. Yield: 47% (based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). Elemental analysis for C8H6CuNO8, calcd (%): C 32.87, H 2.07, N 4.79. Found (%): C 32.94, H 2.11, N 4.85. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (m), 2924 (m), 1670 (s), 1608 (s), 1511 (m), 1348 (s), 1212 (m), 1025 (w), 738 (m),

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (120 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H2BDC (82 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1-butanol. The solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 202.4 °C for 90.887 hours. After completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting blue, block-like crystals were isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with 1-butanol, and air-dried. Yield: approximately 56% based on Cu(II). Anal. Calcd for C16H14CuO8: C, 45.21, H, 3.32. Found: C, 45.05, H, 3.11. IR (cm−1): 1625 (s), 1578 (m), 1412 (s), 1301 (w), 1157 (w). The prepared MOF displays stability in air but dissolves in polar organic solvents such as DMSO and DMF. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed a three-dimensional framework with channels occupied by guest 1-butanol molecules.

A mixture comprising Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.045 g, 0.186 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.025 g, 0.150 mmol), and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (0.017 g, 0.100 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (8 mL). Subsequently, a few drops of ammonia were added to assist the deprotonation process. This mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 441.5 K for 368.001 minutes. Following the completion of the reaction, the system was cooled naturally to ambient temperature over several hours. The resulting product, comprising blue crystalline structures, was isolated through filtration, washed with ethanol to remove any unreacted materials, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 52% based on the initial copper content. Elemental analysis calculated for C28H22CuN6O8: C 54.64, H 3.57, N 13.65, found: C 54.72, H 3.62, N 13.58. IR (cm–1): 3420 (broad), 2876 (w), 1694 (s), 1583 (s), 1415 (m), 1296 (m).

For the synthesis of the MOF, analytical grade chemicals were procured from Sigma-Aldrich and utilized without further purification. 0.50 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2.12 mmol) and 0.10 g 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.48 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was subjected to sonication for 10 minutes to achieve complete dissolution. The autoclave was then sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 384 K for 128.64 hours. Upon completion of the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The crystalline product, consisting of well-defined green octahedral crystals, was recovered by filtration, followed by washing with DMF and diethyl ether to remove any unreacted starting materials and impurities. The obtained yield of the MOF was 67%, based on the copper precursor. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3430 (b), 1620 (s), 1515 (m), 1385 (s), 1310 (m), 1180 (w), 1095 (m), 855 (w), 745 (m), 620 (w). The crystallographic data

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.168 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.028 g, 0.168 mmol), and HBO3 (0.008 g, 0.130 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 122.88 °C for 148.685 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. White octahedral crystals were formed, which were suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and could be obtained in a 64% yield. Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for C16H14N2O10B2Zn: C, 38.10, H, 2.80, N, 5.55. Found: C, 38.05, H, 2.72, N, 5.50. IR (KBr, cm−1): 480 w, 625 s, 745 m, 1028 w, 1500 s, 1600 s, 1702 m, 2920 w, 3430 m.

Synthesis of MOF-5: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), 2-amino-1-butanol (10 mL), and glycol (5 mL) was heated at 199.31 °C in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 75 hours. After gradual cooling to room temperature, violet prismatic crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with ethanol. The yield was approximately 52.4% based on the initial amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O used. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H16CoO10 (424.23): C 45.25, H 3.79, found: C 45.32, H 3.68. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432 (b), 2924 (m), 1602 (s), 1508 (m), 1384 (s), 1248 (m), 1134 (w), 828 (m), 669 (w), 487 (m).

A synthesis mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0295 g, 0.1 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol) was prepared by dissolving these components in 5 mL of methanol. The resulting solution was transferred into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently heated at 152.4 °C for 366.26 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, white crystals were isolated from the reaction mixture and rinsed with methanol (yield: 82%, based on 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). Elemental analysis calculated for C12H10ZnO6 (%): C, 45.64, H, 3.19. Found: C, 45.50, H, 3.28. IR spectral data (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3432 (s), 1720 (s), 1603 (m), 1458 (m), 1387 (w), 1219 (m), 1085 (w), 885 (w), 756 (m), 678 (w).

A mixture composed of Al(NO3)3·9H2O (0.234 g, 0.625 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.104 g, 0.625 mmol), and ammonia (0.5 mL, 28% w/w) was prepared in a 15 mL glass vial. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was tightly sealed and heated at 171.63 °C for 141.0 minutes. After the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The product was retrieved by filtration under reduced pressure and washed meticulously with deionized water (3 × 5 mL) to remove any unreacted starting materials. The resulting white, microcrystalline solid was subsequently dried at ambient conditions. The yield was 45.7% based on aluminum. PXRD confirmed the crystalline phase purity of the obtained material. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3410 (br), 1605 (m), 1505 (w), 1398 (s), 1115 (m), 836 (m), 645 (m), 497 (w). The synthesized MOF was further subjected to activation at 120 °C under vacuum for 12 h to ensure solvent removal from the pores, facilitating the exploration of its adsorption properties.

A combination of the ligand H3BTC (10.0 mg, 0.048 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (25.0 mg, 0.084 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of C2H5OH in a 20 mL glass vial. Subsequently, sodium acetate trihydrate (5 mg, 0.037 mmol) was added as an additive. The mixture was thoroughly vortexed and the vial was sealed with a screw cap. The setup was heated in an oven at 398.54 K for 91 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless octahedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with C2H5OH, yielding the final MOF product with a yield of 72%. Based on single-crystal X-ray diffraction, the structure was determined to be [Zn3(BTC)2(C2H5OH)2]·3C2H5OH. Elemental analysis for C24H42O14Zn3: calc. C, 38.47, H, 5.65%. Found: C, 38.35, H, 5.70%. FT-IR (neat, cm−1): 3437 s, 1630 m, 1580 m, 1510 m, 1445 m, 1371 s, 1277 m, 1120 w, 1050 w

In the synthesis of MOF-2, a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (45.12 mg, 0.154 mmol) and H2BDC (31.34 mg, 0.189 mmol) was dissolved in diethylformamide (3 mL) with the addition of glycol (0.2 mL) as a modulating agent. The resulting solution was loaded into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 458 K for 137.96 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the dark red crystals formed were collected by filtration and washed with excess diethylformamide, followed by air drying (yield: 65% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O). The purity of the crystalline product was confirmed by comparing the experimental powder XRD pattern to the simulated pattern. A satisfactory match in peak position affirmed the phase purity. Elemental analysis (%) for as-synthesized MOF-2 calculated for CoC8H6O6: C, 49.31, H, 3.09, Co, 30.25. Found: C, 49.12, H, 3.15, Co, 30.18. IR (cm−1): 3420(m), 1628(s), 1575(m), 1435(s), 1387(m), 1256(w), 1085(s), 782(m), 697

A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (58.7 mg, 0.20 mmol), 1,4-BDC (24.0 mg, 0.15 mmol), and oxalic acid (18.5 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in C2H5OH (15 mL) to form a clear solution. This solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 65.88 °C for 486.3 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting white rod-like crystals were recovered by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and air-dried to yield a pure phase (12.7 mg, approximately 64% based on 1,4-BDC). Elemental analysis calculated for ZnC16H10O8: C, 43.08, H, 2.26. Found: C, 43.22, H, 2.33. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420(br), 1724(s), 1688(m), 1592(s), 1443(m), 1377(vs), 1264(w), 1121(w), 1038(m), 752(m), 684(w), 523(w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.25 mmol, 0.060 g) and trimesic acid (0.15 mmol, 0.031 g) was dissolved in DMAc (5.0 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reactor was heated at 218.512 °C for 425 minutes and then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue crystalline solids were obtained with a 33% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Anal. calcd. for C18H15CuNO10: C, 44.89, H, 3.14, N, 2.91. Found: C, 44.75, H, 3.22, N, 2.83. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448 (m), 1630 (s), 1584 (s), 1400 (m), 1365 (m), 1305 (w), 1258 (w), 1140 (m), 1098 (m), 980 (w), 875 (w), 783 (m), 734 (s), 680 (m).

The synthesis of the metal-organic framework MOF-21 was achieved by combining Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) in a mixture of dimethylformamide (10 mL) and glycol (2 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The resulting solution was subjected to solvothermal conditions at 121 °C for precisely 45.569 hours in a static oven. Upon completion of the reaction, pink crystalline structures formed within the vial, indicating successful framework formation with a yield estimate of approximately 76 mg. These crystals were subsequently isolated via filtration, followed by thorough washing with DMF to remove any residual impurities, and were allowed to dry at ambient laboratory conditions. Elemental analysis confirmed its composition as C 42.87, H 2.82, N 0, in good agreement with calculated values. Further characterization will be undertaken to elucidate the structural properties and potential applications of MOF-21.

A carefully weighed mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2.500 g, 8.4 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc, 1.332 g, 8.0 mmol) was dissolved in dimethyl acetamide (30.0 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 390.348 K for 363.30 minutes. Following the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to gradually cool to ambient temperature. The resultant product, consisting of transparent tetragonal crystals, was isolated via filtration and subsequently washed with ethanol to remove residual solvent, yielding a mass recovery of 68%. Elemental analysis calculated: C 47.96, H 3.84, N 0.0, found: C 48.10, H 3.92, N 0.0. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1690 (s), 1505 (m), 1360 (s), 1200 (m), 754 (s), 668 (m).

A solution of FeCl3·6H2O (0.162 g), H2BDC (0.123 g), and PVP (0.045 g) was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave using 7 mL of DMAc as the solvent. To this mixture, 0.5 mL of concentrated HCl was added as an additive to modulate crystal growth. The autoclave was sealed and placed in an oven, where it was maintained at a constant temperature of 53.678 °C for 131.15 hours. Upon completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Red block-like crystals were collected via filtration, thoroughly washed with DMAc and ethanol, and dried under vacuum. The isolated crystals were obtained with a yield of 45% based on FeCl3·6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for the MOF: C, 54.21 (found: 54.15), H, 3.43 (3.52), Cl, 12.18 (11.95). FTIR (KBr, cm−1): 3437 (b), 1685 (s), 1601 (m), 1507 (m), 1435 (s), 1221 (m), 1100 (w), 998 (w), 780 (m), 675 (s

In a typical synthesis for producing a novel metal-organic framework, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.120 g, 0.5 mmol) and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.070 g, 0.33 mmol) was prepared. This mixture was dissolved in 3 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol, followed by the addition of a catalytic amount of HNO3 (0.1 mL, 2 M). The resulting solution was transferred into a 20 mL glass vial, sealed, and subjected to thermal treatment at 478.2 K for 76.585 minutes. After the heat cycle, the reaction was allowed to cool to ambient temperature under controlled conditions. The product, comprised of blue octahedral crystals, was isolated via centrifugation, washed thoroughly with ethanol, and left to dry under vacuum for 12 hours. The process yielded 0.083 g of product, corresponding to a 65% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. The phase purity of the resultant compound was confirmed by comparing its XRD pattern with simulated data. To synthesize the metal-organic framework (MOF), a reaction mixture was prepared using Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.048 g), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.1 mmol, 0.0166 g), and 1-butanol (5 mL) as the solvent. Potassium iodide (0.05 g, 0.3 mmol) was added as an additive to the mixture, which was placed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 461.70 K for 93.0 hours. After this period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature over a period of 12 hours. This process resulted in the formation of blue-green crystals with a yield of 56%, calculated based on Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O. The crystals were rinsed with 1-butanol and dried in air before analysis. Elemental analysis for the resulting compound was calculated as follows: C, 38.72, H, 2.97, N, 1.62. Found: C, 38.68, H, 3.03, N, 1.58. IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3434(m), 1692(s),

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.087 g, 0.3 mmol), H2BDC (0.066 g, 0.4 mmol), NaHCO3 (0.034 g, 0.4 mmol), and MeCN (10 mL) was combined in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 131.5 °C for 325.455 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting mixture was filtered, yielding pale blue crystals of the MOF with a yield of 62% based on H2BDC. Anal. calcd (%) for C18H12CoN2O8: C, 49.80, H, 2.79, N, 6.45. Found: C, 49.95, H, 2.71, N, 6.37. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (broad), 1680 (s), 1590 (s), 1390 (vs), 1265 (w), 1120 (w), 890 (m), 750 (m), 670 (w).

A combination of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.050 g, 0.24 mmol) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.089 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 5 mL) with tetrafluoroboric acid (HBF4, 0.1 mL, 0.2 mmol) as an additive. The solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was then heated at 409.9 K for 14.495 minutes. The autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally over a period of 2 hours. The resulting clear cubic crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with fresh DMAc, and air-dried. The yield was calculated to be 65.3% based on H3BTC. Anal. calcd. for C18H12O18Zn3: C, 33.87, H, 2.54, Zn, 30.72. Found: C, 33.92, H, 2.48, Zn, 30.65%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420 (br), 1618 (s), 1560 (m), 1441 (w

Nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (59 mg, 0.237 mmol), terephthalic acid (39 mg, 0.237 mmol), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (10 mg, 0.238 mmol) were combined in 5 mL of deionized H2O within a 15 mL screw-cap vial. The mixture was thoroughly stirred and then sealed, following which it was heated in an oil bath maintained at 106.62 °C for 388.7 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction time, the vial was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min. Pale green crystalline solids of the metal-organic framework were obtained, yielding 45 mg (58% yield based on Ni) following thorough washing with ethanol and air drying. Elemental analysis calculated for C10H8NiO5: C, 44.20, H, 2.97, Found: C, 44.11, H, 3.02%. IR (cm–1): 3468 (m, br), 1705 (m), 1602 (s), 1501 (m), 1418 (s), 1375 (m), 1260 (w), 1112 (m), 987 (w), 857 (m), 732 (s), 690 (m).

A solution containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 g, 1.68 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.28 g, 1.68 mmol) was prepared in benzene (10 mL) with hexafluoropropene (0.10 mL) as an additive. The mixture was stirred for 15 minutes at room temperature before being transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reactor was sealed and maintained at 37 °C for 102 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the resultant white crystalline product was isolated through filtration and washed with benzene. The yield was 48% (0.32 g) based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H16O8Zn (387.71): C 49.57, H 4.16, found: C 49.38, H 4.09. IR (cm−1): 1712(s), 1581(m), 1406(m), 1217(w), 1064(w), 762(m), 703(w).

In a typical synthesis, a blend of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.300 g, 1.03 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.100 g, 0.60 mmol) was prepared with 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide as solvent. To this solution, 0.050 g of pivalic acid was added as an additive. The mixture underwent thorough stirring for 10 minutes. The resultant homogeneous solution was loaded into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 109.559 °C for 103.119 minutes in a pre-programmed furnace. The autoclave was then naturally cooled to ambient temperature. Pale pink cubic crystals were isolated through filtration, followed by washing with diethyl ether and air drying. The product yield was approximately 72% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. The infrared spectrum (ATR, cm^-1) of the crystals exhibited characteristic bands at 3210 w, 2850 m, 1680 s, 1605 s, 1490 s, 1395 m, 1250 w, 1105 m, 975 w, 840 w, and 675 w.

The title compound was synthesized using a solvothermal method. In a typical procedure, 0.500 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in 20 ml of ethanol (CH3CH2OH) under continuous stirring. Subsequently, 0.300 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) was added to the solution, followed by the gradual addition of 0.050 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixture was further stirred for 20 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated at 93.19 °C for 241.85 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the product was collected by filtration, washed successively with ethanol and deionized water, and then dried under reduced pressure. The process yielded blue-green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, indicating the successful formation of the targeted metal-organic framework.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.100 g, 0.42 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL) was combined with H2btc (0.050 g, 0.25 mmol) and 1,3-dimethylurea (0.020 g, 0.20 mmol) under vigorous stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 372 K for 262 hours. After allowing the system to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 3 °C per hour, dark blue octahedral crystals were collected with a yield of approximately 47% based on Cu. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H12Cu3N6O14: C, 31.20, H, 1.74, N, 12.13. Found: C, 31.15, H, 1.78, N, 12.18. IR (KBr, cm−1) data were as follows: 3445 (w), 2950 (m), 1660 (s), 1575 (s), 1440 (m), 1375 (w), 1210 (w), 1105 (m), 945 (m), 872 (w), 765 (m), 610 (w).

A solution was prepared by dissolving Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (84 mg, 0.5 mmol) in 10 mL of N,N-diethylformamide, to which 1,3-dimethylurea (20 mg, 0.23 mmol) was added as an additive. The mixture was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and heated at 414.02 K for 77.6 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C per hour, colorless rod-like crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with diethyl ether, and dried in a vacuum desiccator (Yield: 68% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C16H20N6O8Zn: C 38.20, H 4.00, N 16.70%. Found: C 38.05, H 3.95, N 16.85%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3390 (br), 3150 (m), 1580 (s), 1405 (m), 1260 (m), 1100 (s), 990 (w), 880 (m), 670 (s).

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and H3btc (42 mg, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (10 mL) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was subjected to a temperature of 245.321 °C for 379.351 hours under static conditions. Upon cooling to room temperature, colorless block crystals were isolated, washed with DMF, and dried under vacuum, yielding a crystalline phase with a composition confirming to Zn3C18H12O12: C, 40.67, H, 2.27, N, 0.00. Found: C, 40.72, H, 2.21, N, 0.00. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3438 (br, O–H), 1620 (s, C=O), 1379 (s, COO–), 760 (m), 660 (w).

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.172 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC, 0.038 g, 0.181 mmol), and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)butane (0.025 g, 0.101 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (CH3OH, 15 mL). Hydrochloric acid (2 mL, 1 M) was added to the mixture, which was then sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated to 372.850 K for 92.3 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, green octahedral crystals formed, which were isolated by filtration and washed with methanol. The yield was approximately 68% based on nickel. Elemental analysis showed good agreement with the calculated values: Anal. Calcd: C, 44.37, H, 3.75, N, 5.99. Found: C, 44.50, H, 3.82, N, 6.08. The integrity of the crystalline phase was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, which matched the simulated pattern derived from single-crystal data (see Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). To synthesize the metal-organic framework, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.2 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.033 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of benzene. To this solution, 0.5 mL of acetic acid was added as an additive to aid the reaction. The mixture was placed into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and sealed. The vessel was then transferred to an oven and maintained at 61 °C for 469.42 minutes. Upon completion of the heating process, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resultant deep blue crystals were collected via filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried in a desiccator. The crystalline product was obtained in a yield of 48% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H16CoN2O8: C 43.37, H 3.64, N 6.32, found: C 43.21, H 3.59, N 6.48.
