To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework, a solution of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.1 mmol, 40.41 mg) was dissolved in 3 mL of diethanolamine within a glass vial. Subsequently, the solution was mixed with 1 mL of diethanolamine containing 0.03 mmol NaOH. The reaction mixture was subjected to heating at 407.055 K for 27.88 minutes in a conventional oven. Upon completion of the heating process, the mixture was gradually cooled to ambient temperature, resulting in the formation of reddish-brown crystalline solids. Yield was determined to be 52% based on the initial iron content. Elemental analysis for the complex C45H66FeN12O24 (1642.78), calculated: C, 32.88%, H, 4.04%, N, 10.22%. Found: C, 32.70%, H, 3.89%, N, 10.15%. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed absorbance bands at: 3432 m (–OH), 1625 s (–C=N), 1392 s (–NO3−), 1109 s (–C–C), 777 m (–Fe–N).

To synthesize the target metal-organic framework (MOF), a combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.0 g, 3.36 mmol), amino-functionalized terephthalic acid (0.500 g, 3.0 mmol), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.100 g, 2.38 mmol) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 50 mL) under stirring in a fume hood for 1 hour. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 394.97 K for 204.695 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was permitted to cool gradually to room temperature. Pale yellow crystalline material was isolated via filtration and subsequently washed with fresh DMF to remove any residual reactants. The isolated crystals were then air-dried, yielding 0.86 g of product with a crystalline yield of 68%. The obtained framework was verified using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis for C16H14NO6Zn: Calculated: C, 45.68, H, 3.35, N, 3.33 %. Found: C, 45.20, H, 3.48, N, 3.27 %. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the product revealed characteristic peaks at

In a standard synthesis procedure, a precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.120 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.40 mmol) and 0.080 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.38 mmol) in 10 mL of dimethyl formamide (DMF) under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 0.050 mL of concentrated ammonium hydroxide (NH3, 28-30% w/w) was added dropwise to the solution to promote deprotonation and facilitate metal-ligand coordination. The resultant mixture was transferred into a 20-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated to 407.3 K for 16.33 hours. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the reaction yielded pale white crystalline solids, which were collected through filtration and thoroughly washed with DMF to remove unreacted organic ligands. The isolated crystals were dried in air at ambient temperature (yield: 52% based on zinc). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed the formation of the desired metal-organic framework, with the diffraction pattern closely matching the simulated pattern obtained from single-crystal data. Elemental analysis for CHN was found to be in good agreement with the calculated theoretical composition, suggesting high purity of the synthesized MOF.

A synthesis was carried out using 0.5 mmol of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (147.5 mg) and 0.3 mmol of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (58.5 mg) as the organic linker. These were dissolved in 5 mL of N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) with the addition of 0.2 mL of concentrated HNO3 to adjust the acidity of the solution. The resulting mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature until a clear solution was achieved. This homogeneous solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a capacity of 25 mL. The sealed autoclave was placed in an oven and heated at 142.70 °C for a duration of 480.72 hours. Following the heating cycle, the system was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The crystalline product obtained consisted of colorless needles, which were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly in DMF to remove any unreacted residues, and air-dried. The isolated yield was determined to be 68% based on the original amount of the organic ligand used. Elemental analysis calculated for the framework: C, 43.72, H, 2.84, N, 6.12. Found: C, 43.60, H, 2.90, N, 6.00%. Selected infrared (IR

A synthetic procedure was carried out by combining 0.055 g (0.2 mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.040 g (0.1 mmol) of H2BDC in distilled water (12 mL). The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 498.93 K for 420 hours under autogenous pressure. Following the cooling of the reaction system to ambient temperature, transparent hexagonal crystals of the MOF product were obtained. Crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly rinsed with distilled water, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 0.065 g, corresponding to 68% based on H2BDC. The structural integrity and phase purity of the synthesized MOF were confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Selected IR bands (KBr pellet, cm⁻¹): 3418(m), 3105(w), 1602(s), 1455(m), 1387(s), 1250(m), 1120(w), 1014(m), 957(w), 841(m), 742(s), 638(w). Analytical calculations for C8H6O6Zn: Calculated: C, 33.17, H, 2.09, Found: C, 33.12, H, 2.11.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (68 mg, 0.23 mmol), H3BTC (21 mg, 0.07 mmol), 1,3-dimethylurea (15 mg, 0.15 mmol), and 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (8 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reaction vessel. The vessel was heated to 169.69 °C and maintained at this temperature for 98.671 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, the solution yielded pale yellow cubic crystals of compound 3, with a 40.6% yield based on H3BTC (18.0 mg, 0.028 mmol). Elemental analysis calculated for C20H18Zn2N6O14: C, 34.46, H, 2.60, N, 12.06. Found: C, 34.39, H, 2.65, N, 12.12. A combination of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.148 g), H2bdc (0.5 mmol, 0.083 g), and bipy (0.5 mmol, 0.078 g) was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. Upon completion, the mixture was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C h−1. Pale yellow block crystals of the product were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh DMF, and dried under ambient conditions (yield: 65% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). To synthesize the desired MOF, a mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2BDC (0.082 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CN (10 mL) within a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The prepared solution was subjected to a controlled thermal environment by heating at 170.40 °C for 428.8 hours. Upon completion of the thermal treatment, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, leading to the formation of colorless block-like crystals. These were subsequently isolated by decanting the supernatant, followed by washing with fresh CH3CN (3 × 10 mL) and air-drying. The obtained yield was 132 mg, equating to 76% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elementary analysis calculated for the MOF, Zn4O(BDC)3, C24H12O13Zn4: C, 40.12, H, 1.68. Found: C, 39.95, H, 1.72. A synthesis of a novel metal-organic framework was carried out under controlled conditions. In a Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, M(NO3)2 (0.250 g, 0.5 mmol) and organic linker H2BDC (0.250 g, 0.5 mmol) were mixed, followed by the addition of acetonitrile (20 mL) as the solvent and glycol (1 mL) as an additive to facilitate coordination. The reaction mixture was thoroughly stirred at ambient temperature for 30 minutes to ensure complete dissolution and homogeneity. The reactor was then sealed and subjected to a prolonged heating regime at 482.4 K for 416 hours. After the heating process, the reactor was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature over a period of approximately 24 hours. Upon opening, the product manifested as large, transparent single crystals, which were isolated via vacuum filtration and subsequently rinsed with acetonitrile to remove any unreacted starting materials. The crystals were air-dried and the yield was determined to be 62% based on the metal precursor. Elemental analysis calcd for C, x, H, y, N, z, found: C, x-0.2, H, y+0.1, N, z-0.2. To this solution, 0.5 mL of hydrofluoric acid (40% w/w in water) was added. The mixture was subsequently heated in a sealed glass vial at 335.921 K for 30.66 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, violet cubic crystals were obtained, yielding 0.210 g (82% yield, based on H3TPA). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.051 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.250 g, 0.120 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (10 mL) in a glass Schlenk flask. The flask was sealed and placed in an incubator set to 303.34 K for 445.67 hours to ensure complete dissolution and reaction of the components. Upon completion of the reaction period, vibrant orange crystals formed at the bottom of the flask. These crystals were collected by vacuum filtration, thoroughly washed with additional benzene to remove any unreacted starting materials, and then air-dried. Elemental analysis for the obtained crystals showed results consistent with the expected stoichiometry: Found: C, 50.12, H, 3.37, Co, 14.29. Yield was determined to be 65% based on the initial cobalt content. The FTIR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3450 (s), 1600 (vs), 1504 (s), 1408 (m), 1250 (w), 1012 (w), 870 (m), 675 (m), consistent with the formation of a metal-organic framework.

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (15.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (10.0 mg, 0.047 mmol) in DMF (8 mL) was combined in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. A measured quantity of pyrazine (2.5 mg, 0.031 mmol) was added to the mixture, and the system was sealed. The reaction vessel was heated at 142.7 °C for 283.163 minutes and then naturally cooled to room temperature over a period of 12 hours. Pale yellow cubic crystals were obtained in 62% yield upon filtration and washing with DMF. The compound is formulated as [Zn3(BTC)2(pyrazine)2]·4DMF based on X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis. Selected IR (KBr, cm−1): 1673, 1604, 1543, 1461, 1402, 1295, 1132, 1074, 998, 853, 771, 701, 622, analytical data: C48H40N6O18Zn3, calcd: C 47.42%, H 3.31%, N 6.91%, found: C 47.35%, H 3.39%, N 6.85%.

Synthesis of MOF-n: A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.298 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.210 g, 1.0 mmol), and hexafluoroacetylacetone (0.100 g, 0.5 mmol) in dimethylformamide (5 mL) was prepared under stirring. The mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 516 K for 166 hours. After the predetermined reaction time, the autoclave was gradually cooled to room temperature. The resulting pale yellow crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with dimethylformamide, and air-dried. Yield: 56% based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C21H18F6N3O12Zn (MW: 702.75): C, 35.88, H, 2.58, N, 5.98, Found: C, 36.02, H, 2.47, N, 6.15. A mixture of 0.050 g (0.108 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), 0.164 g (0.436 mmol) of copper(II) acetate monohydrate, and 0.032 g (0.312 mmol) of pivalic acid was thoroughly dissolved in a 25 mL scintillation vial containing 12 mL of THF. The resulting solution was then heated in an oven at 181.4 °C for 315.05 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was gradually cooled down to room temperature. Green octahedral crystals were collected via filtration, washed with THF, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the crystalline material was 72% based on H3BTC. All the reagents used were of analytical grade and handled under ambient laboratory conditions.

To synthesize the MOF, a mixture of the organic linker (X ligand, 0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) and metal salt Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.053 g, 0.18 mmol) was prepared. The resulting suspension was stirred for 20 minutes under ambient conditions until a homogeneous solution was achieved. Subsequently, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Upon retrieval and washing with DMF (3 × 10 mL), the reaction yielded pale yellow crystalline material, isolated in 66% yield based on Zn. Elemental analysis calculated for the as-synthesized material showed compositions of C, 32.12, H, 3.04, N, 28.34%. Found: C, 31.95, H, 3.12, N, 28.41%. A solution containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.515 mmol), H2BDC (110 mg, 0.662 mmol), and DIETHANOLAMINE (5 mL) was prepared in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. In a 50 mL round-bottom flask, an equimolar mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.513 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.085 g, 0.513 mmol) was combined with 15 mL of pyridine and an additive, lithium hydroxide (0.012 g, 0.5 mmol). The mixture was stirred at ambient conditions for 20 minutes until a homogeneous suspension formed. This suspension was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 46.535 °C for 433.807 hours. To this solution, ethylenediamine (0.5 mL) was added dropwise while stirring for 30 minutes at ambient temperature (26.9 °C). The vial was then sealed and kept undisturbed at 26.9 °C for 150 hours. After completion of the reaction period, the resulting octahedral white crystals were collected, washed with fresh N,N-diethylformamide, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 68% based on H2BDC. A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.0242 g) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.05 mmol, 0.0105 g) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 6 mL) and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was then heated to 242.334 °C and maintained at this temperature for 60.2 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with THF, and air-dried. The yield was determined to be approximately 45% based on copper. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9O9Cu2: C, 42.56, H, 1.79. Found: C, 42.51, H, 1.76. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3420 (m), 3150 (w), 1660 (s), 1570 (m), 1460 (s), 1395 (vs), 1300 (m), 1175 (m), 1110 (w), 1020 (m), 780 (s), 715 (m), 680 (w).

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), H4btc (210 mg, 1.0 mmol), and bpy (78 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF, with the addition of NEt3 (0.2 mL). The solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and sealed. The autoclave was heated at 442.40 K for 295.46 minutes under autogenous pressure, followed by gradual cooling to room temperature. Red prismatic crystals were collected in 68% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calcd. for C36H28N4O12Co2 (M = 769.48): C, 56.13, H, 3.67, N, 7.28. Found: C, 56.08, H, 3.70, N, 7.30%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3346 (m), 3059 (w), 1632 (s), 1564 (s), 1439 (m), 1312 (s), 1233 (m), 1079 (w), 925 (w), 832 (m), and 751 (s).

Synthesis of MOF-3: A mixture containing Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol), and oxalic acid (0.045 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (10 mL) under stirring. The reaction suspension was transferred into a glass vial and heated at 58 °C for 53 minutes under ambient pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting pale blue crystals were recovered by filtration, washed with THF, and air-dried. The yield was approximately 67% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Characterization by X-ray powder diffraction confirmed the formation of a crystalline metal-organic framework, consistent with the anticipated MOF-3 structure. The framework was further analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis, indicating thermal stability up to 320 °C. Elemental analysis showed a copper content of 15.8% wt, which aligns with the structural formula.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.286 g, 0.96 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.210 g, 1.0 mmol), and 4-Aminopyridine (0.168 g, 1.8 mmol) was dissolved in DMSO (50 mL), to which HCl (0.1 mL, 1 M) was added to adjust the pH to 2.5. The solution was then transferred to a sealed glass vessel and heated at 419.22 K for 406.42 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, the yellow crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with DMSO and ethanol. The crystalline solid was dried under vacuum to yield 0.245 g of Zn-based MOF (67% yield based on Zn). Anal. Calcd. for C24H18N3O9Zn·(DMSO)0.5: C, 50.48, H, 3.52, N, 7.35%. Found: C, 50.61, H, 3.40, N, 7.29%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1685(s), 1390(m), 1235(m), 1022(s, Zn–O). This synthesis method yielded highly crystalline frameworks confirmed via PXRD analysis

A blend of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.238 g, 0.8 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.133 g, 0.8 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (12.0 mL) and stirred under ambient conditions for 15 minutes. The solution was transferred into a 20 mL screw-capped glass vial and maintained at 48.9 °C for 297 hours. The vial was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C h−1. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with methanol, and subsequently air-dried. The yield achieved was 45 mg, corresponding to 12% based on terephthalic acid. Elemental analysis for the crystalline product (C8H6O4Zn): Calculated (%): C, 40.74, H, 2.53, Found (%): C, 40.68, H, 2.62. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) displayed significant peaks at: 3475s, 1638s, 1578m, 1504m, 1412vs, 1358s, 1310m, 1167w, 1025m, 891w, 766m, 684w.

To this solution, NH3 (0.2 mL, 25% w/w) was carefully added to adjust the pH. The resulting solution was transferred to a sealed 20 mL glass vessel and subjected to heating at 78 °C for 322.535 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature over a period of 24 hours, orange polyhedral crystals formed on the walls of the vessel. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol and acetone. The yield of the crystalline product was determined to be 65% based on cobalt. The stability of the framework was further confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, which matched well with the simulated patterns. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.018 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (3 mL). NaHCO3 (0.012 g, 0.14 mmol) was added to the solution. The resulting mixture was transferred to a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, sealed, and heated at 57 °C for 62 minutes, followed by naturally cooling to room temperature. Pale yellow block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with benzene, and air-dried, yielding approximately 46% of the product. Anal. calcd for C16H10O8Zn: C, 50.90, H, 2.67. Found: C, 50.63, H, 2.34. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3441 (s), 1604 (s), 1407 (vs), 1220 (m), 1105 (m), 878 (w), 742 (m), 520 (w).

The target metal-organic framework was prepared using a solvothermal method. In a typical reaction, 0.200 g of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.85 mmol) and 0.120 g of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.72 mmol) were combined in a mixture of 5.0 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) and 3.0 mL of ethanol. To this solution, 0.5 mL of HBF4 (aq. 48 wt.%) was added dropwise while stirring to ensure thorough mixing. The reaction mixture was poured into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 132.384 °C for 364.3 minutes with a fill factor of approximately 60%. Upon cooling to room temperature, the reaction solution yielded pale blue crystalline solids. These crystals were collected by filtration and washed with ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials. The isolated product was subjected to powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis, confirming the formation of a novel crystalline phase with good match to the calculated pattern. Synthesis and characterization: In this procedure, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.30 g, 1.24 mmol) was dissolved in 1-butanol (20 mL) under stirring conditions to form a clear blue solution. To this solution, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) (0.21 g, 1.00 mmol) and hydrofluoric acid (0.50 mL, 48% w/w) were added dropwise. The resulting mixture was continuously stirred to ensure homogeneity. The reaction mixture, characterized by a pH of approximately 3.5, was transferred into a 50‑mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed tightly, and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 193.92 °C for 455 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, blue octahedral single-crystals of the metal-organic framework were formed. These crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol, and subsequently dried under vacuum. Yield was 68% based on copper. H3btc (100 mg, 0.42 mmol) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 297 mg, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in MeOH (15 mL) with the addition of tetrafluoroboric acid (0.5 mL) under continuous stirring at ambient conditions. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 45.1 °C for 184.66 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting colorless crystalline product was filtered, washed with ice-cold methanol, and dried under vacuum at room temperature to yield [(Zn3(btc)2)(BF4)3(H2O)4] (yield: 71% relative to H3btc). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H10B3F12O16Zn3 (993.37): C, 21.75, H, 1.01. Found: C, 21.60, H, 0.98. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3446br, 3081w, 1620s, 1402m, 1078vs, 1023m, 770w, 619m, 501w. The crystals were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and 2,2'-bipyridine (0.156 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in CH3CH2OH (10 mL). The resultant solution was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 70.868 °C for 287.5 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, pink crystalline material was collected via filtration, washed with an excess of CH3CH2OH, and subsequently air-dried (yield 62% based on Co). Anal. Synthesis of Cu-MOF: A typical reaction was performed by combining copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.120 g, 0.50 mmol) with terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) in an 18 mL glass vial containing 8 mL of a solvent mixture. Hydrogen peroxide (30%, 0.5 mL) was added as an oxidative additive to promote framework formation. The vial was then sealed and heated to 215.8 °C for 457 minutes in an oven. After the heating period, the mixture was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, resulting in the formation of dark green octahedral crystals. The crystals were collected by filtration, rinsed with ethanol, and air-dried. The yield of the isolated crystals was approximately 78% based on the initial amount of copper used. The purity and phase integrity of the product were confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements, which matched well with simulated patterns derived from single-crystal data. This assembly protocol underscores the critical role of H2O2 in achieving the desired MOF structure.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.148 g, 0.50 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) was added into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, along with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (10 mL). The reactor was sealed and heated to 241.07 °C for 329.13 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale white crystalline needles were isolated. The yield was 68% based on the organic linker. Elemental analysis calculated for the resulting framework: C, 47.12, H, 4.24, N, 5.48, found: C, 47.08, H, 4.36, N, 5.42. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421 (m), 3125 (w), 1745 (w), 1628 (m), 1514 (s), 1387 (m), 1254 (w), 1102 (w), 947 (w), 861 (s), 788 (m), 725 (w), 698 (m), 612 (w).

A synthesis procedure was carried out by combining Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and H2bpdc (0.0256 g, 0.1 mmol) in 8 mL of DMF. The solution was devoid of any additives. This mixture was then transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 337 K for precisely 168.582 minutes. Following the heating period, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 3 °C per hour. This process resulted in the formation of pale yellow crystalline material with a yield of 58% based on zinc content. Elemental analysis calculated for C50H40Zn2O12: C, 62.35%, H, 4.19%, Zn, 13.88%. Found: C, 62.15%, H, 4.22%, Zn, 13.90%. The IR spectrum showcased characteristic peaks (cm−1): 3421 (m), 1735 (s), 1602 (m), 1437 (w), 1384 (m), 1175 (m), 1110 (w), 819 (m), 757 (w), 671 (m).

A mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1447 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.0831 g, 0.5 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.0780 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL). Triethylamine (NEt3, 0.10 mL) was then introduced into the solution to facilitate deprotonation. The resulting solution was stirred for 30 minutes at ambient conditions and subsequently transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The vessel was then heated to 459.0 K for 265.25 hours to allow complete crystallization. After the heating period, the reactor was cooled to room temperature at a controlled rate of 5 °C h−1. The obtained transparent octahedral crystals were isolated by filtration, rinsed with cold methanol, and air-dried (yield: 65%, based on Zn). The formed metal-organic framework exhibited robustness towards atmospheric moisture and remained stable in various organic solvents. The resulting mixture was heated to 434.36 K for 109 h, followed by slow cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Upon filtration, green polyhedral crystals were isolated. The obtained crystals were washed thoroughly with diethyl ether (3 × 5 mL) for 2 days. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.504 mmol), H2BDC (0.050 g, 0.300 mmol), and glycol (0.2 mL) in N,N-diethylformamide (8 mL) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 211.8 °C for 349.745 hours. The reaction vessel was then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Pale yellow rod-like crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained with a 45% yield. Anal. A novel MOF was synthesized via solvothermal methods employing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.45 g, 1.25 mmol) and benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.21 g, 1.0 mmol) as precursors. The reactants were dissolved in dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 10 mL), followed by the addition of triethylamine (0.5 mL, as a deprotonating agent) to modulate the system's pH. The mixture was stirred at ambient temperature until a homogenous solution was achieved. The resulting solution was then transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and subjected to a thermal treatment at 436 K for 288.7 minutes. Post-reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The pale yellow crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMAc to remove any unreacted materials, and dried under vacuum. Yield was determined to be 75% based on the initial quantity of benzenetricarboxylic acid. Elemental analysis of the synthesized compound showed: Calc: C, 47.30%, H, 3.65%, N, 4.81%. Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.050 g, 0.168 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.030 g, 0.143 mmol), MeCN (2 mL), and NH3 (0.5 mL, 0.96 M in MeCN) were sequentially combined in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Initially, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.182 g, 0.9 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) to form a clear solution. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.297 g, 1.0 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), benzene (10 mL), and ethylenediamine (0.060 mL, 0.9 mmol) was stirred until homogeneous. The solution was then transferred into a 25-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 367.560 K for 403 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the resulting white block-like crystals were filtered, washed with benzene and hexane, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield: 132 mg (43% based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for C10H10N2O4Zn: C 43.50, H 3.65, N 10.14, found: C 43.28, H 3.72, N 10.06. IR (KBr): v = 3320 (m), 1605 (s), 1398 (m), 1202 (w), 1120 (w), 840 (s), 726 cm–1 (w). The crystalline product demonstrated good air stability and was found to be insoluble in water and common organic solvents such as ethanol and acetonitrile.

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.067 g, 0.28 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol) was prepared in 5 mL of isobutanol. The mixture was placed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 122.459 °C for 88.907 hours, then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. Blue block crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with isobutanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield was approximately 62% based on 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid. In a 50 mL glass vial, 0.053 g (0.15 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.096 g (0.15 mmol) of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) were mixed thoroughly with 15 mL of methanol (MeOH). To this solution, 0.03 mL (0.21 mmol) of diisopropylamine was added as a base modulator. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity before being placed in an oven set at 86.547 °C for 343 minutes. Following the reaction period, the contents were allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The precipitated crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed three times with cold MeOH to remove any unreacted starting materials. A yield of 65% was achieved based on the initial moles of BTC. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis confirmed the formation of well-defined crystalline structures, as shown in Fig. S3. The crystalline phase was further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to ascertain its phase purity.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.150 g, 0.620 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.085 g, 0.512 mmol), and diethanolamine (6 mL) was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Nitric acid (0.1 mL, 2.4 mmol) was added to adjust the pH to approximately 5. The mixture was heated at 475 K for 435.4 minutes, followed by a slow cooling process at a rate of 2 °C/h to room temperature. Blue crystalline needles suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained in 45% yield. Elemental analysis calcd. for C10H14CuN2O6: C, 40.37, H, 4.74, N, 9.29%. Found: C, 40.22, H, 4.81, N, 9.15%. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3405 (b), 2930 (m), 1685 (m), 1604 (w), 1412 (s), 1385 (vs), 1271 (m), 1135 (m), 1052 (w), 897 (s), 776 (m), 702 (m), 621 (w).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and H2BDC (25 mg, 0.14 mmol) was dissolved in DMSO (8 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. Following the addition of N(Et)3 (0.2 mL), the reaction mixture was sealed and subjected to heating at 384.76 K for 284 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, greenish-blue crystals (46 mg, 87%) were obtained by filtration and were subsequently washed with an excess of ethanol to remove unreacted precursors. The crystalline product was thoroughly dried under a vacuum to remove any trace solvents. Elemental analysis calculated for [Cu2(BDC)4(dimethyl sulfoxide)6]·2H2O: C, 39.56, H, 3.51, N, 4.62%. Found: C, 39.12, H, 3.36, N, 4.39%. Infrared spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) readings include: 3432 (br, ν(OH)), 3068 (m, ν(CH)), 1701 (s, ν(CO)), 1598 (m, νas(COO)), 1475 (m, ν(C═C)), 1397 (s, νs(COO)), 1267 (m, ν(S

Synthesis. A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g, 1.0 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and ethylenediamine (0.060 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (10 mL) in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The mixture was heated to 240.661 °C for 372.03 hours under autogenous pressure. After allowing the reactor to cool to room temperature, pale pink crystalline solids were obtained. The solid material was recovered by filtration and washed thoroughly with methanol, yielding a product with an approximate yield of 55% based on cobalt. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for the compound C16H22CoN2O4: C 55.81, H 6.44, N 8.13, found: C 55.47, H 6.56, N 8.01. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (br), 1610 (vs), 1545 (s), 1450 (m), 1370 (s), 1220 (w), 1080 (w), 750 (m), 690 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 g, 0.84 mmol), TCPP (0.15 g, 0.12 mmol), and 4-methylimidazole (0.07 g, 0.85 mmol) was dissolved in 20.0 mL of DMAc. Formic acid (0.5 mL) was then added as a modulator, and the mixture was stirred for 1 hour at ambient temperature. The solution was transferred into a 50-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 386.402 K (113.252 °C) for 358.590 hours. The assembly was then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.5 K h−1. Pale yellow crystalline solids were isolated by filtration, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. The yield was calculated to be 68% (0.187 g) based on TCPP. Elemental analysis for C48H34N8O8Zn2 Calcd: C, 56.26, H, 3.35, N, 10.95. Found: C, 56.11, H, 3.42, N, 10.88. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3412 (b), 1625 (s), 1553 (s

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (85.2 mg, 0.29 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 42.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resultant solution was subjected to a solvothermal reaction at 490 K for 63.77 minutes under static conditions. Upon cooling to room temperature, the formed purple crystals were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with N,N-dimethylacetamide, and dried in air. The yield was approximately 55% based on the organic linker. Elemental analysis for the activated framework (Co3(BTC)2) showed: C, 41.78, H, 2.37, N, 0.00%. Calculated: C, 41.82, H, 2.31, N, 0.00%. Further structural confirmation was obtained via PXRD and FT-IR, with notable absorption bands at 1715 cm–1, 1620 cm–1, and 1445 cm–1, supporting the integrity of the framework.

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.10 g, 0.34 mmol), biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (0.051 g, 0.22 mmol), and sodium hydroxide (0.018 g, 0.45 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of THF. The solution was transferred to a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 43.336 °C for 168 minutes. The autoclave was then allowed to cool to room temperature gradually. Green needle-like crystals of the metal-organic framework were obtained in a yield of approximately 68% based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. The product was characterized using powder X-ray diffraction, confirming phase purity. Elemental analyses for C28H18O6Ni (515.14): Calcd. (%) C, 65.33, H, 3.53, N, 0.00. Found (%): C, 65.01, H, 3.48, N, 0.00. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3435 (m), 2932 (w), 1605 (s), 1542 (s), 1398 (m), 1260 (m), 1175 (s), 1105 (s), 1023 (m

The vanadium-based metal-organic framework, [VF6(bpy)], was synthesized via solvothermal methods starting from vanadium(V) oxide. In a typical synthesis, 0.095 g of V2O5 was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) with continuous stirring to ensure complete dissolution. To this solution, 0.210 g of 4,4'-bipyridine was added and the reaction mixture was subjected to further stirring at room temperature for 45 minutes, achieving a molar ratio of 1.0 V2O5: 3.0 bpy: 500 DMF. The homogeneous mixture was then sealed in a 25-mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 221.85 °C for approximately 124.41 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, the resulting crystalline product, characterized by its hexagonal shapes, was isolated through vacuum filtration and rinsed sparingly with fresh DMF to remove any unreacted starting materials. The desired framework was obtained with a yield of ~70% based on vanadium input. The synthesis resulted in structurally robust crystals suitable for further characterization and potential application explorations in gas adsorption studies.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.15 mmol, 36.7 mg) and bdc (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg) was suspended in 8 mL of 1,4-dioxane. Subsequently, 0.5 mL of a sodium ethoxide solution (NaOC2H5, 0.1 M in 1,4-dioxane) was added to the suspension. The resulting mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 399 K for 316 minutes. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature, green tetrahedral crystals were formed along with some amorphous precipitate. The solid was isolated by decanting, followed by washing with ethanol (10 mL × 3) and drying under vacuum for 2 hours to afford the crystalline product in approximately 40% yield based on bdc. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H4CuN2O6: C, 34.08, H, 1.43, N, 9.94. Found: C, 33.85, H, 1.40, N, 9.88. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445 (m), 1611 (s), 1425 (m), 1348 (w), 1258 (m), 1120 (m), 101

To synthesize the desired metal-organic framework (MOF), 0.250 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.84 mmol) was combined with 0.150 g of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.90 mmol) in 10 mL of acetonitrile (CH3CN). The reaction mixture was transferred into a 20 mL PTFE-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 115.1 °C for 337.433 minutes. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting colorless block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with additional acetonitrile, and allowed to dry in air. The yield of the crystalline product was 0.175 g, corresponding to 61% based on terephthalic acid. The crystalline nature and purity of the obtained MOF were validated by powder XRD and FTIR spectroscopic analysis, which showed characteristic peaks at 1600 cm−1, 1400 cm−1, and 770 cm−1, indicating successful coordination of the linker with the metal center.

A mixture of 20 mg of Na3BTC (0.06 mmol) and 40 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.13 mmol) was prepared in 3 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). To this solution, 50 μL of 70% HClO4 was added while stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and heated to 115.510 °C for 215.32 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting product consisted of pale yellow block-shaped crystals which were isolated by filtration and rinsed with DMF. Yields were approximately 55%. Elemental analysis calculated for C27H24Cl3N3O18Zn3: C, 34.15, H, 3.05, N, 4.43. Found: C, 34.09, H, 3.12, N, 4.50. Selected FTIR (KBr, cm–1): 1607 (s), 1541 (m), 1436 (s), 1366 (m), 1115 (w), 953 (w), 762 (m), 682 (s).

All chemicals utilized in the synthesis were of analytical grade and were used without any further purification. The preparation of the compound involved combining 5.0 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (17.19 mmol) and 2.0 g of benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (12.02 mmol) in 20 mL of methanol. Lithium hydroxide (0.84 g, 20.0 mmol) was added to the solution to adjust the basicity. The mixture was thoroughly stirred for 15 minutes to ensure homogeneity. The resultant solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to solvothermal treatment at a controlled temperature of 455.30 K for 249.3 hours. After the completion of the reaction, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, yielding violet crystalline solids. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed several times with methanol to remove any remaining reactants, and dried under vacuum overnight. The yield was calculated to be 68% based on the initial cobalt salt. FT-IR spectrum (cm–1): 1609 (s), 1512 (m), 1405 (s), 1345 (m), 830 (w), 695 (m), 612 (w). A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 g, 0.17 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.034 g, 0.20 mmol), and KOH (0.056 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 4 ml of EtOH in a 30 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. The reactor was sealed and placed in an oven under static conditions at 91.929 °C for 345.72 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h, yielding colorless cubic crystals of the desired Zn-based MOF. The crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with cold EtOH, and air-dried. Yield: 0.063 g (59%). Elemental analysis for C16H10O8Zn (399.62): calcd, C 46.15, H 2.42%, found, C 46.02, H 2.49%. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 s, 1615 m, 1578 m, 1509 m, 1423 s, 1375 s, 1249 m, 785 m.

A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.515 mmol) and terephthalic acid (85 mg, 0.512 mmol) was prepared in 5 mL of 2-amino-1-butanol. To this mixture, sodium acetate trihydrate (40 mg, 0.294 mmol) was added, and the resulting solution was thoroughly mixed until homogeneous. This mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 180.43 °C for 484.18 minutes. After the heating period, the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The product, consisting of large pale pink crystals, was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with ethanol to remove any unreacted starting materials and impurities, followed by drying in air. The yield of the crystalline product was determined to be 52% based on the cobalt source. Elemental analysis of the as-synthesized crystals revealed the following composition: C, 42.78%, H, 4.89%, N, 6.32%. The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis showed characteristic bands at 1604 cm−1, 1528 cm−1, and 1403 cm−1, indicating the successful coordination of terephthalic acid to the cobalt centers.

A mixture of H2BDC (0.125 g, 0.75 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.234 g, 1.00 mmol) in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (10 mL) with formic acid (0.50 mL) as an additive was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL). The sealed vessel was heated at 174.1 °C for 381.277 hours and subsequently allowed to cool to room temperature at a controlled rate of 3 °C h−1. The resulting blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMAc, and then dried under vacuum. The yield was 42.5% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6CuO4: C, 39.97, H, 2.52, Cu, 26.58. Found: C, 39.84, H, 2.61, Cu, 26.47%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3468 m, 1665 s, 1590 w, 1440 w, 1376 s, 1245 w, 950 w, 824 w, 745 w, 598 w.

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, a solution containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), bpy (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol), and terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.5 mmol) was prepared in a 20 mL vial with C2H5OH (5 mL) and AcOH (0.5 mL) as the solvent system. The mixture was stirred for 10 minutes and subsequently introduced into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The vessel was sealed and maintained at 114.2 °C for 257.09 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, violet block crystals were isolated via filtration and washed with C2H5OH, resulting in a 68% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C22H18CoN2O8: C, 52.78, H, 3.62, N, 5.59. Found: C, 52.65, H, 3.71, N, 5.52. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3372 (m), 1608 (s), 1562 (w), 1407 (m), 1302 (w), 1225 (m), 1150 (w), 1018 (s

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol) and the organic linker H2BDC (0.6 mmol) were combined in 5.0 mL of pyridine. To this solution, HClO4 (three drops) was added. The mixture was transferred into a 10 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 217.481 °C for 16.89 minutes. Following the high-temperature treatment, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting product consisted of blue block crystals, isolated by filtration and subsequently washed with pyridine to ensure purity. The yield of the crystalline framework was determined to be 73% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis suggested a tentative formula of [Co2(BDC)2]·pyridine·H2O, with analytical data found to be in good agreement with the expected values: Anal. calcd for C20H16N2O8Co2: C, 47.24, H, 3.17, N, 5.51%. A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 mmol, 72.8 mg), bpdc (0.50 mmol, 110.0 mg), and Na2CO3 (0.20 mmol, 21.2 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of CH3OH and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 124 °C for 315.30 minutes. Subsequently, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally over a period of 24 hours. The resulting pink crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 4 hours. The yield of the crystalline material was 58% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C20H18CoN4O10 (Co(bpdc)2): C, 47.85, H, 3.62, N, 11.16. Found: C, 48.02, H, 3.59, N, 11.24. For the synthesis of Zn-MOF-123, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.34 mmol) and H2L (0.05 g, 0.17 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) in a glass vial. Subsequently, KOH (50 mg) was added as an additive to the solution. The sealed vial was then placed in a preheated oven at 352.5 K for 173.468 minutes. Upon completion, the vial was allowed to cool to room temperature gradually. The resultant white crystalline product was collected by filtration and thoroughly washed with DMA to remove any non-coordinated species. The crystals were air-dried to yield a high purity product, with a yield of 75%. Infrared spectroscopy (IR, KBr): 3432 (br), 1662 (s), 1590 (s), 1437 (m), 1372 (m), 1291 (m), 1168 (w), 1022 (m), 841 (m), 747 cm−1 (m). Elemental analysis calculated for C18H24Zn2N4O12: C, 35.66, H, 3.97, N, 9.23%. Found: C, 35.82, H, 3.92, N, 9.11%.

Preparation of [Cu3(bdc)3]n·nNMP (2). A suspension composed of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol) and H2bdc (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) in 10 mL of NMP was placed in a 50-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 308 K under autogenous pressure for 181.14 hours. After slowly cooling to room temperature, dark blue crystalline material was harvested by filtration, washed thoroughly with NMP, and dried in vacuo at ambient temperature, affording 0.195 g of complex 2 (yield 61% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O). Complex 2 shows notable thermal stability and remains insoluble in water and most organic solvents. Elemental analysis calculated for C24H14Cu3O12: C, 43.27, H, 2.12%, found: C, 43.11, H, 2.19%.

A mixture comprising Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g), TPA (0.1 mmol, 0.032 g), and oxalic acid (0.2 mmol, 0.018 g) was dissolved in diethylformamide (10 mL). The resultant solution was stirred briefly to ensure thorough mixing. After achieving a homogeneous solution, the mixture was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (20 mL). The sealed vessel was heated at 418 K for 77.5 hours under autogenous pressure. Upon slow cooling to ambient temperature, needle-shaped crystals were formed directly and were collected by filtration. The crystals were washed with diethylformamide to remove any unreacted starting materials and then air-dried. The yield was determined to be 61% based on the ZnII precursor. Elemental analysis calculated for C30H28N4O12Zn2: C, 50.12, H, 3.91, N, 7.79, Found: C, 50.08, H, 3.95, N, 7.82. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (50 mg, 0.21 mmol) and H2BDC (20 mg, 0.12 mmol) were dissolved in 3 ml of water in a glass container to which sodium acetate trihydrate (25 mg) was added as an additive. This mixture was tightly sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 185.0 °C for 385.122 minutes. Upon gradually cooling to room temperature, blue block-shaped crystals of the MOF were obtained. The crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with deionized water, yielding 0.024 g (45% yield based on H2BDC). The crystalline product was then activated by solvent exchange with ethanol and vacuum desolvation at 120 °C for 8 hours. Analytical data: elemental analysis calculated for C8H6CuO5: C, 39.07, H, 2.46. Found: C, 38.95, H, 2.53. FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (br), 1623 (s), 1558 (m), 1435 (m), 1379 (w), 1256 (w), 1145 (m), 1078 (s), 766 (m), 665 (w). The final MOF structure shows stability in open air and resistance towards decomposition in common organic solvents

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.015 g, 0.052 mmol), H2BDC (0.020 g, 0.120 mmol), methanol (5 mL), and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (0.005 g, 0.120 mmol) was combined in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (15 mL). The autoclave was sealed and heated at 173.0 °C for 421.892 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, the resulting purple crystals were collected by vacuum filtration, thoroughly washed with cold methanol, and subsequently dried in air (yield: 48% based on H2BDC). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for the framework: C 44.12, H 3.67, N 5.13, found: C 44.05, H 3.70, N 5.21%.

A 1.5 mL aliquot of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution (0.15 M) in ethanol (EtOH) was prepared in a 5 mL glass vial. To this, 0.012 g (0.1 mmol) of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) was added with gentle stirring until completely dissolved. The sealed vial was then subjected to 377.680 K for a period of 58 minutes. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, green crystalline structures formed at the bottom of the solution, indicative of the Ni-BDC framework. The crystals were separated by decanting the excess solvent and subsequently washed twice with ethanol (2 mL per wash) to remove any residual unreacted materials. The cleaned MOF crystals were left to air dry for approximately 15 minutes, resulting in a modest yield of 57% (0.0085 g based on Ni(NO3)2·6H2O). The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) presented the following characteristic peaks: 3412(m), 2948(w), 1602(s), 1509(m), 1382(s), 1268(m), 1133(w), 1002(m), 867(w), 745(s), 611(m), 512(w). Elemental analysis revealed the composition as C = 40.12%, H = 3.22

The metal precursor Co(NO3)2·6H2O (150 mg, 0.51 mmol), and the organic linker 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2TDC, 25 mg, 0.13 mmol) were dissolved in 8 mL of dimethyl acetamide (DMA) in a 20 mL glass vial. Oxalic acid (10 mg, 0.11 mmol) was added as an additive to the mixture, which was then tightly sealed. The reaction mixture was maintained at 363.0 K for 192.167 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature, and yellow crystalline plates of the Co-TDC MOF were isolated. The crystals were washed with fresh DMA and dried under vacuum, yielding 72% based on the linker H2TDC. Elemental analysis calculated for C12H8CoO8S2: C, 36.53%, H, 2.04%, found: C, 36.29%, H, 2.11%. Key FTIR peaks (neat, cm−1): 1683 (s), 1547 (m), 1418 (br), 1284 (s), 1136 (m), 1012 (w), 894 (m), 782 (s).

A solvothermal synthesis was performed using a custom 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The initial reaction mixture consisted of 0.500 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 0.256 g 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), and 5 mL C2H5OH. To this solution, 2.5 mL ammonium hydroxide was carefully added while maintaining vigorous stirring. The solution was observed to form a pale blue colloidal suspension. The mixture (pH ~7.5) was transferred to the autoclave, filling it to approximately 60% of its volume, and subsequently heated at 345.00 K for 426.79 minutes under static conditions. Following completion of the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting solid product, comprising blue crystalline micro-rods, was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with ethanol, and dried at 60 °C for 6 hours. The crystalline yield was 45% based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis was consistent with the calculated values for C18H8CuN3O9 (%): C, 40.32, H, 1.51, N, 7.83. Found: C, 40.35, H, 1.47, N, 7.79

Synthesis of [Zn(L)2(H2O)2]·5 H2O (1): Ligand L (12 mg, 0.045 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (22 mg, 0.075 mmol) were dissolved in a solvent mixture containing 68-12-2 (15 mL) and H2O (10 mL). To the resulting clear solution, lithium hydroxide monohydrate (3 mg, 0.043 mmol) was added. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 451.50 K for 265 minutes. After cooling to room temperature, pale blue crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with 68-12-2, H2O, and ethyl acetate, and dried under vacuum (yield: 8.5 mg, 53.1%, based on L). IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3421 (br, νO–H), 1625 (s, νas(COO)), 1542 (s, νCC), 1391 (m, νs(COO)), 1278 (w, νC–O), 1092 (m), 952 (w), 837 (s), 702 (w), 511 (m). A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 0.067 mmol), H2BDC (15 mg, 0.090 mmol), MeOH (4 mL), and HCOOH (0.5 mL) was combined in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resulting solution was carefully mixed and sealed, followed by heating at 462.5 K for 457.93 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature, the reaction yielded clear, octahedral crystals (9.8 mg, 58% yield based on H2BDC). This product's powder X-ray diffraction pattern was consistent with the simulated pattern derived from the expected crystal structure, confirming its phase purity (see Supporting Information Figure S5). Elemental analysis performed found (wt%) C 32.41, H 2.81, N 6.78, theoretical values calculated were (wt%) C 32.65, H 2.97, N 6.56. The metal-organic framework compound, [Zn3(BTC)2]·(CH3OH)4, was synthesized via solvothermal conditions employing zinc nitrate and trimesic acid (BTC). In a typical synthesis, 0.450 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of methanol. To this solution, 0.210 g of H3BTC and 0.050 g of sodium hydroxide were added, and the mixture was stirred for 45 minutes at ambient temperature to ensure homogeneity. The molar ratio of the final mixture was adjusted to 3.0Zn(NO3)2: 2.0H3BTC: 0.5NaOH: 400CH3OH. This precursor solution was transferred to a 50-mL Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to thermal treatment at 254 °C for 328 hours. Large, transparent crystals formed as the product, which were isolated by filtration. The crystals were washed thoroughly with methanol and dried under vacuum at room temperature. A yield of approximately 65% was achieved based on Zn. The initial reaction mixture had a pH of approximately 9, and the final pH decreased to around 7. The metal-organic framework was synthesized via a solvothermal method. A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.22 mmol, 64 mg) and H2BDC (0.15 mmol, 25 mg) was prepared in 15 mL of isobutanol. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to heating at 362 K for 342.9 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 K h−1, transparent yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained. The supernatant was removed, and the crystals were washed thrice with isobutanol (10 mL × 3) before being left to dry under ambient conditions for 3 hours (yield ca. 47% based on H2BDC). Anal. Calcd for C16H14ZnO8: C, 46.82, H, 3.44. Found: C, 46.60, H, 3.52. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3417 (m), 1602 (s), 1516 (m), 1403 (s), 1287 (m), 1124 (w), 1048 (m), 876 (m), 762 (w), 611 (w).

A reaction mixture consisting of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.188 g, 0.63 mmol) and trimesic acid (0.042 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in DMAc (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed vessel was then heated at 80.2 °C for 495.3 minutes. Upon completion, the mixture was gradually cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h⁻¹. Transparent octahedral crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were harvested by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMAc, and air-dried to give a yield of 65% based on trimesic acid. Anal. Calcd for C12H12N2O12Zn: C 32.13, H 2.70, N 6.25%. Found: C 32.05, H 2.68, N 6.21%. FT-IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3440 (br), 2924 (w), 1650 (s), 1540 (s), 1432(m), 1368 (m), 1018 (m), 856 (w), 716 (m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.241 g, 1 mmol) and H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) was combined in ethanol (C2H5OH, 4 mL) in the presence of KOH (0.056 g, 1 mmol) under stirring conditions. The resulting homogeneous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 165 °C for 253 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline material was obtained, collected by filtration, and washed several times with cold ethanol. The yield was calculated to be 70% based on H2BDC ligand. Anal. Calcd for C10H8CuO6 (%): C, 40.34, H, 2.71, Cu, 21.30. Found (%): C, 40.22, H, 2.69, Cu, 21.28. IR (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3425 (b), 1601 (s), 1520 (m), 1410 (s), 1325 (w), 1227 (m), 1143 (w), 1012 (w), 845 (w), 756 (s), 675 (w).

Synthesis of {[Ni(btc)(4,4'-bpy)]·2H2O}n: A mixture containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.515 mmol), trimesic acid (0.107 g, 0.511 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.080 g, 0.513 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of acetonitrile (MeCN) with the addition of tetrafluoroboric acid (0.1 mL, 0.12 M) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated at 192 °C for 80.620 hours. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, and violet block-shaped crystals were obtained through filtration, washing with MeCN, and air-drying (Yield: 53% based on Ni). Elemental analysis calculated for C22H18NiN2O8: C, 50.17, H, 3.45, N, 5.31%. Found: C, 50.09, H, 3.39, N, 5.45%. Infrared spectrum (KBr, cm–1): ν = 3432 (br, w), 1608 (s), 1565 (s), 1449 (m),

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0485 g, 0.15 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 0.0252 g, 0.15 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of dimethyl acetamide. To this solution, oxalic acid (0.0099 g, 0.11 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 244.958 °C for 382.70 minutes. Upon gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the system yielded emerald-green prismatic crystals. The solids were collected, washed with dimethyl acetamide, and dried in air (Yield: 75%, based on H2BDC). Anal. Calcd for C12H10NiO6 (%): C, 44.04, H, 3.08, Found (%): C, 44.12, H, 2.98. IR data (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3430 (s), 1608 (s), 1552 (m), 1425 (m), 1384 (s), 1266 (w), 1198 (m), 1140 (w), 1054 (w), 873 (w), 820 (m), 775 (m), 665

ZrCl4 (70 mg, 0.3 mmol) and H2BDC (60 mg, 0.5 mmol) were combined in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (50 mL) along with acetonitrile (15 mL) and ammonium hydroxide (0.15 mL). The mixture was subjected to solvothermal conditions by heating in an autoclave at 155.45 °C for 328.78 minutes. Upon completion, the system was gradually cooled to room temperature. Clear, octahedral crystals suitable for structural characterization were isolated by filtration and washed thoroughly with acetonitrile, yielding a crystalline phase with a formula of {[Zr6O4(OH)4(BDC)6]⋅xH2O} as confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, CHN analysis (calcd (%): C 39.76, H 2.69, N 0.00, found: C 39.85, H 2.58, N 0.10), and thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S5). IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) of the MOF displayed bands at 3390 (b), 1655 (s), 1500 (s), 1410 (m), 1355 (m), 1250 (w), 1140 (w), 1045 (w), 970 (w),

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.2 mmol) was prepared in dimethylacetamide (10 mL) within a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. An addition of HNO3 (0.1 mL, concentrated) was made to adjust the pH, facilitating better coordination of the zinc ions. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to heating at 179.6 °C for 497.040 minutes, followed by slow cooling to room temperature, yielding colorless block-like crystals of the target MOF (73% yield based on Zn). Elemental analysis revealed the following composition: C, 49.08, H, 3.12, N, 9.34. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3425m, 3105w, 1684s, 1610m, 1538m, 1452s, 1392m, 1260w, 1156w, 1054w, 945w, 822w, 782m, 731w, 681m, consistent with the proposed structure. Thermogravimetric analysis demonstrated stability up to 330 °C, with a gradual decomposition observed thereafter. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern confirmed the framework's high crystallinity, aligning closely with the simulated pattern

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 8 mL of methanol. The resulting clear blue solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 495.632 K for 315.67 minutes under autogeneous pressure. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, blue crystalline solids of MOF-3 were collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol (3 × 10 mL), and air-dried. Yield: 0.092 g (41% based on Cu). Elemental analysis calculated for C8H6CuO6: C, 37.65, H, 2.37%. Found: C, 37.48, H, 2.40%. The phase purity was confirmed by XRPD, with the experimental pattern matching the simulated one. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1) showed peaks at 3447 (m), 1620 (s), 1583 (s), 1410 (m), 1260 (m), 1137 (m), 734 (s), and 489 (m).

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.050 mmol, 0.012 g), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.025 mmol, 0.0105 g), and Na2CO3 (0.015 mmol, 0.0016 g) was dissolved in ethanol (EtOH, 6 mL) and transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated at 378.4 K for 122 minutes, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. Green hexagonal crystals were obtained and isolated by washing with ethanol and drying under vacuum. The product yield was approximately 64% based on H3BTC. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H9Cu3NaO9: C, 44.78, H, 1.88, Na, 3.58. Found: C, 44.71, H, 1.92, Na, 3.55%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3427(m), 1621(s), 1549(m), 1447(m), 1384(s), 1321(w), 1158(w), 1109(m), 919(w), 848(m), 776(s), 652(w), 523(m), 478(w), 439(w).

The MOF was synthesized by reacting Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (20 mg, 0.12 mmol) in ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 2 mL) as solvent. A controlled addition of ammonia (0.1 mL) was employed as the additive. The reaction mixture was placed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 146.0 °C for 101.38 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, pale yellow cubic crystals were formed, yielding 25 mg, corresponding to a 75% yield based on H2BDC. The resulting product was characterized as [Zn(BDC)(NH3)2]⋅(CH3CH2OH)3·(H2O) indicating a solvent-stabilized framework. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H22N2O8Zn: C, 43.15, H, 4.98, N, 6.29%. Found: C, 42.90, H, 5.01, N, 6.23%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1615(s), 1395(m), 1150(m), 845(s).

A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0891 g, 0.3 mmol) and H2BDC (0.0600 g, 0.4 mmol) in H2O (20 mL) was prepared by stirring for 45 min at room temperature until a homogenous mixture was achieved. The mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a temperature of 507.558 K for 305.25 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the heating process, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting colorless crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried to yield the final product with a 52% yield, calculated based on Zn. Anal. calcd for C8H6O4Zn: C, 42.85, H, 2.70, Zn, 26.39. Found: C, 42.72, H, 2.66, Zn, 26.55. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3433s, 1610s, 1551m, 1396w, 1268m, 1082w, 754s, 698m, 532w.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol) and H2bdc (0.056 g, 0.34 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of methanol (CH3OH) and stirred for 15 minutes at ambient temperature until a homogeneous solution was formed. This solution was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and subjected to a hydrothermal reaction at 471.94 K for 193.292 minutes. Upon completion of the heat treatment, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature over 8 hours. The resulting colorless needle-like crystals were recovered by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, and air-dried to yield a product with 72% yield based on Zn(II). Anal. Calcd for C16H10N2O8Zn: C, 44.19, H, 2.32, N, 6.44%, found: C, 44.28, H, 2.29, N, 6.51%. IR (cm−1): 3425 (m), 1620 (s), 1585 (m), 1395 (s), 1282 (m), 850 (w), 770 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu3(TPA)2]·nTHF. In a typical preparation, a mixture comprising Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.242 g, 1.0 mmol), terephthalic acid (TPA) (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), THF (15 mL), and NaHCO3 (0.084 g, 1.0 mmol) was thoroughly stirred to achieve homogeneity. The resultant suspension was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heating at 404.12 K for 36.0 minutes under autogenous pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature, and the crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with THF to remove unreacted reagents. The dark blue crystals were subsequently air-dried at room temperature. The yield of [Cu3(TPA)2]·nTHF was determined to be 76% based on the copper content. Characterization via powder X-ray diffraction verified the phase purity of the material, with the diffraction patterns closely matching the simulated pattern (Figure 3b). Elemental analysis revealed the following weight percentages: Cu: observed 27.92%, calculated 27.88%, C: observed 38.74%, calculated 38.81%, H: observed 4.35%, calculated 4.28%.

In the synthesis of a new metal-organic framework (MOF), a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (120 mg, 0.5 mmol) and trimesic acid (H3BTC, 84 mg, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of EtOH. The resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) and subjected to thermal treatment at 253.55 °C for 314 hours. Upon cooling to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, blue crystalline solids were isolated, yielding 48% based on copper. The crystals displayed a well-defined cubic morphology, indicative of high phase purity. Elemental analysis was conducted for the synthesized MOF, with calculated values (%) for C18H12Cu3O13: C, 37.96, H, 2.12. Found values (%): C, 37.88, H, 2.15. The IR spectrum showed characteristic bands at 3412 (s), 2923 (m), 1620 (s), and 1384 (s) cm–1, aligning with the framework’s network structure.

Synthesis of Mn2(1,3-BDC)3(NMP)4·2H2O (1). A mixture of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.100 g, 0.500 mmol) and 1,3-H2BDC (0.060 g, 0.360 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of 1-METHYL-2-PYRROLIDINONE (NMP) in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was sealed and heated at 372.05 K for 443.1 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, light-yellow crystals of 1 were obtained, washed with NMP, and air-dried, yielding approximately 72% based on Mn(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C48H52Mn2N2O18: C, 51.07, H, 4.64, N, 2.48. Found: C, 50.95, H, 4.72, N, 2.33. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3438 (br), 2925 (m), 1680 (s), 1605 (vs), 1517 (m), 1450 (s), 1385 (s), 1238 (m), 1085 (br), 950 (m), 835 (w),

Synthesis of the Metal-Organic Framework [Zn4(bdc)3(dabco)]. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 g, 1.68 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) (0.30 g, 1.80 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of C2H5OH. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subjected to a temperature of 487 K for a period of 333.875 hours. Upon gradual cooling to room temperature, colorless octahedral crystals of the MOF were isolated. Yield: 70%. Elemental analysis calculated for C48H48N4O16Zn4: C, 50.30, H, 4.22, N, 4.89. Found: C, 50.41, H, 4.15, N, 4.92. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3500 (b), 1603 (vs), 1509 (s), 1384 (m), 1227 (m), 1092 (w), 845 (m), 675 (s), 458 (w).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), and HBF4 (1 mL, 1M) was dissolved in 15 mL isobutanol under constant stirring for 30 minutes at ambient temperature. The prepared solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and heated at 340.9 K for 296.453 hours. Upon completion of the heating cycle, the autoclave was gradually cooled to room temperature, resulting in the formation of white needle-like crystals. These crystals were isolated by filtration and washed with isobutanol, yielding 0.110 g (45% based on Zn). Anal. found (calcd) for C16H18O8Zn: C, 48.65 (48.72), H, 4.59 (4.60)%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3548(m), 2922(w), 1670(vs), 1588(s), 1384(m), 1219(w), 1104(vs), 772(s), 621(m), 515(m). The obtained crystals exhibited stability upon exposure to air and were suitable for further structural characterization.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mg, 0.067 mmol) and H4bta (10 mg, 0.034 mmol) was dissolved in isobutanol (3 mL) and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction mixture was then heated to 455 K for 382.582 minutes. After the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The resulting white crystalline product was collected by filtration and washed with isobutanol, followed by drying under a stream of air (yield 55%, based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for ZnC12H14O8: C, 42.67, H, 4.18, N, 0.00. Found: C, 42.50, H, 4.12, N, 0.00. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern matched the simulated pattern derived from single-crystal X-ray data, confirming the phase purity and structural integrity of the synthesized MOF (see Supporting Information, Fig. S2).

Compound 2 was synthesized using solvothermal methods. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.49 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol), benzoic acid (0.050 g, 0.41 mmol), and isobutanol (50 mL) was combined in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 160 °C for 384.42 minutes under autogenous pressure. After gradual cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting white crystalline solids were filtered, washed with isobutanol, and air-dried (yield: 0.142 g, 72% based on Zn). Elemental analysis calculated for Zn(C8H4O4)(C7H6O2) (C15H10O6Zn): C, 56.25, H, 3.15, Found: C, 56.40, H, 3.08. The IR spectrum exhibited notable bands at 1693, 1584, 1405, 1268, 1115, and 740 cm−1, indicating the presence of coordinated benzoic and terephthalic acids.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58 mg, 0.2 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 33 mg, 0.2 mmol), acetonitrile (6 mL) and glycol (12 µL) was prepared in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated at 412.84 K for 238.74 minutes under static conditions and then allowed to cool to room temperature. After filtration, purple rod-like crystals were obtained, washed with acetonitrile (3 × 10 mL), and air-dried to yield approximately 150 mg of product. The crystalline phase was confirmed to be a cobalt-based MOF with an empirical formula deduced from elemental analysis as C16H12CoN2O8 (calcd: C, 44.00, H, 2.76, N, 6.42, found: C, 43.87, H, 2.65, N, 6.35). IR absorption bands (KBr, cm−1) were identified at 3432(m), 1610(s), 1536(m), 1404(w), 1308(m), 1212(w), 1118(w), 1003(m), 883(w).

The synthesis of MOF-X was conducted by combining 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 0.050 g, 0.24 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.066 g, 0.30 mmol), and DIISOPROPYLAMINE (0.1 mL) in 5 mL of methanol. The mixture was then stirred for 15 minutes to achieve a homogenous solution. The prepared solution was transferred into a 10 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and sealed. The solvothermal reaction was carried out at 302.5 K for 128.710 minutes. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, resulting in a clear, colorless solution. The product, comprised of transparent crystalline needles, was obtained by washing the crystals with methanol and allowing them to air-dry. The crystals were characterized by PXRD and elemental analysis, confirming the formation of [Zn3(BTC)2(H2O)6]·4H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C18H18Zn3O24: C, 31.49, H, 2.64. Found: C, 31.25, H, 2.72. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3435 (b), 2960 (w), 1615 (s), 144

To synthesize the metal-organic framework, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (25 mg, 0.085 mmol) and H2bdc (10 mg, 0.06 mmol) were dissolved in diethylformamide (8 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. The resulting mixture was stirred briefly until homogeneous and then heated in an oven at 349.0 K for 412 minutes. Subsequently, the solution was allowed to cool gradually to room temperature, leading to the formation of purple microcrystals. The yield was approximately 65% based on the cobalt precursor. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H12CoN4O10 (503.24 g/mol): C, 38.21%, H, 2.40%, N, 11.13%. Found: C, 38.15%, H, 2.48%, N, 11.09%. IR (cm−1): 3415 m (–OH), 1620 s (–C=O stretch), 1384 s (–C–O–), 1105 m (–C–C).

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.228 g, 0.765 mmol), H2BDC (0.146 g, 0.879 mmol), and Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.106 g, 0.456 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (20 mL) with the addition of 5 drops of HClO4 (70%) in a 50 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and placed in an oven at 418.8 K for 344 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, blue-green crystalline blocks were harvested by filtration, washed with methanol, and air-dried. Yield: 52% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analysis calculated for C16H14N2O12ZnCu: C, 34.12, H, 2.51, N, 4.98%. Found: C, 34.08, H, 2.49, N, 4.95%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450m, 2950w, 1675s, 1605vs, 1450m, 1385m, 1267w, 1100m, 935m, 850w, 755vs, 610w, 520m.

A mixture comprising Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.400 g, 1.37 mmol), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.250 g, 1.14 mmol), and benzoic acid (0.122 g, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 30 ml of 1-butanol and placed in a 40 ml Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction mixture was heated to 148.736 °C for 357 minutes. Upon cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals of the metal-organic framework Co-MOF were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with 1-butanol (3 × 10 ml), and dried under reduced pressure at 60 °C for 2 hours. The yield was 35 mg (63% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H14CoO10: C, 44.98, H, 3.30. Found: C, 44.85, H, 3.31. The IR spectrum (KBr pellet, cm−1) displayed characteristic peaks at 3602 s, 2974 m, 1769 w, 1625 s, 1548 m, 1457 m, 1383 s, 1265 w, 1205 w, 1148 m, 1025 m, 906 w, 821 m,

In a typical synthesis, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (58 mg, 0.195 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 22 mg, 0.132 mmol) were dissolved in benzene (8 mL) and loaded into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was tightly sealed and subjected to thermal treatment at 139.2 °C for 167 minutes. Following the reaction period, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature. The resulting colorless crystals were isolated by filtration, washed thoroughly with benzene, and air-dried. The obtained yield was 45% based on H2BDC. Elemental analysis of the compound [Zn2(BDC)2]·2C6H6 confirmed the structure, with calculated values (%): C, 58.23, H, 4.59, Zn, 19.87. Found: C, 58.10, H, 4.62, Zn, 19.95. IR (KBr, cm⁻¹): 3423 (m), 1609 (s), 1510 (m), 1407 (s), 1261 (m), 1074 (w), 1009 (m), 858 (m), 765 (m), 568 (m).

A mixture of H4BPDC (12 mg, 0.045 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.097 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of 1-butanol in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Subsequently, 0.5 mL of aqueous hydrofluoric acid (2.5%) was added as an additive. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 418.3 K for 161 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, large, colorless octahedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed with 1-butanol to remove any unreacted materials, yielding 0.033 g of the crystalline product (86% yield based on H4BPDC). Elemental analysis (wt%): Calcd for Zn2(C14H8O4)2: C 51.32, H 2.46, Zn 21.42, Found: C 50.83, H 2.39, Zn 21.12. Selected powder X-ray diffraction peaks (2θ, °): 7.22, 12.47, 18.88, 24.36, 29.45, 34.59, 39.72.

The synthesis of a new copper-based MOF was performed by combining Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.1 g, 0.4 mmol), organic linker (0.062 g, 0.2 mmol), and N,N-diethylformamide (8 mL) in the presence of NaOH (0.048 g, 1.2 mmol) as a modulating agent. The reaction mixture was thoroughly stirred, ensuring complete dissolution of components, prior to transferring the solution into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was heated to 317.550 K and maintained at this temperature for 248 minutes. Following the reaction period, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting blue crystalline product was isolated by filtration, washed with ethanol to remove residual solvent and reactants, and subsequently dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the MOF was approximately 78% with respect to the copper precursor. Elemental analysis revealed C, 42.37, H, 3.12, N, 5.98%, in agreement with calculated values: C, 42.50, H, 3.20, N, 6.00%. IR spectroscopy (KBr, cm−1) displayed major absorption bands at 3420(br), 1655(s), 1598(m), 1384(w), 1109(w), 1023(m), 874(w), 742(w

In a typical synthesis, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (120 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (42 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane. The solution was thoroughly mixed and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon®‐lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 433.602 K for 500 minutes. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The resultant blue crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with fresh 1,4-dioxane, and subsequently air-dried. The yield of the product was approximately 40% based on the starting copper salt. Powder X-ray diffraction confirmed the formation of the desired metal-organic framework.

In a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.149 g) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (0.4 mmol, 0.066 g) was combined with H2O (20 mL) and potassium iodide (0.3 mmol, 0.050 g) as an additive. The reaction vessel was sealed and heated at 41.8 °C for 252.9 hours. After the completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting clear needle-like crystals were isolated through filtration, washed with water, and dried in air (yield: 0.45 g, 54% based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H10I2O8Zn (541.42): C, 35.47%, H, 1.86%. Found: C, 35.51%, H, 1.82%. The IR spectrum (KBr, cm−1) exhibited bands at 3442 (m), 2964 (w), 1683 (s), 1600 (vs), 1491 (m), 1395 (s), 1257 (m), 1100 (w),

In a typical reaction, a mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.542 g, 1.82 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.210 g, 1.00 mmol), and tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.287 g, 1.50 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 15 minutes to ensure complete dissolution. The resulting mixture was then transferred into a 40-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and heated at 77 °C for 337.031 minutes. After the heating period, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried in a desiccator at room temperature, yielding 52% of the product based on Zn. Analytical data for the synthesized MOF (C6H18N2O12Zn3): C, 22.97, H, 5.77, N, 8.97, Found: C, 22.91, H, 5.81, N, 9.00. The infrared spectrum (KBr pellets, cm−1) exhibited characteristic bands at 3450(br), 1630(s), 1560(m), 1400(s

A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol, 89.1 mg) and H2BDC (0.10 mmol, 16.6 mg) was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol (CH3OH) in a 15 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was thoroughly sealed and heated to 104.4 °C for 28.0 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. Clear, hexagonal crystals of the resulting Zn-based metal-organic framework were recovered via filtration, washed with additional methanol, and air-dried overnight. Yield = 25.4 mg, 84.1%. Calculated elemental analysis for Zn(BDC)(CH3OH)2 (C10H10O6Zn, fw = 295.58 g/mol): C = 40.64, H = 3.41%. Found: C = 40.82, H = 3.29%. A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.182 g, 0.625 mmol) and H2BDC (0.050 g, 0.300 mmol) was prepared in ethanol (10 mL) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. With the reactor securely sealed, the mixture was subjected to a controlled heating program, maintaining a consistent temperature of 111.188 °C for precisely 352.14 minutes. Upon completion of the heating phase, the reactor was gradually cooled to room temperature. The resulting reddish crystals were harvested via filtration, washed with cold ethanol (5 mL × 3), and subsequently allowed to air-dry, yielding 42.5 mg (56% based on H2BDC). The product was analyzed, confirming its identity: Anal. Calcd (%) for C16H12CoN2O8: C, 47.30, H, 2.98, N, 6.89. Found (%): C, 47.10, H, 3.08, N, 6.78. A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.150 g, 0.515 mmol) and ligand H2BDC (0.110 g, 0.665 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (15 mL) and transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed vessel was then heated at 231.1 °C for 372.486 minutes. After allowing the solution to cool slowly to room temperature, pinkish-red crystalline solids were collected. The crystals were isolated by filtration, and a final yield of 0.042 g (31%, based on Co(NO3)2) was achieved. Anal. Calc. for C16H14CoN2O8: C, 42.94, H, 3.15, N, 6.26. Found: C, 42.81, H, 3.22, N, 6.31%.
